AI.tldr: A scenario-aware testing framework for autonomous driving prediction models that extends beyond ADE/FDE to evaluate performance across scene structures, map context, density, and agent proximity, exposing hidden failure modes and promoting robust, certifiable predictions.
AI.motivation: Current metrics ADE/FDE fail to capture the complexity and safety-critical nature of multi-agent driving scenarios. There is a need for evaluation that probes interactions, proximity effects, and scene layout to reveal vulnerabilities and corner cases.
AI.method: Propose a testing framework that systematically varies scene structures, map context, agent density, and spatial distributions; conducts extensive empirical analyses to quantify how proximity of nearby vs distant agents affects target trajectory prediction; identifies scenario-specific failure cases not revealed by traditional metrics.
AI.result: The analysis reveals a differential impact of agent proximity on prediction accuracy, uncovers scenario-specific failures absent in ADE/FDE benchmarks, and highlights vulnerabilities in state-of-the-art models; the framework demonstrates how scenario-aware evaluation can expose safety-critical weaknesses.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework enables rigorous, scenario-aware, safety-driven validation of autonomous-driving prediction models, facilitates identification of failure-prone corner cases, and supports development of robust, certifiable prediction systems.

title: Adaptive Fusion Network with Temporal-Ranked and Motion-Intensity Dynamic Images for Micro-expression Recognition
summary:
Micro-expressions (MEs) are subtle, transient facial changes with very low
intensity, almost imperceptible to the naked eye, yet they reveal a person
genuine emotion. They are of great value in lie detection, behavioral analysis,
and psychological assessment. This paper proposes a novel MER method with two
main contributions. First, we propose two complementary representations -
Temporal-ranked dynamic image, which emphasizes temporal progression, and
Motion-intensity dynamic image, which highlights subtle motions through a frame
reordering mechanism incorporating motion intensity. Second, we propose an
Adaptive fusion network, which automatically learns to optimally integrate
these two representations, thereby enhancing discriminative ME features while
suppressing noise. Experiments on three benchmark datasets (CASME-II, SAMM and
MMEW) demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method. Specifically, AFN
achieves 93.95 Accuracy and 0.897 UF1 on CASME-II, setting a new
state-of-the-art benchmark. On SAMM, the method attains 82.47 Accuracy and
0.665 UF1, demonstrating more balanced recognition across classes. On MMEW, the
model achieves 76.00 Accuracy, further confirming its generalization ability.
The obtained results show that both the input and the proposed architecture
play important roles in improving the performance of MER. Moreover, they
provide a solid foundation for further research and practical applications in
the fields of affective computing, lie detection, and human-computer
interaction.

AI.tldr: Proposes a two-representation MER framework using Temporal-ranked Dynamic Image and Motion-Intensity Dynamic Image fused by an Adaptive Fusion Network, achieving state-of-the-art results on CASME-II and strong performance on SAMM and MMEW.
AI.motivation: Micro-expressions are extremely subtle and transient, making robust representation and fusion essential to improve recognition accuracy and generalization across datasets.
AI.method: Introduce two complementary representations: Temporal-ranked Dynamic Image (TRDI) emphasizing temporal progression and Motion-Intensity Dynamic Image (MIDI) highlighting subtle motions via a frame-reordering mechanism that incorporates motion intensity; develop an Adaptive Fusion Network (AFN) that automatically learns to integrate TRDI and MIDI for improved ME features and noise suppression.
AI.result: Experiments on CASME-II, SAMM, and MMEW show: CASME-II 93.95% accuracy and 0.897 UF1 (state-of-the-art); SAMM 82.47% accuracy and 0.665 UF1 (more balanced across classes); MMEW 76.00% accuracy, demonstrating generalization across datasets.
AI.conclusion: The combination of complementary ME representations and adaptive fusion enhances discriminative power and robustness, providing a solid foundation for future research and practical applications in affective computing, lie detection, and HCI.

title: Assessment of different loss functions for fitting equivalent circuit models to electrochemical impedance spectroscopy data
summary:
Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) data is typically modeled using
an equivalent circuit model (ECM), with parameters obtained by minimizing a
loss function via nonlinear least squares fitting. This paper introduces two
new loss functions, log-B and log-BW, derived from the Bode representation of
EIS. Using a large dataset of generated EIS data, the performance of proposed
loss functions was evaluated alongside existing ones in terms of R2 scores,
chi-squared, computational efficiency, and the mean absolute percentage error
(MAPE) between the predicted component values and the original values.
Statistical comparisons revealed that the choice of loss function impacts
convergence, computational efficiency, quality of fit, and MAPE. Our analysis
showed that X2 loss function (squared sum of residuals with proportional
weighting) achieved the highest performance across multiple quality of fit
metrics, making it the preferred choice when the quality of fit is the primary
goal. On the other hand, log-B offered a slightly lower quality of fit while
being approximately 1.4 times faster and producing lower MAPE for most circuit
components, making log-B as a strong alternative. This is a critical factor for
large-scale least squares fitting in data-driven applications, such as training
machine learning models on extensive datasets or iterations.

AI.tldr: X2 loss function yields best fit quality in EIS ECM fitting; log-B is a strong alternative offering faster fitting (~1.4x) and lower MAPE for most components; log-BW is proposed but not highlighted as the top performer; choice depends on whether the priority is fit quality or scalability to large datasets.
AI.motivation: To improve parameter estimation for electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) by introducing loss functions derived from the Bode representation and assessing their impact on convergence, efficiency, and accuracy in data-driven ECM fitting.
AI.method: Introduce two new loss functions, log-B and log-BW, based on Bode representation of EIS. Evaluate their performance against existing losses using a large synthetic EIS dataset. Fit ECM parameters via nonlinear least squares and assess using R^2, chi-squared, computational time, and mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) between predicted and true component values. Conduct statistical comparisons to determine the influence of loss choice on convergence, efficiency, fit quality, and parameter accuracy.
AI.result: X2 loss function achieved the highest performance across multiple quality-of-fit metrics. The log-B loss offered a slightly lower quality of fit but was approximately 1.4 times faster and produced lower MAPE for most circuit components, making it a strong alternative for large-scale LS fitting. The abstract also introduces log-BW, but its relative performance is not summarized as clearly as X2 or log-B in the provided text.
AI.conclusion: The loss function chosen for nonlinear least squares fitting in EIS ECMs materially affects convergence behavior, computational efficiency, fit quality, and parameter accuracy. For applications prioritizing fit quality, X2 is preferred; for large-scale data-driven tasks where speed and component-wise MAPE are important, log-B provides a compelling alternative. log-BW is a proposed option with trade-offs that require further clarification on its performance.

title: Follow My Lead: Logical Fallacy Classification with Knowledge-Augmented LLMs
comment:
Accepted as a poster at the Twelfth Annual Conference on Advances in
  Cognitive Systems. 21 pages, 7 figures and 1 table
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) suffer from critical reasoning gaps, including a
tendency to hallucinate and poor accuracy in classifying logical fallacies.
This limitation stems from their default System 1 processing, which is fast and
intuitive, whereas reliable reasoning requires the deliberate, effortful System
2 approach (Kahneman, 2011; Li et al., 2025). Since full System 2 training is
often prohibitively expensive, we explore a low-cost, instruction-based
intervention to bridge this gap. Our methodology introduces a novel stepwise
instruction dataset that decomposes fallacy classification into a series of
atomic procedural steps (simple binary questions). We further augment this with
a final verification step where models consult a relational knowledge graph of
related fallacies. This procedural, rule-based intervention yields a
significant improvement in LLM logical fallacy classification. Crucially, the
approach also provides enhanced transparency into the LLMs' decision-making,
highlighting a practical pathway for Neuro-symbolic architectures to address
LLM reasoning deficits.

AI.tldr: A low-cost, instruction-based, stepwise approach with binary questions and a final knowledge-graph verification improves LLM performance on logical fallacy classification and enhances transparency, offering a neuro-symbolic path to mitigate reasoning gaps without full System 2 training.
AI.motivation: LLMs exhibit critical reasoning gaps, including hallucinations and poor performance in classifying logical fallacies, largely due to reliance on fast but flawed System 1 processing. Full System 2 training is expensive, creating a need for cheaper, effective interventions to improve reasoning. The work aims to bridge this gap with a cost-efficient, instruction-based method.
AI.method: The approach introduces a stepwise instruction dataset that decomposes fallacy classification into a sequence of atomic procedural steps implemented as simple binary questions. It adds a final verification step in which the model consults a relational knowledge graph of related fallacies to support decisions, forming a rule-based, neuro-symbolic intervention.
AI.result: The proposed procedural, rule-based intervention yields a significant improvement in LLMs' accuracy on logical fallacy classification and provides enhanced transparency into the models' decision-making processes.
AI.conclusion: The method offers a practical, low-cost pathway toward mitigating LLM reasoning deficits, supporting a neuro-symbolic architecture that can achieve more reliable fallacy classification without expensive System 2 training.

title: Ctrl-World: A Controllable Generative World Model for Robot Manipulation
summary:
Generalist robot policies can now perform a wide range of manipulation
skills, but evaluating and improving their ability with unfamiliar objects and
instructions remains a significant challenge. Rigorous evaluation requires a
large number of real-world rollouts, while systematic improvement demands
additional corrective data with expert labels. Both of these processes are
slow, costly, and difficult to scale. World models offer a promising, scalable
alternative by enabling policies to rollout within imagination space. However,
a key challenge is building a controllable world model that can handle
multi-step interactions with generalist robot policies. This requires a world
model compatible with modern generalist policies by supporting multi-view
prediction, fine-grained action control, and consistent long-horizon
interactions, which is not achieved by previous works. In this paper, we make a
step forward by introducing a controllable multi-view world model that can be
used to evaluate and improve the instruction-following ability of generalist
robot policies. Our model maintains long-horizon consistency with a
pose-conditioned memory retrieval mechanism and achieves precise action control
through frame-level action conditioning. Trained on the DROID dataset (95k
trajectories, 564 scenes), our model generates spatially and temporally
consistent trajectories under novel scenarios and new camera placements for
over 20 seconds. We show that our method can accurately rank policy performance
without real-world robot rollouts. Moreover, by synthesizing successful
trajectories in imagination and using them for supervised fine-tuning, our
approach can improve policy success by 44.7\%.

AI.tldr: Proposes a controllable multi-view world model to evaluate and improve instruction-following for generalist robot policies via imagination, enabling long-horizon, multi-view predictions and frame-level action control; improves policy performance and ranking without real-world rollouts.
AI.motivation: Evaluating and improving generalist robot policies on unfamiliar objects/instructions is slow and costly with real-world rollouts; scalable alternatives are needed.
AI.method: Introduce a controllable multi-view world model with pose-conditioned memory retrieval for long-horizon consistency and frame-level action conditioning. Trained on the DROID dataset (95k trajectories, 564 scenes). Uses imagination to synthesize trajectories under novel scenarios and new camera placements for evaluation and policy fine-tuning.
AI.result: The model generates spatially and temporally consistent trajectories over 20+ seconds in new scenarios, can accurately rank policy performance without real-world rollouts, and improves policy success by 44.7% when imagined trajectories are used for supervised fine-tuning.
AI.conclusion: A scalable approach for evaluating and improving generalist robot policies by leveraging a controllable imagination-based world model that supports multi-view predictions, action-level control, and long-horizon consistency.

title: Multi Camera Connected Vision System with Multi View Analytics: A Comprehensive Survey
summary:
Connected Vision Systems (CVS) are transforming a variety of applications,
including autonomous vehicles, smart cities, surveillance, and human-robot
interaction. These systems harness multi-view multi-camera (MVMC) data to
provide enhanced situational awareness through the integration of MVMC
tracking, re-identification (Re-ID), and action understanding (AU). However,
deploying CVS in real-world, dynamic environments presents a number of
challenges, particularly in addressing occlusions, diverse viewpoints, and
environmental variability. Existing surveys have focused primarily on isolated
tasks such as tracking, Re-ID, and AU, often neglecting their integration into
a cohesive system. These reviews typically emphasize single-view setups,
overlooking the complexities and opportunities provided by multi-camera
collaboration and multi-view data analysis. To the best of our knowledge, this
survey is the first to offer a comprehensive and integrated review of MVMC that
unifies MVMC tracking, Re-ID, and AU into a single framework. We propose a
unique taxonomy to better understand the critical components of CVS, dividing
it into four key parts: MVMC tracking, Re-ID, AU, and combined methods. We
systematically arrange and summarize the state-of-the-art datasets,
methodologies, results, and evaluation metrics, providing a structured view of
the field's progression. Furthermore, we identify and discuss the open research
questions and challenges, along with emerging technologies such as lifelong
learning, privacy, and federated learning, that need to be addressed for future
advancements. The paper concludes by outlining key research directions for
enhancing the robustness, efficiency, and adaptability of CVS in complex,
real-world applications. We hope this survey will inspire innovative solutions
and guide future research toward the next generation of intelligent and
adaptive CVS.

AI.tldr: An integrated MVMC CVS survey that unifies tracking, Re-ID, and action understanding (AU); introduces a four-part taxonomy; consolidates datasets, methods, results, and metrics; and outlines open challenges and future directions including privacy and lifelong learning.
AI.motivation: Address the research gap where multi-view, multi-camera data are treated in isolation and to enable a cohesive, robust CVS framework for real-world, dynamic environments.
AI.method: Systematic literature review, taxonomy construction, and synthesis of datasets, methodologies, results, and evaluation metrics for MVMC tracking, Re-ID, AU, and their integration; critical discussion of challenges and opportunities.
AI.result: Proposes a unified MVMC CVS framework with a four-part taxonomy (MVMC tracking, Re-ID, AU, combined methods); provides a structured survey of datasets, methods, results, and metrics; identifies open research questions and emerging technologies; outlines future directions.
AI.conclusion: A comprehensive guide for advancing CVS robustness, efficiency, and adaptability in complex real-world settings, emphasizing lifelong learning, privacy, and federated learning as key future directions.

title: Semantic-Cohesive Knowledge Distillation for Deep Cross-modal Hashing
summary:
Recently, deep supervised cross-modal hashing methods have achieve compelling
success by learning semantic information in a self-supervised way. However,
they still suffer from the key limitation that the multi-label semantic
extraction process fail to explicitly interact with raw multimodal data, making
the learned representation-level semantic information not compatible with the
heterogeneous multimodal data and hindering the performance of bridging
modality gap. To address this limitation, in this paper, we propose a novel
semantic cohesive knowledge distillation scheme for deep cross-modal hashing,
dubbed as SODA. Specifically, the multi-label information is introduced as a
new textual modality and reformulated as a set of ground-truth label prompt,
depicting the semantics presented in the image like the text modality. Then, a
cross-modal teacher network is devised to effectively distill cross-modal
semantic characteristics between image and label modalities and thus learn a
well-mapped Hamming space for image modality. In a sense, such Hamming space
can be regarded as a kind of prior knowledge to guide the learning of
cross-modal student network and comprehensively preserve the semantic
similarities between image and text modality. Extensive experiments on two
benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of our model over the
state-of-the-art methods.

AI.tldr: SODA introduces semantic cohesive knowledge distillation for deep cross-modal hashing, treating multi-labels as a textual modality and distilling cross-modal semantics from image and label to align them in a shared Hamming space, improving performance on benchmark datasets.
AI.motivation: Current deep supervised cross-modal hashing methods struggle to explicitly interact with raw multimodal data for multi-label semantics, causing semantic misalignment and hindering cross-modal retrieval performance.
AI.method: Formulate multi-label information as an additional textual modality via ground-truth label prompts. Develop a cross-modal teacher network to distill semantic characteristics between image and label modalities, learning a well-mapped Hamming space for images. Use this space as prior to guide a cross-modal student network, preserving semantic similarities between image and text modalities.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on two benchmark datasets show that SODA outperforms state-of-the-art methods.
AI.conclusion: Semantic cohesive knowledge distillation effectively bridges the modality gap in deep cross-modal hashing by integrating label-derived text as an auxiliary modality and employing teacher–student distillation to align image and text semantics in a unified Hamming space.

title: Deliberative Dynamics and Value Alignment in LLM Debates
summary:
As large language models (LLMs) are increasingly deployed in sensitive
everyday contexts - offering personal advice, mental health support, and moral
guidance - understanding their elicited values in navigating complex moral
reasoning is essential. Most evaluations study this sociotechnical alignment
through single-turn prompts, but it is unclear if these findings extend to
multi-turn settings where values emerge through dialogue, revision, and
consensus. We address this gap using LLM debate to examine deliberative
dynamics and value alignment in multi-turn settings by prompting subsets of
three models (GPT-4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet, and Gemini 2.0 Flash) to collectively
assign blame in 1,000 everyday dilemmas from Reddit's "Am I the Asshole"
community. We use both synchronous (parallel responses) and round-robin
(sequential responses) formats to test order effects and verdict revision. Our
findings show striking behavioral differences. In the synchronous setting, GPT
showed strong inertia (0.6-3.1% revision rates) while Claude and Gemini were
far more flexible (28-41%). Value patterns also diverged: GPT emphasized
personal autonomy and direct communication, while Claude and Gemini prioritized
empathetic dialogue. Certain values proved especially effective at driving
verdict changes. We further find that deliberation format had a strong impact
on model behavior: GPT and Gemini stood out as highly conforming relative to
Claude, with their verdict behavior strongly shaped by order effects. These
results show how deliberation format and model-specific behaviors shape moral
reasoning in multi-turn interactions, underscoring that sociotechnical
alignment depends on how systems structure dialogue as much as on their
outputs.

AI.tldr: Debate among LLMs to study multi-turn moral reasoning and value alignment in 1,000 Reddit 'Am I the Asshole' dilemmas; compares synchronous (parallel) vs round-robin formats; reveals model-specific differences in revision inertia, value emphasis, and susceptibility to order effects; highlights that dialogue structure shapes sociotechnical alignment as much as outputs.
AI.motivation: To understand how values and moral reasoning emerge in extended dialogue among language models, and how deliberation formats influence alignment in sensitive, everyday moral decision tasks.
AI.method: Prompt subsets of three models (GPT-4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet, Gemini 2.0 Flash) to collectively assign blame for 1,000 Reddit 'Am I the Asshole' dilemmas. Compare synchronous (parallel responses) and round-robin (sequential responses) formats to test order effects and verdict revision. Measure revision rates, value emphasis, and final verdicts to assess deliberative dynamics and cross-model alignment.
AI.result: Synchronous responses reveal model-specific dynamics: GPT shows strong verdict inertia with low revision rates (0.6-3.1%), while Claude and Gemini demonstrate higher flexibility (28-41% revisions). Value patterns diverge across models—GPT favors personal autonomy and direct communication; Claude and Gemini emphasize empathetic dialogue. Certain values more effectively drive verdict changes. Deliberation format exerts strong influence: GPT and Gemini are more conforming overall, with verdicts heavily shaped by order effects; Claude less constrained. These findings indicate that the dialogic structure and model-specific tendencies substantially shape moral reasoning in multi-turn interactions, underscoring that sociotechnical alignment depends on dialogue design as much as on outputs.
AI.conclusion: Value alignment in LLMs in multi-turn, sensitive domains hinges on both the chosen deliberation format and model-specific behaviors. Relying on single-turn prompts may misrepresent alignment; evaluating and deploying LLMs for moral guidance requires attention to how dialogue structure, turn order, and revision dynamics shape final judgments.

title: CompassNav: Steering From Path Imitation To Decision Understanding In Navigation
summary:
The dominant paradigm for training Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) in
navigation relies on imitating expert trajectories. This approach reduces the
complex navigation task to a sequence-to-sequence replication of a single
correct path, fundamentally limiting the agent's ability to explore and
generalize. In this work, we argue for and introduce a new paradigm: a shift
from Path Imitation to Decision Understanding. The goal of this paradigm is to
build agents that do not just follow, but truly understand how to navigate. We
materialize this through two core contributions: first, we introduce
Compass-Data-22k, a novel 22k-trajectory dataset.Its Reinforcement Fine-Tuning
(RFT) subset provides a panoramic view of the decision landscape by annotating
all feasible actions with A* geodesic distances. Second, we design a novel
gap-aware hybrid reward function that dynamically adapts its feedback to
decision certainty, shifting between decisive signals for optimal actions and
nuanced scores to encourage exploration. Integrated into an SFT-then-RFT
recipe, our CompassNav agent is trained not to memorize static routes, but to
develop an internal ``compass'' that constantly intuits the direction to the
goal by evaluating the relative quality of all possible moves. This approach
enables our 7B agent to set a new state-of-the-art on Goal navigation
benchmarks, outperforming even larger proprietary models, and achieve robust
real-world goal navigation on a physical robot.

AI.tldr: Shifts LVLM navigation from path imitation to decision understanding, introducing CompassNav with a 22k-trajectory Compass-Data-22k and a decision-aware RFT; achieves state-of-the-art goal navigation with a 7B model and real-robot robustness.
AI.motivation: Imitation-based training reduces navigation to replicating a single correct route, hindering exploration and generalization. There is a need for agents that understand navigation decisions and can evaluate multiple action options relative to the goal.
AI.method: Introduce Compass-Data-22k with a Reinforcement Fine-Tuning (RFT) subset annotating all feasible actions with A* geodesic distances. Propose a gap-aware hybrid reward that adapts feedback based on decision certainty. Train using an SFT-then-RFT recipe to develop an internal compass that evaluates the relative quality of moves rather than memorizing routes.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance on goal navigation benchmarks with a 7B agent, outperforming larger proprietary models, and demonstrates robust real-world navigation on a physical robot.
AI.conclusion: Reframing navigation from path imitation to decision understanding enables better generalization and robustness, yielding an interpretable internal compass and improved navigation performance.

title: Constructive Distortion: Improving MLLMs with Attention-Guided Image Warping
summary:
Multimodal large language models (MLLMs) often miss small details and spatial
relations in cluttered scenes, leading to errors in fine-grained perceptual
grounding. We introduce AttWarp, a lightweight method that allocates more
resolution to query-relevant content while compressing less informative areas,
all while preserving global context. At test time, the approach uses an MLLM's
cross-modal attention to perform rectilinear warping of the input image,
reallocating spatial resolution toward regions the model deems important,
without changing model weights or architecture. This attention-guided warping
preserves all original image information but redistributes it non-uniformly, so
small objects and subtle relationships become easier for the same model to read
while the global layout remains intact. Across five benchmarks (TextVQA, GQA,
DocVQA, POPE, MMMU) and four MLLMs (LLaVA, Qwen-VL, InternVL, and
InstructBLIP), AttWarp consistently improves accuracy, strengthens
compositional reasoning, and reduces hallucinations, outperforming four
competitive baselines that manipulate raw images at test time. Together, these
results show that attention-guided warping prioritizes information relevant to
the query while preserving context, and that the same MLLMs perform better when
given such warped inputs.

AI.tldr: AttWarp uses cross-attention-guided rectilinear warping to allocate higher resolution to query-relevant content in images for multimodal LLMs, improving fine-grained grounding and reducing hallucinations without retraining.
AI.motivation: Multimodal LLMs often miss small details and spatial relations in cluttered scenes, causing errors in fine-grained perceptual grounding.
AI.method: At test time, AttWarp applies a rectilinear warp to the input image guided by the model's cross-modal attention, reallocating spatial resolution toward regions the model deems important; this preserves all original information and context, and does not modify model weights or architecture. The approach is evaluated across multiple LLMs and benchmarks.
AI.result: Across five benchmarks (TextVQA, GQA, DocVQA, POPE, MMMU) and four LLMs (LLaVA, Qwen-VL, InternVL, InstructBLIP), AttWarp yields consistent accuracy gains, strengthens compositional reasoning, and reduces hallucinations, outperforming baselines that modify raw images at test time.
AI.conclusion: Attention-guided warping is an effective, plug-in test-time technique that prioritizes query-relevant information while preserving global context, enabling MLLMs to read small objects and subtle relations more accurately without retraining.

title: LMCache: An Efficient KV Cache Layer for Enterprise-Scale LLM Inference
summary:
Today's LLM inference systems treat individual engines and queries
independently for simplicity, but this causes significant resource
inefficiencies. While there are proposals to avoid redundant computation by
reusing KV caches across queries and to increase GPU utilization by
disaggregating a single query to different engines, their promises cannot be
realized without efficiently offloading and communicating KV cache across LLM
inference engines and queries.
  We present LMCache, the first and so far the most efficient open-source KV
caching solution, which extracts and stores KV caches generated by modern LLM
engines (vLLM and SGLang) and shares the KV caches across engines and queries.
LMCache exposes KV caches in the LLM engine interface, effectively transforming
LLM engines from individual token processors to a collection of engines with KV
cache as the storage and communication medium. In particular, it supports both
cache offloading (prefix reuse across queries) and prefill-decode
disaggregation (cross-engine cache transfer). LMCache's high performance and
wide adoption stem from the following contributions: highly optimized KV cache
data movement with performance optimizations including batched data movement
operations, compute and I/O pipelining; a modular KV cache connector component,
decoupling LMCache from the rapid evolution of inference engines; a first-class
control API, such as pinning, lookup, cleanup, movement, and compression, for
flexible cache orchestration across GPU, CPU, storage, and network layers.
Evaluation shows that combining LMCache with vLLM achieves up to 15x
improvement in throughput across diverse workloads. With a growing community,
LMCache has seen dramatic growth in adoption by enterprise inference systems,
which provides valuable lessons for future KV caching solutions. The source
code of LMCache is at: https://github.com/LMCache/LMCache.

AI.tldr: LMCache is an open-source KV caching system for LLM inferences that extracts/stores KV caches from engines (vLLM, SGLang) and shares them across engines/queries to boost throughput; it enables cache offloading and cross-engine transfer, with optimizations and a flexible API, achieving up to 15x throughput improvements with vLLM.
AI.motivation: Current LLM inference tends to treat engines and queries independently, leading to wasted computation and underutilization. The paper argues that reusing KV caches across queries and cross-engine deployment require efficient offloading and communication of KV caches.
AI.method: Develop LMCache: a modular KV cache caching layer that extracts/stores KV caches from modern LLM engines and shares them across engines/queries. Supports cache offloading (prefix reuse) and prefill-decode disaggregation (cross-engine cache transfer). Implements optimized data movement (batched transfers, compute/I-O pipelining), a modular KV cache connector, and a first-class API (pinning, lookup, cleanup, movement, compression) for orchestration across GPU/CPU/storage/network.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation shows up to 15x throughput improvement when combined with vLLM across workloads. LMCache has gained substantial enterprise adoption.
AI.conclusion: LMCache stands as the first and most efficient open-source KV caching solution, demonstrating that shared KV caches across engines/queries can yield substantial performance gains and offering design lessons for future KV caching systems; source code available at the provided GitHub URL.

title: RIPRAG: Hack a Black-box Retrieval-Augmented Generation Question-Answering System with Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems based on Large Language Models
(LLMs) have become a core technology for tasks such as question-answering (QA)
and content generation. However, by injecting poisoned documents into the
database of RAG systems, attackers can manipulate LLMs to generate text that
aligns with their intended preferences. Existing research has primarily focused
on white-box attacks against simplified RAG architectures. In this paper, we
investigate a more complex and realistic scenario: the attacker lacks knowledge
of the RAG system's internal composition and implementation details, and the
RAG system comprises components beyond a mere retriever. Specifically, we
propose the RIPRAG attack framework, an end-to-end attack pipeline that treats
the target RAG system as a black box, where the only information accessible to
the attacker is whether the poisoning succeeds. Our method leverages
Reinforcement Learning (RL) to optimize the generation model for poisoned
documents, ensuring that the generated poisoned document aligns with the target
RAG system's preferences. Experimental results demonstrate that this method can
effectively execute poisoning attacks against most complex RAG systems,
achieving an attack success rate (ASR) improvement of up to 0.72 compared to
baseline methods. This highlights prevalent deficiencies in current defensive
methods and provides critical insights for LLM security research.

AI.tldr: A black-box poisoning attack against complex RAG systems using reinforcement learning to generate poisoned documents, improving attack success and exposing defense gaps.
AI.motivation: To study poisoning in realistic, multi-component RAG pipelines when the attacker has limited knowledge of internal system details, addressing limitations of prior white-box, simplified attacks.
AI.method: RIPRAG is an end-to-end attack pipeline that treats the target RAG system as a black box. It uses reinforcement learning to optimize the generation of poisoned documents, using only a success/failure signal as feedback across diverse RAG architectures.
AI.result: The approach achieves up to a 0.72 improvement in attack success rate over baseline methods and is effective against most complex RAG systems, revealing weaknesses in current defenses.
AI.conclusion: Black-box, multi-component RAG setups present significant security challenges; defenses must consider RL-driven poisoning in realistic attack scenarios, guiding future LLM security research.

title: Dejavu: Post-Deployment Learning for Embodied Agents via Experience Feedback
summary:
Embodied agents face a fundamental limitation: once deployed in real-world
environments to perform specific tasks, they are unable to acquire new useful
knowledge to enhance task performance. In this paper, we propose a general
post-deployment learning framework called Dejavu, which employs an Experience
Feedback Network (EFN) and augments the frozen Vision-Language-Action (VLA)
policy with retrieved execution memories. EFN automatically identifies
contextually successful prior action experiences and conditions action
prediction on this retrieved guidance. We adopt reinforcement learning with
semantic similarity rewards on EFN to ensure that the predicted actions align
with past successful behaviors under current observations. During deployment,
EFN continually enriches its memory with new trajectories, enabling the agent
to exhibit "learning from experience" despite fixed weights. Experiments across
diverse embodied tasks show that EFN significantly improves adaptability,
robustness, and success rates over frozen baselines. These results highlight a
promising path toward embodied agents that continually refine their behavior
after deployment.

AI.tldr: A post-deployment learning framework (Dejavu) uses an Experience Feedback Network to augment frozen Vision-Language-Action policies with retrieved execution memories, enabling continual learning from experience and improved performance in deployed embodied agents.
AI.motivation: Deployed embodied agents cannot conveniently acquire new knowledge to adapt to new tasks or environments; there is a need for post-deployment, continual learning without altering frozen base models.
AI.method: Introduce an Experience Feedback Network (EFN) that retrieves contextually successful prior action experiences and conditions action prediction on these memories. Train EFN with reinforcement learning using semantic-similarity rewards to align predicted actions with past successful behaviors. EFN continually enriches its memory with new trajectories during deployment to support ongoing adaptation.
AI.result: Experiments across diverse embodied tasks show that EFN significantly improves adaptability, robustness, and success rates compared with frozen baselines.
AI.conclusion: EFN enables post-deployment learning by continually refining behavior without changing the base VLA policy weights, demonstrating a promising direction for adaptable embodied agents.

title: Towards Understanding Ambiguity Resolution in Multimodal Inference of Meaning
comment:
Accepted to International Conference on Development and Learning
  (ICDL) 2025
summary:
We investigate a new setting for foreign language learning, where learners
infer the meaning of unfamiliar words in a multimodal context of a sentence
describing a paired image. We conduct studies with human participants using
different image-text pairs. We analyze the features of the data (i.e., images
and texts) that make it easier for participants to infer the meaning of a
masked or unfamiliar word, and what language backgrounds of the participants
correlate with success. We find only some intuitive features have strong
correlations with participant performance, prompting the need for further
investigating of predictive features for success in these tasks. We also
analyze the ability of AI systems to reason about participant performance, and
discover promising future directions for improving this reasoning ability.

AI.tldr: A study of multimodal word learning where meanings are inferred from image-text pairs; finds limited strong predictive features for success and suggests improving AI reasoning about participant performance.
AI.motivation: To understand how visual and textual context aids vocabulary inference in foreign language learning and to identify predictive cues of learner success and to assess AI's ability to model/reason about such human performance.
AI.method: Experimental study with human participants using multiple image-text pairs, with masked or unfamiliar words; analysis of data features in images and texts and their correlation with learner success; examination of language backgrounds; evaluation of AI systems' ability to reason about participant performance.
AI.result: Only some intuitive features show strong correlations with performance; many predictive features remain unidentified, indicating a need for further investigation; AI systems show potential in reasoning about human performance but require improvements.
AI.conclusion: There is a need to identify robust predictive features for success in multimodal word learning tasks and to advance AI reasoning capabilities to better model and support human learning in multimodal contexts.

title: Spatial Uncertainty Quantification in Wildfire Forecasting for Climate-Resilient Emergency Planning
summary:
Climate change is intensifying wildfire risks globally, making reliable
forecasting critical for adaptation strategies. While machine learning shows
promise for wildfire prediction from Earth observation data, current approaches
lack uncertainty quantification essential for risk-aware decision making. We
present the first systematic analysis of spatial uncertainty in wildfire spread
forecasting using multimodal Earth observation inputs. We demonstrate that
predictive uncertainty exhibits coherent spatial structure concentrated near
fire perimeters. Our novel distance metric reveals high-uncertainty regions
form consistent 20-60 meter buffer zones around predicted firelines - directly
applicable for emergency planning. Feature attribution identifies vegetation
health and fire activity as primary uncertainty drivers. This work enables more
robust wildfire management systems supporting communities adapting to
increasing fire risk under climate change.

AI.tldr: Systematic analysis of spatial uncertainty in wildfire spread forecasting using multimodal Earth observation data. Finds coherent uncertainty near fire perimeters, with 20–60 m buffer zones around predicted firelines; vegetation health and fire activity drive uncertainty; enables risk-aware emergency planning.
AI.motivation: Climate change is increasing wildfire risk and reliable forecasts with uncertainty quantification are needed for risk-aware decision making and emergency planning.
AI.method: Systematic analysis of spatial uncertainty in wildfire forecasting using multimodal Earth observation inputs. Introduces a novel distance metric to identify high-uncertainty regions and uses feature attribution to determine uncertainty drivers (vegetation health, fire activity).
AI.result: Predictive uncertainty exhibits coherent spatial structure concentrated near fire perimeters. High-uncertainty regions form consistent 20–60 meter buffer zones around predicted firelines. Vegetation health and fire activity are identified as primary drivers of uncertainty.
AI.conclusion: This work supports the development of robust wildfire management systems and emergency planning by highlighting where forecasts are less certain and what factors drive that uncertainty, aiding communities adapting to increasing fire risk under climate change.

title: Failure-Driven Workflow Refinement
summary:
Optimizing LLM-based workflows is typically formulated as a global search,
where candidate workflows are evaluated based on a scalar metric. This
paradigm, however, suffers from a critical flaw: information collapse. By
reducing rich, multi-step execution traces to simple success/failure signals,
existing methods are rendered blind to the underlying structure of failures,
fundamentally preventing them from modeling the workflow's failure
distribution. We reconceptualize this challenge as a distributional problem. We
propose a new paradigm where the optimization goal is not to maximize a scalar
score, but to directly minimize a workflow's Expected Failure Mass, i.e., the
integral of its failure probability density function defined over a
high-dimensional Failure Signature Space (FSS). This distributional lens allows
us to move from inefficient, zero-order optimization to a principled,
gradient-like descent on the failure landscape itself. We introduce CE-Graph, a
framework that operationalizes this paradigm through a novel, failure-driven
refinement process. CE-Graph approximates the failure distribution from a pool
of counterexamples, identifies its densest regions as recurring failure modes,
and applies targeted, operator-constrained graph edits via a Propose-and-Verify
mechanism to greedily reduce the failure mass. On math, code, and QA
benchmarks, our CE-Graph achieves higher robustness at a significantly lower
cost than strong baselines. This suggests that a system's reliability emerges
not from avoiding failures, but from systematically learning and reshaping the
geometric structure of its failure distributions.

AI.tldr: Reconceptualizes LLM workflow optimization as minimizing Expected Failure Mass in a high-dimensional Failure Signature Space using CE-Graph, a failure-driven graph-edit framework that targets dense failure modes from counterexamples, achieving higher robustness at lower cost than baselines on math/code/QA tasks.
AI.motivation: Scalar success/failure signals collapse rich failure structure, hindering understanding of failure distributions; a distributional view is needed to guide robust improvements.
AI.method: Introduce CE-Graph; approximate failure distribution from counterexamples; identify densest regions (recurring failure modes); Propose-and-Verify constrained graph edits to reduce observed failure mass; perform gradient-like descent on the failure landscape.
AI.result: Outperforms strong baselines in math, code, QA benchmarks; higher robustness at significantly lower cost.
AI.conclusion: Reliability emerges from learning and reshaping the geometry of failure distributions; a distributional lens enables principled improvements over scalar optimization.

title: It Takes Two: Learning Interactive Whole-Body Control Between Humanoid Robots
summary:
The true promise of humanoid robotics lies beyond single-agent autonomy: two
or more humanoids must engage in physically grounded, socially meaningful
whole-body interactions that echo the richness of human social interaction.
However, single-humanoid methods suffer from the isolation issue, ignoring
inter-agent dynamics and causing misaligned contacts, interpenetrations, and
unrealistic motions. To address this, we present Harmanoid , a dual-humanoid
motion imitation framework that transfers interacting human motions to two
robots while preserving both kinematic fidelity and physical realism. Harmanoid
comprises two key components: (i) contact-aware motion retargeting, which
restores inter-body coordination by aligning SMPL contacts with robot vertices,
and (ii) interaction-driven motion controller, which leverages
interaction-specific rewards to enforce coordinated keypoints and physically
plausible contacts. By explicitly modeling inter-agent contacts and
interaction-aware dynamics, Harmanoid captures the coupled behaviors between
humanoids that single-humanoid frameworks inherently overlook. Experiments
demonstrate that Harmanoid significantly improves interactive motion imitation,
surpassing existing single-humanoid frameworks that largely fail in such
scenarios.

AI.tldr: A dual-humanoid motion imitation framework, Harmanoid, transfers interacting human motions to two robots using contact-aware retargeting and an interaction-driven controller to achieve coordinated, physically plausible motions, outperforming single-humanoid methods.
AI.motivation: To address the neglected inter-agent dynamics and contact realism in single-humanoid systems, enabling physically grounded two-humanoid interactions.
AI.method: Two components: (1) contact-aware motion retargeting aligning SMPL contacts with robot vertices to restore inter-body coordination; (2) interaction-driven motion controller using interaction-specific rewards to enforce coordinated keypoints and plausible contacts.
AI.result: Experiments show Harmanoid significantly improves interactive motion imitation and surpasses existing single-humanoid frameworks that fail in interactive scenarios.
AI.conclusion: Modeling inter-agent contacts and interaction-aware dynamics is essential for realistic two-humanoid imitation; Harmanoid demonstrates the viability and benefits of this approach.

title: Task-Aware Resolution Optimization for Visual Large Language Models
comment:
Accepted as a main conference paper at EMNLP 2025. 9 pages (main
  content), 7 figures
summary:
Real-world vision-language applications demand varying levels of perceptual
granularity. However, most existing visual large language models (VLLMs), such
as LLaVA, pre-assume a fixed resolution for downstream tasks, which leads to
subpar performance. To address this problem, we first conduct a comprehensive
and pioneering investigation into the resolution preferences of different
vision-language tasks, revealing a correlation between resolution preferences
with image complexity, and uncertainty variance of the VLLM at different image
input resolutions. Building on this insight, we propose an empirical formula to
determine the optimal resolution for a given vision-language task, combining
these two factors. Second, based on rigorous experiments, we propose a novel
parameter-efficient fine-tuning technique to extend the visual input resolution
of pre-trained VLLMs to the identified optimal resolution. Extensive
experiments on various vision-language tasks validate the effectiveness of our
method.

AI.tldr: Empirically determine the optimal image resolution for vision-language tasks by combining image complexity and model uncertainty, and provide a parameter-efficient fine-tuning method to extend VLLMs to that resolution; validated across tasks.
AI.motivation: Current VLLMs typically fix input resolution, which can degrade performance on real-world data with varying perceptual granularity. There is a need to tailor resolution to task demands and input complexity.
AI.method: 1) Analyze resolution preferences across vision-language tasks and quantify image complexity and VLLM uncertainty at multiple resolutions. 2) Propose an empirical formula that combines image complexity and uncertainty variance to predict the optimal resolution for a given task. 3) Introduce a parameter-efficient fine-tuning technique to enable VLLMs to operate at the identified optimal resolution. 4) Validate the approach through extensive experiments on diverse V+L tasks.
AI.result: The empirical formula effectively predicts near-optimal resolutions per task, and the proposed tuning method allows upgrading the model's perceptual input to that resolution with minimal trainable parameters, yielding improvements over fixed-resolution baselines across multiple tasks.
AI.conclusion: Adaptive, task-aware resolution selection together with efficient fine-tuning enhances VLLMs’ performance and practicality in real-world vision-language applications, supporting more flexible and efficient perceptual granularity.

title: A Hybrid Computational Intelligence Framework with Metaheuristic Optimization for Drug-Drug Interaction Prediction
summary:
Drug-drug interactions (DDIs) are a leading cause of preventable adverse
events, often complicating treatment and increasing healthcare costs. At the
same time, knowing which drugs do not interact is equally important, as such
knowledge supports safer prescriptions and better patient outcomes. In this
study, we propose an interpretable and efficient framework that blends modern
machine learning with domain knowledge to improve DDI prediction. Our approach
combines two complementary molecular embeddings - Mol2Vec, which captures
fragment-level structural patterns, and SMILES-BERT, which learns contextual
chemical features - together with a leakage-free, rule-based clinical score
(RBScore) that injects pharmacological knowledge without relying on interaction
labels. A lightweight neural classifier is then optimized using a novel
three-stage metaheuristic strategy (RSmpl-ACO-PSO), which balances global
exploration and local refinement for stable performance. Experiments on
real-world datasets demonstrate that the model achieves high predictive
accuracy (ROC-AUC 0.911, PR-AUC 0.867 on DrugBank) and generalizes well to a
clinically relevant Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus cohort. Beyond raw performance,
studies show how embedding fusion, RBScore, and the optimizer each contribute
to precision and robustness. Together, these results highlight a practical
pathway for building reliable, interpretable, and computationally efficient
models that can support safer drug therapies and clinical decision-making.

AI.tldr: An interpretable, efficient DDI predictor that fuses molecular embeddings (Mol2Vec + SMILES-BERT) with a leakage-free, rule-based RBScore and optimizes a lightweight classifier via a three-stage metaheuristic (RSmpl-ACO-PSO), achieving strong DrugBank performance (ROC-AUC 0.911, PR-AUC 0.867) and generalizing to a T2DM patient cohort.
AI.motivation: DDIs are a major source of adverse events and healthcare costs; knowing non-interactions is equally important for safe prescription. There is a need for models that are both accurate and interpretable, and that leverage domain knowledge without overfitting to interaction labels.
AI.method: Combine two complementary molecular embeddings—Mol2Vec (fragment-level patterns) and SMILES-BERT (contextual chemical features)—with a leakage-free, rule-based clinical score (RBScore) that injects pharmacological knowledge without using interaction labels. Train a lightweight neural classifier using a novel three-stage metaheuristic optimizer (RSmpl-ACO-PSO) to balance global exploration and local refinement.
AI.result: On DrugBank data: ROC-AUC 0.911 and PR-AUC 0.867. The model generalizes to a clinically relevant Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus cohort.
AI.conclusion: Embedding fusion, RBScore, and the three-stage optimizer collectively enhance precision and robustness, yielding an interpretable, efficient framework to support safer drug therapies and informed clinical decisions.

title: Belief Graphs with Reasoning Zones: Structure, Dynamics, and Epistemic Activation
summary:
Belief systems are rarely globally consistent, yet effective reasoning often
persists locally. We propose a novel graph-theoretic framework that cleanly
separates credibility--external, a priori trust in sources--from confidence--an
internal, emergent valuation induced by network structure. Beliefs are nodes in
a directed, signed, weighted graph whose edges encode support and
contradiction. Confidence is obtained by a contractive propagation process that
mixes a stated prior with structure-aware influence and guarantees a unique,
stable solution. Within this dynamics, we define reasoning zones:
high-confidence, structurally balanced subgraphs on which classical inference
is safe despite global contradictions. We provide a near-linear procedure that
seeds zones by confidence, tests balance using a parity-based coloring, and
applies a greedy, locality-preserving repair with Jaccard de-duplication to
build a compact atlas. To model belief change, we introduce shock updates that
locally downscale support and elevate targeted contradictions while preserving
contractivity via a simple backtracking rule. Re-propagation yields localized
reconfiguration-zones may shrink, split, or collapse--without destabilizing the
entire graph. We outline an empirical protocol on synthetic signed graphs with
planted zones, reporting zone recovery, stability under shocks, and runtime.
The result is a principled foundation for contradiction-tolerant reasoning that
activates classical logic precisely where structure supports it.

AI.tldr: A graph-based framework that separates external credibility from internal confidence, uses contractive belief propagation over signed, directed graphs, defines high-confidence reasoning zones, and uses local repairs and shock updates to enable contradiction-tolerant, locality-preserving inference.
AI.motivation: Belief systems are often globally inconsistent; the key challenge is to reason safely in regions of the network where structure supports classical inference, while down-weighting or isolating contradictions elsewhere. The framework aims to disentangle source trust from internal network-derived confidence and to provide scalable, localizable reasoning mechanisms.
AI.method: Beliefs are nodes in a directed, signed, weighted graph with edges for support/contradiction. Confidence is obtained via a contractive propagation that blends a stated prior with structure-aware influence to yield a unique, stable solution. Reasoning zones are high-confidence, structurally balanced subgraphs. Seeding zones uses confidence, balance is tested with a parity-based coloring, and a greedy, locality-preserving repair with Jaccard dedup builds a compact atlas. Shock updates locally downscale support and elevate targeted contradictions, with backtracking to maintain contractivity; re-propagation yields reconfiguration zones without destabilizing the entire graph. Evaluation protocol on synthetic planted-sign graphs reports zone recovery, stability under shocks, and runtime.
AI.result: A near-linear procedure for identifying and repairing reasoning zones, with a validated protocol on synthetic data showing zone recovery, stability to shocks, and favorable runtime characteristics.
AI.conclusion: The work offers a principled foundation for contradiction-tolerant reasoning, activating classical logic precisely where the structure supports it, and scales to large graphs through local, contractive dynamics.

title: UF-RNN: Real-Time Adaptive Motion Generation Using Uncertainty-Driven Foresight Prediction
summary:
Training robots to operate effectively in environments with uncertain states,
such as ambiguous object properties or unpredictable interactions, remains a
longstanding challenge in robotics. Imitation learning methods typically rely
on successful examples and often neglect failure scenarios where uncertainty is
most pronounced. To address this limitation, we propose the Uncertainty-driven
Foresight Recurrent Neural Network (UF-RNN), a model that combines standard
time-series prediction with an active "Foresight" module. This module performs
internal simulations of multiple future trajectories and refines the hidden
state to minimize predicted variance, enabling the model to selectively explore
actions under high uncertainty. We evaluate UF-RNN on a door-opening task in
both simulation and a real-robot setting, demonstrating that, despite the
absence of explicit failure demonstrations, the model exhibits robust
adaptation by leveraging self-induced chaotic dynamics in its latent space.
When guided by the Foresight module, these chaotic properties stimulate
exploratory behaviors precisely when the environment is ambiguous, yielding
improved success rates compared to conventional stochastic RNN baselines. These
findings suggest that integrating uncertainty-driven foresight into imitation
learning pipelines can significantly enhance a robot's ability to handle
unpredictable real-world conditions.

AI.tldr: UF-RNN introduces a Foresight module that internally simulates multiple futures to minimize predicted variance, enabling uncertainty-driven exploration and improved robustness in a door-opening task, even without explicit failure demonstrations.
AI.motivation: Imitation learning often fails under real-world uncertainty due to scarce failure data and unseen states. A mechanism to actively explore uncertain actions can improve robustness.
AI.method: A recurrent network augmented with a Foresight module that performs internal simulations of multiple future trajectories to refine hidden states and reduce predicted variance. The model leverages self-induced chaotic latent dynamics to stimulate exploration when environment is ambiguous, and is evaluated on door-opening in simulation and on a real robot.
AI.result: The UF-RNN achieves higher success rates and more robust adaptation to uncertain conditions compared to conventional stochastic RNN baselines, demonstrating productive exploratory behavior driven by foresight even without explicit failure examples.
AI.conclusion: Integrating uncertainty-driven foresight into imitation learning can significantly enhance a robot's ability to handle unpredictable real-world conditions, with potential generalization to other manipulation tasks.

title: Post Processing of image segmentation using Conditional Random Fields
summary:
The output of image the segmentation process is usually not very clear due to
low quality features of Satellite images. The purpose of this study is to find
a suitable Conditional Random Field (CRF) to achieve better clarity in a
segmented image. We started with different types of CRFs and studied them as to
why they are or are not suitable for our purpose. We evaluated our approach on
two different datasets - Satellite imagery having low quality features and high
quality Aerial photographs. During the study we experimented with various CRFs
to find which CRF gives the best results on images and compared our results on
these datasets to show the pitfalls and potentials of different approaches.

AI.tldr: Assesses multiple CRF variants to enhance segmentation clarity in satellite imagery, using two datasets (low-quality satellite and high-quality aerial) and comparing performance to uncover the pros/cons of CRF types.
AI.motivation: Improve segmentation clarity in satellite imagery by selecting an effective CRF, addressing the issue of low-quality feature representations.
AI.method: Started with different types of CRFs, studied their suitability, and evaluated them on two datasets (low-quality satellite imagery and high-quality aerial photographs) by experimenting with various CRFs to identify which yields the best results and to discuss pitfalls and potentials.
AI.result: The study identifies which CRF provides the best results across datasets and discusses the pitfalls and potentials of different CRF approaches; results show that effectiveness depends on data quality and CRF type.
AI.conclusion: CRFs can improve segmentation clarity, but their success is data-dependent; careful selection and understanding of CRF properties are necessary.

title: Population synthesis with geographic coordinates
summary:
It is increasingly important to generate synthetic populations with explicit
coordinates rather than coarse geographic areas, yet no established methods
exist to achieve this. One reason is that latitude and longitude differ from
other continuous variables, exhibiting large empty spaces and highly uneven
densities. To address this, we propose a population synthesis algorithm that
first maps spatial coordinates into a more regular latent space using
Normalizing Flows (NF), and then combines them with other features in a
Variational Autoencoder (VAE) to generate synthetic populations. This approach
also learns the joint distribution between spatial and non-spatial features,
exploiting spatial autocorrelations. We demonstrate the method by generating
synthetic homes with the same statistical properties of real homes in 121
datasets, corresponding to diverse geographies. We further propose an
evaluation framework that measures both spatial accuracy and practical utility,
while ensuring privacy preservation. Our results show that the NF+VAE
architecture outperforms popular benchmarks, including copula-based methods and
uniform allocation within geographic areas. The ability to generate geolocated
synthetic populations at fine spatial resolution opens the door to applications
requiring detailed geography, from household responses to floods, to epidemic
spread, evacuation planning, and transport modeling.

AI.tldr: Introduces a NF+VAE pipeline for generating geolocated synthetic populations by mapping latitude/longitude to a latent space with Normalizing Flows and combining with non-spatial features in a Variational Autoencoder; evaluated on 121 diverse datasets; outperforms copula-based and uniform-area baselines; enables high-resolution, privacy-preserving synthetic geographies.
AI.motivation: There is a need to generate synthetic populations with explicit coordinates for accurate spatial analysis, but latitude/longitude distributions are highly irregular with large empty spaces. Existing methods underperform in preserving spatial structure and privacy.
AI.method: Map spatial coordinates into a regular latent space using Normalizing Flows, then integrate with non-spatial features in a Variational Autoencoder to learn the joint distribution and generate synthetic homes; develop an evaluation framework assessing spatial accuracy, practical utility, and privacy; compare against copula-based methods and uniform geographic allocation across 121 datasets.
AI.result: NF+VAE outperforms popular benchmarks (including copula-based methods and uniform allocation) in preserving the statistical properties of real homes across 121 datasets with diverse geographies; demonstrates the ability to generate geolocated synthetic populations at fine spatial resolution.
AI.conclusion: The NF+VAE approach enables realistic, fine-grained, geolocated synthetic populations while incorporating spatial autocorrelation and joint spatial-non-spatial distributions; broad applicability to risk assessment, evacuation, epidemic modeling, and transport planning, with an emphasis on privacy-preserving evaluation.

title: SwarmSys: Decentralized Swarm-Inspired Agents for Scalable and Adaptive Reasoning
summary:
Large language model (LLM) agents have shown remarkable reasoning abilities.
However, existing multi-agent frameworks often rely on fixed roles or
centralized control, limiting scalability and adaptability in long-horizon
reasoning. We introduce SwarmSys, a closed-loop framework for distributed
multi-agent reasoning inspired by swarm intelligence. Coordination in SwarmSys
emerges through iterative interactions among three specialized roles,
Explorers, Workers, and Validators, that continuously cycle through
exploration, exploitation, and validation. To enable scalable and adaptive
collaboration, we integrate adaptive agent and event profiles, embedding-based
probabilistic matching, and a pheromone-inspired reinforcement mechanism,
supporting dynamic task allocation and self-organizing convergence without
global supervision. Across symbolic reasoning, research synthesis, and
scientific programming tasks, SwarmSys consistently outperforms baselines,
improving both accuracy and reasoning stability. These findings highlight
swarm-inspired coordination as a promising paradigm for scalable, robust, and
adaptive multi-agent reasoning, suggesting that coordination scaling may rival
model scaling in advancing LLM intelligence.

AI.tldr: SwarmSys introduces a swarm-inspired, closed-loop multi-agent framework that coordinates Explorers, Workers, and Validators to enable scalable, adaptive long-horizon reasoning without centralized control. It uses adaptive profiles, embedding-based matching, and pheromone-like reinforcement to dynamically allocate tasks and self-organize, achieving improved accuracy and reasoning stability across symbolic reasoning, research synthesis, and scientific programming tasks, suggesting coordination scaling can rival model scaling.
AI.motivation: Existing multi-agent systems rely on fixed roles or centralized control, which hampers scalability and adaptability in long-horizon reasoning. There is a need for scalable, robust coordination mechanisms that can adapt to dynamic tasks without global supervision.
AI.method: SwarmSys implements three specialized roles—Explorers, Workers, and Validators—that iteratively cycle through exploration, exploitation, and validation in a closed loop. It introduces adaptive agent and event profiles, embedding-based probabilistic matching for task assignment, and a pheromone-inspired reinforcement mechanism to guide dynamic task allocation and self-organization without global supervision. The framework is evaluated on symbolic reasoning, research synthesis, and scientific programming tasks.
AI.result: SwarmSys consistently outperforms baselines across the evaluated tasks, achieving higher accuracy and greater reasoning stability in symbolic reasoning, research synthesis, and scientific programming.
AI.conclusion: SwarmSys demonstrates that swarm-inspired coordination is a promising paradigm for scalable, robust, and adaptive multi-agent reasoning. The approach suggests that coordination scaling could rival model scaling in advancing LLM intelligence.

title: A3RNN: Bi-directional Fusion of Bottom-up and Top-down Process for Developmental Visual Attention in Robots
summary:
This study investigates the developmental interaction between top-down (TD)
and bottom-up (BU) visual attention in robotic learning. Our goal is to
understand how structured, human-like attentional behavior emerges through the
mutual adaptation of TD and BU mechanisms over time. To this end, we propose a
novel attention model $A^3 RNN$ that integrates predictive TD signals and
saliency-based BU cues through a bi-directional attention architecture.
  We evaluate our model in robotic manipulation tasks using imitation learning.
Experimental results show that attention behaviors evolve throughout training,
from saliency-driven exploration to prediction-driven direction. Initially, BU
attention highlights visually salient regions, which guide TD processes, while
as learning progresses, TD attention stabilizes and begins to reshape what is
perceived as salient. This trajectory reflects principles from cognitive
science and the free-energy framework, suggesting the importance of
self-organizing attention through interaction between perception and internal
prediction. Although not explicitly optimized for stability, our model exhibits
more coherent and interpretable attention patterns than baselines, supporting
the idea that developmental mechanisms contribute to robust attention
formation.

AI.tldr: Develops a developmental attention model A^3 RNN that merges top-down predictive signals with bottom-up saliency via bidirectional attention, showing emergent, human-like attention in robotic imitation tasks that evolves from saliency-driven to prediction-driven control and yields coherent, interpretable patterns.
AI.motivation: To understand how structured, human-like attentional behavior can emerge through mutual adaptation of top-down and bottom-up mechanisms in robotics, connecting cognitive science with the free-energy framework and aiming for self-organizing attention without explicit stability optimization.
AI.method: Proposes A^3 RNN, a bidirectional attention architecture that integrates predictive top-down signals and saliency-based bottom-up cues. Evaluated in robotic manipulation tasks using imitation learning; analyzes how attention patterns evolve during training.
AI.result: Attention behaviors evolve from saliency-driven exploration to prediction-driven focus. Early BU attention highlights salient regions guiding TD, while later TD stabilizes and reshapes what is perceived as salient. The model shows more coherent and interpretable attention patterns than baselines, aligning with self-organization principles of perception and prediction.
AI.conclusion: Developmental interaction between perception and internal prediction can yield robust, self-organizing attention in robots. The approach aligns with cognitive science and the free-energy framework and suggests that mutual adaptation can produce stable, interpretable attention patterns even without explicit stability optimization.

title: Exploration of Incremental Synthetic Non-Morphed Images for Single Morphing Attack Detection
summary:
This paper investigates the use of synthetic face data to enhance
Single-Morphing Attack Detection (S-MAD), addressing the limitations of
availability of large-scale datasets of bona fide images due to privacy
concerns. Various morphing tools and cross-dataset evaluation schemes were
utilized to conduct this study. An incremental testing protocol was implemented
to assess the generalization capabilities as more and more synthetic images
were added. The results of the experiments show that generalization can be
improved by carefully incorporating a controlled number of synthetic images
into existing datasets or by gradually adding bona fide images during training.
However, indiscriminate use of synthetic data can lead to sub-optimal
performance. Evenmore, the use of only synthetic data (morphed and non-morphed
images) achieves the highest Equal Error Rate (EER), which means in operational
scenarios the best option is not relying only on synthetic data for S-MAD.

AI.tldr: Synthetic face data can boost S-MAD generalization when added progressively and in controlled amounts; naive use of synthetic data degrades performance.
AI.motivation: Privacy concerns limit access to large-scale bona fide face datasets, creating a need to improve S-MAD generalization with synthetic data.
AI.method: Use diverse morphing tools and cross-dataset evaluation; implement an incremental testing protocol to measure generalization as synthetic images are added; mix synthetic images with existing data and gradually add bona fide images during training.
AI.result: Generalization improves with carefully controlled incorporation of synthetic data; indiscriminate use leads to sub-optimal performance; relying solely on synthetic data yields the highest EER.
AI.conclusion: Synthetic data can aid S-MAD when used in a controlled, incremental manner, but relying exclusively on synthetic data is not advisable; a mixed training approach with bona fide data is preferable.

title: A physics-aware deep learning model for shear band formation around collapsing pores in shocked reactive materials
summary:
Modeling shock-to-detonation phenomena in energetic materials (EMs) requires
capturing complex physical processes such as strong shocks, rapid changes in
microstructural morphology, and nonlinear dynamics of chemical reaction fronts.
These processes participate in energy localization at hotspots, which initiate
chemical energy release leading to detonation. This study addresses the
formation of hotspots in crystalline EMs subjected to weak-to-moderate shock
loading, which, despite its critical relevance to the safe storage and handling
of EMs, remains underexplored compared to the well-studied strong shock
conditions. To overcome the computational challenges associated with direct
numerical simulations, we advance the Physics-Aware Recurrent Convolutional
Neural Network (PARCv2), which has been shown to be capable of predicting
strong shock responses in EMs. We improved the architecture of PARCv2 to
rapidly predict shear localizations and plastic heating, which play important
roles in the weak-to-moderate shock regime. PARCv2 is benchmarked against two
widely used physics-informed models, namely, Fourier neural operator and neural
ordinary differential equation; we demonstrate its superior performance in
capturing the spatiotemporal dynamics of shear band formation. While all models
exhibit certain failure modes, our findings underscore the importance of
domain-specific considerations in developing robust AI-accelerated simulation
tools for reactive materials.

AI.tldr: An enhanced Physics-Aware Recurrent Convolutional Neural Network (PARCv2) is developed to predict hotspot formation under weak-to-moderate shocks in crystalline energetic materials, outperforming Fourier neural operator and neural ODE in capturing shear localization dynamics.
AI.motivation: Enable safe storage/handling of energetic materials by efficiently simulating hotspot formation and shear heating under weaker shocks, where current models are less explored and full simulations are computationally expensive.
AI.method: Improved PARCv2 architecture to rapidly predict shear localization and plastic heating; benchmarked against Fourier neural operator and neural ODE to assess spatiotemporal dynamics of shear bands in EMs under weak-to-moderate shock.
AI.result: PARCv2 demonstrates superior performance in capturing spatiotemporal dynamics of shear band formation; all models have failure modes; domain-specific design is important for robust AI-accelerated simulations of reactive materials.
AI.conclusion: Domain-specific AI tools like physics-aware networks are essential for robustly modeling reactive materials; addressing weak-to-moderate shock regimes remains critical; results underscore need to incorporate microstructural and nonlinear reaction front dynamics.

title: SyncLipMAE: Contrastive Masked Pretraining for Audio-Visual Talking-Face Representation
summary:
We introduce SyncLipMAE, a self-supervised pretraining framework for
talking-face video that learns synchronization-aware and transferable facial
dynamics from unlabeled audio-visual streams. Our approach couples masked
visual modeling with cross-modal contrastive alignment and employs three
per-frame prompt tokens that explicitly encode the essential factors of a
talking-face frame - identity, vocal motion (speech-synchronized facial
dynamics), and ambient motion (audio-agnostic movements such as blinks and head
pose). The contrastive objective uses time-aligned vocal-motion and audio
tokens as positives and misaligned pairs as negatives, driving both modalities
into a shared embedding space and yielding token-level audio-visual stream
synchronization. After pretraining, the aligned audio tokens together with the
visual prompt tokens (identity, vocal motion, ambient motion) form a unified
interface for four disparate downstream settings: (i) audio-visual stream
synchronization; (ii) facial emotion and head/face action recognition; (iii)
visual speech recognition; and (iv) visual dubbing, for which we enable
indistinguishable audio- or video-driven control within a single model. Across
four task families that require distinct capabilities, SyncLipMAE achieves
state-of-the-art results, underscoring the effectiveness of
synchronization-aware, factorized self-supervised pretraining.

AI.tldr: SyncLipMAE is a self-supervised pretraining method for talking-face video that learns synchronization-aware and transferable facial dynamics via masked visual modeling and cross-modal contrastive alignment, using per-frame tokens for identity, vocal motion, and ambient motion; achieves state-of-the-art across four task families including synchronization, emotion/action recognition, visual speech recognition, and visual dubbing.
AI.motivation: Address the need for a unified pretraining framework that explicitly encodes synchronization and factorized components of facial dynamics to enable transfer across multiple audio-visual tasks.
AI.method: Couples masked visual modeling with cross-modal contrastive learning; uses time-aligned vocal-motion and audio tokens as positives and misaligned pairs as negatives; introduces per-frame tokens for identity, vocal motion, ambient motion; aligns audio and visual streams into a shared embedding space.
AI.result: Four task families show state-of-the-art results; improved synchronization and performance across audio-visual synchronization, emotion/action recognition, visual speech recognition, and visual dubbing; demonstrates effectiveness of synchronization-aware, factorized pretraining.
AI.conclusion: A unified, synchronization-aware self-supervised pretraining framework enabling versatile downstream tasks with shared representation and token-level alignment, outperforming existing methods.

title: Integration of the TIAGo Robot into Isaac Sim with Mecanum Drive Modeling and Learned S-Curve Velocity Profiles
comment:
In Proceedings of IEEE 21st International Conference on Automation
  Science and Engineering (CASE), Los Angeles, USA, August 2025
summary:
