obtain in practice. We present a sampling-based pipeline that leverages
large-scale pretrained generative models to produce probabilistic priors
capturing environmental uncertainty and spatio-semantic relationships in a
zero-shot manner. Conditioned on partial observations, the pipeline recovers
complete RGB-D point cloud samples with occupancy and target semantics,
formulated to be directly useful in configuration-space planning. We establish
a Matterport3D benchmark of rooms partially visible through doorways, where a
robot must navigate to an unobserved target object. Effective priors for this
setting must represent both occupancy and target-location uncertainty in
unobserved regions. Experiments show that our approach recovers commonsense
spatial semantics consistent with ground truth, yielding diverse, clean 3D
point clouds usable in motion planning, highlight the promise of generative
models as a rich source of priors for robotic planning.

AI.tldr: Zero-shot, sampling-based priors from large pretrained generative models enable recovery of complete 3D scenes (occupancy + target semantics) from partial observations for planning under partial observability.
AI.motivation: Priors are essential for planning under partial observability but are hard to obtain in practice; need priors that capture environmental uncertainty and spatio-semantic relationships without task-specific data collection.
AI.method: A sampling-based pipeline conditioned on partial observations uses large-scale pretrained generative models to produce probabilistic priors, reconstructing complete RGB-D point clouds with occupancy and target semantics for configuration-space planning. Evaluated on a Matterport3D-based benchmark with rooms visible through doorways to test occupancy and target-location uncertainty.
AI.result: The approach recovers commonsense spatial semantics consistent with ground truth, yielding diverse, clean 3D point clouds suitable for motion planning, demonstrating that generative models can serve as rich, zero-shot priors for robotic planning.
AI.conclusion: Generative models offer a promising, zero-shot source of priors for planning under partial observability, capable of modeling occupancy and target-location uncertainty in unobserved regions and improving configuration-space planning.

title: Color3D: Controllable and Consistent 3D Colorization with Personalized Colorizer
summary:
In this work, we present Color3D, a highly adaptable framework for colorizing
both static and dynamic 3D scenes from monochromatic inputs, delivering
visually diverse and chromatically vibrant reconstructions with flexible
user-guided control. In contrast to existing methods that focus solely on
static scenarios and enforce multi-view consistency by averaging color
variations which inevitably sacrifice both chromatic richness and
controllability, our approach is able to preserve color diversity and
steerability while ensuring cross-view and cross-time consistency. In
particular, the core insight of our method is to colorize only a single key
view and then fine-tune a personalized colorizer to propagate its color to
novel views and time steps. Through personalization, the colorizer learns a
scene-specific deterministic color mapping underlying the reference view,
enabling it to consistently project corresponding colors to the content in
novel views and video frames via its inherent inductive bias. Once trained, the
personalized colorizer can be applied to infer consistent chrominance for all
other images, enabling direct reconstruction of colorful 3D scenes with a
dedicated Lab color space Gaussian splatting representation. The proposed
framework ingeniously recasts complicated 3D colorization as a more tractable
single image paradigm, allowing seamless integration of arbitrary image
colorization models with enhanced flexibility and controllability. Extensive
experiments across diverse static and dynamic 3D colorization benchmarks
substantiate that our method can deliver more consistent and chromatically rich
renderings with precise user control. Project Page
https://yecongwan.github.io/Color3D/.

AI.tldr: Color3D reframes 3D colorization as a single-image colorization task by training a scene-specific, personalized colorizer from a single reference view to propagate colors across novel views and time steps, enabling consistent, diverse, and user-controlled colorizations for static and dynamic scenes using a Lab color space Gaussian splatting representation.
AI.motivation: Existing 3D colorization methods often enforce multi-view consistency by averaging color variations, which reduces chromatic richness and controllability. There is a need for retaining color diversity and user steerability while ensuring cross-view and cross-time consistency in static and dynamic scenes.
AI.method: Train a personalized colorizer on a single key view to learn a deterministic, scene-specific color mapping. Use this colorizer to propagate colors to novel views and video frames. Represent color with a Lab-space Gaussian splatting approach. Recast 3D colorization as a single-image paradigm, allowing integration of arbitrary image colorization models. Apply to both static and dynamic 3D scenes with controllable user guidance.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on static and dynamic 3D colorization benchmarks show improved chromatic richness, cross-view/time consistency, and user control compared to averaging-based baselines. Demonstrates robust performance across diverse scenes and under user-guided manipulations. Project page provided for reference.
AI.conclusion: Color3D offers a flexible, controllable, and consistent 3D colorization framework by leveraging a personalized colorizer learned from a single reference view, enabling arbitrary image colorization models to colorize 3D content while maintaining cross-view and cross-time coherence.

title: Decomposer Networks: Deep Component Analysis and Synthesis
summary:
We propose the Decomposer Networks (DecompNet), a semantic autoencoder that
factorizes an input into multiple interpretable components. Unlike classical
autoencoders that compress an input into a single latent representation, the
Decomposer Network maintains N parallel branches, each assigned a residual
input defined as the original signal minus the reconstructions of all other
branches. By unrolling a Gauss--Seidel style block-coordinate descent into a
differentiable network, DecompNet enforce explicit competition among
components, yielding parsimonious, semantically meaningful representations. We
situate our model relative to linear decomposition methods (PCA, NMF), deep
unrolled optimization, and object-centric architectures (MONet, IODINE, Slot
Attention), and highlight its novelty as the first semantic autoencoder to
implement an all-but-one residual update rule.

AI.tldr: Proposes Decomposer Networks (DecompNet), a semantic autoencoder with N parallel branches that factorizes an input into interpretable components using all-but-one residual updates via an unrolled Gauss-Seidel optimization.
AI.motivation: To obtain interpretable, multi-component representations beyond a single latent, bridging classical decomposition methods (PCA, NMF) with modern deep and object-centric architectures, and addressing competition and redundancy among latent factors.
AI.method: Maintain N parallel branches where each branch processes a residual equal to the original input minus reconstructions of the other branches. Unroll a Gauss-Seidel style block-coordinate descent into a differentiable network to enforce competition among components, situating the approach relative to PCA/NMF, deep unrolled optimization, and MONet/IODINE/Slot Attention; novelty claimed as the first semantic autoencoder with an all-but-one residual update rule.
AI.result: Yields parsimonious, semantically meaningful representations and demonstrates the integration of competitive, residual-based decomposition within a semantic autoencoding framework, positioning DecompNet among related linear and deep decomposition methods and object-centric architectures.
AI.conclusion: Introduces a novel semantic autoencoder design that uses all-but-one residual updates to factorize inputs into interpretable components, highlighting its novelty and potential to bridge classical factorization and contemporary object-centric modeling.

title: Scalable and Explainable Enterprise Knowledge Discovery Using Graph-Centric Hybrid Retrieval
summary:
Modern enterprises manage vast knowledge distributed across heterogeneous
systems such as Jira, Git repositories, Confluence, and wikis. Conventional
retrieval methods based on keyword search or static embeddings often fail to
answer complex queries that require contextual reasoning and multi-hop
inference across artifacts. We present a modular hybrid retrieval framework for
adaptive enterprise information access that integrates Knowledge Base
Language-Augmented Models (KBLam), DeepGraph representations, and
embedding-driven semantic search. The framework builds a unified knowledge
graph from parsed repositories including code, pull requests, and commit
histories, enabling semantic similarity search, structural inference, and
multi-hop reasoning. Query analysis dynamically determines the optimal
retrieval strategy, supporting both structured and unstructured data sources
through independent or fused processing. An interactive interface provides
graph visualizations, subgraph exploration, and context-aware query routing to
generate concise and explainable answers. Experiments on large-scale Git
repositories show that the unified reasoning layer improves answer relevance by
up to 80 percent compared with standalone GPT-based retrieval pipelines. By
combining graph construction, hybrid reasoning, and interactive visualization,
the proposed framework offers a scalable, explainable, and user-centric
foundation for intelligent knowledge assistants in enterprise environments.

AI.tldr: A modular hybrid retrieval framework that builds a unified knowledge graph from enterprise artifacts (code, PRs, commits) and uses adaptive, graph-based reasoning (KBLam, DeepGraph, embeddings) to enable multi-hop, explainable answers with interactive visualization; it outperforms standalone GPT-based pipelines by up to 80% in relevance on large Git repos.
AI.motivation: Enterprises store knowledge across heterogeneous systems (Jira, Git, Confluence, wikis). Traditional keyword search and static embeddings fail for complex, context-driven, multi-hop queries that require cross-artifact reasoning.
AI.method: Construct a unified knowledge graph from parsed repositories (code, pull requests, commit histories). Integrate Knowledge Base Language-Augmented Models (KBLam), DeepGraph representations, and embedding-driven semantic search. Use dynamic query analysis to select retrieval strategies (structured/unstructured data, independent or fused processing). Provide an interactive interface with graph visualizations, subgraph exploration, and context-aware query routing to produce concise, explainable answers.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on large-scale Git repositories shows the unified reasoning layer improves answer relevance by up to 80% compared with standalone GPT-based retrieval pipelines.
AI.conclusion: The framework offers a scalable, explainable, and user-centric foundation for intelligent enterprise knowledge assistants by combining graph construction, hybrid reasoning, and interactive visualization.

title: Refinery: Active Fine-tuning and Deployment-time Optimization for Contact-Rich Policies
comment:
in submission. 8 pages, 6 figures. Website:
  https://refinery-2025.github.io/refinery/
summary:
Simulation-based learning has enabled policies for precise, contact-rich
tasks (e.g., robotic assembly) to reach high success rates (~80%) under high
levels of observation noise and control error. Although such performance may be
sufficient for research applications, it falls short of industry standards and
makes policy chaining exceptionally brittle. A key limitation is the high
variance in individual policy performance across diverse initial conditions. We
introduce Refinery, an effective framework that bridges this performance gap,
robustifying policy performance across initial conditions. We propose Bayesian
Optimization-guided fine-tuning to improve individual policies, and Gaussian
Mixture Model-based sampling during deployment to select initializations that
maximize execution success. Using Refinery, we improve mean success rates by
10.98% over state-of-the-art methods in simulation-based learning for robotic
assembly, reaching 91.51% in simulation and comparable performance in the real
world. Furthermore, we demonstrate that these fine-tuned policies can be
chained to accomplish long-horizon, multi-part
assembly$\unicode{x2013}$successfully assembling up to 8 parts without
requiring explicit multi-step training.

AI.tldr: Refinery boosts robustness of policies in simulation-based robotic assembly by coordinating Bayesian Optimization-guided fine-tuning of individual policies with Gaussian Mixture Model-based initial-condition sampling at deployment, yielding a ~11 percentage-point improvement to 91.51% in simulation and enabling reliable chaining of up to 8 parts without extra training.
AI.motivation: Policy performance in simulation-based learning for contact-rich tasks is highly variable across initial conditions, hindering industry-grade reliability and long-horizon task chaining.
AI.method: 1) Bayesian Optimization-guided fine-tuning of each policy to improve performance under noise and control errors. 2) Gaussian Mixture Model-based sampling of initial conditions during deployment to select favorable initializations that maximize execution success. 3) Demonstration: chaining of fine-tuned policies to accomplish long-horizon assembly without explicit multi-step training.
AI.result: Mean success rate improved by 10.98% over state-of-the-art methods in simulation-based robotic assembly, reaching 91.51% in simulation. Real-world performance is comparable. The approach enables chaining of policies to assemble up to 8 parts without additional multi-step training.
AI.conclusion: Refinery effectively bridges the performance gap in simulation-based learning for robotic assembly by robustifying policy performance across initial conditions, enabling longer-horizon tasks and improved reliability suitable for industry standards.

title: Stroke Locus Net: Occluded Vessel Localization from MRI Modalities
comment:
This version of the paper was accepted in the ADMA 2025 conference in
  Kyoto, Japan
summary:
A key challenge in ischemic stroke diagnosis using medical imaging is the
accurate localization of the occluded vessel. Current machine learning methods
in focus primarily on lesion segmentation, with limited work on vessel
localization. In this study, we introduce Stroke Locus Net, an end-to-end deep
learning pipeline for detection, segmentation, and occluded vessel localization
using only MRI scans. The proposed system combines a segmentation branch using
nnUNet for lesion detection with an arterial atlas for vessel mapping and
identification, and a generation branch using pGAN to synthesize MRA images
from MRI. Our implementation demonstrates promising results in localizing
occluded vessels on stroke-affected T1 MRI scans, with potential for faster and
more informed stroke diagnosis.

AI.tldr: Stroke Locus Net proposes an end-to-end pipeline combining lesion segmentation and arterial atlas-based vessel localization with MRI-to-MRA synthesis to localize occluded vessels in ischemic stroke.
AI.motivation: Current ML approaches in ischemic stroke focus mainly on lesion segmentation, with limited work on accurate vessel localization; precise occluded-vessel localization could improve diagnostic speed and treatment planning.
AI.method: An end-to-end pipeline with (1) a segmentation branch using nnUNet for lesion detection, (2) an arterial atlas for vessel mapping/localization, and (3) a generation branch using pGAN to synthesize MR angiography from MRI, enabling simultaneous detection, segmentation, and occluded-vessel localization.
AI.result: The approach demonstrates promising capability to localize occluded vessels on stroke-affected T1 MRI scans, indicating potential for faster and more informed stroke diagnosis.
AI.conclusion: The study shows feasibility of integrating segmentation with atlas-based vessel localization and MRI-to-MRA synthesis to localize occluded vessels, suggesting a viable path toward clinically useful tools; further validation on larger datasets is needed.

title: An Exploration of Non-Euclidean Gradient Descent: Muon and its Many Variants
summary:
To define a steepest descent method over a neural network, we need to choose
a norm for each layer, a way to aggregate these norms across layers, and
whether to use normalization. We systematically explore different alternatives
for aggregating norms across layers, both formalizing existing combinations of
Adam and the recently proposed Muon as a type of non-Euclidean gradient
descent, and deriving new variants of the Muon optimizer. Through a
comprehensive experimental evaluation of the optimizers within our framework,
we find that Muon is sensitive to the choice of learning rate, whereas a new
variant we call MuonMax is significantly more robust. We then show how to
combine any non-Euclidean gradient method with model based momentum (known as
Momo). The new Momo variants of Muon are significantly more robust to
hyperparameter tuning, and often achieve a better validation score. Thus for
new tasks, where the optimal hyperparameters are not known, we advocate for
using Momo in combination with MuonMax to save on costly hyperparameter tuning.

AI.tldr: The paper surveys steepest-descent neural network optimization using layer-wise non-Euclidean norms, introduces Muon variants (including MuonMax), and combines them with model-based momentum (Momo); experiments show MuonMax is more robust to hyperparameters and combining with Momo yields robust, high-performing optimizers, recommended for new tasks.
AI.motivation: Define and compare non-Euclidean gradient strategies for neural networks by selecting per-layer norms, aggregation across layers, and normalization; extend existing optimizers (Adam, Muon) and develop more robust variants to reduce hyperparameter sensitivity.
AI.method: Systematically formalize layer-norm aggregations; derive new Muon variants including MuonMax; combine non-Euclidean gradient methods with Momo (model-based momentum); perform comprehensive experimental evaluation of these optimizers within a unified framework.
AI.result: Muon performance is sensitive to learning rate; MuonMax offers significantly better robustness; Momo-enhanced Muon variants show improved robustness to hyperparameters and often better validation scores.
AI.conclusion: For new tasks with unknown hyperparameters, use Momo with MuonMax to minimize tuning; the framework enables a spectrum of non-Euclidean gradient methods and robust variants.

title: Video-STR: Reinforcing MLLMs in Video Spatio-Temporal Reasoning with Relation Graph
summary:
Recent progress in Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) has demonstrated
strong semantic understanding capabilities, but struggles to perform precise
spatio-temporal understanding. Existing spatio-temporal methods primarily focus
on the video itself, while overlooking the physical information within the
video, such as multi-object layouts and motion. Such limitations restrict the
use of MLLMs in downstream applications that demand high precision, including
embodied intelligence and VR. To address this issue, we present Video-STR, a
novel graph-based reinforcement method for precise Video Spatio-Temporal
Reasoning. Building upon the capacity of Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable
Reward (RLVR) to improve model abilities, we introduce a reasoning mechanism
using graph-based Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) method to guide the
model in inferring the underlying spatio-temporal topology of scenarios during
the thinking process. To resolve the lack of spatio-temporal training data, we
construct the STV-205k dataset with 205k question-answering pairs, covering
dynamic multi-object scenes in both indoor and outdoor environments, to support
the model training. Experiments show that Video-STR achieves state-of-the-art
results on various benchmarks, outperforming the base model by 13% on
STI-Bench, and demonstrating the effectiveness of our approach and dataset.
Code, model, and data will be released.

AI.tldr: Video-STR introduces a graph-based reinforcement approach for precise video spatio-temporal reasoning, leveraging RLVR with Graph-based Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) and a new STV-205k dataset. It achieves state-of-the-art results on STI-Bench (≈13% improvement) and promises released code, model, and data.
AI.motivation: Existing multimodal large language models excel at semantic understanding but struggle with precise spatio-temporal reasoning. They often ignore physical video information (object layouts, motion), limiting use in high-precision tasks like embodied intelligence and VR. There is a need for methods that infer the underlying spatio-temporal topology of scenes.
AI.method: Proposes Video-STR, a graph-based reinforcement framework using RLVR (Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Reward) and a Graph-based Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) to guide the model in inferring spatio-temporal topology during reasoning. Addresses data scarcity by constructing STV-205k, a 205k-question dataset covering dynamic multi-object scenes in indoor and outdoor environments.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance on STI-Bench, outperforming the base model by 13% on STI-Bench. Demonstrates effectiveness of the GRPO+RLVR approach and the STV-205k dataset.
AI.conclusion: Video-STR effectively enhances precise video spatio-temporal reasoning in MLLMs. The combination of graph-based policy optimization and a large, diverse training dataset enables substantial performance gains and supports future research with released code, model, and data.

title: XGrasp: Gripper-Aware Grasp Detection with Multi-Gripper Data Generation
summary:
Most robotic grasping methods are typically designed for single gripper
types, which limits their applicability in real-world scenarios requiring
diverse end-effectors. We propose XGrasp, a real-time gripper-aware grasp
detection framework that efficiently handles multiple gripper configurations.
The proposed method addresses data scarcity by systematically augmenting
existing datasets with multi-gripper annotations. XGrasp employs a hierarchical
two-stage architecture. In the first stage, a Grasp Point Predictor (GPP)
identifies optimal locations using global scene information and gripper
specifications. In the second stage, an Angle-Width Predictor (AWP) refines the
grasp angle and width using local features. Contrastive learning in the AWP
module enables zero-shot generalization to unseen grippers by learning
fundamental grasping characteristics. The modular framework integrates
seamlessly with vision foundation models, providing pathways for future
vision-language capabilities. The experimental results demonstrate competitive
grasp success rates across various gripper types, while achieving substantial
improvements in inference speed compared to existing gripper-aware methods.
Project page: https://sites.google.com/view/xgrasp

AI.tldr: XGrasp is a real-time, gripper-aware grasp detection framework that supports multiple gripper configurations through a hierarchical two-stage design, dataset augmentation, and contrastive learning for zero-shot generalization to unseen grippers, achieving faster inference and competitive grasp success across grippers.
AI.motivation: The field often optimizes grasping for a single gripper type, limiting applicability in real-world tasks requiring diverse end-effectors. Data scarcity for multi-gripper scenarios further hinders progress. A real-time, gripper-agnostic approach with fast inference and generalization is needed.
AI.method: A two-stage architecture: (1) Grasp Point Predictor (GPP) uses global scene context and gripper specifications to propose grasp points; (2) Angle-Width Predictor (AWP) refines grasp angle and width using local features. Contrastive learning in AWP enables zero-shot generalization to unseen grippers. The approach augments existing datasets with multi-gripper annotations, and integrates with vision foundation models to enable future vision-language capabilities.
AI.result: Experimental results show competitive grasp success rates across multiple gripper types and substantial improvements in inference speed compared to existing gripper-aware methods.
AI.conclusion: XGrasp offers a real-time, versatile grasp detection framework capable of handling diverse gripper configurations, with data augmentation to address scarcity, and a contrastive-learning-based path to zero-shot gripper generalization, plus integration potential with vision-language foundations.

title: ReMix: Towards a Unified View of Consistent Character Generation and Editing
summary:
Recent advances in large-scale text-to-image diffusion models (e.g., FLUX.1)
have greatly improved visual fidelity in consistent character generation and
editing. However, existing methods rarely unify these tasks within a single
framework. Generation-based approaches struggle with fine-grained identity
consistency across instances, while editing-based methods often lose spatial
controllability and instruction alignment. To bridge this gap, we propose
ReMix, a unified framework for character-consistent generation and editing. It
constitutes two core components: the ReMix Module and IP-ControlNet. The ReMix
Module leverages the multimodal reasoning ability of MLLMs to edit semantic
features of input images and adapt instruction embeddings to the native DiT
backbone without fine-tuning. While this ensures coherent semantic layouts,
pixel-level consistency and pose controllability remain challenging. To address
this, IP-ControlNet extends ControlNet to decouple semantic and layout cues
from reference images and introduces an {\epsilon}-equivariant latent space
that jointly denoises the reference and target images within a shared noise
space. Inspired by convergent evolution and quantum decoherence,i.e., where
environmental noise drives state convergence, this design promotes feature
alignment in the hidden space, enabling consistent object generation while
preserving identity. ReMix supports a wide range of tasks, including
personalized generation, image editing, style transfer, and multi-condition
synthesis. Extensive experiments validate its effectiveness and efficiency as a
unified framework for character-consistent image generation and editing.

AI.tldr: ReMix is a unified diffusion-based framework for character-consistent generation and editing, built from a ReMix Module and IP-ControlNet that align semantics and layout without fine-tuning.
AI.motivation: Generation and editing methods are largely separate and struggle to consistently preserve identity while maintaining spatial control. A single framework is needed to unify tasks like personalized generation, editing, style transfer, and multi-condition synthesis.
AI.method: Two core components: (1) ReMix Module, which uses multimodal LLMs to edit semantic features of input images and adapt instruction embeddings to the DiT backbone without fine-tuning; (2) IP-ControlNet, an extension of ControlNet that decouples semantic and layout cues from reference images and introduces an epsilon-equivariant latent space to jointly denoise reference and target images in a shared noise space, promoting hidden-space feature alignment.
AI.result: Extensive experiments validate the framework’s effectiveness and efficiency across a range of tasks (personalized generation, editing, style transfer, multi-condition synthesis) with improved identity consistency and spatial control.
AI.conclusion: ReMix provides a cohesive, scalable approach to character-consistent image generation and editing, bridging the gap between generation and editing within a single framework and enabling versatile tasks without heavy fine-tuning.

title: Harnessing Self-Supervised Deep Learning and Geostationary Remote Sensing for Advancing Wildfire and Associated Air Quality Monitoring: Improved Smoke and Fire Front Masking using GOES and TEMPO Radiance Data
summary:
This work demonstrates the possibilities for improving wildfire and air
quality management in the western United States by leveraging the unprecedented
hourly data from NASA's TEMPO satellite mission and advances in self-supervised
deep learning. Here we demonstrate the efficacy of deep learning for mapping
the near real-time hourly spread of wildfire fronts and smoke plumes using an
innovative self-supervised deep learning-system: successfully distinguishing
smoke plumes from clouds using GOES-18 and TEMPO data, strong agreement across
the smoke and fire masks generated from different sensing modalities as well as
significant improvement over operational products for the same cases.

AI.tldr: Self-supervised deep learning with TEMPO and GOES-18 enables near real-time mapping of hourly wildfire fronts and smoke plumes, distinguishing smoke from clouds with cross-sensor agreement and outperforming existing operational products.
AI.motivation: To exploit TEMPO's unprecedented hourly data to improve wildfire and air quality management in the western United States by advancing real-time plume/fires mapping.
AI.method: An innovative self-supervised deep learning system trained on multi-sensor data (TEMPO and GOES-18) to generate near real-time masks for wildfire fronts and smoke plumes, including discrimination between smoke plumes and clouds.
AI.result: The approach yields strong agreement between masks across sensing modalities and shows significant improvement over current operational products for the studied cases, enabling higher-fidelity, hourly mapping of fires and smoke.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates a viable path to enhanced wildfire and air quality management through hourly TEMPO data and self-supervised learning, with potential for real-time decision support.

title: Revisiting Model Interpolation for Efficient Reasoning
comment: 14 pages, 6 figures, 7 tables. Working in progress
summary:
Model merging, typically on Instruct and Thinking models, has shown
remarkable performance for efficient reasoning. In this paper, we
systematically revisit the simplest merging method that interpolates two
weights directly. Particularly, we observe that model interpolation follows a
three-stage evolutionary paradigm with distinct behaviors on the reasoning
trajectory. These dynamics provide a principled guide for navigating the
performance-cost trade-off. Empirical results demonstrate that a strategically
interpolated model surprisingly surpasses sophisticated model merging baselines
on both efficiency and effectiveness. We further validate our findings with
extensive ablation studies on model layers, modules, and decoding strategies.
Ultimately, this work demystifies model interpolation and offers a practical
framework for crafting models with precisely targeted reasoning capabilities.
Code is available at \href{https://github.com/wutaiqiang/MI}{Github}.

AI.tldr: A simple weight interpolation method for merging instruction/Thinking models reveals a three-stage evolution in the reasoning trajectory, offering favorable efficiency–performance trade-offs and even surpassing complex merging baselines; validated by extensive ablations and decoding studies with a practical framework and public code.
AI.motivation: To understand whether a straightforward weight interpolation can rival or exceed sophisticated model-merging approaches, and to reveal the dynamics of how interpolation affects reasoning capabilities and resource costs, enabling targeted improvements.
AI.method: Direct interpolation of two pretrained model weights, followed by analysis of its reasoning trajectory divided into three stages. Systematic ablations across layers, modules, and decoding strategies, and comparisons against advanced merging baselines to assess performance and efficiency. Codebase available for replication.
AI.result: A strategically interpolated model can outperform sophisticated merging baselines in both efficiency and effectiveness. The three-stage dynamics guide how to balance performance and cost. Ablation results show robustness across layers, modules, and decoding settings, supporting a practical framework for targeted reasoning capabilities.
AI.conclusion: Model interpolation emerges as a demystified, practical tool for engineering models with precisely targeted reasoning abilities. The work provides actionable guidance and a framework for tailoring reasoning capabilities via simple interpolation, with empirical support and accessible code.

title: Unveiling Uncertainty-Aware Autonomous Cooperative Learning Based Planning Strategy
summary:
In future intelligent transportation systems, autonomous cooperative planning
(ACP), becomes a promising technique to increase the effectiveness and security
of multi-vehicle interactions. However, multiple uncertainties cannot be fully
addressed for existing ACP strategies, e.g. perception, planning, and
communication uncertainties. To address these, a novel deep reinforcement
learning-based autonomous cooperative planning (DRLACP) framework is proposed
to tackle various uncertainties on cooperative motion planning schemes.
Specifically, the soft actor-critic (SAC) with the implementation of gate
recurrent units (GRUs) is adopted to learn the deterministic optimal
time-varying actions with imperfect state information occurred by planning,
communication, and perception uncertainties. In addition, the real-time actions
of autonomous vehicles (AVs) are demonstrated via the Car Learning to Act
(CARLA) simulation platform. Evaluation results show that the proposed DRLACP
learns and performs cooperative planning effectively, which outperforms other
baseline methods under different scenarios with imperfect AV state information.

AI.tldr: A DRL-based autonomous cooperative planning framework using SAC with GRUs to handle perception, planning, and communication uncertainties in multi-vehicle coordination; demonstrated in CARLA and outperforming baselines.
AI.motivation: Address multiple uncertainties (perception, planning, communication) that hinder cooperative motion planning in autonomous vehicle networks, aiming to improve safety and efficiency.
AI.method: Propose DRLACP using Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) augmented with Gate Recurrent Units (GRUs) to learn robust time-varying actions under imperfect state information caused by uncertainties in planning, communication, and perception.
AI.result: DRLACP successfully learns cooperative planning policies and outperforms baseline methods across scenarios with imperfect AV state information in CARLA simulations.
AI.conclusion: DRLACP is an effective framework for coping with uncertainty in autonomous cooperative planning, enabling real-time, robust multi-vehicle coordination demonstrated in CARLA; suggests potential for improving ITS safety and performance.

title: SaFiRe: Saccade-Fixation Reiteration with Mamba for Referring Image Segmentation
summary:
Referring Image Segmentation (RIS) aims to segment the target object in an
image given a natural language expression. While recent methods leverage
pre-trained vision backbones and more training corpus to achieve impressive
results, they predominantly focus on simple expressions--short, clear noun
phrases like "red car" or "left girl". This simplification often reduces RIS to
a key word/concept matching problem, limiting the model's ability to handle
referential ambiguity in expressions. In this work, we identify two challenging
real-world scenarios: object-distracting expressions, which involve multiple
entities with contextual cues, and category-implicit expressions, where the
object class is not explicitly stated. To address the challenges, we propose a
novel framework, SaFiRe, which mimics the human two-phase cognitive
process--first forming a global understanding, then refining it through
detail-oriented inspection. This is naturally supported by Mamba's
scan-then-update property, which aligns with our phased design and enables
efficient multi-cycle refinement with linear complexity. We further introduce
aRefCOCO, a new benchmark designed to evaluate RIS models under ambiguous
referring expressions. Extensive experiments on both standard and proposed
datasets demonstrate the superiority of SaFiRe over state-of-the-art baselines.

AI.tldr: SaFiRe introduces a two-phase RIS framework inspired by human cognition and Mamba's scan-update property to handle ambiguous referring expressions, plus a new aRefCOCO benchmark; it achieves state-of-the-art performance with linear-time multi-cycle refinement.
AI.motivation: RIS models struggle with referential ambiguity due to expressions containing multiple entities or implicit categories. Existing methods over-rely on keyword matching of simple phrases, limiting robustness. The paper aims to enable global understanding before detailed refinement and to evaluate these scenarios with a dedicated benchmark.
AI.method: Two-phase SaFiRe framework: (1) global understanding from the expression and image; (2) iterative, detail-oriented refinement guided by a scan-update mechanism (Mamba) that allows multiple refinement cycles with linear complexity. Also introduces aRefCOCO benchmark to test RIS under ambiguous referring expressions.
AI.result: Empirical results on standard RIS benchmarks and the proposed aRefCOCO dataset show SaFiRe outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, particularly in object-distracting and category-implicit scenarios.
AI.conclusion: A two-phase cognitive-inspired RIS approach with an efficient scan-update refinement and a dedicated ambiguous-expression benchmark effectively addresses referential ambiguity, marking a promising direction for robust RIS in realistic settings.

title: CALM: A Causal Analysis Language Model for Tabular Data in Complex Systems with Local Scores, Conditional Independence Tests, and Relation Attributes
summary:
Causal discovery from observational data is fundamental to scientific fields
like biology, where controlled experiments are often impractical. However,
existing methods, including constraint-based (e.g., PC, causalMGM) and
score-based approaches (e.g., NOTEARS), face significant limitations. These
include an inability to resolve causal direction, restrictions to linear
associations, sensitivity to violations of the faithfulness assumption, and
inefficiency in searching vast hypothesis spaces. While large language models
(LLMs) offer powerful reasoning capabilities, their application is hindered by
a fundamental discrepancy: they are designed for text, while most causal data
is tabular. To address these challenges, we introduce CALM, a novel causal
analysis language model specifically designed for tabular data in complex
systems. CALM leverages a Mamba-based architecture to classify causal patterns
from pairwise variable relationships. It integrates a comprehensive suite of
evidence, including local causal scores, conditional independence tests, and
relational attributes, to capture a wide spectrum of linear, nonlinear, and
conditional causal mechanisms. Trained on a diverse corpus of synthetic data
(from linear, mixed, and nonlinear models) and 10 real-world biological
datasets with rigorously validated causal relationships, our model ensures
robustness and generalizability. Empirical evaluation demonstrates that CALM
significantly outperforms existing methods in both simulation studies,
achieving over 91% accuracy, and in a real-world application identifying causal
factors in Hepatitis C virus progression. This work represents a significant
step towards accurate and generalizable causal discovery by successfully
adapting the pattern recognition capabilities of language models to the
intricacies of tabular data.

AI.tldr: CALM is a tabular-data causal discovery model using a Mamba-based architecture that classifies causal patterns from pairwise relationships, achieving 91%+ accuracy in simulations and successfully identifying causal factors in Hepatitis C progression, outperforming PC, causalMGM, and NOTEARS.
AI.motivation: Causal discovery from observational tabular data is essential in biology and other fields where controlled experiments are impractical. Existing constraint-based and score-based methods struggle with directionality, linearity assumptions, faithfulness violations, and computational efficiency. LLMs excel at pattern recognition but are ill-suited for tabular causal data, necessitating a specialized model.
AI.method: Introduce CALM, a causal analysis language model for tabular data with a Mamba-based architecture that classifies causal patterns from pairwise variable relationships. It fuses local causal scores, conditional independence tests, and relational attributes to capture linear, nonlinear, and conditional causality. Training combines synthetic data spans (linear, mixed, nonlinear) and 10 real-world biological datasets with rigorously validated causal relationships. The model is evaluated on simulations and a real-world Hepatitis C progression application.
AI.result: CALM significantly outperforms existing methods in simulations, reaching over 91% accuracy, and demonstrates practical utility by identifying causal factors in Hepatitis C virus progression.
AI.conclusion: This work demonstrates that adapting language-model-style pattern recognition to tabular data enables accurate and generalizable causal discovery, marking a key step toward robust causal analysis in complex systems.

title: FBS Model-based Maintenance Record Accumulation for Failure-Cause Inference in Manufacturing Systems
summary:
In manufacturing systems, identifying the causes of failures is crucial for
maintaining and improving production efficiency. In knowledge-based
failure-cause inference, it is important that the knowledge base (1) explicitly
structures knowledge about the target system and about failures, and (2)
contains sufficiently long causal chains of failures. In this study, we
constructed Diagnostic Knowledge Ontology and proposed a
Function-Behavior-Structure (FBS) model-based maintenance-record accumulation
method based on it. Failure-cause inference using the maintenance records
accumulated by the proposed method showed better agreement with the set of
candidate causes enumerated by experts, especially in difficult cases where the
number of related cases is small and the vocabulary used differs. In the
future, it will be necessary to develop inference methods tailored to these
maintenance records, build a user interface, and carry out validation on larger
and more diverse systems. Additionally, this approach leverages the
understanding and knowledge of the target in the design phase to support
knowledge accumulation and problem solving during the maintenance phase, and it
is expected to become a foundation for knowledge sharing across the entire
engineering chain in the future.

AI.tldr: Developed Diagnostic Knowledge Ontology and FBS-based maintenance-record accumulation to improve failure-cause inference in manufacturing. It achieves better agreement with expert-candidate causes, especially in data-scarce or vocabulary-divergent cases, with plans for UI and broader validation.
AI.motivation: To enhance knowledge-based failure-cause inference by explicitly structuring knowledge about the target system and failures and by building long causal failure chains through maintenance records, enabling knowledge sharing across the engineering chain.
AI.method: Construct a Diagnostic Knowledge Ontology and propose a Function-Behavior-Structure (FBS) model-based maintenance-record accumulation method; apply the method to infer failure causes from accumulated maintenance records; evaluate against expert-identified candidate causes, noting improvements in difficult cases.
AI.result: Failure-cause inferences using the proposed maintenance records show better agreement with expert-candidate causes, particularly when the number of related cases is small and vocabulary differs.
AI.conclusion: The approach leverages design-phase knowledge to support maintenance-phase knowledge accumulation and problem solving, laying a foundation for knowledge sharing across the engineering chain; future work includes tailored inference methods for maintenance records, a user interface, and validation on larger/diverse systems.

title: PhysHSI: Towards a Real-World Generalizable and Natural Humanoid-Scene Interaction System
summary:
Deploying humanoid robots to interact with real-world environments--such as
carrying objects or sitting on chairs--requires generalizable, lifelike motions
and robust scene perception. Although prior approaches have advanced each
capability individually, combining them in a unified system is still an ongoing
challenge. In this work, we present a physical-world humanoid-scene interaction
system, PhysHSI, that enables humanoids to autonomously perform diverse
interaction tasks while maintaining natural and lifelike behaviors. PhysHSI
comprises a simulation training pipeline and a real-world deployment system. In
simulation, we adopt adversarial motion prior-based policy learning to imitate
natural humanoid-scene interaction data across diverse scenarios, achieving
both generalization and lifelike behaviors. For real-world deployment, we
introduce a coarse-to-fine object localization module that combines LiDAR and
camera inputs to provide continuous and robust scene perception. We validate
PhysHSI on four representative interactive tasks--box carrying, sitting, lying,
and standing up--in both simulation and real-world settings, demonstrating
consistently high success rates, strong generalization across diverse task
goals, and natural motion patterns.

AI.tldr: A unified physical-world humanoid-scene interaction system (PhysHSI) combines adversarial motion-prior policy learning in simulation with a LiDAR-camera perception module for real-world deployment, enabling lifelike, generalizable behaviors across tasks like box carrying, sitting, lying, and standing.
AI.motivation: Bridge the gap between perception and manipulation for humanoid robots in real-world environments. Prior work often tackled perception and motion separately or lacked real-world robustness and lifelike motion; there is a need for an end-to-end system that can generalize to diverse tasks and environments.
AI.method: In simulation, use adversarial motion-prior-based policy learning to imitate natural humanoid-scene interactions across varied scenarios, achieving generalization and lifelike motion. For real-world deployment, implement a coarse-to-fine object localization module that fuses LiDAR and camera inputs to provide continuous, robust scene perception. Validate on four tasks (box carrying, sitting, lying, standing up) in both simulation and real world.
AI.result: PhysHSI achieves consistently high success rates and strong generalization across diverse task goals, with natural, lifelike motion patterns demonstrated in both simulation and real-world settings.
AI.conclusion: The proposed PhysHSI system enables autonomous humanoid-scene interactions with lifelike behavior and robust perception, addressing the integration challenge of perception and manipulation for real-world humanoid robotics.

title: SparseUWSeg: Active Sparse Point-Label Augmentation for Underwater Semantic Segmentation
summary:
Semantic segmentation is essential to automate underwater imagery analysis
with ecology monitoring purposes. Unfortunately, fine grained underwater scene
analysis is still an open problem even for top performing segmentation models.
The high cost of obtaining dense, expert-annotated, segmentation labels hinders
the supervision of models in this domain. While sparse point-labels are easier
to obtain, they introduce challenges regarding which points to annotate and how
to propagate the sparse information. We present SparseUWSeg, a novel framework
that addresses both issues. SparseUWSeg employs an active sampling strategy to
guide annotators, maximizing the value of their point labels. Then, it
propagates these sparse labels with a hybrid approach leverages both the best
of SAM2 and superpixel-based methods. Experiments on two diverse underwater
datasets demonstrate the benefits of SparseUWSeg over state-of-the-art
approaches, achieving up to +5\% mIoU over D+NN. Our main contribution is the
design and release of a simple but effective interactive annotation tool,
integrating our algorithms. It enables ecology researchers to leverage
foundation models and computer vision to efficiently generate high-quality
segmentation masks to process their data.

AI.tldr: A framework called SparseUWSeg uses active sampling to select sparse points for annotation and a hybrid label-propagation strategy (SAM2 + superpixels) to produce dense underwater segmentation masks, aimed at efficient ecology monitoring.
AI.motivation: Dense, expert-annotated segmentation labels are expensive in underwater imagery. Sparse point-labels are easier but require effective annotation guidance and propagation. The work aims to maximize information gain from sparse labels and convert them into high-quality masks for ecological analysis.
AI.method: An active sampling strategy selects informative annotation points for experts. Sparse labels are then propagated via a hybrid method that combines SAM2-based segmentation with superpixel-based propagation.
AI.result: On two diverse underwater datasets, SparseUWSeg achieves up to +5 percentage points mIoU over D+NN, outperforming state-of-the-art. An interactive annotation tool is released to help researchers generate segmentation masks efficiently.
AI.conclusion: The proposed simple yet effective pipeline demonstrates that well-chosen sparse labels, guided by active sampling and combined propagation, can yield competitive segmentation quality while enabling practical, tool-assisted annotation for ecology researchers.

title: ProxRouter: Proximity-Weighted LLM Query Routing for Improved Robustness to Outliers
summary:
Large language model (LLM) query routers are critical to modern AI platforms
as they seek to improve efficiency by assigning inference queries to accurate,
yet low-cost models. Parametric routers typically use trained neural networks
for LLM selection but suffer from retraining and maintenance overheads.
Nonparametric routers are training-free, instead estimating LLM accuracy and
cost via similarity between encodings of the input query and training set
queries. However, like their parametric counterparts, nonparametric routers
struggle to generalize to outlier queries, an issue exacerbated by limited
diversity in training sets which are costly to expand and difficult to keep
current with ever-evolving use cases. We propose ProxRouter, which applies an
exponentially tilted aggregation mechanism to balance bias and variance in
nonparametric routers, improving their robustness to outliers. Experiments show
ProxRouter enhances outlier routing while preserving inlier performance with
minimal overhead.

AI.tldr: ProxRouter uses exponentially tilted aggregation to make nonparametric LLM routers more robust to outliers, improving outlier routing with minimal overhead while preserving inlier performance.
AI.motivation: Nonparametric routers are training-free and estimate LLM accuracy and cost via similarity to training queries, but they struggle to generalize to outlier queries. Limited training diversity makes expansion costly and keeps pace with evolving use cases. A method that improves robustness without retraining is needed.
AI.method: Introduce an exponentially tilted aggregation mechanism over the similarity-based estimates used by nonparametric routers. This tilting adjusts the influence of neighboring training queries to balance bias and variance, thereby reducing sensitivity to outliers. Integrate the tilted aggregation into the routing decision process and evaluate against standard baselines.
AI.result: ProxRouter enhances outlier routing performance while maintaining inlier performance, with minimal computational overhead compared to baseline nonparametric routers.
AI.conclusion: An efficient, training-free enhancement for nonparametric LLM routers, ProxRouter reduces vulnerability to outliers and can seamlessly replace or augment existing routing strategies in dynamic AI platforms.

title: Argumentation-Based Explainability for Legal AI: Comparative and Regulatory Perspectives
summary:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) systems are increasingly deployed in legal
contexts, where their opacity raises significant challenges for fairness,
accountability, and trust. The so-called ``black box problem'' undermines the
legitimacy of automated decision-making, as affected individuals often lack
access to meaningful explanations. In response, the field of Explainable AI
(XAI) has proposed a variety of methods to enhance transparency, ranging from
example-based and rule-based techniques to hybrid and argumentation-based
approaches. This paper promotes computational models of arguments and their
role in providing legally relevant explanations, with particular attention to
their alignment with emerging regulatory frameworks such as the EU General Data
Protection Regulation (GDPR) and the Artificial Intelligence Act (AIA). We
analyze the strengths and limitations of different explanation strategies,
evaluate their applicability to legal reasoning, and highlight how
argumentation frameworks -- by capturing the defeasible, contestable, and
value-sensitive nature of law -- offer a particularly robust foundation for
explainable legal AI. Finally, we identify open challenges and research
directions, including bias mitigation, empirical validation in judicial
settings, and compliance with evolving ethical and legal standards, arguing
that computational argumentation is best positioned to meet both technical and
normative requirements of transparency in the law domain.

AI.tldr: Computational argumentation provides a robust framework for explainable legal AI, aligning with GDPR/AIA; it foregrounds defeasible, contestable, and value-sensitive aspects of law, but requires work on bias, empirical validation, and regulatory alignment.
AI.motivation: Legal AI systems are increasingly deployed but remain opaque, undermining fairness, accountability, and trust. The paper argues for explanations that meet legal and normative requirements under GDPR and the AI Act.
AI.method: Review and compare explanation strategies (example-based, rule-based, hybrid, and argumentation-based). Analyze their applicability to legal reasoning and regulatory compliance; advocate for computational argumentation as a foundation for explainable legal AI; outline strengths, limitations, and open challenges.
AI.result: Argues that argumentation frameworks capture the defeasible, contestable, and value-sensitive nature of law and thus offer a robust basis for explainable legal AI. Provides a critical evaluation of explanation strategies, and highlights open challenges such as bias mitigation, empirical validation in judicial settings, and regulatory compliance.
AI.conclusion: Computational argumentation is well positioned to meet both technical and normative transparency requirements in law; calls for ongoing research on bias mitigation, empirical validation, and alignment with evolving ethical and legal standards.

title: Flow Matching-Based Autonomous Driving Planning with Advanced Interactive Behavior Modeling
summary:
Modeling interactive driving behaviors in complex scenarios remains a
fundamental challenge for autonomous driving planning. Learning-based
approaches attempt to address this challenge with advanced generative models,
removing the dependency on over-engineered architectures for representation
fusion. However, brute-force implementation by simply stacking transformer
blocks lacks a dedicated mechanism for modeling interactive behaviors that are
common in real driving scenarios. The scarcity of interactive driving data
further exacerbates this problem, leaving conventional imitation learning
methods ill-equipped to capture high-value interactive behaviors. We propose
Flow Planner, which tackles these problems through coordinated innovations in
data modeling, model architecture, and learning scheme. Specifically, we first
introduce fine-grained trajectory tokenization, which decomposes the trajectory
into overlapping segments to decrease the complexity of whole trajectory
modeling. With a sophisticatedly designed architecture, we achieve efficient
temporal and spatial fusion of planning and scene information, to better
capture interactive behaviors. In addition, the framework incorporates flow
matching with classifier-free guidance for multi-modal behavior generation,
which dynamically reweights agent interactions during inference to maintain
coherent response strategies, providing a critical boost for interactive
scenario understanding. Experimental results on the large-scale nuPlan dataset
and challenging interactive interPlan dataset demonstrate that Flow Planner
achieves state-of-the-art performance among learning-based approaches while
effectively modeling interactive behaviors in complex driving scenarios.

AI.tldr: Flow Planner introduces fine-grained trajectory tokenization, a fusion-focused architecture, and flow-matched, classifier-free guided multi-modal generation to model interactive driving; it achieves state-of-the-art results on nuPlan and interPlan datasets.
AI.motivation: Modeling interactive driving behaviors is hard due to data scarcity and the ineffectiveness of naive transformer stacking for interactions; existing imitation learning struggles with high-value interactive dynamics.
AI.method: 1) Fine-grained trajectory tokenization with overlapping segments to reduce modeling complexity. 2) Architecture enabling efficient temporal and spatial fusion of planning and scene information to capture interactions. 3) Flow matching with classifier-free guidance to generate multi-modal behaviors and dynamically reweight agent interactions during inference.
AI.result: On nuPlan and interPlan datasets, Flow Planner achieves state-of-the-art performance among learning-based approaches and better models interactive behaviors in complex scenarios.
AI.conclusion: Flow Planner effectively addresses interactive driving modeling by combining data modeling, architecture, and learning scheme; demonstrates strong interactive behavior modeling and planning performance in realistic driving tasks.

title: ViConEx-Med: Visual Concept Explainability via Multi-Concept Token Transformer for Medical Image Analysis
comment: This work has been submitted to the IEEE for possible publication
summary:
Concept-based models aim to explain model decisions with human-understandable
concepts. However, most existing approaches treat concepts as numerical
attributes, without providing complementary visual explanations that could
localize the predicted concepts. This limits their utility in real-world
applications and particularly in high-stakes scenarios, such as medical
use-cases. This paper proposes ViConEx-Med, a novel transformer-based framework
for visual concept explainability, which introduces multi-concept learnable
tokens to jointly predict and localize visual concepts. By leveraging
specialized attention layers for processing visual and text-based concept
tokens, our method produces concept-level localization maps while maintaining
high predictive accuracy. Experiments on both synthetic and real-world medical
datasets demonstrate that ViConEx-Med outperforms prior concept-based models
and achieves competitive performance with black-box models in terms of both
concept detection and localization precision. Our results suggest a promising
direction for building inherently interpretable models grounded in visual
concepts. Code is publicly available at
https://github.com/CristianoPatricio/viconex-med.

AI.tldr: ViConEx-Med is a transformer-based framework that jointly predicts and localizes visual concepts using multi-concept learnable tokens and specialized attention, achieving improved concept detection and localization, with performance competitive to black-box models in medical datasets.
AI.motivation: Existing concept-based explanations treat concepts as numerical attributes and lack complementary visual localization, limiting interpretability and usefulness in high-stakes domains like medicine. There is a need for models that provide both concept-level predictions and spatial localization maps.
AI.method: Propose ViConEx-Med, a transformer-based framework with multi-concept learnable tokens and specialized attention layers to process visual and text-based concept tokens. The model jointly predicts concepts and generates concept-level localization maps without sacrificing predictive accuracy.
AI.result: Experiments on synthetic and real-world medical datasets show ViConEx-Med outperforms prior concept-based models and achieves competitive performance with black-box models in both concept detection and localization precision.
AI.conclusion: ViConEx-Med demonstrates a promising direction for inherently interpretable models grounded in visual concepts and provides a publicly available implementation.

title: WARC-Bench: Web Archive Based Benchmark for GUI Subtask Executions
summary:
Training web agents to navigate complex, real-world websites requires them to
master $\textit{subtasks}$ - short-horizon interactions on multiple UI
components (e.g., choosing the correct date in a date picker, or scrolling in a
container to extract information). We introduce WARC-Bench (Web Archive
Benchmark), a novel web navigation benchmark featuring 438 tasks designed to
evaluate multimodal AI agents on subtasks. WARC-Bench enables sandboxed
interactions with dynamic and realistic webpages using Web ARChive files. We
show that WARC-Bench is challenging for leading computer-use models, with the
highest observed success rate being 64.8%. To improve open source models on
subtask, we explore two common training techniques: supervised fine-tuning
(SFT) and reinforcement learning with verifiable rewards (RLVR). Experiments
show that SFT models obtain a 48.8% success rate on the benchmark. Training
with RLVR over SFT checkpoints, even in data-scarce settings, improves the
score to 52.8% on WARC-Bench, outperforming many frontier models. Our analysis
concludes that mastering these subtasks is essential for robust web planning
and navigation, and is a capability not extensively evaluated by existing
benchmarks.

AI.tldr: Introduces WARC-Bench, a 438-task web navigation benchmark using Web ARChive to evaluate subtasks; finds current models struggle on subtasks, with top models reaching up to 64.8% success, while supervised fine-tuning (SFT) improves to 48.8% and reinforcement learning with verifiable rewards (RLVR) over SFT pushes to 52.8%, outperforming many frontier models.
AI.motivation: To study short-horizon subtasks within web navigation and provide a sandboxed, realistic benchmark that existing benchmarks under-evaluate. The goal is to measure multimodal agents' ability to perform UI interactions (e.g., date pickers, scrolling) on dynamic webpages.
AI.method: Create WARC-Bench with 438 tasks that enable sandboxed interactions on dynamic webpages using Web ARChive files. Evaluate multimodal agents. Compare training approaches: supervised fine-tuning (SFT) and reinforcement learning with verifiable rewards (RLVR). Assess performance under data-scarce conditions and benchmark against frontier models.
AI.result: WARC-Bench proves challenging for leading models; the highest observed success rate is 64.8% on some tasks. SFT models achieve 48.8% on the benchmark. Applying RLVR on top of SFT checkpoints yields 52.8% accuracy, outperforming many frontier models, even with limited data.
AI.conclusion: Mastering subtasks is essential for robust web planning and navigation and constitutes a capability not extensively evaluated by existing benchmarks. WARC-Bench provides a focused, realistic platform to study and improve this competence.

title: Modeling AI-Driven Production and Competitiveness A Multi-Agent Economic Simulation of China and the United States
summary:
With the rapid development of artificial intelligence (AI) technology,
socio-economic systems are entering a new stage of "human-AI co-creation."
Building upon a previously established multi-level intelligent agent economic
model, this paper conducts simulation-based comparisons of macroeconomic output
evolution in China and the United States under different mechanisms-AI
collaboration, network effects, and AI autonomous production. The results show
that: (1) when AI functions as an independent productive entity, the overall
growth rate of social output far exceeds that of traditional human-labor-based
models; (2) China demonstrates clear potential for acceleration in both the
expansion of intelligent agent populations and the pace of technological
catch-up, offering the possibility of achieving technological convergence or
even partial surpassing. This study provides a systematic, model-based
analytical framework for understanding AI-driven production system
transformation and shifts in international competitiveness, as well as
quantitative insights for relevant policy formulation.

AI.tldr: AI-driven production with autonomous agents can substantially raise macro output, with China showing potential for faster tech catch-up; the paper offers a model-based framework and policy insights.
AI.motivation: Quantify macroeconomic effects of AI-driven production and human–AI co-creation, and compare China and the US under various AI mechanisms to inform policy design.
AI.method: Simulation-based analysis using a pre-existing multi-level intelligent agent economic model; scenarios compare AI collaboration, network effects, and AI autonomous production.
AI.result: (1) If AI acts as an independent productive entity, total social output growth outpaces traditional labor-based models; (2) China shows clear potential for accelerated growth in intelligent agent populations and faster technological catch-up, with prospects for convergence or partial surpassing.
AI.conclusion: Provides a systematic, model-based analytical framework to understand AI-driven production transformation and shifts in international competitiveness, with quantitative insights for policy formulation.

title: Design and Koopman Model Predictive Control of A Soft Exoskeleton Based on Origami-Inspired Pneumatic Actuator for Knee Rehabilitation
summary:
Effective rehabilitation methods are essential for the recovery of lower limb
dysfunction caused by stroke. Nowadays, robotic exoskeletons have shown great
potentials in rehabilitation. Nevertheless, traditional rigid exoskeletons are
usually heavy and need a lot of work to help the patients to put them on.
Moreover, it also requires extra compliance control to guarantee the safety. In
contrast, soft exoskeletons are easy and comfortable to wear and have intrinsic
compliance, but their complex nonlinear human-robot interaction dynamics would
pose significant challenges for control. In this work, based on the pneumatic
actuators inspired by origami, we design a rehabilitation exoskeleton for knee
that is easy and comfortable to wear. To guarantee the control performance and
enable a nice human-robot interaction, we first use Deep Koopman Network to
model the human-robot interaction dynamics. In particular, by viewing the
electromyography (EMG) signals and the duty cycle of the PWM wave that controls
the pneumatic robot's valves and pump as the inputs, the linear Koopman model
accurately captures the complex human-robot interaction dynamics. Next, based
on the obtained Koopman model, we further use Model Predictive Control (MPC) to
control the soft robot and help the user to do rehabilitation training in
real-time. The goal of the rehabilitation training is to track a given
reference signal shown on the screen. Experiments show that by integrating the
EMG signals into the Koopman model, we have improved the model accuracy to
great extent. In addition, a personalized Koopman model trained from the
individual's own data performs better than the non-personalized model.
Consequently, our control framework outperforms the traditional PID control in
both passive and active training modes. Hence the proposed method provides a
new control framework for soft rehabilitation robots.

AI.tldr: A soft, knee rehabilitation exoskeleton using origami-inspired pneumatic actuators is controlled by a Deep Koopman Network model of human-robot interaction that incorporates EMG and PWM inputs, with MPC-based control; personalization improves model accuracy and the approach outperforms PID in passive and active training, offering a new framework for soft rehab robots.
AI.motivation: Rigid exoskeletons are heavy and require substantial don/doffing effort and safety-compliance control. Soft exoskeletons offer comfort and intrinsic compliance but pose challenging nonlinear HRI dynamics. A modeling-based control framework is needed to enable real-time, comfortable, and safe rehabilitation with soft robots.
AI.method: Design a knee rehabilitation soft exoskeleton using origami-inspired pneumatic actuators. Model the human-robot interaction dynamics with a Deep Koopman Network, taking EMG signals and the PWM duty cycle controlling valves/pump as inputs. Use the resulting linear Koopman model within a Model Predictive Control framework to track a reference trajectory in real time. Compare EMG-integrated vs non-EMG models and personalized vs non-personalized models, and contrast the MPC framework against traditional PID in both passive and active training modes.
AI.result: Incorporating EMG signals into the Koopman model significantly improves model accuracy. A personalized Koopman model trained on an individual’s data performs better than a non-personalized one. The proposed MPC-based control framework outperforms PID in both passive and active training modes.
AI.conclusion: The study presents a viable, real-time control framework for soft rehabilitation robots, combining origami-inspired pneumatic actuation, EMG-informed Koopman modeling, and MPC to enhance safety, comfort, and rehabilitation effectiveness.

title: HccePose(BF): Predicting Front \& Back Surfaces to Construct Ultra-Dense 2D-3D Correspondences for Pose Estimation
comment:
International Conference on Computer Vision, ICCV 2025 (Highlight)
  https://iccv.thecvf.com/virtual/2025/poster/338
summary:
In pose estimation for seen objects, a prevalent pipeline involves using
neural networks to predict dense 3D coordinates of the object surface on 2D
images, which are then used to establish dense 2D-3D correspondences. However,
current methods primarily focus on more efficient encoding techniques to
improve the precision of predicted 3D coordinates on the object's front
surface, overlooking the potential benefits of incorporating the back surface
and interior of the object. To better utilize the full surface and interior of
the object, this study predicts 3D coordinates of both the object's front and
back surfaces and densely samples 3D coordinates between them. This process
creates ultra-dense 2D-3D correspondences, effectively enhancing pose
estimation accuracy based on the Perspective-n-Point (PnP) algorithm.
Additionally, we propose Hierarchical Continuous Coordinate Encoding (HCCE) to
provide a more accurate and efficient representation of front and back surface
coordinates. Experimental results show that, compared to existing
state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods on the BOP website, the proposed approach
outperforms across seven classic BOP core datasets. Code is available at
https://github.com/WangYuLin-SEU/HCCEPose.

AI.tldr: Proposes ultra-dense 2D-3D correspondences by predicting 3D coordinates for both front and back object surfaces and densely sampling between them, enabled by Hierarchical Continuous Coordinate Encoding (HCCE); shows improved pose estimation on seven BOP core datasets.
AI.motivation: Current dense-3D coordinate methods mainly exploit front-surface information and efficient encoding, neglecting back surface and interior data that could improve PnP-based pose estimation.
AI.method: Predict 3D coordinates for front and back surfaces, densely sample coordinates between them to form ultra-dense correspondences; introduce Hierarchical Continuous Coordinate Encoding (HCCE) for efficient and accurate surface representations; use PnP for pose estimation.
AI.result: Outperforms state-of-the-art methods on seven classic BOP core datasets as reported on the BOP website.
AI.conclusion: Leveraging full surface (front + back) and interior sampling, with HCCE, yields more accurate pose estimates and superior performance compared to existing approaches.

title: Myopic Bayesian Decision Theory for Batch Active Learning with Partial Batch Label Sampling
summary:
Over the past couple of decades, many active learning acquisition functions
have been proposed, leaving practitioners with an unclear choice of which to
use. Bayesian Decision Theory (BDT) offers a universal principle to guide
decision-making. In this work, we derive BDT for (Bayesian) active learning in
the myopic framework, where we imagine we only have one more point to label.
This derivation leads to effective algorithms such as Expected Error Reduction
(EER), Expected Predictive Information Gain (EPIG), and other algorithms that
appear in the literature. Furthermore, we show that BAIT (active learning based
on V-optimal experimental design) can be derived from BDT and asymptotic
approximations. A key challenge of such methods is the difficult scaling to
large batch sizes, leading to either computational challenges (BatchBALD) or
dramatic performance drops (top-$B$ selection). Here, using a particular
formulation of the decision process, we derive Partial Batch Label Sampling
(ParBaLS) for the EPIG algorithm. We show experimentally for several datasets
that ParBaLS EPIG gives superior performance for a fixed budget and Bayesian
Logistic Regression on Neural Embeddings. Our code is available at
https://github.com/ADDAPT-ML/ParBaLS.

AI.tldr: Bayesian decision theory (BDT) provides a principled, one-step lookahead framework for active learning, deriving known AL strategies (EER, EPIG, BAIT) and addressing batch-sampling with ParBaLS; empirically, ParBaLS EPIG improves performance at fixed budgets, with code released.
AI.motivation: There are many active learning acquisition functions with unclear guidance on which to use. A universal, principled framework is needed. BDT offers a decision rule to pick the next label that maximizes expected utility under uncertainty.
AI.method: Derive BDT for the myopic, one-label-to-acquire setting in Bayesian active learning. Show that this yields algorithms such as EER and EPIG; derive BAIT from BDT with asymptotic approximations. Address batch-sampling scalability by formulating a Partial Batch Label Sampling (ParBaLS) for EPIG, and evaluate on neural-embedding features with Bayesian logistic regression.
AI.result: BDT-based derivations reproduce established AL strategies (EER, EPIG, BAIT). ParBaLS provides a scalable, effective batching approach for EPIG. Empirical tests on several datasets with Bayesian logistic regression on neural embeddings show ParBaLS-EPIG achieves superior performance at fixed labeling budgets; code released at the provided GitHub URL.
AI.conclusion: BDT furnishes a universal, principled framework for Bayesian active learning. It clarifies how several AL methods follow from a single decision-theoretic principle and offers a scalable batching approach (ParBaLS) for EPIG that improves practical performance.

title: Improving AI Efficiency in Data Centres by Power Dynamic Response
summary:
The steady growth of artificial intelligence (AI) has accelerated in the
recent years, facilitated by the development of sophisticated models such as
large language models and foundation models. Ensuring robust and reliable power
infrastructures is fundamental to take advantage of the full potential of AI.
However, AI data centres are extremely hungry for power, putting the problem of
their power management in the spotlight, especially with respect to their
impact on environment and sustainable development. In this work, we investigate
the capacity and limits of solutions based on an innovative approach for the
power management of AI data centres, i.e., making part of the input power as
dynamic as the power used for data-computing functions. The performance of
passive and active devices are quantified and compared in terms of
computational gain, energy efficiency, reduction of capital expenditure, and
management costs by analysing power trends from multiple data platforms
worldwide. This strategy, which identifies a paradigm shift in the AI data
centre power management, has the potential to strongly improve the
sustainability of AI hyperscalers, enhancing their footprint on environmental,
financial, and societal fields.

AI.tldr: Proposes dynamic power management for AI data centers by making part of input power as flexible as compute power; compares passive and active devices; analyzes power trends globally to assess impact on energy efficiency, capex, and management costs; suggests substantial sustainability gains.
AI.motivation: AI data centers consume large amounts of power; robust and sustainable power management is essential to unlock scalable AI while minimizing environmental and financial costs.
AI.method: Quantify performance of passive vs. active power devices; analyze power trends from multiple data platforms worldwide; assess effects on computational gain, energy efficiency, capex reduction, and management costs; present a paradigm shift in power management strategy.
AI.result: The strategy shows potential for strong sustainability improvements for AI hyperscalers; provides quantitative analyses of energy and cost benefits across platforms; demonstrates trade-offs between device types and dynamic input power.
AI.conclusion: Dynamic input power management could be a paradigm shift enabling more sustainable AI data centers, with environmental, financial, and societal benefits.

title: A Primer on SO(3) Action Representations in Deep Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Many robotic control tasks require policies to act on orientations, yet the
geometry of SO(3) makes this nontrivial. Because SO(3) admits no global,
smooth, minimal parameterization, common representations such as Euler angles,
quaternions, rotation matrices, and Lie algebra coordinates introduce distinct
constraints and failure modes. While these trade-offs are well studied for
supervised learning, their implications for actions in reinforcement learning
remain unclear. We systematically evaluate SO(3) action representations across
three standard continuous control algorithms, PPO, SAC, and TD3, under dense
and sparse rewards. We compare how representations shape exploration, interact
with entropy regularization, and affect training stability through empirical
studies and analyze the implications of different projections for obtaining
