thereby supporting strategies that reduce attrition and strengthen customer
loyalty.

AI.tldr: Proposes a three-component, interpretable framework combining explainable AI, survival analysis, and RFM profiling to design personalized retention strategies and identify high-risk segments in online retail.
AI.motivation: Contemporary churn models are often opaque, hindering understanding of what drives attrition, when to intervene, and which customer segments to target. There is a need for interpretable evidence to inform retention actions.
AI.method: A three-component framework: (1) explainable AI to quantify feature contributions, (2) survival analysis to model time-to-churn risk, and (3) RFM profiling to segment customers by transactional behaviour; combined to attribute churn drivers, estimate intervention windows, and prioritize segments for targeted retention actions.
AI.result: Describes an integrated framework and its intended outputs—driver attribution, intervention timing, and segment prioritization—facilitating actionable retention strategies.
AI.conclusion: Integrating explainable AI, survival analysis, and RFM profiling can guide interpretable, timely, and targeted retention actions that reduce attrition and strengthen customer loyalty.

title: Robot Soccer Kit: Omniwheel Tracked Soccer Robots for Education
summary:
Recent developments of low cost off-the-shelf programmable components, their
modularity, and also rapid prototyping made educational robotics flourish, as
it is accessible in most schools today. They allow to illustrate and embody
theoretical problems in practical and tangible applications, and gather
multidisciplinary skills. They also give a rich natural context for
project-oriented pedagogy. However, most current robot kits all are limited to
egocentric aspect of the robots perception. This makes it difficult to access
more high-level problems involving e.g. coordinates or navigation. In this
paper we introduce an educational holonomous robot kit that comes with an
external tracking system, which lightens the constraint on embedded systems,
but allows in the same time to discover high-level aspects of robotics,
otherwise unreachable.

AI.tldr: Introduces an educational holonomous robot kit with an external tracking system to expose high-level robotics concepts (coordinates, navigation) beyond embedded limits.
AI.motivation: Current off-the-shelf educational robots focus on egocentric perception, which restricts access to higher-level problems like coordinate systems and navigation. A modular, low-cost approach paired with external tracking could broaden pedagogy.
AI.method: Describe a holonomous robot kit paired with an external tracking system that provides precise position/orientation data, offloading computation from embedded controllers and enabling study of high-level robotics tasks.
AI.result: The external tracking system reduces embedded constraints, enabling exploration of high-level robotics topics previously unreachable in typical educational kits.
AI.conclusion: Coupling external tracking with modular, affordable robots expands the educational scope, supporting project-based, multidisciplinary robotics education.

title: Ortho-Fuse: Orthomosaic Generation for Sparse High-Resolution Crop Health Maps Through Intermediate Optical Flow Estimation
summary:
AI-driven crop health mapping systems offer substantial advantages over
conventional monitoring approaches through accelerated data acquisition and
cost reduction. However, widespread farmer adoption remains constrained by
technical limitations in orthomosaic generation from sparse aerial imagery
datasets. Traditional photogrammetric reconstruction requires 70-80\%
inter-image overlap to establish sufficient feature correspondences for
accurate geometric registration. AI-driven systems operating under
resource-constrained conditions cannot consistently achieve these overlap
thresholds, resulting in degraded reconstruction quality that undermines user
confidence in autonomous monitoring technologies. In this paper, we present
Ortho-Fuse, an optical flow-based framework that enables the generation of a
reliable orthomosaic with reduced overlap requirements. Our approach employs
intermediate flow estimation to synthesize transitional imagery between
consecutive aerial frames, artificially augmenting feature correspondences for
improved geometric reconstruction. Experimental validation demonstrates a 20\%
reduction in minimum overlap requirements. We further analyze adoption barriers
in precision agriculture to identify pathways for enhanced integration of
AI-driven monitoring systems.

AI.tldr: Ortho-Fuse uses optical-flow to synthesize intermediate frames and reduce required image overlap for orthomosaic reconstruction by 20%.
AI.motivation: Photogrammetric orthomosaic generation demands high inter-image overlap (70-80%), hindering AI-driven crop monitoring under resource constraints; improving robustness and uptake.
AI.method: An optical-flow-based framework that estimates intermediate frames between successive aerial images to augment feature correspondences, enabling reliable geometric reconstruction with lower overlap.
AI.result: Experimental validation shows a 20% reduction in minimum overlap requirements; improved reconstruction reliability in sparse imagery; includes adoption barriers analysis for precision agriculture.
AI.conclusion: Ortho-Fuse enables reliable orthomosaic generation with reduced overlap, facilitating broader adoption of AI-driven crop health monitoring; highlights integration pathways to overcome adoption barriers.

title: Reinforcement Fine-Tuning of Flow-Matching Policies for Vision-Language-Action Models
summary:
Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models such as OpenVLA, Octo, and $\pi_0$ have
shown strong generalization by leveraging large-scale demonstrations, yet their
performance is still fundamentally constrained by the quality and coverage of
supervised data. Reinforcement learning (RL) provides a promising path for
improving and fine-tuning VLAs through online interaction. However,
conventional policy gradient methods are computationally infeasible in the
context of flow-matching based models due to the intractability of the
importance sampling process, which requires explicit computation of policy
ratios. To overcome this limitation, we propose Flow Policy Optimization (FPO)
algorithm, which reformulates importance sampling by leveraging per-sample
changes in the conditional flow-matching objective. Furthermore, FPO achieves
stable and scalable online reinforcement fine-tuning of the $\pi_0$ model by
integrating structure-aware credit assignment to enhance gradient efficiency,
clipped surrogate objectives to stabilize optimization, multi-step latent
exploration to encourage diverse policy updates, and a Q-ensemble mechanism to
provide robust value estimation. We evaluate FPO on the LIBERO benchmark and
the ALOHA simulation task against supervised, preference-aligned,
diffusion-based, autoregressive online RL, and $\pi_0$-FAST baselines,
observing consistent improvements over the imitation prior and strong
alternatives with stable learning under sparse rewards. In addition, ablation
studies and analyses of the latent space dynamics further highlight the
contributions of individual components within FPO, validating the effectiveness
of the proposed computational modules and the stable convergence of the
conditional flow-matching objective during online RL.

AI.tldr: A novel Flow Policy Optimization (FPO) approach for online RL fine-tuning of flow-matching Vision-Language-Action models, addressing importance sampling via per-sample objective changes and introducing structure-aware credit assignment, clipped objectives, latent exploration, and a Q-ensemble; shows empirical gains on LIBERO and ALOHA against various baselines and ablations.
AI.motivation: VLAs generalize well with large supervised data but are bounded by data quality/coverage. RL promises improvement via online interaction, yet standard policy gradients are infeasible for flow-matching models due to intractable importance sampling, necessitating scalable online RL methods.
AI.method: Flow Policy Optimization (FPO) reformulates importance sampling by exploiting per-sample changes in the conditional flow-matching objective. It also introduces structure-aware credit assignment to improve gradient efficiency, clipped surrogate objectives for stability, multi-step latent exploration to encourage diverse policy updates, and a Q-ensemble for robust value estimation. The approach enables online RL fine-tuning of the pi0 model and is evaluated on LIBERO and ALOHA, compared against supervised, preference-aligned, diffusion-based, autoregressive online RL, and pi0-FAST baselines, with ablations.
AI.result: FPO achieves consistent improvements over the imitation prior and competitive performance against strong baselines, including stable learning under sparse rewards. Ablation studies and analyses of latent space dynamics corroborate the effectiveness of individual components and show stable convergence of the conditional flow-matching objective during online RL.
AI.conclusion: FPO makes online RL fine-tuning of flow-matching VLAs feasible and effective, delivering performance gains and stable optimization. It demonstrates a viable pathway for improving VLA systems via online interaction without prohibitive computation.

title: ParaCook: On Time-Efficient Planning for Multi-Agent Systems
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) exhibit strong reasoning abilities for planning
long-horizon, real-world tasks, yet existing agent benchmarks focus on task
completion while neglecting time efficiency in parallel and asynchronous
operations. To address this, we present ParaCook, a benchmark for
time-efficient collaborative planning. Inspired by the Overcooked game,
ParaCook provides an environment for various challenging interaction planning
of multi-agent systems that are instantiated as cooking tasks, with a
simplified action space to isolate the core challenge of strategic parallel
planning. Through a comprehensive evaluation of state-of-the-art LLMs, we find
that current approaches achieve suboptimal plans, which struggle with parallel
actions or coordination. Our analysis also reveals LLMs' potential on abstract
tasks where they can focus on high-level parallel optimization. ParaCook
provides a scalable evaluation framework with adjustable complexity,
establishing a foundation for developing and assessing time efficiency-aware
multi-agent planning. The code and data are available at
https://github.com/zsq259/ParaCook.

AI.tldr: ParaCook is a scalable benchmark for time-efficient collaborative planning in multi-agent LLM settings, inspired by Overcooked, highlighting current LLMs' weaknesses in coordinating parallel actions while enabling high-level parallel optimization on abstract tasks; provides an adjustable framework and public code.
AI.motivation: Existing agent benchmarks emphasize task completion rather than time efficiency in parallel/asynchronous planning; there is a need to evaluate and push LLMs toward time-efficient, coordinated multi-agent planning.
AI.method: Introduce ParaCook environment with simplified action space for multi-agent cooking-like tasks; instantiate challenging interaction planning problems; vary complexity; evaluate state-of-the-art LLMs on planning with attention to parallelism; analyze coordination issues; offer a scalable framework with downloadable data/code.
AI.result: State-of-the-art LLMs produce suboptimal plans, struggle with parallel actions and coordination, though they show potential on abstract tasks where high-level parallel optimization is possible; ParaCook serves as a framework for time-efficiency-aware multi-agent planning evaluation.
AI.conclusion: ParaCook provides a foundation for developing and assessing time-efficiency-aware multi-agent planning; scalable, adjustable complexity; code and data available at GitHub, enabling broader research.

title: SCOOP'D: Learning Mixed-Liquid-Solid Scooping via Sim2Real Generative Policy
summary:
Scooping items with tools such as spoons and ladles is common in daily life,
ranging from assistive feeding to retrieving items from environmental disaster
sites. However, developing a general and autonomous robotic scooping policy is
challenging since it requires reasoning about complex tool-object interactions.
Furthermore, scooping often involves manipulating deformable objects, such as
granular media or liquids, which is challenging due to their
infinite-dimensional configuration spaces and complex dynamics. We propose a
method, SCOOP'D, which uses simulation from OmniGibson (built on NVIDIA
Omniverse) to collect scooping demonstrations using algorithmic procedures that
rely on privileged state information. Then, we use generative policies via
diffusion to imitate demonstrations from observational input. We directly apply
the learned policy in diverse real-world scenarios, testing its performance on
various item quantities, item characteristics, and container types. In
zero-shot deployment, our method demonstrates promising results across 465
trials in diverse scenarios, including objects of different difficulty levels
that we categorize as "Level 1" and "Level 2." SCOOP'D outperforms all
baselines and ablations, suggesting that this is a promising approach to
acquiring robotic scooping skills. Project page is at
https://scoopdiff.github.io/.

AI.tldr: Diffusion-based policy learning for robotic scooping (SCOOP'D) trained with privileged-simulation demonstrations and deployed zero-shot in the real world, outperforming baselines across varied scenarios (465 trials).
AI.motivation: Robotic scooping with deformable materials and complex tool–object interactions is hard; a general autonomous policy is needed that can transfer from simulation to real-world, handling diverse items, quantities, and containers.
AI.method: Collect scooping demonstrations in OmniGibson/NVIDIA Omniverse using privileged state information; train a diffusion-based policy to imitate demonstrations from observational input; deploy zero-shot to real-world scenarios with varying item quantities, characteristics, and containers.
AI.result: 465 trials across diverse scenarios; SCOOP'D outperforms all baselines and ablations, across object difficulty levels (Level 1 and Level 2).
AI.conclusion: SCOOP'D demonstrates the promise of diffusion-based imitation from privileged-simulated data for robotic scooping, enabling generalizable skills across deformable materials and diverse real-world settings.

title: PointMAC: Meta-Learned Adaptation for Robust Test-Time Point Cloud Completion
summary:
Point cloud completion is essential for robust 3D perception in
safety-critical applications such as robotics and augmented reality. However,
existing models perform static inference and rely heavily on inductive biases
learned during training, limiting their ability to adapt to novel structural
patterns and sensor-induced distortions at test time. To address this
limitation, we propose PointMAC, a meta-learned framework for robust test-time
adaptation in point cloud completion. It enables sample-specific refinement
without requiring additional supervision. Our method optimizes the completion
model under two self-supervised auxiliary objectives that simulate structural
and sensor-level incompleteness. A meta-auxiliary learning strategy based on
Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML) ensures that adaptation driven by auxiliary
objectives is consistently aligned with the primary completion task. During
inference, we adapt the shared encoder on-the-fly by optimizing auxiliary
losses, with the decoder kept fixed. To further stabilize adaptation, we
introduce Adaptive $\lambda$-Calibration, a meta-learned mechanism for
balancing gradients between primary and auxiliary objectives. Extensive
experiments on synthetic, simulated, and real-world datasets demonstrate that
PointMAC achieves state-of-the-art results by refining each sample individually
to produce high-quality completions. To the best of our knowledge, this is the
first work to apply meta-auxiliary test-time adaptation to point cloud
completion.

AI.tldr: PointMAC uses meta-learned test-time adaptation with self-supervised auxiliary objectives to refine point cloud encoders per-sample for robust completion, achieving state-of-the-art results without extra supervision.
AI.motivation: Current point cloud completion models are static and rely on inductive biases learned during training, which hurts adaptability to novel structural patterns and sensor distortions at test time.
AI.method: Two self-supervised auxiliary objectives simulate structural and sensor-level incompleteness. A Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML) based meta-auxiliary strategy aligns auxiliary-driven adaptation with the main completion task. During inference, the shared encoder is adapted online using auxiliary losses while the decoder stays fixed. Adaptive λ-Calibration meta-learns gradient balancing between primary and auxiliary objectives.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on synthetic, simulated, and real-world data show PointMAC achieves state-of-the-art results by refining each sample individually for high-quality completions; claimed to be the first to apply meta-auxiliary test-time adaptation to point cloud completion.
AI.conclusion: PointMAC enables per-sample refinement at test time to improve completion quality, introducing a new meta-learning approach for robust 3D perception and opening avenues for future meta-auxiliary test-time adaptation in point clouds.

title: An Unsupervised Time Series Anomaly Detection Approach for Efficient Online Process Monitoring of Additive Manufacturing
comment:
2025 IEEE 21st International Conference on Automation Science and
  Engineering
summary:
Online sensing plays an important role in advancing modern manufacturing. The
real-time sensor signals, which can be stored as high-resolution time series
data, contain rich information about the operation status. One of its popular
usages is online process monitoring, which can be achieved by effective anomaly
detection from the sensor signals. However, most existing approaches either
heavily rely on labeled data for training supervised models, or are designed to
detect only extreme outliers, thus are ineffective at identifying subtle
semantic off-track anomalies to capture where new regimes or unexpected
routines start. To address this challenge, we propose an matrix profile-based
unsupervised anomaly detection algorithm that captures fabrication cycle
similarity and performs semantic segmentation to precisely identify the onset
of defect anomalies in additive manufacturing. The effectiveness of the
proposed method is demonstrated by the experiments on real-world sensor data.

AI.tldr: Matrix profile-based unsupervised anomaly detection for online sensing in additive manufacturing, enabling semantic segmentation to locate onset of defects without heavy reliance on labeled data, validated on real-world sensor data.
AI.motivation: There is a need to detect subtle, semantically meaningful anomalies in high-resolution sensor time series for online manufacturing monitoring, without requiring extensive labeled data, and to identify when new regimes or defect-onset occurs.
AI.method: Proposes a matrix-profile-based unsupervised anomaly detection algorithm that measures fabrication cycle similarity and performs semantic segmentation to precisely identify the onset of defect anomalies in additive manufacturing.
AI.result: Experiments on real-world sensor data demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in detecting onset of defects and capturing semantic changes during fabrication.
AI.conclusion: An unsupervised, matrix-profile-based approach can effectively monitor additive manufacturing processes by detecting subtle, semantic anomalies and segmenting defect onset without relying on labeled data.

title: SR-Scientist: Scientific Equation Discovery With Agentic AI
summary:
Recently, Large Language Models (LLMs) have been applied to scientific
equation discovery, leveraging their embedded scientific knowledge for
hypothesis generation. However, current methods typically confine LLMs to the
role of an equation proposer within search algorithms like genetic programming.
In this paper, we present SR-Scientist, a framework that elevates the LLM from
a simple equation proposer to an autonomous AI scientist that writes code to
analyze data, implements the equation as code, submits it for evaluation, and
optimizes the equation based on experimental feedback. Specifically, we wrap
the code interpreter into a set of tools for data analysis and equation
evaluation. The agent is instructed to optimize the equation by utilizing these
tools over a long horizon with minimal human-defined pipelines. Empirical
results show that SR-Scientist outperforms baseline methods by an absolute
margin of 6% to 35% on datasets covering four science disciplines.
Additionally, we demonstrate our method's robustness to noise, the
generalization of the discovered equations to out-of-domain data, and their
symbolic accuracy. Furthermore, we develop an end-to-end reinforcement learning
framework to enhance the agent's capabilities.

AI.tldr: SR-Scientist introduces an autonomous AI scientist framework that enables an LLM to write, run, and optimize equations via coding and data-analysis tools, achieving substantial gains over baselines across four scientific domains and demonstrating robustness and generalization, with an RL-enhanced training approach.
AI.motivation: Current setups limit LLMs to proposing equations within genetic-programming-like search loops. There is a need for an autonomous agent that can implement, evaluate, and refine equations directly by coding against data, reducing human-driven pipelines and enabling longer-horizon optimization.
AI.method: Wrap a code interpreter into data-analysis and equation-evaluation tools. The agent writes code to analyze data, implements the equation as code, executes evaluations, and refines the equation over long horizons using feedback from experiments. An end-to-end reinforcement learning framework trains the agent to perform these tasks with minimal human-defined pipelines.
AI.result: SR-Scientist outperforms baselines by an absolute margin of 6% to 35% on datasets spanning four science disciplines. The approach shows robustness to noise, generalization to out-of-domain data, and preservation of symbolic accuracy.
AI.conclusion: The framework demonstrates that autonomous scientific discovery is feasible for equation discovery tasks, with LLM-driven code synthesis and long-horizon optimization yielding practical improvements. The end-to-end RL enhancement further strengthens the agent’s capabilities.

title: Calibrated Dynamic Modeling for Force and Payload Estimation in Hydraulic Machinery
summary:
Accurate real-time estimation of end effector interaction forces in hydraulic
excavators is a key enabler for advanced automation in heavy machinery.
Accurate knowledge of these forces allows improved, precise grading and digging
maneuvers. To address these challenges, we introduce a high-accuracy,
retrofittable 2D force- and payload estimation algorithm that does not impose
additional requirements on the operator regarding trajectory, acceleration or
the use of the slew joint. The approach is designed for retrofittability,
requires minimal calibration and no prior knowledge of machine-specific dynamic
characteristics. Specifically, we propose a method for identifying a dynamic
model, necessary to estimate both end effector interaction forces and bucket
payload during normal operation. Our optimization-based payload estimation
achieves a full-scale payload accuracy of 1%. On a standard 25 t excavator, the
online force measurement from pressure and inertial measurements achieves a
direction accuracy of 13 degree and a magnitude accuracy of 383 N. The method's
accuracy and generalization capability are validated on two excavator platforms
of different type and weight classes. We benchmark our payload estimation
against a classical quasistatic method and a commercially available system. Our
system outperforms both in accuracy and precision.

AI.tldr: A retrofit 2D force- and payload estimation method for hydraulic excavators estimates end-effector interaction forces and bucket payload in real time without extra operator requirements or prior machine dynamics knowledge. It uses dynamic-model identification and optimization-based payload estimation, validated across two platforms, outperforming quasistatic and commercial baselines with ~1% payload accuracy and 13° direction, 383 N magnitude force accuracy on a 25 t machine.
AI.motivation: Enable precise, real-time end-effector force estimation to improve automation (grading/digging) in heavy machinery while allowing retrofitting with minimal calibration and no dependence on machine-specific dynamic characteristics or slew-joint trajectories.
AI.method: Identify a dynamic model suitable for online force and payload estimation. Develop a 2D force- and payload-estimation algorithm that operates online using pressure and inertial measurements. Employ optimization-based payload estimation to achieve high accuracy. The approach is designed to be retrofittable and requires minimal calibration and no prior machine dynamic knowledge.
AI.result: Payload estimation accuracy of 1% of full scale. On a standard 25 t excavator, online force-measurement yields direction accuracy ~13 degrees and magnitude accuracy ~383 N. Validated on two excavator platforms of differing type and weight. Benchmark tests show the method outperforms a classical quasistatic method and a commercially available system in both accuracy and precision.
AI.conclusion: A practical, generalizable retrofittable method for real-time end-effector force and bucket payload estimation in hydraulic excavators. Requires minimal calibration, no machine-specific dynamic modeling, and demonstrates superior accuracy relative to existing baselines across platforms.

title: Vision4PPG: Emergent PPG Analysis Capability of Vision Foundation Models for Vital Signs like Blood Pressure
summary:
Photoplethysmography (PPG) sensor in wearable and clinical devices provides
valuable physiological insights in a non-invasive and real-time fashion.
Specialized Foundation Models (FM) or repurposed time-series FMs are used to
benchmark physiological tasks. Our experiments with fine-tuning FMs reveal that
Vision FM (VFM) can also be utilized for this purpose and, in fact,
surprisingly leads to state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance on many tasks,
notably blood pressure estimation. We leverage VFMs by simply transforming
one-dimensional PPG signals into image-like two-dimensional representations,
such as the Short-Time Fourier transform (STFT). Using the latest VFMs, such as
DINOv3 and SIGLIP-2, we achieve promising performance on other vital signs and
blood lab measurement tasks as well. Our proposal, Vision4PPG, unlocks a new
class of FMs to achieve SOTA performance with notable generalization to other
2D input representations, including STFT phase and recurrence plots. Our work
improves upon prior investigations of vision models for PPG by conducting a
comprehensive study, comparing them to state-of-the-art time-series FMs, and
demonstrating the general PPG processing ability by reporting results on six
additional tasks. Thus, we provide clinician-scientists with a new set of
powerful tools that is also computationally efficient, thanks to
Parameter-Efficient Fine-Tuning (PEFT) techniques.

AI.tldr: Vision-based foundation models applied to PPG by converting 1D signals into 2D representations (e.g., STFT). Fine-tuned VFMs like DINOv3/SIGLIP-2 yield SOTA results on BP estimation and other tasks, with good generalization and efficiency via PEFT.
AI.motivation: PPG offers noninvasive real-time physiological insights, but robust, general models are needed. Vision models, especially foundation models, may transfer well to time-series data when cast as images.
AI.method: Transform 1D PPG into 2D inputs (STFT, phase, recurrence plots). Fine-tune vision foundation models (DINOv3, SIGLIP-2) using parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT). Compare to time-series FMs across six tasks; test generalization to other 2D representations.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance on several tasks, notably blood pressure estimation; demonstrates strong performance on other vital signs and lab measurements; shows generalization across different 2D representations; efficient training via PEFT.
AI.conclusion: Vision4PPG opens a new use of vision foundation models for PPG, offering SOTA potential and broad applicability with efficient fine-tuning, enabling clinicians to leverage powerful 2D-FM tools.

title: Learning Joint Embeddings of Function and Process Call Graphs for Malware Detection
summary:
Software systems can be represented as graphs, capturing dependencies among
functions and processes. An interesting aspect of software systems is that they
can be represented as different types of graphs, depending on the extraction
goals and priorities. For example, function calls within the software can be
captured to create function call graphs, which highlight the relationships
between functions and their dependencies. Alternatively, the processes spawned
by the software can be modeled to generate process interaction graphs, which
focus on runtime behavior and inter-process communication. While these graph
representations are related, each captures a distinct perspective of the
system, providing complementary insights into its structure and operation.
While previous studies have leveraged graph neural networks (GNNs) to analyze
software behaviors, most of this work has focused on a single type of graph
representation. The joint modeling of both function call graphs and process
interaction graphs remains largely underexplored, leaving opportunities for
deeper, multi-perspective analysis of software systems. This paper presents a
pipeline for constructing and training Function Call Graphs (FCGs) and Process
Call Graphs (PCGs) and learning joint embeddings. We demonstrate that joint
embeddings outperform a single-graph model. In this paper, we propose
GeminiNet, a unified neural network approach that learns joint embeddings from
both FCGs and PCGs. We construct a new dataset of 635 Windows executables (318
malicious and 317 benign), extracting FCGs via Ghidra and PCGs via Any.Run
sandbox. GeminiNet employs dual graph convolutional branches with an adaptive
gating mechanism that balances contributions from static and dynamic views.

AI.tldr: GeminiNet learns joint embeddings from two software-graph views—Function Call Graphs (FCGs) and Process Call Graphs (PCGs)—using dual GCN branches with adaptive gating, showing superior performance over single-graph models on a dataset of 635 Windows executables (318 malicious, 317 benign).
AI.motivation: Software systems can be represented by multiple graph types (static function calls vs dynamic process interactions); jointly modeling these complementary perspectives can yield richer embeddings and improve downstream tasks like malware detection or behavior analysis.
AI.method: Construct FCGs via Ghidra and PCGs via Any.Run sandbox; GeminiNet uses two graph convolutional branches to process each graph type, coupled with an adaptive gating mechanism to balance static and dynamic views; trained on a dataset of 635 Windows executables (318 malicious, 317 benign).
AI.result: Joint embeddings outperform a single-graph model, demonstrating the benefit of integrating static and dynamic graph views in a unified representation.
AI.conclusion: Multi-view learning with GeminiNet provides enhanced software behavior representations and improves decision quality when comparing malicious vs benign software, highlighting the value of jointly modeling multiple graph perspectives.

title: Operand Quant: A Single-Agent Architecture for Autonomous Machine Learning Engineering
comment: 8 pages. No figures. Evaluated on MLE-Benchmark 2025
summary:
We present Operand Quant, a single-agent, IDE-based architecture for
autonomous machine learning engineering (MLE). Operand Quant departs from
conventional multi-agent orchestration frameworks by consolidating all MLE
lifecycle stages -- exploration, modeling, experimentation, and deployment --
within a single, context-aware agent. On the MLE-Benchmark (2025), Operand
Quant achieved a new state-of-the-art (SOTA) result, with an overall medal rate
of 0.3956 +/- 0.0565 across 75 problems -- the highest recorded performance
among all evaluated systems to date. The architecture demonstrates that a
linear, non-blocking agent, operating autonomously within a controlled IDE
environment, can outperform multi-agent and orchestrated systems under
identical constraints.

AI.tldr: Operand Quant is a single-agent, IDE-integrated ML engineering system that consolidates exploration, modeling, experimentation, and deployment, achieving SOTA performance on MLE-Benchmark 2025 with a medal rate of 0.3956 ± 0.0565 across 75 problems, outperforming multi-agent systems under identical constraints.
AI.motivation: To overcome fragmentation and inefficiency of multi-agent orchestration in MLE by integrating all lifecycle stages into one context-aware agent within an IDE, aiming for improved performance under the same constraints.
AI.method: Developed Operand Quant, a linear, non-blocking, context-aware agent operating autonomously inside a controlled IDE to cover all MLE lifecycle stages; evaluated against baselines on the MLE-Benchmark 2025 under identical constraints.
AI.result: Attained SOTA overall medal rate 0.3956 ± 0.0565 across 75 problems—the highest among evaluated systems to date.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates that a single, IDE-based, non-blocking agent can outperform traditional multi-agent orchestration under equivalent constraints, challenging the assumption that distributed agents are necessary for optimal MLE performance.

title: ManiAgent: An Agentic Framework for General Robotic Manipulation
summary:
While Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models have demonstrated impressive
capabilities in robotic manipulation, their performance in complex reasoning
and long-horizon task planning is limited by data scarcity and model capacity.
To address this, we introduce ManiAgent, an agentic architecture for general
manipulation tasks that achieves end-to-end output from task descriptions and
environmental inputs to robotic manipulation actions. In this framework,
multiple agents involve inter-agent communication to perform environmental
perception, sub-task decomposition and action generation, enabling efficient
handling of complex manipulation scenarios. Evaluations show ManiAgent achieves
an 86.8% success rate on the SimplerEnv benchmark and 95.8% on real-world
pick-and-place tasks, enabling efficient data collection that yields VLA models
with performance comparable to those trained on human-annotated datasets.The
project webpage is available at https://yi-yang929.github.io/ManiAgent/.

AI.tldr: A multi-agent, end-to-end manipulation framework (ManiAgent) that coordinates perception, planning, and action to boost long-horizon manipulation, achieving high success rates and data-efficient VLA modeling.
AI.motivation: Data scarcity and limited model capacity hinder Vision-Language-Action (VLA) based robotic manipulation, especially for complex, long-horizon tasks; there is a need for scalable, inter-agent coordination to improve reasoning and planning.
AI.method: Introduce ManiAgent, an agentic architecture with multiple interacting agents that handle environmental perception, sub-task decomposition, and action generation, enabling end-to-end outputs from task descriptions and environment inputs to robotic actions via inter-agent communication.
AI.result: 86.8% success on the SimplerEnv benchmark and 95.8% on real-world pick-and-place tasks; data-efficient collection that yields VLA models with performance comparable to those trained on human-annotated datasets.
AI.conclusion: ManiAgent demonstrates the viability of agentic, multi-agent manipulation architectures for general tasks, improving performance and data efficiency and suggesting broad applicability beyond the tested benchmarks.

title: Self-Supervised Multi-Scale Transformer with Attention-Guided Fusion for Efficient Crack Detection
comment:
The paper has been published at Automation in Construction journal.
  The paper has 53 pages and 11 figures
summary:
Pavement crack detection has long depended on costly and time-intensive
pixel-level annotations, which limit its scalability for large-scale
infrastructure monitoring. To overcome this barrier, this paper examines the
feasibility of achieving effective pixel-level crack segmentation entirely
without manual annotations. Building on this objective, a fully self-supervised
framework, Crack-Segmenter, is developed, integrating three complementary
modules: the Scale-Adaptive Embedder (SAE) for robust multi-scale feature
extraction, the Directional Attention Transformer (DAT) for maintaining linear
crack continuity, and the Attention-Guided Fusion (AGF) module for adaptive
feature integration. Through evaluations on ten public datasets,
Crack-Segmenter consistently outperforms 13 state-of-the-art supervised methods
across all major metrics, including mean Intersection over Union (mIoU), Dice
score, XOR, and Hausdorff Distance (HD). These findings demonstrate that
annotation-free crack detection is not only feasible but also superior,
enabling transportation agencies and infrastructure managers to conduct
scalable and cost-effective monitoring. This work advances self-supervised
learning and motivates pavement cracks detection research.

AI.tldr: A fully self-supervised framework, Crack-Segmenter, achieves pixel-level pavement crack segmentation without manual annotations and outperforms 13 supervised methods across 10 public datasets.
AI.motivation: Crack detection traditionally requires costly pixel-level annotations, hindering scalable, large-scale infrastructure monitoring; a calibration-free, annotation-free approach could enable widespread, cost-effective maintenance.
AI.method: Crack-Segmenter combines three modules: Scale-Adaptive Embedder (SAE) for multi-scale feature extraction, Directional Attention Transformer (DAT) for preserving linear crack continuity, and Attention-Guided Fusion (AGF) for adaptive feature integration, all trained in a self-supervised manner and evaluated on 10 public datasets.
AI.result: Consistently outperforms 13 state-of-the-art supervised methods on major metrics (mIoU, Dice, XOR, Hausdorff Distance) across ten datasets, demonstrating the feasibility and superiority of annotation-free crack detection.
AI.conclusion: Annotation-free crack detection is feasible and superior, enabling scalable, cost-effective pavement monitoring and advancing self-supervised learning in infrastructure image analysis.

title: Tight Robustness Certificates and Wasserstein Distributional Attacks for Deep Neural Networks
summary:
Wasserstein distributionally robust optimization (WDRO) provides a framework
for adversarial robustness, yet existing methods based on global Lipschitz
continuity or strong duality often yield loose upper bounds or require
prohibitive computation. In this work, we address these limitations by
introducing a primal approach and adopting a notion of exact Lipschitz
certificate to tighten this upper bound of WDRO. In addition, we propose a
novel Wasserstein distributional attack (WDA) that directly constructs a
candidate for the worst-case distribution. Compared to existing point-wise
attack and its variants, our WDA offers greater flexibility in the number and
location of attack points. In particular, by leveraging the piecewise-affine
structure of ReLU networks on their activation cells, our approach results in
an exact tractable characterization of the corresponding WDRO problem.
Extensive evaluations demonstrate that our method achieves competitive robust
accuracy against state-of-the-art baselines while offering tighter certificates
than existing methods. Our code is available at
https://github.com/OLab-Repo/WDA

AI.tldr: A primal WDRO framework with exact Lipschitz certificates and a Wasserstein distributional attack (WDA) that uses ReLU piecewise-affine structure to obtain an exact, tractable WDRO characterization, yielding tighter certificates and competitive robustness; code available.
AI.motivation: Existing WDRO methods relying on global Lipschitz or strong duality often produce loose bounds or be computationally prohibitive; there is a need for tighter, tractable robustness certificates and more flexible worst-case distribution construction.
AI.method: Develop a primal WDRO approach using exact Lipschitz certificates; introduce a Wasserstein distributional attack (WDA) that directly constructs the worst-case distribution; leverage the piecewise-affine structure of ReLU networks on activation cells to achieve an exact tractable WDRO formulation.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation shows competitive robust accuracy against state-of-the-art baselines and tighter certificates than existing WDRO methods; code is available at the provided GitHub link.
AI.conclusion: The proposed combination of primal WDRO with exact Lipschitz certificates and WDA provides tighter guarantees and practical tractability, enabling more flexible adversarial modeling under Wasserstein DRO.

title: Ego-Vision World Model for Humanoid Contact Planning
summary:
Enabling humanoid robots to exploit physical contact, rather than simply
avoid collisions, is crucial for autonomy in unstructured environments.
Traditional optimization-based planners struggle with contact complexity, while
on-policy reinforcement learning (RL) is sample-inefficient and has limited
multi-task ability. We propose a framework combining a learned world model with
sampling-based Model Predictive Control (MPC), trained on a demonstration-free
offline dataset to predict future outcomes in a compressed latent space. To
address sparse contact rewards and sensor noise, the MPC uses a learned
surrogate value function for dense, robust planning. Our single, scalable model
supports contact-aware tasks, including wall support after perturbation,
blocking incoming objects, and traversing height-limited arches, with improved
data efficiency and multi-task capability over on-policy RL. Deployed on a
physical humanoid, our system achieves robust, real-time contact planning from
proprioception and ego-centric depth images. Website:
https://ego-vcp.github.io/

AI.tldr: A model-based MPC with a learned latent dynamics model and a surrogate value function trained on offline data enables robust contact-aware planning for humanoid robots, outperforming on-policy RL and enabling multi-task behavior from proprioception and ego-centric depth images.
AI.motivation: Overcome the limitations of traditional optimization-based planners in handling contact complexity and the sample inefficiency of on-policy RL, by enabling fast, contact-rich planning in unstructured environments using a demonstration-free offline dataset and a latent-space world model.
AI.method: Train a latent-space world model; perform sampling-based Model Predictive Control guided by a dense surrogate value function to handle sparse contact rewards and sensor noise; train entirely on offline, demonstration-free data; deploy on a physical humanoid using proprioception and ego-centric depth for planning.
AI.result: The approach achieves robust, real-time contact planning for tasks such as wall support after perturbation, blocking incoming objects, and traversing height-limited arches; exhibits improved data efficiency and multi-task capability compared with on-policy RL; demonstrated on a physical humanoid.
AI.conclusion: A scalable, single-model framework can enable contact-aware, real-time planning in unstructured environments by coupling latent dynamics with MPC and a learned value function trained on offline data, bridging optimization and reinforcement learning and enabling versatile, multi-task manipulation and locomotion.

title: Identifying bias in CNN image classification using image scrambling and transforms
summary:
CNNs are now prevalent as the primary choice for most machine vision problems
due to their superior rate of classification and the availability of
user-friendly libraries. These networks effortlessly identify and select
features in a non-intuitive data-driven manner, making it difficult to
determine which features were most influential. That leads to a ``black box",
where users cannot know how the image data are analyzed but rely on empirical
results. Therefore the decision-making process can be biased by background
information that is difficult to detect. Here we discuss examples of such
hidden biases and propose techniques for identifying them, methods to
distinguish between contextual information and background noise, and explore
whether CNNs learn from irrelevant features. One effective approach to identify
dataset bias is to classify blank background parts of the images. However, in
some situations a blank background in the images is not available, making it
more difficult to separate the foreground information from the blank
background. Such parts of the image can also be considered contextual learning,
not necessarily bias. To overcome this, we propose two approaches that were
tested on six different datasets, including natural, synthetic, and hybrid
datasets. The first method involves dividing images into smaller,
non-overlapping tiles of various sizes, which are then shuffled randomly,
making classification more challenging. The second method involves the
application of several image transforms, including Fourier, Wavelet transforms,
and Median filter, and their combinations. These transforms help recover
background noise information used by CNN to classify images. Results indicate
that this method can effectively distinguish between contextual information and
background noise, and alert on the presence of background noise even without
the need to use background information.

AI.tldr: Proposes methods to detect and separate contextual bias vs background noise in CNNs; uses tile-shuffling and image transforms; validated on six datasets; enables bias awareness without labeled background data.
AI.motivation: CNNs are powerful yet opaque; their decisions can rely on hidden contextual cues and background information, leading to biased or spurious results. There is a need to identify such biases and differentiate context from noise.
AI.method: Two approaches: (1) divide images into smaller non-overlapping tiles of varying sizes and shuffle them to disrupt context; (2) apply several image transforms (Fourier, Wavelet, Median filter) and combinations to reveal background noise information used by CNNs; tested on six datasets including natural, synthetic, and hybrid.
AI.result: Transform-based and tiling methods help recover and identify background noise cues; the approaches can effectively distinguish contextual information from background noise and alert users to the presence of background noise even without background data.
AI.conclusion: The study offers practical techniques to diagnose CNN biases, enabling practitioners to separate context from foreground signals and to flag background noise that may drive classification decisions.

title: Bidirectional Time-Frequency Pyramid Network for Enhanced Robust EEG Classification
summary:
Existing EEG recognition models suffer from poor cross-paradigm
generalization due to dataset-specific constraints and individual variability.
To overcome these limitations, we propose BITE (Bidirectional Time-Freq Pyramid
Network), an end-to-end unified architecture featuring robust multistream
synergy, pyramid time-frequency attention (PTFA), and bidirectional adaptive
convolutions. The framework uniquely integrates: 1) Aligned time-frequency
streams maintaining temporal synchronization with STFT for bidirectional
modeling, 2) PTFA-based multi-scale feature enhancement amplifying critical
neural patterns, 3) BiTCN with learnable fusion capturing forward/backward
neural dynamics. Demonstrating enhanced robustness, BITE achieves
state-of-the-art performance across four divergent paradigms (BCICIV-2A/2B,
HGD, SD-SSVEP), excelling in both within-subject accuracy and cross-subject
generalization. As a unified architecture, it combines robust performance
across both MI and SSVEP tasks with exceptional computational efficiency. Our
work validates that paradigm-aligned spectral-temporal processing is essential
for reliable BCI systems. Just as its name suggests, BITE "takes a bite out of
EEG." The source code is available at https://github.com/cindy-hong/BiteEEG.

AI.tldr: A unified end-to-end EEG classifier (BITE) using aligned time-frequency streams, pyramid attention, and bidirectional convolutions to boost cross-paradigm generalization and MI/SSVEP performance; achieves state-of-the-art across four datasets; code available.
AI.motivation: Need robust cross-paradigm EEG recognition amid dataset-specific constraints and substantial inter-subject variability; paradigm-aligned spectral-temporal processing is crucial for reliable BCI systems.
AI.method: Introduce BITE with (1) aligned STFT-based time-frequency streams for bidirectional modeling, (2) pyramid time-frequency attention (PTFA) for multi-scale feature enhancement, (3) BiTCN with learnable fusion capturing forward/backward neural dynamics. Evaluated end-to-end on four paradigms (BCICIV-2A/2B, HGD, SD-SSVEP) with within-subject and cross-subject tests; designed for efficiency.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance across four divergent EEG paradigms; strong within-subject accuracy and cross-subject generalization; unified MI and SSVEP handling with computational efficiency.
AI.conclusion: Paradigm-aligned spectral-temporal processing is essential for reliable BCI systems. BITE provides a robust, unified architecture for EEG recognition; code released at GitHub.

title: Phys2Real: Fusing VLM Priors with Interactive Online Adaptation for Uncertainty-Aware Sim-to-Real Manipulation
summary:
Learning robotic manipulation policies directly in the real world can be
expensive and time-consuming. While reinforcement learning (RL) policies
trained in simulation present a scalable alternative, effective sim-to-real
transfer remains challenging, particularly for tasks that require precise
dynamics. To address this, we propose Phys2Real, a real-to-sim-to-real RL
pipeline that combines vision-language model (VLM)-inferred physical parameter
estimates with interactive adaptation through uncertainty-aware fusion. Our
approach consists of three core components: (1) high-fidelity geometric
reconstruction with 3D Gaussian splatting, (2) VLM-inferred prior distributions
over physical parameters, and (3) online physical parameter estimation from
interaction data. Phys2Real conditions policies on interpretable physical
parameters, refining VLM predictions with online estimates via ensemble-based
uncertainty quantification. On planar pushing tasks of a T-block with varying
center of mass (CoM) and a hammer with an off-center mass distribution,
Phys2Real achieves substantial improvements over a domain randomization
baseline: 100% vs 79% success rate for the bottom-weighted T-block, 57% vs 23%
in the challenging top-weighted T-block, and 15% faster average task completion
for hammer pushing. Ablation studies indicate that the combination of VLM and
interaction information is essential for success. Project website:
https://phys2real.github.io/ .

AI.tldr: Phys2Real is a real-to-sim-to-real RL framework that uses vision-language model (VLM) inferred priors over physical parameters and online parameter estimation to improve sim-to-real transfer for manipulation tasks, outperforming domain randomization on planar pushing tasks.
AI.motivation: Transferring policies learned in simulation to the real world is challenging when tasks depend on precise dynamics. Existing sim-to-real methods (e.g., domain randomization) may not capture hard-to-estimate physical parameters. The paper proposes leveraging VLMs to provide priors on physical parameters and online adaptation to refine them, enabling better real-world performance.
AI.method: Three components: (1) high-fidelity geometric reconstruction via 3D Gaussian splatting; (2) VLM-inferred prior distributions over physical parameters; (3) online estimation of physical parameters from interaction data using ensemble-based uncertainty quantification, with policies conditioned on interpretable physical parameters and fusion of VLM priors with online estimates.
AI.result: Phys2Real achieves substantial improvements over a domain randomization baseline on planar pushing tasks: 100% vs 79% success for the bottom-weighted T-block, 57% vs 23% for the top-weighted T-block, and 15% faster average hammer pushing. Ablations show that using both VLM priors and interaction data is essential for success.
AI.conclusion: Integrating VLM-derived physical priors with online interaction-based estimation and uncertainty-aware fusion enables more effective sim-to-real transfer for dynamics-sensitive manipulation tasks, as demonstrated by stronger performance and the ablation results.

title: AVoCaDO: An Audiovisual Video Captioner Driven by Temporal Orchestration
summary:
Audiovisual video captioning aims to generate semantically rich descriptions
with temporal alignment between visual and auditory events, thereby benefiting
both video understanding and generation. In this paper, we present AVoCaDO, a
powerful audiovisual video captioner driven by the temporal orchestration
between audio and visual modalities. We propose a two-stage post-training
pipeline: (1) AVoCaDO SFT, which fine-tunes the model on a newly curated
dataset of 107K high-quality, temporally-aligned audiovisual captions; and (2)
AVoCaDO GRPO, which leverages tailored reward functions to further enhance
temporal coherence and dialogue accuracy while regularizing caption length and
reducing collapse. Experimental results demonstrate that AVoCaDO significantly
outperforms existing open-source models across four audiovisual video
captioning benchmarks, and also achieves competitive performance on the VDC and
DREAM-1K benchmark under visual-only settings.

AI.tldr: AVoCaDO introduces a two-stage post-training framework for audiovisual video captioning that achieves superior temporal alignment and outperforms open-source baselines on multiple benchmarks.
AI.motivation: To generate semantically rich, temporally aligned captions by leveraging both audio and visual modalities, addressing temporal coherence, dialogue accuracy, and caption length collapse issues.
AI.method: Stage 1 AVoCaDO SFT: fine-tunes on a curated dataset of 107K temporally-aligned audiovisual captions. Stage 2 AVoCaDO GRPO: uses tailored reward functions to boost temporal coherence and dialogue accuracy while regularizing caption length and reducing collapse.
AI.result: Significantly outperforms existing open-source models on four audiovisual video captioning benchmarks; competitive performance on VDC and DREAM-1K in visual-only settings.
AI.conclusion: A two-stage post-training approach effectively leverages audio-visual signals to produce high-quality, temporally coherent captions with strong benchmark performance and robustness in visual-only scenarios.

title: Skill-Targeted Adaptive Training
summary:
Language models often show little to no improvement (i.e., "saturation") when
trained via vanilla supervised fine-tuning (SFT) on data similar to what they
saw in their training set (e.g., MATH). We introduce a new fine-tuning
strategy, STAT, to train such a student model by using the metacognition
ability of a stronger large language model (LLM) as the teacher. The teacher
uses the task dataset to create a list of skills needed for the task, and then
labels each data point with its required skills (Didolkar et al., 2024). By
monitoring the student's answers, the teacher creates a Missing-Skill-Profile
for the student, tracking how often they failed to apply each skill in their
responses. We use this idea to build a modified training set in one of two
ways. In STAT-Sel, the teacher uses an existing set of training examples but
adaptively reweights them according to the Missing-Skill-Profile. In STAT-Syn,
the teacher synthesizes additional examples involving missing skills. Across
extensive experiments on Llama and Qwen models, our methods yield improvements
of up to 7.5% on MATH, whereas SFT provides only limited gains. Furthermore,
STAT enhances performance on out-of-distribution benchmarks (e.g., AIME24/25,
AMC23, etc.) by an average of 4.6%. Crucially, we find that STAT is
complementary to RL via GRPO (Shao et al., 2024): after the model is improved
using STAT to address skill gaps, GRPO continues to add further gains. We
conclude that skill-targeted adaptive training should broadly improve current
training pipelines. Our code is available at:
https://github.com/princeton-pli/STAT.

AI.tldr: Introduce STAT, a skill-targeted fine-tuning framework where a stronger LLM identifies missing skills per data point and guides adaptive training (reweighting or synthetic data). It yields notable gains on MATH and OOD benchmarks and complements RL with GRPO.
AI.motivation: Overcome saturation of vanilla supervised fine-tuning on data similar to training distribution by diagnosing and addressing skill gaps using an LLM's metacognitive abilities; improve generalization, including out-of-distribution tasks.
AI.method: Teacher-LM analyzes the dataset to enumerate task-required skills and labels examples with these skills; monitor student responses to form a Missing-Skill-Profile; STAT-Sel reweights existing training examples by skill gaps; STAT-Syn generates new examples that target missing skills; experiments on Llama and Qwen; results show compatibility with GRPO.
AI.result: Achieves up to 7.5 percentage-point gains on MATH and about 4.6% average improvement on OOD benchmarks; STAT is complementary to RL via GRPO; code released.
AI.conclusion: Skill-targeted adaptive training can broadly improve SFT pipelines by addressing explicit skill gaps, offering a practical path to better performance and generalization.

title: Mesh-Gait: A Unified Framework for Gait Recognition Through Multi-Modal Representation Learning from 2D Silhouettes
summary:
Gait recognition, a fundamental biometric technology, leverages unique
walking patterns for individual identification, typically using 2D
representations such as silhouettes or skeletons. However, these methods often
struggle with viewpoint variations, occlusions, and noise. Multi-modal
approaches that incorporate 3D body shape information offer improved robustness
but are computationally expensive, limiting their feasibility for real-time
applications. To address these challenges, we introduce Mesh-Gait, a novel
end-to-end multi-modal gait recognition framework that directly reconstructs 3D
representations from 2D silhouettes, effectively combining the strengths of
both modalities. Compared to existing methods, directly learning 3D features
from 3D joints or meshes is complex and difficult to fuse with silhouette-based
gait features. To overcome this, Mesh-Gait reconstructs 3D heatmaps as an
intermediate representation, enabling the model to effectively capture 3D
geometric information while maintaining simplicity and computational
efficiency. During training, the intermediate 3D heatmaps are gradually
reconstructed and become increasingly accurate under supervised learning, where
the loss is calculated between the reconstructed 3D joints, virtual markers,
and 3D meshes and their corresponding ground truth, ensuring precise spatial
alignment and consistent 3D structure. Mesh-Gait extracts discriminative
features from both silhouettes and reconstructed 3D heatmaps in a
computationally efficient manner. This design enables the model to capture
spatial and structural gait characteristics while avoiding the heavy overhead
of direct 3D reconstruction from RGB videos, allowing the network to focus on
motion dynamics rather than irrelevant visual details. Extensive experiments
demonstrate that Mesh-Gait achieves state-of-the-art accuracy. The code will be
released upon acceptance of the paper.

AI.tldr: Mesh-Gait: an end-to-end multi-modal gait recognition framework that reconstructs 3D heatmaps from 2D silhouettes to fuse 3D geometry with silhouette-based features for robust, efficient recognition.
AI.motivation: Gait recognition is vulnerable to viewpoint changes, occlusions, and noise. While multi-modal 3D methods improve robustness, they are often too computationally expensive for real-time use. A lightweight approach that leverages 3D information without full 3D reconstruction is needed.
AI.method: Introduce 3D heatmaps as an intermediate representation reconstructed from 2D silhouettes. Train with supervised losses comparing reconstructed 3D joints, virtual markers, and 3D meshes to ground truth. Extract discriminative features from both silhouettes and reconstructed 3D heatmaps for efficient fusion, enabling robust gait dynamics capture without heavy RGB-based 3D reconstruction.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show state-of-the-art accuracy, validating the effectiveness of the intermediate 3D heatmap approach and the multi-modal fusion strategy.
AI.conclusion: Mesh-Gait offers a computationally efficient, end-to-end framework that leverages 3D geometry through intermediate heatmaps, achieving high accuracy while avoiding costly full 3D reconstruction; code to be released upon acceptance.

title: Efficient Onboard Vision-Language Inference in UAV-Enabled Low-Altitude Economy Networks via LLM-Enhanced Optimization
summary:
The rapid advancement of Low-Altitude Economy Networks (LAENets) has enabled
a variety of applications, including aerial surveillance, environmental
sensing, and semantic data collection. To support these scenarios, unmanned
aerial vehicles (UAVs) equipped with onboard vision-language models (VLMs)
offer a promising solution for real-time multimodal inference. However,
ensuring both inference accuracy and communication efficiency remains a
significant challenge due to limited onboard resources and dynamic network
conditions. In this paper, we first propose a UAV-enabled LAENet system model
that jointly captures UAV mobility, user-UAV communication, and the onboard
visual question answering (VQA) pipeline. Based on this model, we formulate a
mixed-integer non-convex optimization problem to minimize task latency and
power consumption under user-specific accuracy constraints. To solve the
problem, we design a hierarchical optimization framework composed of two parts:
(i) an Alternating Resolution and Power Optimization (ARPO) algorithm for
resource allocation under accuracy constraints, and (ii) a Large Language
Model-augmented Reinforcement Learning Approach (LLaRA) for adaptive UAV
trajectory optimization. The large language model (LLM) serves as an expert in
refining reward design of reinforcement learning in an offline fashion,
introducing no additional latency in real-time decision-making. Numerical
results demonstrate the efficacy of our proposed framework in improving
inference performance and communication efficiency under dynamic LAENet
conditions.

AI.tldr: A UAV-enabled Low-Altitude Economy Network (LAENet) system that uses onboard vision-language models for real-time multimodal inference, with a hierarchical optimization framework (ARPO and LLaRA) to balance task latency, power consumption, and accuracy under dynamic network conditions.
AI.motivation: To enable accurate, efficient real-time multimodal inference on resource-constrained UAVs in LAENets, addressing the trade-off between inference accuracy and communication efficiency amid mobility and varying link conditions.
AI.method: Develop a UAV-LAENet system model capturing UAV mobility, user-UAV communications, and VQA pipeline; formulate a mixed-integer non-convex optimization to minimize latency and energy under user-specific accuracy constraints; solve via a two-component framework: ARPO for resource allocation under accuracy constraints, and LLaRA (LLM-augmented RL) for adaptive UAV trajectory optimization, where the LLM offline-refines the RL reward design to avoid extra real-time latency.
AI.result: Numerical results indicate improved inference performance and communication efficiency under dynamic LAENet conditions.
AI.conclusion: The proposed hierarchical framework effectively improves latency and power efficiency while maintaining accuracy; LLM-assisted offline reward shaping enhances RL-based trajectory optimization without adding real-time latency.

title: Guided Image Feature Matching using Feature Spatial Order
summary:
Image feature matching plays a vital role in many computer vision tasks.
Although many image feature detection and matching techniques have been
proposed over the past few decades, it is still time-consuming to match feature
points in two images, especially for images with a large number of detected
features. Feature spatial order can estimate the probability that a pair of
features is correct. Since it is a completely independent concept from epipolar
geometry, it can be used to complement epipolar geometry in guiding feature
match in a target region so as to improve matching efficiency. In this paper,
we integrate the concept of feature spatial order into a progressive matching
framework. We use some of the initially matched features to build a
computational model of feature spatial order and employs it to calculates the
possible spatial range of subsequent feature matches, thus filtering out
unnecessary feature matches. We also integrate it with epipolar geometry to
further improve matching efficiency and accuracy. Since the spatial order of
feature points is affected by image rotation, we propose a suitable image
alignment method from the fundamental matrix of epipolar geometry to remove the
effect of image rotation. To verify the feasibility of the proposed method, we
conduct a series of experiments, including a standard benchmark dataset,
self-generated simulated images, and real images. The results demonstrate that
our proposed method is significantly more efficient and has more accurate
feature matching than the traditional method.

AI.tldr: A progressive feature-matching method that leverages feature spatial order to prune candidate matches and improve efficiency, augmented by epipolar geometry and rotation-invariant image alignment, yielding faster and more accurate matching on benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Feature matching remains slow for images with many detected features. Feature spatial order is independent of epipolar geometry and can guide match search to reduce computation and improve robustness.
AI.method: Build a model of feature spatial order from initial matches; use it to predict spatial ranges for subsequent matches; filter candidates; integrate with epipolar constraints; handle image rotation by aligning via the fundamental matrix; evaluate on standard and synthetic/real datasets.
AI.result: Experiments show significantly higher efficiency and accuracy than traditional methods, validating the approach across benchmark, simulated, and real-image tests.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating spatial order into progressive matching and aligning with epipolar geometry yields faster, more accurate feature matching and demonstrates potential for scalable matching tasks.

title: Experience-Efficient Model-Free Deep Reinforcement Learning Using Pre-Training
summary:
We introduce PPOPT - Proximal Policy Optimization using Pretraining, a novel,
model-free deep-reinforcement-learning algorithm that leverages pretraining to
achieve high training efficiency and stability on very small training samples
in physics-based environments. Reinforcement learning agents typically rely on
large samples of environment interactions to learn a policy. However, frequent
interactions with a (computer-simulated) environment may incur high
computational costs, especially when the environment is complex. Our main
innovation is a new policy neural network architecture that consists of a
pretrained neural network middle section sandwiched between two fully-connected
networks. Pretraining part of the network on a different environment with
similar physics will help the agent learn the target environment with high
efficiency because it will leverage a general understanding of the
transferrable physics characteristics from the pretraining environment. We
demonstrate that PPOPT outperforms baseline classic PPO on small training
samples both in terms of rewards gained and general training stability. While
PPOPT underperforms against classic model-based methods such as DYNA DDPG, the
model-free nature of PPOPT allows it to train in significantly less time than
its model-based counterparts. Finally, we present our implementation of PPOPT
as open-source software, available at github.com/Davidrxyang/PPOPT.

AI.tldr: PPOPT is a model-free reinforcement learning algorithm that uses a pretrained middle neural network to boost PPO's training efficiency and stability on small-sample physics tasks, achieving better rewards and stability than PPO, but slower than model-based methods like DYNA DDPG; it is open-source.
AI.motivation: Address sample-inefficiency in RL for physics-based environments by leveraging transfer learning from a pretraining environment with similar physics to improve learning efficiency and stability.
AI.method: Introduce PPOPT, a PPO-based algorithm with a neural network architecture that places a pretrained middle section between two fully-connected networks. Pretrain the middle section on a different environment with similar physics, then train the full network with PPO updates in the target environment.
AI.result: PPOPT outperforms classic PPO on small training samples in both rewards and training stability. It underperforms compared to model-based methods like DYNA DDPG, but being model-free, it requires significantly less training time than those counterparts.
AI.conclusion: PPOPT provides improved sample efficiency and stability for physics-based tasks in a model-free setting by leveraging a pretrained network component, offering faster training times than model-based approaches and an open-source implementation.

title: Combo-Gait: Unified Transformer Framework for Multi-Modal Gait Recognition and Attribute Analysis
summary:
Gait recognition is an important biometric for human identification at a
distance, particularly under low-resolution or unconstrained environments.
Current works typically focus on either 2D representations (e.g., silhouettes
and skeletons) or 3D representations (e.g., meshes and SMPLs), but relying on a
single modality often fails to capture the full geometric and dynamic
complexity of human walking patterns. In this paper, we propose a multi-modal
and multi-task framework that combines 2D temporal silhouettes with 3D SMPL
features for robust gait analysis. Beyond identification, we introduce a
multitask learning strategy that jointly performs gait recognition and human
attribute estimation, including age, body mass index (BMI), and gender. A
unified transformer is employed to effectively fuse multi-modal gait features
and better learn attribute-related representations, while preserving
discriminative identity cues. Extensive experiments on the large-scale BRIAR
datasets, collected under challenging conditions such as long-range distances
(up to 1 km) and extreme pitch angles (up to 50{\deg}), demonstrate that our
approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in gait recognition and provides
accurate human attribute estimation. These results highlight the promise of
multi-modal and multitask learning for advancing gait-based human understanding
in real-world scenarios.

AI.tldr: Proposes a multi-modal, multi-task gait analysis framework leveraging 2D silhouettes and 3D SMPL features, fused via a transformer, with multitask learning for gait recognition plus age, BMI, and gender estimation; demonstrates superior performance on challenging BRIAR data.
AI.motivation: Single-modality gait representations (2D silhouettes or 3D meshes) often fail to capture full geometric and dynamic walking patterns, especially in unconstrained, long-range, or extreme-view scenarios. The work aims to improve recognition robustness and add human attribute estimation.
AI.method: Integrates 2D temporal silhouettes with 3D SMPL features; uses a unified transformer to fuse multi-modal gait features; applies multitask learning to jointly perform gait recognition and attribute estimation (age, BMI, gender); evaluated on large-scale BRIAR datasets with long-range distances and extreme pitch angles.
AI.result: Outperforms state-of-the-art gait recognition methods and provides accurate human attribute estimation under challenging conditions.
AI.conclusion: Multi-modal, multitask learning with transformer-based fusion enhances gait-based identification and human attribute understanding in real-world scenarios.

title: FOSSIL: Regret-Minimizing Curriculum Learning for Metadata-Free and Low-Data Mpox Diagnosis
comment:
35 pages, 11 figures, submitted to Computers in Biology and Medicine
  (Elsevier, under review)
summary:
Deep learning in small and imbalanced biomedical datasets remains
fundamentally constrained by unstable optimization and poor generalization. We
present the first biomedical implementation of FOSSIL (Flexible Optimization
via Sample-Sensitive Importance Learning), a regret-minimizing weighting
framework that adaptively balances training emphasis according to sample
difficulty. Using softmax-based uncertainty as a continuous measure of
difficulty, we construct a four-stage curriculum (Easy-Very Hard) and integrate
FOSSIL into both convolutional and transformer-based architectures for Mpox
skin lesion diagnosis. Across all settings, FOSSIL substantially improves
discrimination (AUC = 0.9573), calibration (ECE = 0.053), and robustness under
real-world perturbations, outperforming conventional baselines without
metadata, manual curation, or synthetic augmentation. The results position
FOSSIL as a generalizable, data-efficient, and interpretable framework for
difficulty-aware learning in medical imaging under data scarcity.

AI.tldr: A sample-sensitive, four-stage curriculum (FOSSIL) for medical imaging that balances training emphasis by sample difficulty; enhances AUC, calibration, and robustness in Mpox skin lesion diagnosis using CNN/Transformer models without extra data.
AI.motivation: Small, imbalanced biomedical datasets hamper optimization and generalization. There is a need for data-efficient, interpretable learning that does not rely on metadata or synthetic augmentation.
AI.method: FOSSIL uses softmax-based uncertainty to quantify difficulty, constructs a four-stage Easy–Very Hard curriculum, and applies a regret-minimizing weighting scheme integrated into CNN and transformer architectures for Mpox lesion classification.
AI.result: Across settings, FOSSIL improves discrimination (AUC = 0.9573), calibration (ECE = 0.053), and robustness to real-world perturbations, outperforming conventional baselines without metadata, manual curation, or synthetic augmentation.
AI.conclusion: FOSSIL is a generalizable, data-efficient, and interpretable framework for difficulty-aware learning in medical imaging under data scarcity.

title: MonoSE(3)-Diffusion: A Monocular SE(3) Diffusion Framework for Robust Camera-to-Robot Pose Estimation
summary:
We propose MonoSE(3)-Diffusion, a monocular SE(3) diffusion framework that
formulates markerless, image-based robot pose estimation as a conditional
denoising diffusion process. The framework consists of two processes: a
visibility-constrained diffusion process for diverse pose augmentation and a
timestep-aware reverse process for progressive pose refinement. The diffusion
process progressively perturbs ground-truth poses to noisy transformations for
training a pose denoising network. Importantly, we integrate visibility
constraints into the process, ensuring the transformations remain within the
camera field of view. Compared to the fixed-scale perturbations used in current
methods, the diffusion process generates in-view and diverse training poses,
thereby improving the network generalization capability. Furthermore, the
reverse process iteratively predicts the poses by the denoising network and
refines pose estimates by sampling from the diffusion posterior of current
timestep, following a scheduled coarse-to-fine procedure. Moreover, the
timestep indicates the transformation scales, which guide the denoising network
to achieve more accurate pose predictions. The reverse process demonstrates
higher robustness than direct prediction, benefiting from its timestep-aware
refinement scheme. Our approach demonstrates improvements across two benchmarks
(DREAM and RoboKeyGen), achieving a notable AUC of 66.75 on the most
challenging dataset, representing a 32.3% gain over the state-of-the-art.

AI.tldr: Monocular SE(3) pose estimation via diffusion-based denoising with visibility constraints improves training diversity and robustness, achieving state-of-the-art gains.
AI.motivation: Address limited generalization from fixed-scale pose perturbations and lack of robust image-based monocular SE(3) pose estimation.
AI.method: Two diffusion processes: visibility-constrained pose augmentation and a timestep-aware reverse denoising process; diffusion perturbs ground-truth poses within camera view; reverse process uses denoising network and posterior sampling with coarse-to-fine refinement; timestep encodes transformation scale.
AI.result: Improved generalization and robustness; AUC 66.75 on the hardest dataset; 32.3% improvement over SOTA on DREAM and RoboKeyGen.
AI.conclusion: Diffusion-based, visibility-aware pose estimation with timesteps is effective for image-based monocular pose estimation, yielding stronger performance and generalization.

title: Towards Cybersickness Severity Classification from VR Gameplay Videos Using Transfer Learning and Temporal Modeling
summary:
With the rapid advancement of virtual reality (VR) technology, its adoption
across domains such as healthcare, education, and entertainment has grown
significantly. However, the persistent issue of cybersickness, marked by
symptoms resembling motion sickness, continues to hinder widespread acceptance
of VR. While recent research has explored multimodal deep learning approaches
leveraging data from integrated VR sensors like eye and head tracking, there
remains limited investigation into the use of video-based features for
predicting cybersickness. In this study, we address this gap by utilizing
transfer learning to extract high-level visual features from VR gameplay videos
using the InceptionV3 model pretrained on the ImageNet dataset. These features
are then passed to a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network to capture the
temporal dynamics of the VR experience and predict cybersickness severity over
time. Our approach effectively leverages the time-series nature of video data,
achieving a 68.4% classification accuracy for cybersickness severity. This
surpasses the performance of existing models trained solely on video data,
