providing a practical tool for VR developers to evaluate and mitigate
cybersickness in virtual environments. Furthermore, this work lays the
foundation for future research on video-based temporal modeling for enhancing
user comfort in VR applications.

AI.tldr: Video-based temporal modeling using InceptionV3 features and LSTM predicts cybersickness severity with 68.4% accuracy, addressing the gap where video data alone was underexplored.
AI.motivation: Cybersickness limits VR adoption. While multimodal sensor approaches exist (eye/head tracking), there is limited work using video-based features for cybersickness prediction. A video-based temporal model could offer a practical, non-intrusive tool for developers to assess and mitigate discomfort.
AI.method: Apply transfer learning: extract high-level visual features from VR gameplay videos using InceptionV3 pretrained on ImageNet. Feed the time-series features into an LSTM to capture temporal dynamics and predict cybersickness severity over time (classification task).
AI.result: Achieves 68.4% classification accuracy for cybersickness severity. Outperforms existing models trained solely on video data, suggesting the approach is competitive and practical for VR development.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates the viability of video-based temporal modeling for predicting cybersickness and improving user comfort in VR. Lays groundwork for future work in video-based analyses and prompts exploration of multimodal extensions and more diverse VR scenarios.

title: One4Many-StablePacker: An Efficient Deep Reinforcement Learning Framework for the 3D Bin Packing Problem
summary:
The three-dimensional bin packing problem (3D-BPP) is widely applied in
logistics and warehousing. Existing learning-based approaches often neglect
practical stability-related constraints and exhibit limitations in generalizing
across diverse bin dimensions. To address these limitations, we propose a novel
deep reinforcement learning framework, One4Many-StablePacker (O4M-SP). The
primary advantage of O4M-SP is its ability to handle various bin dimensions in
a single training process while incorporating support and weight constraints
common in practice. Our training method introduces two innovative mechanisms.
First, it employs a weighted reward function that integrates loading rate and a
new height difference metric for packing layouts, promoting improved bin
utilization through flatter packing configurations. Second, it combines clipped
policy gradient optimization with a tailored policy drifting method to mitigate
policy entropy collapse, encouraging exploration at critical decision nodes
during packing to avoid suboptimal solutions. Extensive experiments demonstrate
that O4M-SP generalizes successfully across diverse bin dimensions and
significantly outperforms baseline methods. Furthermore, O4M-SP exhibits strong
practical applicability by effectively addressing packing scenarios with
stability constraints.

AI.tldr: A deep RL framework (O4M-SP) for 3D-BPP that generalizes across multiple bin dimensions within a single training run, incorporating stability constraints. It uses a weighted reward (loading rate + height-difference for flatter layouts) and a clipped policy gradient with policy drifting to sustain exploration, yielding strong generalization and superior performance over baselines.
AI.motivation: To address the lack of stability-related constraints and poor generalization across diverse bin dimensions in existing learning-based 3D-BPP approaches.
AI.method: Propose One4Many-StablePacker (O4M-SP), a deep reinforcement learning framework trained across varying bin dimensions in a single process. The training uses (1) a weighted reward combining loading rate and a height-difference metric to promote flatter, more stable layouts, and (2) a clipped policy gradient optimization with a tailored policy drifting mechanism to prevent entropy collapse and encourage exploration at key packing decisions.
AI.result: O4M-SP generalizes well across diverse bin dimensions and significantly outperforms baseline methods, demonstrating strong practical applicability for stability-constrained packing.
AI.conclusion: O4M-SP provides an effective, generalizable, and practically applicable solution for stability-aware 3D-BPP, addressing both dimension variability and stability constraints in packing.

title: Align2Act: Instruction-Tuned Models for Human-Aligned Autonomous Driving
summary:
Motion planning in complex scenarios is a core challenge in autonomous
driving. Conventional methods apply predefined rules or learn from driving data
to generate trajectories, while recent approaches leverage large language
models (LLMs) for decision-making. However, it remains unclear whether LLMs
truly capture human driving logic. We propose Align2Act, a motion planning
framework that transforms instruction-tuned LLMs into interpretable planners
aligned with human behavior. We derive structured driving instructions based on
human reasoning patterns (e.g., anticipate hazards, yield at intersections) and
traffic rules (e.g., stop at red lights, maintain lane boundaries). Our
Align2ActChain module guides step-by-step reasoning to produce both an
interpretable rationale and a safe trajectory. By fine-tuning LLaMA-2-7B with
LoRA on one million scenarios from the nuPlan dataset, our method achieves an
open-loop score of 85.17 and closed-loop scores of 70.31 (non-reactive) and
66.96 (reactive) on Test14-random. Unlike prior work focused on synthetic or
open-loop settings, we demonstrate improved planning quality and human-likeness
on the real-world nuPlan closed-loop benchmark. Ablation studies confirm that
structured reasoning significantly improves performance over baseline LLM
planners.

AI.tldr: Align2Act transforms instruction-tuned LLMs into interpretable, human-aligned planners for autonomous driving by enforcing structured reasoning and rationale generation, achieving strong open-loop and competitive closed-loop performance on nuPlan.
AI.motivation: Fill the gap where LLM-based planning may not reflect human driving logic or provide interpretable, safe decisions. Create a framework that yields human-like reasoning and traceable trajectories for autonomous driving.
AI.method: Derive structured driving instructions (e.g., anticipate hazards, yield at intersections) and use Align2ActChain for step-by-step reasoning to produce both an interpretable rationale and a safe trajectory. Fine-tune LLaMA-2-7B via LoRA on ~1M nuPlan scenarios; evaluate open-loop and closed-loop performance on Test14-random.
AI.result: The approach delivers an open-loop score of 85.17 and closed-loop scores of 70.31 (non-reactive) and 66.96 (reactive), with improved planning quality and human-likeness on the nuPlan closed-loop benchmark; ablations show structured reasoning boosts performance over baseline LLM planners.
AI.conclusion: Structured reasoning-enabled LLM planners like Align2Act can align decision-making with human driving logic and deliver interpretable, safe motion plans in real-world benchmarks, offering a path beyond purely synthetic or non-interpretable planning.

title: Taming a Retrieval Framework to Read Images in Humanlike Manner for Augmenting Generation of MLLMs
summary:
Multimodal large language models (MLLMs) often fail in fine-grained visual
question answering, producing hallucinations about object identities,
positions, and relations because textual queries are not explicitly anchored to
visual referents. Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) alleviates some errors,
but it fails to align with human-like processing at both the retrieval and
augmentation levels. Specifically, it focuses only on global-level image
information but lacks local detail and limits reasoning about fine-grained
interactions. To overcome this limitation, we present Human-Like
Retrieval-Augmented Generation (HuLiRAG), a framework that stages multimodal
reasoning as a ``what--where--reweight'' cascade. Queries are first anchored to
candidate referents via open-vocabulary detection (what), then spatially
resolved with SAM-derived masks to recover fine-grained precision (where), and
adaptively prioritized through the trade-off between local and global alignment
(reweight). Mask-guided fine-tuning further injects spatial evidence into the
generation process, transforming grounding from a passive bias into an explicit
constraint on answer formulation. Extensive experiments demonstrate that this
human-like cascade improves grounding fidelity and factual consistency while
reducing hallucinations, advancing multimodal question answering toward
trustworthy reasoning.

AI.tldr: A three-stage retrieval-augmented generation framework (HuLiRAG) that mimics human-like processing to ground multimodal QA on visual referents via what-where-reweight, improving grounding and reducing hallucinations.
AI.motivation: MLLMs often hallucinate due to lack of fine-grained grounding; existing RAG is global and ignores local detail; need human-like anchored reasoning to align queries with specific visual referents.
AI.method: What: open-vocabulary object detection anchors queries to referents; Where: SAM-derived masks provide spatially precise grounding; Reweight: adaptive local-global alignment to prioritize relational context; Mask-guided fine-tuning injects spatial evidence as constraints in generation.
AI.result: Empirical results show improved grounding fidelity and factual consistency, reductions in hallucinations, and stronger trustworthy reasoning on multimodal QA tasks.
AI.conclusion: HuLiRAG demonstrates a scalable, human-like reasoning cascade for MLLMs, potentially generalizable to other multimodal tasks while mitigating hallucinations; further work may address detector reliability and efficiency.

title: Translution: Unifying Self-attention and Convolution for Adaptive and Relative Modeling
summary:
When modeling a given type of data, we consider it to involve two key
aspects: 1) identifying relevant elements (e.g., image pixels or textual words)
to a central element, as in a convolutional receptive field, or to a query
element, as in self-attention, and 2) encoding these tokens effectively.
Self-attention can adaptively identify these elements but relies on absolute
positional embedding for structural representation learning. In contrast,
convolution encodes elements in a relative manner, yet their fixed kernel size
limits their ability to adaptively select the relevant elements. In this paper,
we introduce Translution, an operation that unifies the adaptive identification
capability of self-attention and the relative encoding advantage of
convolution. However, this integration leads to a substantial increase in the
number of parameters, exceeding most currently available computational
resources. Therefore, we propose a lightweight variant of Translution, named
{\alpha}-Translution. Experiments on computer vision and natural language
processing tasks show that Translution (including {\alpha}-Translution)
achieves superior accuracy compared to self-attention. The code is available at
https://github.com/hehefan/Translution.

AI.tldr: Translution unifies adaptive element identification (self-attention) with relative encoding (convolution) and introduces a lightweight variant, α-Translution. It outperforms self-attention on computer vision and natural language processing tasks; code is released.
AI.motivation: Self-attention learns structure via absolute positional embeddings but can be parameter-heavy and data-hungry; convolution encodes elements relatively but fixed kernel sizes limit adaptivity. The goal is a unified operation that combines adaptive identification with relative encoding while keeping parameters manageable.
AI.method: Define Translution as a fusion of adaptive element identification and relative encoding. Develop α-Translution, a lightweight variant with reduced parameter count. Validate on computer vision and natural language processing tasks, comparing against self-attention baselines. Provide source code.
AI.result: Translution (and α-Translution) achieves superior accuracy compared to self-attention baselines on the tested CV and NLP tasks. The lightweight variant maintains performance with a substantially lower parameter count.
AI.conclusion: Translution offers a new, unified approach that leverages the strengths of self-attention and convolution. The α-Translution variant makes the approach practical by reducing parameters, and the approach is demonstrated across vision and language tasks, with code available for reproducibility.

title: ADEPT: Continual Pretraining via Adaptive Expansion and Dynamic Decoupled Tuning
summary:
Conventional continual pretraining (CPT) for large language model (LLM)
domain adaptation often suffers from catastrophic forgetting and limited domain
capacity. Existing strategies adopt layer expansion, introducing additional
trainable parameters to accommodate new knowledge. However, the uniform
expansion and updates still entangle general and domain learning, undermining
its effectiveness. Our pilot studies reveal that LLMs exhibit functional
specialization, where layers and units differentially encode general-critical
capabilities, suggesting that parameter expansion and optimization should be
function-aware. We then propose ADEPT, Adaptive Expansion and Dynamic Decoupled
Tuning for continual pretraining, a two-stage framework for domain-adaptive
CPT. ADEPT first performs General-Competence Guided Selective Layer Expansion,
duplicating layers least critical for the general domain to increase
representational capacity while minimizing interference with general knowledge.
It then applies Adaptive Unit-Wise Decoupled Tuning, disentangling parameter
units within expanded layers according to their general-domain importance and
assigning asymmetric learning rates to balance knowledge injection and
retention. Experiments on mathematical and medical benchmarks show that ADEPT
outperforms full-parameter CPT by up to 5.76% on the general domain and 5.58%
on the target domain with only 15% of parameters tuned and less than 50%
training time. Ablation studies, theoretical analysis, and extended
investigations further demonstrate the necessity of targeted expansion and
decoupled optimization, providing new principles for efficient and robust
domain-adaptive CPT. Our code is open-sourced at
https://github.com/PuppyKnightUniversity/ADEPT

AI.tldr: ADEPT: a two-stage, function-aware CPT method that selectively expands layers and performs unit-wise, decoupled tuning to improve domain adaptation with minimal parameter updates and training time.
AI.motivation: Conventional continual pretraining suffers from catastrophic forgetting and limited domain capacity. By recognizing functional specialization in LLMs, the method aims to expand and tune selectively to minimize interference between general and domain-specific knowledge.
AI.method: Stage 1: General-Competence Guided Selective Layer Expansion—duplicate layers least critical for the general domain to boost capacity with minimal interference. Stage 2: Adaptive Unit-Wise Decoupled Tuning—within expanded layers, disentangle parameter units by general-domain importance and apply asymmetric learning rates to balance knowledge injection and retention.
AI.result: ADEPT outperforms full-parameter CPT by up to 5.76% on the general domain and 5.58% on the target domain, using only 15% of parameters tuned and with less than 50% of the training time.
AI.conclusion: Targeted, function-aware expansion and decoupled optimization are necessary for efficient and robust domain-adaptive CPT. The approach provides new principles for efficient adaptation, with open-source code available.

title: DKPMV: Dense Keypoints Fusion from Multi-View RGB Frames for 6D Pose Estimation of Textureless Objects
summary:
6D pose estimation of textureless objects is valuable for industrial robotic
applications, yet remains challenging due to the frequent loss of depth
information. Current multi-view methods either rely on depth data or
insufficiently exploit multi-view geometric cues, limiting their performance.
In this paper, we propose DKPMV, a pipeline that achieves dense keypoint-level
fusion using only multi-view RGB images as input. We design a three-stage
progressive pose optimization strategy that leverages dense multi-view keypoint
geometry information. To enable effective dense keypoint fusion, we enhance the
keypoint network with attentional aggregation and symmetry-aware training,
improving prediction accuracy and resolving ambiguities on symmetric objects.
Extensive experiments on the ROBI dataset demonstrate that DKPMV outperforms
state-of-the-art multi-view RGB approaches and even surpasses the RGB-D methods
in the majority of cases. The code will be available soon.

AI.tldr: DKPMV presents dense keypoint-level fusion from multi-view RGB to estimate 6D pose of textureless objects without depth data, using a three-stage optimization and symmetry-aware, attentional keypoint network; achieves state-of-the-art among RGB-based multi-view methods and often outperforms RGB-D methods on ROBI dataset.
AI.motivation: Textureless object pose estimation remains challenging due to depth data loss; existing multi-view RGB methods underutilize geometric cues or rely on depth. There is a need for robust dense keypoint fusion using only RGB across views.
AI.method: A three-stage progressive pose optimization pipeline (DKPMV) that performs dense keypoint fusion from multi-view RGB. The keypoint network is enhanced with attentional aggregation and symmetry-aware training to improve accuracy and resolve symmetries. The approach operates purely on RGB data across multiple views.
AI.result: On ROBI dataset, DKPMV outperforms state-of-the-art multi-view RGB methods and often surpasses RGB-D methods. The authors report strong improvements across experiments, indicating the effectiveness of dense keypoint fusion and symmetry-aware training.
AI.conclusion: Dense multi-view RGB pose estimation with attentive, symmetry-aware keypoint fusion and a staged optimization can rival, and in many cases exceed, RGB-D approaches for textureless object 6D pose, highlighting the value of dense multi-view geometric cues and robust keypoint predictions.

title: On the Problem of Consistent Anomalies in Zero-Shot Industrial Anomaly Detection
summary:
Zero-shot image anomaly classification (AC) and segmentation (AS) are vital
for industrial quality control, detecting defects without prior training data.
Existing representation-based methods compare patch features with nearest
neighbors in unlabeled test images but struggle with consistent anomalies --
similar defects recurring across multiple images -- resulting in poor AC/AS
performance. We introduce Consistent-Anomaly Detection Graph (CoDeGraph), a
novel algorithm that identifies and filters consistent anomalies from
similarity computations. Our key insight is that normal patches in industrial
images show stable, gradually increasing similarity to other test images, while
consistent-anomaly patches exhibit abrupt similarity spikes after exhausting a
limited set of similar matches, a phenomenon we term ``neighbor-burnout.''
CoDeGraph constructs an image-level graph, with images as nodes and edges
connecting those with shared consistent-anomaly patterns, using community
detection to filter these anomalies. We provide a theoretical foundation using
Extreme Value Theory to explain the effectiveness of our approach. Experiments
on MVTec AD with the ViT-L-14-336 backbone achieve 98.3% AUROC for AC and AS
performance of 66.8% (+4.2%) F1 and 68.1% (+5.4%) AP over state-of-the-art
zero-shot methods. Using the DINOv2 backbone further improves segmentation,
yielding 69.1% (+6.5%) F1 and 71.9% (+9.2%) AP, demonstrating robustness across
architectures.

AI.tldr: CoDeGraph uses neighbor-burnout to detect and filter consistent anomalies, building an image-level graph to isolate anomalies; this yields strong zero-shot AC/AS performance on MVTec AD across ViT and DINOv2 backbones.
AI.motivation: Industrial quality control requires zero-shot anomaly detection and segmentation without labeled defect data. Existing representation-based methods struggle with consistent, recurring anomalies across images, limiting AC/AS performance.
AI.method: Identify stable normal-patch similarities and abrupt similarity spikes for consistent anomalies (neighbor-burnout). Construct an image-level graph where nodes are images and edges connect images sharing consistent-anomaly patterns; apply community detection to filter anomalies. Provide theoretical grounding via Extreme Value Theory.
AI.result: On MVTec AD with ViT-L-14-336: AC AUROC 98.3%; AS: F1 66.8% (+4.2%), AP 68.1% (+5.4%). With DINOv2 backbone: F1 69.1% (+6.5%), AP 71.9% (+9.2%). Demonstrates robustness across architectures and surpasses state-of-the-art zero-shot methods.
AI.conclusion: CoDeGraph effectively filters consistent anomalies through a graph-based community-detection approach grounded in Extreme Value Theory, delivering strong zero-shot AC/AS performance and generalizing across backbones.

title: Gradient-based Model Shortcut Detection for Time Series Classification
summary:
Deep learning models have attracted lots of research attention in time series
classification (TSC) task in the past two decades. Recently, deep neural
networks (DNN) have surpassed classical distance-based methods and achieved
state-of-the-art performance. Despite their promising performance, deep neural
networks (DNNs) have been shown to rely on spurious correlations present in the
training data, which can hinder generalization. For instance, a model might
incorrectly associate the presence of grass with the label ``cat" if the
training set have majority of cats lying in grassy backgrounds. However, the
shortcut behavior of DNNs in time series remain under-explored. Most existing
shortcut work are relying on external attributes such as gender, patients
group, instead of focus on the internal bias behavior in time series models.
  In this paper, we take the first step to investigate and establish
point-based shortcut learning behavior in deep learning time series
classification. We further propose a simple detection method based on other
class to detect shortcut occurs without relying on test data or clean training
classes. We test our proposed method in UCR time series datasets.

AI.tldr: Introduces point-based shortcut learning in time-series classification, proposes a testable detection method that relies on other classes rather than test data or clean labels, and validates on UCR datasets.
AI.motivation: DNNs in time-series classification (TSC) rely on spurious correlations, harming generalization; shortcut behavior in time series is under-explored and prior work often relies on external attributes; study internal biases and develop detection methods.
AI.method: Define point-based shortcut learning in TSC and present a simple detection approach using information from other classes that does not require test data or clean training classes.
AI.result: Applied the detection method to UCR datasets, demonstrating feasibility of detecting point-based shortcuts; results support the existence of shortcut learning and the utility of the proposed detector.
AI.conclusion: This work begins the study of point-based shortcut learning in deep TSC, introduces a data-efficient detector, and suggests directions for mitigating shortcuts in time-series models.

title: REACT3D: Recovering Articulations for Interactive Physical 3D Scenes
summary:
Interactive 3D scenes are increasingly vital for embodied intelligence, yet
existing datasets remain limited due to the labor-intensive process of
annotating part segmentation, kinematic types, and motion trajectories. We
present REACT3D, a scalable zero-shot framework that converts static 3D scenes
into simulation-ready interactive replicas with consistent geometry, enabling
direct use in diverse downstream tasks. Our contributions include: (i)
openable-object detection and segmentation to extract candidate movable parts
from static scenes, (ii) articulation estimation that infers joint types and
motion parameters, (iii) hidden-geometry completion followed by interactive
object assembly, and (iv) interactive scene integration in widely supported
formats to ensure compatibility with standard simulation platforms. We achieve
state-of-the-art performance on detection/segmentation and articulation metrics
across diverse indoor scenes, demonstrating the effectiveness of our framework
and providing a practical foundation for scalable interactive scene generation,
thereby lowering the barrier to large-scale research on articulated scene
understanding. Our project page is
\textit{\hypersetup{urlcolor=black}\href{https://react3d.github.io/}{react3d.github.io}}.

AI.tldr: A zero-shot pipeline (REACT3D) converts static 3D scenes into simulation-ready, interactive articulated scenes by detecting openable parts, estimating joints/parameters, completing hidden geometry, and exporting into common formats; achieves state-of-the-art on relevant metrics and enables scalable interactive scene generation.
AI.motivation: Annotating part segmentation, kinematic types, and motion trajectories is labor-intensive. A scalable, zero-shot framework to generate interactive, articulation-aware scenes from static environments would accelerate research in embodied AI and articulated scene understanding.
AI.method: A four-stage pipeline: (i) openable-object detection and segmentation to identify movable parts in static scenes, (ii) articulation estimation to infer joint types and motion parameters, (iii) hidden-geometry completion followed by interactive object assembly, (iv) interactive scene integration by exporting to widely supported formats for standard simulation platforms. The approach is zero-shot, aiming for generalization across diverse indoor scenes.
AI.result: Demonstrates state-of-the-art performance on detection/segmentation and articulation metrics across diverse indoor scenes; validates scalability and practicality for generating interactive scenes; provides a foundation for large-scale research into articulated scene understanding.
AI.conclusion: REACT3D offers a scalable, zero-shot solution to create interactive articulated scenes from static data, lowering barriers to large-scale research in articulated scene understanding and facilitating broader adoption of interactive simulations across downstream tasks.

title: Learning from Disagreement: A Group Decision Simulation Framework for Robust Medical Image Segmentation
summary:
Medical image segmentation annotation suffers from inter-rater variability
(IRV) due to differences in annotators' expertise and the inherent blurriness
of medical images. Standard approaches that simply average expert labels are
flawed, as they discard the valuable clinical uncertainty revealed in
disagreements. We introduce a fundamentally new approach with our group
decision simulation framework, which works by mimicking the collaborative
decision-making process of a clinical panel. Under this framework, an Expert
Signature Generator (ESG) learns to represent individual annotator styles in a
unique latent space. A Simulated Consultation Module (SCM) then intelligently
generates the final segmentation by sampling from this space. This method
achieved state-of-the-art results on challenging CBCT and MRI datasets (92.11%
and 90.72% Dice scores). By treating expert disagreement as a useful signal
instead of noise, our work provides a clear path toward more robust and
trustworthy AI systems for healthcare.

AI.tldr: A group decision simulation framework that models annotator styles and uses a simulated consultation to produce final segmentation, turning disagreement into a signal and achieving state-of-the-art Dice on CBCT and MRI datasets.
AI.motivation: Inter-rater variability in medical image segmentation arises from differences in annotator expertise and inherent image blurriness; simply averaging labels discards useful clinical uncertainty.
AI.method: Expert Signature Generator (ESG) learns a latent space representing individual annotator styles; Simulated Consultation Module (SCM) samples from this space to generate the final segmentation, mimicking a clinical panel decision.
AI.result: State-of-the-art Dice scores on challenging CBCT and MRI datasets: 92.11% and 90.72%.
AI.conclusion: Treat expert disagreement as a useful signal rather than noise, paving the way for more robust and trustworthy AI systems in healthcare.

title: What Makes Looped Transformers Perform Better Than Non-Recursive Ones (Provably)
summary:
While looped transformers (termed as Looped-Attn) often outperform standard
transformers (termed as Single-Attn) on complex reasoning tasks, the
theoretical basis for this advantage remains underexplored. In this paper, we
explain this phenomenon through the lens of loss landscape geometry, inspired
by empirical observations of their distinct dynamics at both sample and Hessian
levels. To formalize this, we extend the River-Valley landscape model by
distinguishing between U-shaped valleys (flat) and V-shaped valleys (steep).
Based on empirical observations, we conjecture that the recursive architecture
of Looped-Attn induces a landscape-level inductive bias towards River-V-Valley.
Theoretical derivations based on this inductive bias guarantee a better loss
convergence along the river due to valley hopping, and further encourage
learning about complex patterns compared to the River-U-Valley induced by
Single-Attn. Building on this insight, we propose SHIFT (Staged HIerarchical
Framework for Progressive Training), a staged training framework that
accelerates the training process of Looped-Attn while achieving comparable
performances.

AI.tldr: Looped-attention models outperform standard transformers due to an inductive bias embedded in a loss-landscape geometry. By extending a River–Valley landscape to include flat (River-U) and steep (River-V) valleys, the recursive Looped-Attn is hypothesized to prefer River-V valleys, enabling faster convergence through valley hopping and better learning of complex patterns. A staged hierarchical training framework (SHIFT) is proposed to accelerate training of Looped-Attn while matching performance.
AI.motivation: Theoretical grounding for the empirical advantage of looped transformers is lacking. The paper seeks to connect architecture-induced dynamics (sample and Hessian behavior) to loss-landscape geometry, offering a principled explanation for when and why Looped-Attn helps on complex reasoning tasks.
AI.method: Extend the River–Valley landscape model by distinguishing flat (U-shaped) valleys and steep (V-shaped) valleys. Propose a conjectured inductive bias that Looped-Attn steers optimization toward River-V-Valleys. Provide theoretical derivations showing improved convergence along river paths via valley hopping and enhanced learning of complex patterns. Introduce SHIFT (Staged HIerarchical Framework for Progressive Training) to accelerate Looped-Attn training while retaining performance.
AI.result: Theoretical results indicate better loss convergence along River–Valley paths due to valley hopping and enhanced learning of complex patterns under the Looped-Attn bias. SHIFT is proposed as a practical training framework to speed up training without sacrificing accuracy, enabling comparable performance to standard approaches with less training time.
AI.conclusion: Looped attention's practical advantage can be rooted in loss-landscape geometry; a staged training approach (SHIFT) can realize efficient training while preserving or matching the performance gains, justifying the architectural choice for complex reasoning tasks.

title: Context-Aware Model-Based Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Racing
summary:
Autonomous vehicles have shown promising potential to be a groundbreaking
technology for improving the safety of road users. For these vehicles, as well
as many other safety-critical robotic technologies, to be deployed in
real-world applications, we require algorithms that can generalize well to
unseen scenarios and data. Model-based reinforcement learning algorithms (MBRL)
have demonstrated state-of-the-art performance and data efficiency across a
diverse set of domains. However, these algorithms have also shown
susceptibility to changes in the environment and its transition dynamics.
  In this work, we explore the performance and generalization capabilities of
MBRL algorithms for autonomous driving, specifically in the simulated
autonomous racing environment, Roboracer (formerly F1Tenth). We frame the
head-to-head racing task as a learning problem using contextual Markov decision
processes and parameterize the driving behavior of the adversaries using the
context of the episode, thereby also parameterizing the transition and reward
dynamics. We benchmark the behavior of MBRL algorithms in this environment and
propose a novel context-aware extension of the existing literature, cMask. We
demonstrate that context-aware MBRL algorithms generalize better to
out-of-distribution adversary behaviors relative to context-free approaches. We
also demonstrate that cMask displays strong generalization capabilities, as
well as further performance improvement relative to other context-aware MBRL
approaches when racing against adversaries with in-distribution behaviors.

AI.tldr: Context-aware model-based RL with cMask improves generalization to unseen adversary behaviors in autonomous racing; shows better out-of-distribution generalization and superior performance against in-distribution adversaries compared to other baselines.
AI.motivation: Autonomous driving demands robust generalization and safety. Model-based RL is data-efficient but sensitive to environment/transition changes. There is a need for methods that generalize to unseen contexts, including adversarial behaviors, in safety-critical driving tasks.
AI.method: Frame the racing task as contextual Markov decision processes. Parameterize adversary behavior using the episode context, thereby conditioning the transition and reward dynamics. Propose cMask, a context-aware extension of existing MBRL approaches. Benchmark in Roboracer (F1Tenth) against context-free and other context-aware baselines.
AI.result: Context-aware MBRL generalizes better to out-of-distribution adversary behaviors. cMask shows strong generalization and further performance improvement relative to other context-aware MBRL approaches when racing against adversaries with in-distribution behaviors.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating context into MBRL improves generalization in safety-critical autonomous driving tasks; cMask is an effective context-aware extension with strong performance across both out-of-distribution and in-distribution adversarial settings.

title: Post-TIPS Prediction via Multimodal Interaction: A Multi-Center Dataset and Framework for Survival, Complication, and Portal Pressure Assessment
summary:
Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) is an established
procedure for portal hypertension, but provides variable survival outcomes and
frequent overt hepatic encephalopathy (OHE), indicating the necessity of
accurate preoperative prognostic modeling. Current studies typically build
machine learning models from preoperative CT images or clinical
characteristics, but face three key challenges: (1) labor-intensive
region-of-interest (ROI) annotation, (2) poor reliability and generalizability
of unimodal methods, and (3) incomplete assessment from single-endpoint
prediction. Moreover, the lack of publicly accessible datasets constrains
research in this field. Therefore, we present MultiTIPS, the first public
multi-center dataset for TIPS prognosis, and propose a novel multimodal
prognostic framework based on it. The framework comprises three core modules:
(1) dual-option segmentation, which integrates semi-supervised and foundation
model-based pipelines to achieve robust ROI segmentation with limited
annotations and facilitate subsequent feature extraction; (2) multimodal
interaction, where three techniques, multi-grained radiomics attention (MGRA),
progressive orthogonal disentanglement (POD), and clinically guided prognostic
enhancement (CGPE), are introduced to enable cross-modal feature interaction
and complementary representation integration, thus improving model accuracy and
robustness; and (3) multi-task prediction, where a staged training strategy is
used to perform stable optimization of survival, portal pressure gradient
(PPG), and OHE prediction for comprehensive prognostic assessment. Extensive
experiments on MultiTIPS demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method
over state-of-the-art approaches, along with strong cross-domain generalization
and interpretability, indicating its promise for clinical application. The
dataset and code are available.

AI.tldr: Public dataset MultiTIPS enables multimodal, multi-task prognosis for TIPS with a robust segmentation framework and superior cross-domain performance.
AI.motivation: TIPS prognosis is challenged by ROI annotation burden, unimodal limitations, and single-endpoint predictions; public data is lacking, hindering progress.
AI.method: Three-module framework: (1) dual-option segmentation (semi-supervised + foundation-model-based); (2) multimodal interaction (MGRA, POD, CGPE) for cross-modal feature fusion; (3) multi-task prediction with staged training for survival, portal pressure gradient, and OHE; evaluation on MultiTIPS shows improved accuracy and generalization.
AI.result: Outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, demonstrates strong cross-domain generalization and interpretability; reliable ROI segmentation with limited annotations; provides dataset and code.
AI.conclusion: MultiTIPS advances TIPS prognosis research by offering a public resource and a robust, interpretable multimodal framework suitable for clinical translation.

title: Rademacher Meets Colors: More Expressivity, but at What Cost ?
summary:
The expressive power of graph neural networks (GNNs) is typically understood
through their correspondence with graph isomorphism tests such as the
Weisfeiler-Leman (WL) hierarchy. While more expressive GNNs can distinguish a
richer set of graphs, they are also observed to suffer from higher
generalization error. This work provides a theoretical explanation for this
trade-off by linking expressivity and generalization through the lens of
coloring algorithms. Specifically, we show that the number of equivalence
classes induced by WL colorings directly bounds the GNNs Rademacher complexity
-- a key data-dependent measure of generalization. Our analysis reveals that
greater expressivity leads to higher complexity and thus weaker generalization
guarantees. Furthermore, we prove that the Rademacher complexity is stable
under perturbations in the color counts across different samples, ensuring
robustness to sampling variability across datasets. Importantly, our framework
is not restricted to message-passing GNNs or 1-WL, but extends to arbitrary GNN
architectures and expressivity measures that partition graphs into equivalence
classes. These results unify the study of expressivity and generalization in
GNNs, providing a principled understanding of why increasing expressive power
often comes at the cost of generalization.

AI.tldr: Increasing GNN expressivity via WL colorings increases the number of equivalence classes, which raises Rademacher complexity and weakens generalization; the framework shows stability to sampling perturbations and extends beyond 1-WL.
AI.motivation: Explain the observed trade-off between expressivity and generalization in GNNs by linking expressivity to dataset-dependent complexity through WL colorings and Rademacher complexity.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis deriving bounds: the number of WL-induced equivalence classes bounds Rademacher complexity; show stability of this complexity under perturbations of color counts across samples; generalization results extend to arbitrary GNN architectures and color-based partitions.
AI.result: Greater expressivity yields higher Rademacher complexity and weaker generalization guarantees; Rademacher complexity is stable to sampling variability; the framework unifies expressivity and generalization across GNNs.
AI.conclusion: This framework explains the trade-off and provides principled understanding; applicability beyond MP-GNNs and 1-WL; guides design of GNNs balancing expressivity and generalization.

title: When Images Speak Louder: Mitigating Language Bias-induced Hallucinations in VLMs through Cross-Modal Guidance
summary:
Vision-Language Models (VLMs) have shown solid ability for multimodal
understanding of both visual and language contexts. However, existing VLMs
often face severe challenges of hallucinations, meaning that VLMs tend to
generate responses that are only fluent in the language but irrelevant to
images in previous contexts. To address this issue, we analyze how language
bias contributes to hallucinations and then introduce Cross-Modal
Guidance(CMG), a training-free decoding method that addresses the
hallucinations by leveraging the difference between the output distributions of
the original model and the one with degraded visual-language attention. In
practice, we adaptively mask the attention weight of the most influential image
tokens in selected transformer layers to corrupt the visual-language perception
as a concrete type of degradation. Such a degradation-induced decoding
emphasizes the perception of visual contexts and therefore significantly
reduces language bias without harming the ability of VLMs. In experiment
sections, we conduct comprehensive studies. All results demonstrate the
superior advantages of CMG with neither additional conditions nor training
costs. We also quantitatively show CMG can improve different VLM's performance
on hallucination-specific benchmarks and generalize effectively.

AI.tldr: Cross-Modal Guidance (CMG) is a training-free decoding method that reduces hallucinations in Vision-Language Models by degrading visual-language attention to emphasize visual context, improving alignment without extra training.
AI.motivation: Vision-Language Models often hallucinate by exploiting language priors; there is a need for a decoding-time mechanism that mitigates language bias without retraining.
AI.method: During decoding, CMG adaptively masks the attention weights of the most influential image tokens in selected transformer layers to degrade visual-language perception, then uses the difference between the output distributions of the original model and the degraded-model to guide decoding.
AI.result: CMG reduces language bias and hallucinations across hallucination-specific benchmarks, improves different VLMs' performance on such benchmarks, and generalizes effectively, all without additional training or cost.
AI.conclusion: A training-free decoding-time intervention that strengthens visual grounding in VLMs by perturbing visual-context attention, yielding better alignment with images without sacrificing fluency.

title: PANTHER: Generative Pretraining Beyond Language for Sequential User Behavior Modeling
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) have shown that generative pretraining can
distill vast world knowledge into compact token representations. While LLMs
encapsulate extensive world knowledge, they remain limited in modeling the
behavioral knowledge contained within user interaction histories. User behavior
forms a distinct modality, where each action, defined by multi-dimensional
attributes such as time, context, and transaction type, constitutes a
behavioral token. Modeling these high-cardinality sequences is challenging, and
discriminative models often falter under limited supervision. To bridge this
gap, we extend generative pretraining to user behavior, learning transferable
representations from unlabeled behavioral data analogous to how LLMs learn from
text. We present PANTHER, a hybrid generative-discriminative framework that
unifies user behavior pretraining and downstream adaptation, enabling
large-scale sequential user representation learning and real-time inference.
PANTHER introduces: (1) Structured Tokenization to compress multi-dimensional
transaction attributes into an interpretable vocabulary; (2) Sequence Pattern
Recognition Module (SPRM) for modeling periodic transaction motifs; (3) a
Unified User-Profile Embedding that fuses static demographics with dynamic
transaction histories; and (4) Real-time scalability enabled by offline caching
of pretrained embeddings for millisecond-level inference. Fully deployed and
operational online at WeChat Pay, PANTHER delivers a 25.6 percent boost in
next-transaction prediction HitRate@1 and a 38.6 percent relative improvement
in fraud detection recall over baselines. Cross-domain evaluations on public
benchmarks show strong generalization, achieving up to 21 percent HitRate@1
gains over transformer baselines, establishing PANTHER as a scalable,
high-performance framework for industrial sequential user behavior modeling.

AI.tldr: A hybrid generative–discriminative framework (PANTHER) for scalable sequential user behavior modeling that pretrains on unlabeled behavior data and adapts for downstream tasks.
AI.motivation: Bridge the gap between LLM-style pretraining on text and modeling high-cardinality, multi-attribute user behavior sequences; enable transferable, real-time representations from unlabeled data for tasks like next-transaction prediction and fraud detection.
AI.method: Structured Tokenization to compress multi-dimensional attributes into a discrete vocabulary; Sequence Pattern Recognition Module (SPRM) to model periodic motifs; Unified User-Profile Embedding combining static demographics with dynamic histories; offline embedding caching to enable millisecond online inference.
AI.result: Deployed at WeChat Pay with a 25.6% lift in HitRate@1 for next-transaction prediction and a 38.6% relative improvement in fraud-detection recall over baselines; public benchmarks show up to 21% HitRate@1 gains over transformer baselines.
AI.conclusion: PANTHER demonstrates scalable, high-performance sequential user representation learning by unifying pretraining and downstream adaptation, with strong industrial deployment and cross-domain generalization.

title: DAGLFNet:Deep Attention-Guided Global-Local Feature Fusion for Pseudo-Image Point Cloud Segmentation
summary:
Environmental perception systems play a critical role in high-precision
mapping and autonomous navigation, with LiDAR serving as a core sensor that
provides accurate 3D point cloud data. How to efficiently process unstructured
point clouds while extracting structured semantic information remains a
significant challenge, and in recent years, numerous pseudo-image-based
representation methods have emerged to achieve a balance between efficiency and
performance. However, they often overlook the structural and semantic details
of point clouds, resulting in limited feature fusion and discriminability. In
this work, we propose DAGLFNet, a pseudo-image-based semantic segmentation
framework designed to extract discriminative features. First, the Global-Local
Feature Fusion Encoding module is used to enhance the correlation among local
features within a set and capture global contextual information. Second, the
Multi-Branch Feature Extraction network is employed to capture more
neighborhood information and enhance the discriminability of contour features.
Finally, a Feature Fusion via Deep Feature-guided Attention mechanism is
introduced to improve the precision of cross-channel feature fusion.
Experimental evaluations show that DAGLFNet achieves 69.83\% and 78.65\% on the
validation sets of SemanticKITTI and nuScenes, respectively. The method
balances high performance with real-time capability, demonstrating great
potential for LiDAR-based real-time applications.

AI.tldr: DAGLFNet is a real-time pseudo-image-based LiDAR semantic segmentation framework that uses global-local feature fusion, multi-branch extraction, and attention-guided feature fusion to achieve competitive results on SemanticKITTI and nuScenes.
AI.motivation: Efficiently converting unstructured LiDAR point clouds into structured semantic representations while preserving structural and semantic details; existing pseudo-image methods trade discriminability for speed.
AI.method: Global-Local Feature Fusion Encoding to enhance local-to-global relations; Multi-Branch Feature Extraction to capture varied neighborhood information and refine contour features; Deep Feature-guided Attention for cross-channel feature fusion.
AI.result: Reported validation accuracies of 69.83% on SemanticKITTI and 78.65% on nuScenes, indicating strong accuracy with real-time capability.
AI.conclusion: The architecture achieves discriminative, robust segmentation with a balance of accuracy and efficiency, showing potential for real-time LiDAR-based applications.

title: Lighter-X: An Efficient and Plug-and-play Strategy for Graph-based Recommendation through Decoupled Propagation
summary:
Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have demonstrated remarkable effectiveness in
recommendation systems. However, conventional graph-based recommenders, such as
LightGCN, require maintaining embeddings of size $d$ for each node, resulting
in a parameter complexity of $\mathcal{O}(n \times d)$, where $n$ represents
the total number of users and items. This scaling pattern poses significant
challenges for deployment on large-scale graphs encountered in real-world
applications. To address this scalability limitation, we propose
\textbf{Lighter-X}, an efficient and modular framework that can be seamlessly
integrated with existing GNN-based recommender architectures. Our approach
substantially reduces both parameter size and computational complexity while
preserving the theoretical guarantees and empirical performance of the base
models, thereby enabling practical deployment at scale. Specifically, we
analyze the original structure and inherent redundancy in their parameters,
identifying opportunities for optimization. Based on this insight, we propose
an efficient compression scheme for the sparse adjacency structure and
high-dimensional embedding matrices, achieving a parameter complexity of
$\mathcal{O}(h \times d)$, where $h \ll n$. Furthermore, the model is optimized
through a decoupled framework, reducing computational complexity during the
training process and enhancing scalability. Extensive experiments demonstrate
that Lighter-X achieves comparable performance to baseline models with
significantly fewer parameters. In particular, on large-scale interaction
graphs with millions of edges, we are able to attain even better results with
only 1\% of the parameter over LightGCN.

AI.tldr: Lighter-X compresses GNN-based recommender models to dramatically reduce parameter count and computation while preserving performance, enabling scalable deployment. It achieves parameter complexity O(h × d) with h ≪ n by compressing sparse adjacency and high-dimensional embeddings, and uses a decoupled training framework; on large graphs, it attains comparable or better results with only 1% of LightGCN parameters.
AI.motivation: GNN-based recommender systems (e.g., LightGCN) suffer from high parameter and memory costs due to per-node embeddings, hindering deployment on large-scale graphs. There's a need to reduce model size and compute while maintaining performance and guarantees.
AI.method: Propose Lighter-X, a modular compression framework that identifies redundancy in original GNN parameters and applies a sparse-adjacency and embedding matrix compression scheme to achieve parameter complexity O(h × d) (with h ≪ n). It also introduces a decoupled training paradigm to cut training-time computations. The framework is designed to plug into existing GNN-based recommender architectures without changing their core modeling ambitions.
AI.result: Empirical evaluations show Lighter-X matches the performance of baseline models with significantly fewer parameters. On large-scale graphs with millions of edges, it can achieve even better results using only about 1% of the parameters used by LightGCN.
AI.conclusion: Lighter-X offers a scalable, practical solution for deploying GNN-based recommender systems by drastically reducing parameter size and computation while preserving accuracy, and it can be integrated with existing architectures to enable efficient large-scale deployment.

title: MSF-Mamba: Motion-aware State Fusion Mamba for Efficient Micro-Gesture Recognition
summary:
Micro-gesture recognition (MGR) targets the identification of subtle and
fine-grained human motions and requires accurate modeling of both long-range
and local spatiotemporal dependencies. While CNNs are effective at capturing
local patterns, they struggle with long-range dependencies due to their limited
receptive fields. Transformer-based models address this limitation through
self-attention mechanisms but suffer from high computational costs. Recently,
Mamba has shown promise as an efficient model, leveraging state space models
(SSMs) to enable linear-time processing However, directly applying the vanilla
Mamba to MGR may not be optimal. This is because Mamba processes inputs as 1D
sequences, with state updates relying solely on the previous state, and thus
lacks the ability to model local spatiotemporal dependencies. In addition,
previous methods lack a design of motion-awareness, which is crucial in MGR. To
overcome these limitations, we propose motion-aware state fusion mamba
(MSF-Mamba), which enhances Mamba with local spatiotemporal modeling by fusing
local contextual neighboring states. Our design introduces a motion-aware state
fusion module based on central frame difference (CFD). Furthermore, a
multiscale version named MSF-Mamba+ has been proposed. Specifically, MSF-Mamba
supports multiscale motion-aware state fusion, as well as an adaptive scale
weighting module that dynamically weighs the fused states across different
scales. These enhancements explicitly address the limitations of vanilla Mamba
by enabling motion-aware local spatiotemporal modeling, allowing MSF-Mamba and
MSF-Mamba to effectively capture subtle motion cues for MGR. Experiments on two
public MGR datasets demonstrate that even the lightweight version, namely,
MSF-Mamba, achieves SoTA performance, outperforming existing CNN-,
Transformer-, and SSM-based models while maintaining high efficiency.

AI.tldr: MSF-Mamba and MSF-Mamba+ introduce motion-aware local spatiotemporal fusion to the Mamba framework, enabling efficient, state-space-based MGR with multiscale fusion and adaptive weighting, achieving state-of-the-art results on two MGR datasets.
AI.motivation: To address MGR's need to model both long-range dependencies and fine-grained local motion; vanilla Mamba is 1D and lacks local modeling; CNNs/Transformers tradeoffs; goal is a lightweight yet accurate model that is motion-aware.
AI.method: Add motion-aware state fusion module using central frame difference to fuse neighboring states into the Mamba update; extend to multiscale MSF-Mamba+ with adaptive scale weighting to combine information across scales.
AI.result: MSF-Mamba achieves state-of-the-art performance on two public MGR datasets, outperforming CNN-, Transformer-, and SSM-based models while preserving high efficiency; the lightweight version already SoTA.
AI.conclusion: Motion-aware local spatiotemporal modeling via state fusion effectively captures subtle micro-gestures in MGR; multiscale extension offers flexible trade-offs between accuracy and efficiency; MSF-Mamba family advances MGR modeling over vanilla Mamba.

title: Preference-driven Knowledge Distillation for Few-shot Node Classification
summary:
Graph neural networks (GNNs) can efficiently process text-attributed graphs
(TAGs) due to their message-passing mechanisms, but their training heavily
relies on the human-annotated labels. Moreover, the complex and diverse local
topologies of nodes of real-world TAGs make it challenging for a single
mechanism to handle. Large language models (LLMs) perform well in
zero-/few-shot learning on TAGs but suffer from a scalability challenge.
Therefore, we propose a preference-driven knowledge distillation (PKD)
framework to synergize the complementary strengths of LLMs and various GNNs for
few-shot node classification. Specifically, we develop a GNN-preference-driven
node selector that effectively promotes prediction distillation from LLMs to
teacher GNNs. To further tackle nodes' intricate local topologies, we develop a
node-preference-driven GNN selector that identifies the most suitable teacher
GNN for each node, thereby facilitating tailored knowledge distillation from
teacher GNNs to the student GNN. Extensive experiments validate the efficacy of
our proposed framework in few-shot node classification on real-world TAGs.

AI.tldr: A knowledge-distillation framework, PKD, unites LLMs and multiple GNNs for few-shot node classification on text-attributed graphs (TAGs) by two personalized distillation mechanisms: (i) a GNN-preference-driven node selector that guides LLM-to-teacher distillation to GNN teachers, and (ii) a node-preference-driven GNN selector that picks the best teacher per node for tailored distillation to a student GNN.
AI.motivation: GNNs rely on labeled data and struggle with diverse local topologies in real-world TAGs; LLMs excel at zero-/few-shot reasoning but are not scalable for large graphs. Combining both can leverage cheap, broad knowledge from LLMs and specialized graph-structural reasoning from GNNs to improve few-shot node classification.
AI.method: Propose the PKD framework with two components: (1) a GNN-preference-driven node selector that promotes distillation from LLMs to teacher GNNs for node-level predictions, and (2) a node-preference-driven GNN selector that assigns the most suitable teacher GNN per node to enable tailored knowledge distillation to a student GNN. The approach integrates LLM-derived signals and multiple GNN teachers to perform few-shot node classification on TAGs, with experiments on real-world datasets to assess performance.
AI.result: Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of PKD for few-shot node classification on real-world TAGs, showing improved performance over baselines by leveraging both LLMs and multiple GNN teachers through targeted distillation.
AI.conclusion: PKD provides a principled way to synergize LLMs and diverse GNNs for few-shot node classification on TAGs. The selective, per-node and per-teacher distillation mechanisms help address label scarcity and topological heterogeneity, though practical considerations include prompting design, computational costs, and the robustness of selectors.

title: Towards Self-Refinement of Vision-Language Models with Triangular Consistency
summary:
Vision-Language Models (VLMs) integrate visual knowledge with the analytical
capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) through supervised visual
instruction tuning, using image-question-answer triplets. However, the
potential of VLMs trained without supervised instruction remains largely
unexplored. This study validates that VLMs possess inherent self-refinement
capabilities, enabling them to generate high-quality supervised data without
external inputs and thereby learn autonomously. Specifically, to stimulate the
self-refinement ability of VLMs, we propose a self-refinement framework based
on a Triangular Consistency principle: within the image-query-answer triangle,
any masked elements should be consistently and accurately reconstructed. The
framework involves three steps: (1) We enable the instruction generation
ability of VLMs by adding multi-task instruction tuning like
image$\rightarrow$question-answer or image-answer$\rightarrow$question. (2) We
generate image-query-answer triplets from unlabeled images and use the
Triangular Consistency principle for filtering. (3) The model is further
updated using the filtered synthetic data. To investigate the underlying
mechanisms behind this self-refinement capability, we conduct a theoretical
analysis from a causal perspective. Using the widely recognized LLaVA-1.5 as
our baseline, our experiments reveal that the model can autonomously achieve
consistent, though deliberately modest, improvements across multiple benchmarks
without any external supervision, such as human annotations or environmental
feedback. We expect that the insights of this study on the self-refinement
ability of VLMs can inspire future research on the learning mechanism of VLMs.
Code is available at https://github.com/dengyl20/SRF-LLaVA-1.5.

AI.tldr: Vision-Language Models can self-refine and learn autonomously from unlabeled data by generating and filtering pseudo supervision via a Triangular Consistency principle, yielding consistent but modest gains without external supervision when initialized from LLaVA-1.5.
AI.motivation: Address the underexplored potential of VLMs trained without supervised instruction and whether they can leverage self-generated data for autonomous learning.
AI.method: Introduce Triangular Consistency within an image-query-answer triangle. Step 1: enable instruction generation via multi-task instruction tuning (image→question-answer; image-answer→question). Step 2: generate image-query-answer triplets from unlabeled images and filter using Triangular Consistency. Step 3: update the model with the filtered synthetic data. Supplement with a causal-perspective theoretical analysis. Baseline: LLaVA-1.5; evaluation on multiple benchmarks; code provided.
AI.result: Experiments show autonomous, consistent improvements across several benchmarks without external supervision; improvements are modest but robust. The approach demonstrates the viability of self-generated supervision in VLMs.
AI.conclusion: Self-refinement via Triangular Consistency enables VLMs to learn from unlabeled data, offering a path toward reducing reliance on labeled data and stimulating future research on VLM learning mechanisms.

title: CacheClip: Accelerating RAG with Effective KV Cache Reuse
summary:
Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems suffer from severe
time-to-first-token (TTFT) bottlenecks due to long input sequences. Existing KV
cache reuse methods face a fundamental trade-off: prefix caching requires
identical prefixes that rarely occur in RAG scenarios, while direct
precomputation sacrifices quality due to missing inter-chunk attention and
repeated attention sinks. Recent methods like APE and CacheBlend partially
address these issues but remain inadequate for robust RAG applications. This
paper presents CacheClip, a novel framework that achieves both fast TTFT and
high generation quality. Our key insight is that small auxiliary LLMs exhibit
similar last-layer attention distributions to primary LLMs (the target model
for generation), enabling efficient identification of tokens critical for
restoring inter-chunk attention, thereby significantly improving response
quality on cross-chunk reasoning tasks. CacheClip integrates three techniques:
(1) auxiliary-model-guided token selection for selective KV cache
recomputation, where the auxiliary model is finetuned to improve selection
accuracy, (2) shared prefixes to eliminate redundant attention sinks, and (3)
grouping strategy to maintain local coherence during partial KV cache updates.
Experiments show CacheClip retains up to 94.8% and 85.0% of full-attention
performance on NIAH and LongBench, outperforming APE and CacheBlend by 25.2%
and 35.1% on NIAH (with reomp% = 20%). Meanwhile, CacheClip accelerates LLM
inference by up to 1.92x in prefill time, providing a practical solution to the
efficiency-quality trade-off in RAG systems.

AI.tldr: CacheClip accelerates RAG inference by selective KV cache recomputation guided by a small auxiliary LLM, using shared prefixes and grouping to preserve inter-chunk attention, achieving near full-attention quality with up to 1.92x speedup.
AI.motivation: RAG systems suffer from long TTFT due to long input sequences and trade-offs in existing KV-cache methods. There is a need for robust, high-quality cross-chunk reasoning without sacrificing efficiency.
AI.method: Three techniques: (1) auxiliary-model-guided token selection for selective KV cache recomputation with a finetuned auxiliary model for better selection accuracy; (2) shared prefixes to eliminate redundant attention sinks; (3) grouping strategy to maintain local coherence during partial KV cache updates.
AI.result: CacheClip retains 94.8% and 85.0% of full-attention on NIAH and LongBench, outperforming APE and CacheBlend by 25.2% and 35.1% on NIAH (reomp% = 20%). Inference speedup up to 1.92x in prefill time.
AI.conclusion: CacheClip provides an efficient solution to the efficiency-quality trade-off in RAG, enabling robust cross-chunk reasoning with high generation quality and significantly faster inference.

title: Head-wise Adaptive Rotary Positional Encoding for Fine-Grained Image Generation
summary:
Transformers rely on explicit positional encoding to model structure in data.
While Rotary Position Embedding (RoPE) excels in 1D domains, its application to
image generation reveals significant limitations such as fine-grained spatial
relation modeling, color cues, and object counting. This paper identifies key
limitations of standard multi-dimensional RoPE-rigid frequency allocation,
axis-wise independence, and uniform head treatment-in capturing the complex
structural biases required for fine-grained image generation. We propose
HARoPE, a head-wise adaptive extension that inserts a learnable linear
transformation parameterized via singular value decomposition (SVD) before the
rotary mapping. This lightweight modification enables dynamic frequency
reallocation, semantic alignment of rotary planes, and head-specific positional
receptive fields while rigorously preserving RoPE's relative-position property.
Extensive experiments on class-conditional ImageNet and text-to-image
generation (Flux and MMDiT) demonstrate that HARoPE consistently improves
performance over strong RoPE baselines and other extensions. The method serves
as an effective drop-in replacement, offering a principled and adaptable
solution for enhancing positional awareness in transformer-based image
generative models.

AI.tldr: HARoPE: a lightweight head-wise adaptive extension to RoPE that inserts a learnable linear transformation (via SVD) before rotary mapping to enable dynamic frequency allocation, semantic alignment of planes, and head-specific positional receptive fields for image generation. It preserves RoPE's relative-position property and acts as a drop-in replacement with improved performance on image-generation benchmarks.
AI.motivation: RoPE's standard multi-dimensional, axis-wise independent, and uniformly treated frequency allocation struggles to capture fine-grained spatial relations, color cues, and object counting in 2D image generation, limiting RoPE's effectiveness beyond 1D domains.
AI.method: Introduce HARoPE, a head-wise adaptive extension that applies a learnable linear transformation (parameterized by SVD) before the rotary mapping. This enables dynamic frequency reallocation, semantic alignment of rotary planes, and head-specific receptive fields, while preserving RoPE's relative-position property. It remains a lightweight modification suitable as a drop-in replacement.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on class-conditional ImageNet and text-to-image tasks (Flux and MMDiT) shows HARoPE consistently improves performance over strong RoPE baselines and other extensions, validating its effectiveness across diverse image-generation settings.
AI.conclusion: HARoPE provides a principled, adaptable, and lightweight mechanism to enhance positional awareness in transformer-based image generators, outperforming standard RoPE and serving as an effective drop-in replacement.

title: PermLLM: Learnable Channel Permutation for N:M Sparse Large Language Models
summary:
Channel permutation is a powerful technique for enhancing the accuracy of N:M
sparse models by reordering the channels of weight matrices to prioritize the
retention of important weights. However, traditional channel permutation
methods rely on handcrafted quality metrics, which often fail to accurately
capture the true impact of pruning on model performance. To address this
limitation, we propose PermLLM, a novel post-training pruning framework that
introduces learnable channel permutation (LCP) for N:M sparsity. LCP leverages
Sinkhorn normalization to transform discrete permutation matrices into
differentiable soft permutation matrices, enabling end-to-end optimization.
Additionally, PermLLM incorporates an efficient block-wise channel permutation
strategy, which significantly reduces the number of learnable parameters and
computational complexity. PermLLM seamlessly integrates with existing one-shot
pruning methods to adaptively optimize channel permutations, effectively
mitigating pruning-induced errors. Extensive experiments on the LLaMA series,
Qwen, and OPT models demonstrate that PermLLM achieves superior performance in
optimizing N:M sparse models. The code is available at
https://github.com/lanchengzou/PermLLM.

AI.tldr: A learnable channel permutation framework (PermLLM) for N:M sparse models. It uses differentiable soft permutations via Sinkhorn, a block-wise strategy to reduce parameters, and integrates with one-shot pruning to adapt channel order for better accuracy on large LLMs.
AI.motivation: Traditional channel permutation relies on handcrafted quality metrics that poorly reflect pruning impact, leading to suboptimal channel reordering and performance loss. There is a need for differentiable, adaptive permutation methods that directly optimize for pruning outcomes.
AI.method: Introduce learnable channel permutation (LCP) with Sinkhorn normalization to convert permutation matrices into differentiable soft permutations, enabling end-to-end optimization. Implement a block-wise channel permutation strategy to lower parameter count and computation. Combine with existing one-shot pruning methods to adaptively optimize channel order under N:M sparsity during post-training pruning.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on LLaMA, Qwen, and OPT shows PermLLM achieves superior performance in optimizing N:M sparse models compared to baseline channel-permutation methods. Code available at the provided GitHub link.
AI.conclusion: PermLLM provides an effective, efficient approach to mitigating pruning-induced errors in N:M sparse models by learning channel permutations, and can be integrated with existing pruning pipelines to boost sparse-model accuracy.

title: Jigsaw3D: Disentangled 3D Style Transfer via Patch Shuffling and Masking
summary:
Controllable 3D style transfer seeks to restyle a 3D asset so that its
textures match a reference image while preserving the integrity and multi-view
consistency. The prevalent methods either rely on direct reference style token
injection or score-distillation from 2D diffusion models, which incurs heavy
per-scene optimization and often entangles style with semantic content. We
introduce Jigsaw3D, a multi-view diffusion based pipeline that decouples style
from content and enables fast, view-consistent stylization. Our key idea is to
leverage the jigsaw operation - spatial shuffling and random masking of
reference patches - to suppress object semantics and isolate stylistic
statistics (color palettes, strokes, textures). We integrate these style cues
into a multi-view diffusion model via reference-to-view cross-attention,
producing view-consistent stylized renderings conditioned on the input mesh.
The renders are then style-baked onto the surface to yield seamless textures.
Across standard 3D stylization benchmarks, Jigsaw3D achieves high style
fidelity and multi-view consistency with substantially lower latency, and
generalizes to masked partial reference stylization, multi-object scene
styling, and tileable texture generation. Project page is available at:
https://babahui.github.io/jigsaw3D.github.io/

AI.tldr: Jigsaw3D is a diffusion-based 3D style transfer pipeline that decouples style from content using a jigsaw operation on reference patches, enabling fast, multi-view consistent stylization and texture baking onto the mesh.
AI.motivation: Current 3D stylization methods either inject style tokens or distill from 2D diffusion models, which entangles style with content and incurs heavy per-scene optimization or high latency. A clean separation of style and content with view-consistent guidance is needed for faster, more robust 3D stylization.
AI.method: Apply a jigsaw operation (spatial shuffling and random masking) on reference patches to suppress object semantics and extract stylistic statistics. Use multi-view diffusion with reference-to-view cross-attention to generate view-consistent stylizations conditioned on the input mesh. Bake the style-rendered views onto the surface to obtain seamless textures.
AI.result: On standard 3D stylization benchmarks, Jigsaw3D achieves high style fidelity and strong multi-view consistency with substantially lower latency, and generalizes to masked partial-reference stylization, multi-object scenes, and tileable texture generation.
AI.conclusion: Jigsaw3D demonstrates that decoupling content and style via jigsaw references and cross-attentive diffusion can deliver fast, view-consistent 3D stylization with broad generalization, reducing optimization burden while enabling flexible styling scenarios.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Downstream Weather Forecasting Models: Application to Tropical Cyclone Trajectory Prediction
summary:
Deep learning based weather forecasting (DLWF) models leverage past weather
observations to generate future forecasts, supporting a wide range of
downstream tasks, including tropical cyclone (TC) trajectory prediction. In
this paper, we investigate their vulnerability to adversarial attacks, where
subtle perturbations to the upstream weather forecasts can alter the downstream
TC trajectory predictions. Although research on adversarial attacks in DLWF
models has grown recently, generating perturbed upstream forecasts that
reliably steer downstream output toward attacker-specified trajectories remains
a challenge. First, conventional TC detection systems are opaque,
non-differentiable black boxes, making standard gradient-based attacks
infeasible. Second, the extreme rarity of TC events leads to severe class
imbalance problem, making it difficult to develop efficient attack methods that
will produce the attacker's target trajectories. Furthermore, maintaining
physical consistency in adversarially generated forecasts presents another
significant challenge. To overcome these limitations, we propose Cyc-Attack, a
novel method that perturbs the upstream forecasts of DLWF models to generate
adversarial trajectories. First, we pre-train a differentiable surrogate model
to approximate the TC detector's output, enabling the construction of
gradient-based attacks. Cyc-Attack also employs skewness-aware loss function
with kernel dilation strategy to address the imbalance problem. Finally, a
distance-based gradient weighting scheme and regularization are used to
constrain the perturbations and eliminate spurious trajectories to ensure the
adversarial forecasts are realistic and not easily detectable.

AI.tldr: Cyc-Attack enables gradient-based adversarial perturbations of upstream weather forecasts to steer TC trajectories, addressing black-box detector, data imbalance, and physical consistency.
AI.motivation: Deep learning based weather forecasting models are vulnerable to adversarial perturbations that can alter downstream tropical cyclone trajectory predictions. Challenges include: (1) TC detectors are opaque and non-differentiable, hindering gradient-based attacks; (2) extreme rarity of TC events causes severe class imbalance, complicating targeted attack generation; (3) perturbations must preserve physical realism to be plausible.
AI.method: Train a differentiable surrogate to approximate the detector output to enable gradient-based attacks. Use a skewness-aware loss with a kernel dilation strategy to mitigate imbalance. Apply a distance-based gradient weighting scheme and regularization to constrain perturbations, ensuring adversarial forecasts remain realistic and not easily detectable.
AI.result: The proposed Cyc-Attack can generate adversarial upstream forecasts that steer downstream TC trajectories toward attacker-specified targets, overcoming black-box and imbalance challenges while preserving physical plausibility.
AI.conclusion: Cyc-Attack demonstrates a practical vulnerability of DLWF-based TC forecasting to adversarial perturbations and motivates the development of robust defenses; it provides a concrete framework for future defense research and evaluation.

title: VR-Thinker: Boosting Video Reward Models through Thinking-with-Image Reasoning
summary:
Recent advancements in multimodal reward models (RMs) have substantially
improved post-training for visual generative models. However, current RMs face
inherent limitations: (1) visual inputs consume large context budgets, forcing
fewer frames and causing loss of fine-grained details; and (2) all visual
information is packed into the initial prompt, exacerbating hallucination and
forgetting during chain-of-thought reasoning. To overcome these issues, we
introduce VideoReward Thinker (VR-Thinker), a thinking-with-image framework
that equips the RM with visual reasoning operations (e.g., select frame) and a
configurable visual memory window. This allows the RM to actively acquire and
update visual evidence within context limits, improving reasoning fidelity and
reliability. We activate visual reasoning via a reinforcement fine-tuning
pipeline: (i) Cold Start with curated visual chain-of-thought data to distill
basic reasoning skills and operation formatting; (ii) select samples whose
per-dimension and overall judgments are all correct, then conduct Rejection
sampling Fine-Tuning on these high-quality traces to further enhance reasoning;
and (iii) apply Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) to strengthen
reasoning. Our approach delivers state-of-the-art accuracy among open-source
models on video preference benchmarks, especially for longer videos: a 7B
VR-Thinker achieves 80.5% on VideoGen Reward, 82.3% on GenAI-Bench, and 75.6%
on MJ-Bench-Video. These results validate the effectiveness and promise of
thinking-with-image multimodal reward modeling.

title: A Unified Frequency Domain Decomposition Framework for Interpretable and Robust Time Series Forecasting
summary:
Current approaches for time series forecasting, whether in the time or
frequency domain, predominantly use deep learning models based on linear layers
or transformers. They often encode time series data in a black-box manner and
rely on trial-and-error optimization solely based on forecasting performance,
leading to limited interpretability and theoretical understanding. Furthermore,
the dynamics in data distribution over time and frequency domains pose a
critical challenge to accurate forecasting. We propose FIRE, a unified
frequency domain decomposition framework that provides a mathematical
abstraction for diverse types of time series, so as to achieve interpretable
and robust time series forecasting. FIRE introduces several key innovations:
(i) independent modeling of amplitude and phase components, (ii) adaptive
