AI.result: RADiAnce significantly outperforms baselines on metrics including binding affinity and recovery of geometries and interactions. It demonstrates cross-domain generalization: retrieved interfaces from diverse domains improve binder generation for other domains, validating the retrieval-guided generative paradigm.
AI.conclusion: The work establishes a new paradigm integrating retrieval with generative AI for protein binder design, bridging knowledge from existing interfaces to guide novel binder generation and enabling cross-domain transfer to enhance drug discovery.

title: EGD-YOLO: A Lightweight Multimodal Framework for Robust Drone-Bird Discrimination via Ghost-Enhanced YOLOv8n and EMA Attention under Adverse Condition
summary:
Identifying drones and birds correctly is essential for keeping the skies
safe and improving security systems. Using the VIP CUP 2025 dataset, which
provides both RGB and infrared (IR) images, this study presents EGD-YOLOv8n, a
new lightweight yet powerful model for object detection. The model improves how
image features are captured and understood, making detection more accurate and
efficient. It uses smart design changes and attention layers to focus on
important details while reducing the amount of computation needed. A special
detection head helps the model adapt to objects of different shapes and sizes.
We trained three versions: one using RGB images, one using IR images, and one
combining both. The combined model achieved the best accuracy and reliability
while running fast enough for real-time use on common GPUs.

AI.tldr: EGD-YOLOv8n is a lightweight multi-spectral detector for drones and birds using RGB, IR, and fused data (VIP CUP 2025). It enhances feature extraction with attention and a specialized detection head for scale variation, achieving real-time performance on common GPUs, with the fusion model performing best.
AI.motivation: To safely and securely separate drones from birds while enabling real-time detection. The VIP CUP 2025 dataset provides both RGB and infrared imagery, enabling multispectral fusion to improve robustness and accuracy in varied conditions.
AI.method: EGD-YOLOv8n is a lightweight YOLOv8n-based detector with enhanced feature-capture blocks and attention layers, plus a specialized detection head to handle objects across scales. Three models are trained: RGB-only, IR-only, and RGB+IR fusion, evaluated for accuracy and speed on standard GPUs.
AI.result: The fused RGB+IR model achieves the best accuracy and reliability while maintaining real-time inference speeds suitable for common GPU hardware.
AI.conclusion: A multi-spectral fusion approach with a lightweight detector can effectively detect drones and birds in RGB and IR imagery, with fusion offering the strongest performance. This supports deployment in real-world airspace monitoring with potential for further refinement.

title: Gradient Enhanced Self-Training Physics-Informed Neural Network (gST-PINN) for Solving Nonlinear Partial Differential Equations
summary:
Partial differential equations (PDEs) provide a mathematical foundation for
simulating and understanding intricate behaviors in both physical sciences and
engineering. With the growing capabilities of deep learning, data$-$driven
approaches like Physics$-$Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) have been developed,
offering a mesh$-$free, analytic type framework for efficiently solving PDEs
across a wide range of applications. However, traditional PINNs often struggle
with challenges such as limited precision, slow training dynamics, lack of
labeled data availability, and inadequate handling of multi$-$physics
interactions. To overcome these challenging issues of PINNs, we proposed a
Gradient Enhanced Self$-$Training PINN (gST$-$PINN) method that specifically
introduces a gradient based pseudo point self$-$learning algorithm for solving
PDEs. We tested the proposed method on three different types of PDE problems
from various fields, each representing distinct scenarios. The effectiveness of
the proposed method is evident, as the PINN approach for solving the Burgers$'$
equation attains a mean square error (MSE) on the order of $10^{-3}$, while the
diffusion$-$sorption equation achieves an MSE on the order of $10^{-4}$ after
12,500 iterations, with no further improvement as the iterations increase. In
contrast, the MSE for both PDEs in the gST$-$PINN model continues to decrease,
demonstrating better generalization and reaching an MSE on the order of
$10^{-5}$ after 18,500 iterations. Furthermore, the results show that the
proposed purely semi$-$supervised gST$-$PINN consistently outperforms the
standard PINN method in all cases, even when solution of the PDEs are
unavailable. It generalizes both PINN and Gradient$-$enhanced PINN (gPINN), and
can be effectively applied in scenarios prone to low accuracy and convergence
issues, particularly in the absence of labeled data.

AI.tldr: Gradient Enhanced Self-Training PINN (gST-PINN) improves PINNs by gradient-based pseudo point self-learning, yielding superior accuracy and robustness especially with limited labeled data; tested on Burgers' and diffusion-sorption PDEs, outperforming PINN and gPINN.
AI.motivation: Address core PINN challenges: limited precision, slow convergence, scarce labeled data, and poor handling of multi-physics interactions.
AI.method: Introduce gradient-based pseudo point self-learning within a semi-supervised framework (gST-PINN). The method extends PINN and gPINN, leveraging gradient information and pseudo points to train without requiring abundant labeled solutions, enabling better generalization across multi-physics PDEs.
AI.result: For Burgers' equation, PINN MSE ~1e-3; diffusion-sorption MSE ~1e-4 after ~12.5k iterations. gST-PINN continues reducing error, reaching ~1e-5 after ~18.5k iterations. Purely semi-supervised gST-PINN outperforms standard PINN in all tested scenarios, even with unavailable labeled solutions.
AI.conclusion: gST-PINN generalizes PINN and gPINN and offers robust performance in low-accuracy/convergence-challenged settings, particularly when labeled data is scarce or absent.

title: Structured Spectral Graph Learning for Multi-label Abnormality Classification in 3D Chest CT Scans
summary:
With the growing volume of CT examinations, there is an increasing demand for
automated tools such as organ segmentation, abnormality detection, and report
generation to support radiologists in managing their clinical workload.
Multi-label classification of 3D Chest CT scans remains a critical yet
challenging problem due to the complex spatial relationships inherent in
volumetric data and the wide variability of abnormalities. Existing methods
based on 3D convolutional neural networks struggle to capture long-range
dependencies, while Vision Transformers often require extensive pre-training on
large-scale, domain-specific datasets to perform competitively. In this work,
we propose a 2.5D alternative by introducing a new graph-based framework that
represents 3D CT volumes as structured graphs, where axial slice triplets serve
as nodes processed through spectral graph convolution, enabling the model to
reason over inter-slice dependencies while maintaining complexity compatible
with clinical deployment. Our method, trained and evaluated on 3 datasets from
independent institutions, achieves strong cross-dataset generalization, and
shows competitive performance compared to state-of-the-art visual encoders. We
further conduct comprehensive ablation studies to evaluate the impact of
various aggregation strategies, edge-weighting schemes, and graph connectivity
patterns. Additionally, we demonstrate the broader applicability of our
approach through transfer experiments on automated radiology report generation
and abdominal CT data.\\ This work extends our previous contribution presented
at the MICCAI 2025 EMERGE Workshop.

AI.tldr: A 2.5D graph-based framework for 3D chest CT multi-label classification using axial slice triplets as nodes with spectral graph convolution to capture inter-slice dependencies, achieving strong cross-dataset generalization and competitive performance with SOTA encoders, with ablations and transfer experiments indicating broader applicability to tasks like report generation and abdominal CT; extends MICCAI 2025 EMERGE Workshop work.
AI.motivation: Automated CT tools are increasingly needed to manage radiologist workload. Multi-label classification on 3D chest CT is challenging due to complex spatial relationships and variability of abnormalities. 3D CNNs struggle with long-range dependencies; Vision Transformers require extensive pre-training. A lightweight, generalizable approach that captures inter-slice dependencies efficiently is desirable.
AI.method: Represent 3D CT volumes as structured graphs where axial slice triplets form nodes. Apply spectral graph convolution to reason over inter-slice dependencies. Explore aggregation strategies, edge-weighting schemes, and graph connectivity patterns. Train and evaluate on three independent datasets to assess cross-dataset generalization. Conduct ablation studies. Demonstrate transferability to automated radiology report generation and abdominal CT data.
AI.result: The method achieves strong cross-dataset generalization and competitive performance compared to state-of-the-art visual encoders. Ablation studies clarify the impact of aggregation methods, edge weighting, and connectivity. Transfer experiments indicate broader applicability beyond chest CT tasks.
AI.conclusion: A 2.5D graph-based representation is effective for 3D chest CT multi-label classification, balancing performance with deployment-ready efficiency, and generalizes well across datasets; the work extends prior MICCAI 2025 EMERGE Workshop contributions.

title: DISC-GAN: Disentangling Style and Content for Cluster-Specific Synthetic Underwater Image Generation
summary:
In this paper, we propose a novel framework, Disentangled Style-Content GAN
(DISC-GAN), which integrates style-content disentanglement with a
cluster-specific training strategy towards photorealistic underwater image
synthesis. The quality of synthetic underwater images is challenged by optical
due to phenomena such as color attenuation and turbidity. These phenomena are
represented by distinct stylistic variations across different waterbodies, such
as changes in tint and haze. While generative models are well-suited to capture
complex patterns, they often lack the ability to model the non-uniform
conditions of diverse underwater environments. To address these challenges, we
employ K-means clustering to partition a dataset into style-specific domains.
We use separate encoders to get latent spaces for style and content; we further
integrate these latent representations via Adaptive Instance Normalization
(AdaIN) and decode the result to produce the final synthetic image. The model
is trained independently on each style cluster to preserve domain-specific
characteristics. Our framework demonstrates state-of-the-art performance,
obtaining a Structural Similarity Index (SSIM) of 0.9012, an average Peak
Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR) of 32.5118 dB, and a Frechet Inception Distance
(FID) of 13.3728.

AI.tldr: A disentangled style-content GAN (DISC-GAN) for photorealistic underwater image synthesis using K-means style clustering and per-cluster training with separate style/content encoders and AdaIN, achieving SSIM 0.9012, PSNR 32.51 dB, FID 13.37.
AI.motivation: Underwater imaging suffers from optical effects (color attenuation, turbidity) that vary across waterbodies. These non-uniform conditions create distinct style domains; a model must capture style-content disentanglement across these domains to synthesize realistic underwater images.
AI.method: Two encoders extract latent style and content representations; Adaptive Instance Normalization (AdaIN) fuses them. K-means clusters the dataset into style-specific domains. The model is trained independently on each cluster; a decoder generates the final image.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art metrics: SSIM 0.9012, PSNR 32.5118 dB, FID 13.3728.
AI.conclusion: The proposed DISC-GAN effectively models style variations in underwater environments via style-content disentanglement and cluster-specific training, improving photorealistic underwater synthesis. Nonetheless, cluster choice and cross-cluster generalization warrant further ablations.

title: f-INE: A Hypothesis Testing Framework for Estimating Influence under Training Randomness
summary:
Influence estimation methods promise to explain and debug machine learning by
estimating the impact of individual samples on the final model. Yet, existing
methods collapse under training randomness: the same example may appear
critical in one run and irrelevant in the next. Such instability undermines
their use in data curation or cleanup since it is unclear if we indeed
deleted/kept the correct datapoints. To overcome this, we introduce
*f-influence* -- a new influence estimation framework grounded in hypothesis
testing that explicitly accounts for training randomness, and establish
desirable properties that make it suitable for reliable influence estimation.
We also design a highly efficient algorithm **f**-**IN**fluence **E**stimation
(**f-INE**) that computes f-influence **in a single training run**. Finally, we
scale up f-INE to estimate influence of instruction tuning data on Llama-3.1-8B
and show it can reliably detect poisoned samples that steer model opinions,
demonstrating its utility for data cleanup and attributing model behavior.

AI.tldr: Proposes f-influence, a hypothesis-testing framework for influence estimation that accounts for training randomness; introduces f-INE to compute influence in a single training run; demonstrates effectiveness in detecting poisoned data on a large Llama-3.1-8B model.
AI.motivation: Influence methods are unstable across training runs due to randomness, hindering data curation and cleanup. A statistically principled, stable influence estimator is needed.
AI.method: Develop the f-influence framework based on hypothesis testing with desirable properties for robustness; design the f-INE algorithm to compute influence in one training run; apply to dataset including instruction-tuning data for Llama-3.1-8B.
AI.result: Empirical results show that f-INE reliably detects poisoned samples that steer model opinions, enabling reliable data cleanup and attribution of model behavior.
AI.conclusion: f-influence provides a stable, principled approach to influence estimation under training randomness and scales to large models, facilitating data curation and understanding of model behavior.

title: ImHead: A Large-scale Implicit Morphable Model for Localized Head Modeling
summary:
Over the last years, 3D morphable models (3DMMs) have emerged as a
state-of-the-art methodology for modeling and generating expressive 3D avatars.
However, given their reliance on a strict topology, along with their linear
nature, they struggle to represent complex full-head shapes. Following the
advent of deep implicit functions, we propose imHead, a novel implicit 3DMM
that not only models expressive 3D head avatars but also facilitates localized
editing of the facial features. Previous methods directly divided the latent
space into local components accompanied by an identity encoding to capture the
global shape variations, leading to expensive latent sizes. In contrast, we
retain a single compact identity space and introduce an intermediate
region-specific latent representation to enable local edits. To train imHead,
we curate a large-scale dataset of 4K distinct identities, making a
step-towards large scale 3D head modeling. Under a series of experiments we
demonstrate the expressive power of the proposed model to represent diverse
identities and expressions outperforming previous approaches. Additionally, the
proposed approach provides an interpretable solution for 3D face manipulation,
allowing the user to make localized edits.

AI.tldr: Introduces imHead, an implicit 3D morphable model for expressive 3D head avatars with localized editing, using a single identity latent plus region-specific latents, trained on 4K identities, achieving expressive diversity and interpretable local manipulation.
AI.motivation: Traditional 3D morphable models are constrained by fixed topology and linearity, limiting complex full-head shapes. Deep implicit functions offer flexible, high-fidelity modeling, but scalable, editable head representations with localized control are still needed.
AI.method: Propose imHead, an implicit 3DMM that keeps a compact global identity latent and adds region-specific latent representations to enable localized edits. Train on a large-scale dataset of 4K identities, enabling scalable 3D head modeling with editable regions.
AI.result: Demonstrates strong expressive power to represent diverse identities and expressions, outperforming prior approaches, and provides an interpretable mechanism for localized facial edits.
AI.conclusion: imHead offers a scalable, expressive, and editable implicit 3D head model, advancing the ability to model and manipulate 3D heads with region-wise control.

title: A Hybrid Machine Learning Approach for Synthetic Data Generation with Post Hoc Calibration for Clinical Tabular Datasets
summary:
Healthcare research and development face significant obstacles due to data
scarcity and stringent privacy regulations, such as HIPAA and the GDPR,
restricting access to essential real-world medical data. These limitations
impede innovation, delay robust AI model creation, and hinder advancements in
patient-centered care. Synthetic data generation offers a transformative
solution by producing artificial datasets that emulate real data statistics
while safeguarding patient privacy. We introduce a novel hybrid framework for
high-fidelity healthcare data synthesis integrating five augmentation methods:
noise injection, interpolation, Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM) sampling,
Conditional Variational Autoencoder (CVAE) sampling, and SMOTE, combined via a
reinforcement learning-based dynamic weight selection mechanism. Its key
innovations include advanced calibration techniques -- moment matching, full
histogram matching, soft and adaptive soft histogram matching, and iterative
refinement -- that align marginal distributions and preserve joint feature
dependencies. Evaluated on the Breast Cancer Wisconsin (UCI Repository) and
Khulna Medical College cardiology datasets, our calibrated hybrid achieves
Wasserstein distances as low as 0.001 and Kolmogorov-Smirnov statistics around
0.01, demonstrating near-zero marginal discrepancy. Pairwise trend scores
surpass 90%, and Nearest Neighbor Adversarial Accuracy approaches 50%,
confirming robust privacy protection. Downstream classifiers trained on
synthetic data achieve up to 94% accuracy and F1 scores above 93%, comparable
to models trained on real data. This scalable, privacy-preserving approach
matches state-of-the-art methods, sets new benchmarks for joint-distribution
fidelity in healthcare, and supports sensitive AI applications.

AI.tldr: A new hybrid, RL-guided synthetic data framework for healthcare integrates five augmentation methods to synthesize high-fidelity, privacy-preserving data. It achieves near-zero marginal distribution discrepancies, strong joint-distribution fidelity, and comparable downstream task performance to real data across two datasets.
AI.motivation: Healthcare data are scarce and tightly regulated (HIPAA/GDPR), hindering AI model development. Synthetic data can enable research and deployment while protecting patient privacy.
AI.method: Combine noise injection, interpolation, Gaussian Mixture Model sampling, Conditional Variational Autoencoder sampling, and SMOTE, with a reinforcement learning-based dynamic weighting mechanism. Employ advanced calibration steps (moment matching, full histogram matching, soft histogram matching, and iterative refinement) to align marginal distributions and preserve joint feature dependencies.
AI.result: Achieved Wasserstein distances as low as 0.001 and KS statistics around 0.01, indicating near-zero marginal discrepancy. Pairwise trend scores >90% and Nearest Neighbor Adversarial Accuracy ~50% indicate strong privacy. Downstream classifiers trained on synthetic data reach up to 94% accuracy and F1 > 93%, comparable to models trained on real data.
AI.conclusion: The framework is scalable and privacy-preserving, matching or surpassing state-of-the-art methods in joint-distribution fidelity for healthcare data and enabling sensitive AI applications.

title: Full segmentation annotations of 3D time-lapse microscopy images of MDA231 cells
summary:
High-quality, publicly available segmentation annotations of image and video
datasets are critical for advancing the field of image processing. In
particular, annotations of volumetric images of a large number of targets are
time-consuming and challenging. In (Melnikova, A., & Matula, P., 2025), we
presented the first publicly available full 3D time-lapse segmentation
annotations of migrating cells with complex dynamic shapes. Concretely, three
distinct humans annotated two sequences of MDA231 human breast carcinoma cells
(Fluo-C3DL-MDA231) from the Cell Tracking Challenge (CTC).
  This paper aims to provide a comprehensive description of the dataset and
accompanying experiments that were not included in (Melnikova, A., & Matula,
P., 2025) due to limitations in publication space. Namely, we show that the
created annotations are consistent with the previously published tracking
markers provided by the CTC organizers and the segmentation accuracy measured
based on the 2D gold truth of CTC is within the inter-annotator variability
margins. We compared the created 3D annotations with automatically created
silver truth provided by CTC. We have found the proposed annotations better
represent the complexity of the input images. The presented annotations can be
used for testing and training cell segmentation, or analyzing 3D shapes of
highly dynamic objects.

AI.tldr: First publicly available full 3D time-lapse segmentation annotations for migrating cells, with validation against existing markers and 2D gold truth; dataset and experiments described beyond the earlier paper.
AI.motivation: High-quality segmentation annotations for volumetric/time-resolved data are scarce and costly to produce; enabling robust training, testing, and analysis of dynamic 3D cellular shapes.
AI.method: Three human annotators labeled two sequences of MDA231 breast carcinoma cells (CTC dataset); validated 3D annotations against CTC tracking markers and 2D gold truth; compared with automatically generated silver truth; assessed inter-annotator variability; detailed dataset description and experiments not in the earlier paper.
AI.result: 3D annotations are consistent with tracking markers; segmentation accuracy falls within inter-annotator variability margins; annotations better capture input image complexity than silver truth; dataset is suitable for testing/training cell segmentation and 3D shape analysis of dynamic objects.
AI.conclusion: Provides a public resource for 3D time-lapse cell segmentation annotation; first of its kind; enables improved testing, training, and analysis of dynamic 3D cellular structures.

title: Reinforced Domain Selection for Continuous Domain Adaptation
summary:
Continuous Domain Adaptation (CDA) effectively bridges significant domain
shifts by progressively adapting from the source domain through intermediate
domains to the target domain. However, selecting intermediate domains without
explicit metadata remains a substantial challenge that has not been extensively
explored in existing studies. To tackle this issue, we propose a novel
framework that combines reinforcement learning with feature disentanglement to
conduct domain path selection in an unsupervised CDA setting. Our approach
introduces an innovative unsupervised reward mechanism that leverages the
distances between latent domain embeddings to facilitate the identification of
optimal transfer paths. Furthermore, by disentangling features, our method
facilitates the calculation of unsupervised rewards using domain-specific
features and promotes domain adaptation by aligning domain-invariant features.
This integrated strategy is designed to simultaneously optimize transfer paths
and target task performance, enhancing the effectiveness of domain adaptation
processes. Extensive empirical evaluations on datasets such as Rotated MNIST
and ADNI demonstrate substantial improvements in prediction accuracy and domain
selection efficiency, establishing our method's superiority over traditional
CDA approaches.

AI.tldr: A novel unsupervised Continuous Domain Adaptation (CDA) framework that uses reinforcement learning and feature disentanglement to select intermediate domains without metadata, employing unsupervised rewards based on latent domain distances and aligning domain-invariant features, yielding improved target accuracy and domain-path efficiency on Rotated MNIST and ADNI.
AI.motivation: Selecting informative intermediate domains in CDA is challenging without explicit metadata, hindering transfer efficiency and target performance. An unsupervised method to discover transfer paths is needed.
AI.method: Proposes a framework that combines reinforcement learning with feature disentanglement. It uses an unsupervised reward based on distances between latent domain embeddings and disentangles features to compute rewards and align domain-invariant features, jointly optimizing path selection and target task performance.
AI.result: Empirical evaluations on Rotated MNIST and ADNI show substantial improvements in prediction accuracy and faster/domain-selection efficiency, outperforming traditional CDA methods.
AI.conclusion: The approach addresses the metadata-free intermediate-domain selection problem in CDA and demonstrates strong potential for robust cross-domain adaptation by learning effective transfer paths and improving target performance through unsupervised domain-aware rewards.

title: MSCloudCAM: Cross-Attention with Multi-Scale Context for Multispectral Cloud Segmentation
summary:
Clouds remain a critical challenge in optical satellite imagery, hindering
reliable analysis for environmental monitoring, land cover mapping, and climate
research. To overcome this, we propose MSCloudCAM, a Cross-Attention with
Multi-Scale Context Network tailored for multispectral and multi-sensor cloud
segmentation. Our framework exploits the spectral richness of Sentinel-2
(CloudSEN12) and Landsat-8 (L8Biome) data to classify four semantic categories:
clear sky, thin cloud, thick cloud, and cloud shadow. MSCloudCAM combines a
Swin Transformer backbone for hierarchical feature extraction with multi-scale
context modules ASPP and PSP for enhanced scale-aware learning. A
Cross-Attention block enables effective multisensor and multispectral feature
fusion, while the integration of an Efficient Channel Attention Block (ECAB)
and a Spatial Attention Module adaptively refine feature representations.
Comprehensive experiments on CloudSEN12 and L8Biome demonstrate that MSCloudCAM
delivers state-of-the-art segmentation accuracy, surpassing leading baseline
architectures while maintaining competitive parameter efficiency and FLOPs.
These results underscore the model's effectiveness and practicality, making it
well-suited for large-scale Earth observation tasks and real-world
applications.

AI.tldr: MSCloudCAM is a cross-attention, multi-scale network for multispectral cloud segmentation (Sentinel-2 and Landsat-8) achieving state-of-the-art accuracy for four classes (clear sky, thin cloud, thick cloud, cloud shadow).
AI.motivation: Clouds hinder optical satellite analysis; robust, scale-aware, multisensor cloud segmentation is needed for reliable environmental monitoring, land cover mapping, and climate research.
AI.method: A Swin Transformer backbone with ASPP/PSP multi-scale context modules; a Cross-Attention block for multisensor/multispectral feature fusion; Efficient Channel Attention Block (ECAB) and a Spatial Attention Module for adaptive refinement; outputs four semantic categories.
AI.result: On CloudSEN12 and L8Biome benchmarks, MSCloudCAM achieves state-of-the-art segmentation accuracy, surpassing leading baselines while maintaining competitive parameter efficiency and FLOPs.
AI.conclusion: MSCloudCAM is effective and practical for large-scale Earth observation tasks and real-world applications.

title: Rethinking RL Evaluation: Can Benchmarks Truly Reveal Failures of RL Methods?
summary:
Current benchmarks are inadequate for evaluating progress in reinforcement
learning (RL) for large language models (LLMs).Despite recent benchmark gains
reported for RL, we find that training on these benchmarks' training sets
achieves nearly the same performance as training directly on the test sets,
suggesting that the benchmarks cannot reliably separate further progress.To
study this phenomenon, we introduce a diagnostic suite and the Oracle
Performance Gap (OPG) metric that quantifies the performance difference between
training on the train split versus the test split of a benchmark. We further
analyze this phenomenon with stress tests and find that, despite strong
benchmark scores, existing RL methods struggle to generalize across
distribution shifts, varying levels of difficulty, and counterfactual
scenarios: shortcomings that current benchmarks fail to reveal.We conclude that
current benchmarks are insufficient for evaluating generalization and propose
three core principles for designing more faithful benchmarks: sufficient
difficulty, balanced evaluation, and distributional robustness.

AI.tldr: Existing RL benchmarks for LLMs do not reliably measure progress; a diagnostic suite and Oracle Performance Gap reveal poor generalization and distributional robustness, calling for benchmarks with sufficient difficulty, balanced evaluation, and distributional robustness.
AI.motivation: Current benchmarks allow training on train and test splits to achieve similar performance, so progress is not truly measured; there is a need to quantify and study generalization gaps.
AI.method: Introduce Oracle Performance Gap (OPG) metric comparing performance when training on train vs test splits; develop a diagnostic suite; conduct stress tests across distribution shifts, difficulty levels, and counterfactuals.
AI.result: Benchmark scores can be high even when models fail to generalize; RL methods struggle under distributional shifts despite favorable scores; OPG highlights gaps; stress tests reveal limitations.
AI.conclusion: Benchmarks are insufficient; propose three core design principles for more faithful benchmarks: sufficient difficulty, balanced evaluation, and distributional robustness; recommend building benchmarks that better capture generalization in RL for LLMs.

title: From Detection to Mitigation: Addressing Bias in Deep Learning Models for Chest X-Ray Diagnosis
comment:
Preprint of an article published in Pacific Symposium on Biocomputing
  \c{opyright} 2026 World Scientific Publishing Co., Singapore,
  http://psb.stanford.edu/
summary:
Deep learning models have shown promise in improving diagnostic accuracy from
chest X-rays, but they also risk perpetuating healthcare disparities when
performance varies across demographic groups. In this work, we present a
comprehensive bias detection and mitigation framework targeting sex, age, and
race-based disparities when performing diagnostic tasks with chest X-rays. We
extend a recent CNN-XGBoost pipeline to support multi-label classification and
evaluate its performance across four medical conditions. We show that replacing
the final layer of CNN with an eXtreme Gradient Boosting classifier improves
the fairness of the subgroup while maintaining or improving the overall
predictive performance. To validate its generalizability, we apply the method
to different backbones, namely DenseNet-121 and ResNet-50, and achieve
similarly strong performance and fairness outcomes, confirming its
model-agnostic design. We further compare this lightweight adapter training
method with traditional full-model training bias mitigation techniques,
including adversarial training, reweighting, data augmentation, and active
learning, and find that our approach offers competitive or superior bias
reduction at a fraction of the computational cost. Finally, we show that
combining eXtreme Gradient Boosting retraining with active learning yields the
largest reduction in bias across all demographic subgroups, both in and out of
distribution on the CheXpert and MIMIC datasets, establishing a practical and
effective path toward equitable deep learning deployment in clinical radiology.

AI.tldr: A bias detection and mitigation framework for chest X-ray diagnosis using a CNN-XGBoost adapter improves fairness across sex, age, and race without sacrificing accuracy; it is model-agnostic, data-efficient, and scalable, outperforming traditional bias mitigation methods in many cases, especially when combined with active learning on CheXpert and MIMIC datasets.
AI.motivation: To address healthcare disparities arising from demographic-dependent performance in deep learning models for chest X-ray diagnostics by developing a practical, scalable bias mitigation approach that preserves accuracy.
AI.method: Extend a CNN-XGBoost pipeline to multi-label classification; replace the CNN final layer with an XGBoost classifier; evaluate on DenseNet-121 and ResNet-50 backbones; compare against adversarial training, reweighting, data augmentation, and active learning; apply retraining of XGBoost plus active learning; test on four medical conditions; assess fairness across sex, age, and race; validate on CheXpert and MIMIC datasets.
AI.result: Replacing the final CNN layer with an XGBoost classifier improves fairness across demographic subgroups while maintaining or improving overall predictive performance; the approach is model-agnostic (works with DenseNet-121 and ResNet-50) and offers competitive or superior bias reduction with lower computational cost compared to traditional bias mitigation techniques; combining XGBoost retraining with active learning yields the largest bias reduction across all subgroups and distribution settings.
AI.conclusion: A practical and effective path toward equitable deep learning deployment in clinical radiology, via a lightweight, model-agnostic bias mitigation strategy that scales across backbones and outperforms traditional methods, particularly when coupled with active learning.

title: PAC-Bayesian Reinforcement Learning Trains Generalizable Policies
summary:
We derive a novel PAC-Bayesian generalization bound for reinforcement
learning that explicitly accounts for Markov dependencies in the data, through
the chain's mixing time. This contributes to overcoming challenges in obtaining
generalization guarantees for reinforcement learning, where the sequential
nature of data breaks the independence assumptions underlying classical bounds.
Our bound provides non-vacuous certificates for modern off-policy algorithms
like Soft Actor-Critic. We demonstrate the bound's practical utility through
PB-SAC, a novel algorithm that optimizes the bound during training to guide
exploration. Experiments across continuous control tasks show that our approach
provides meaningful confidence certificates while maintaining competitive
performance.

AI.tldr: A new PAC-Bayesian generalization bound for reinforcement learning that accounts for Markov data via mixing time, enabling non-vacuous certificates for off-policy methods like Soft Actor-Critic; introduces PB-SAC, which optimizes the bound during training to guide exploration; experiments show the bound provides meaningful confidence certificates with competitive performance.
AI.motivation: Generalization guarantees in RL are difficult due to sequential data and dependencies that violate IID assumptions. Classical bounds fail to capture dependencies; incorporating Markovian structure through mixing time could yield meaningful certificates and bridge theory with practice for off-policy RL.
AI.method: Derive a PAC-Bayesian bound that explicitly incorporates the chain's mixing time to handle Markov dependencies in RL data. Propose PB-SAC, a practical algorithm that optimizes this bound during training to guide exploration and policy updates in off-policy settings.
AI.result: The bound yields non-vacuous generalization certificates for modern off-policy algorithms such as SAC. PB-SAC demonstrates meaningful confidence certificates while achieving competitive performance on continuous control tasks.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating Markov dependencies via mixing time into PAC-Bayes bounds provides practical generalization guarantees for RL and enables training-time optimization of these certificates (PB-SAC) without sacrificing performance.

title: FastHMR: Accelerating Human Mesh Recovery via Token and Layer Merging with Diffusion Decoding
summary:
Recent transformer-based models for 3D Human Mesh Recovery (HMR) have
achieved strong performance but often suffer from high computational cost and
complexity due to deep transformer architectures and redundant tokens. In this
paper, we introduce two HMR-specific merging strategies: Error-Constrained
Layer Merging (ECLM) and Mask-guided Token Merging (Mask-ToMe). ECLM
selectively merges transformer layers that have minimal impact on the Mean Per
Joint Position Error (MPJPE), while Mask-ToMe focuses on merging background
tokens that contribute little to the final prediction. To further address the
potential performance drop caused by merging, we propose a diffusion-based
decoder that incorporates temporal context and leverages pose priors learned
from large-scale motion capture datasets. Experiments across multiple
benchmarks demonstrate that our method achieves up to 2.3x speed-up while
slightly improving performance over the baseline.

AI.tldr: Introduces two HMR-specific merging strategies, ECLM and Mask-ToMe, plus a diffusion-based decoder to reduce compute while maintaining or improving accuracy, achieving up to 2.3x speed-up on benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Transformer-based 3D HMR models achieve strong accuracy but incur high computational cost due to deep architectures and redundant tokens; there is a need to reduce complexity without sacrificing performance.
AI.method: Error-Constrained Layer Merging (ECLM) selectively merges transformer layers with minimal impact on MPJPE. Mask-guided Token Merging (Mask-ToMe) merges background tokens that contribute little to the final prediction. A diffusion-based decoder is introduced to incorporate temporal context and leverage pose priors learned from large-scale motion capture datasets.
AI.result: Experiments across multiple benchmarks show up to 2.3x speed-up with performance that slightly improves over the baseline.
AI.conclusion: Efficient HMR is attainable by combining targeted layer/token merging with a diffusion-based decoder that leverages temporal context and pose priors, offering practical gains in speed without sacrificing accuracy.

title: Multi-scale Frequency-Aware Adversarial Network for Parkinson's Disease Assessment Using Wearable Sensors
summary:
Severity assessment of Parkinson's disease (PD) using wearable sensors offers
an effective, objective basis for clinical management. However, general-purpose
time series models often lack pathological specificity in feature extraction,
making it difficult to capture subtle signals highly correlated with
PD.Furthermore, the temporal sparsity of PD symptoms causes key diagnostic
features to be easily "diluted" by traditional aggregation methods, further
complicating assessment. To address these issues, we propose the Multi-scale
Frequency-Aware Adversarial Multi-Instance Network (MFAM). This model enhances
feature specificity through a frequency decomposition module guided by medical
prior knowledge. Furthermore, by introducing an attention-based multi-instance
learning (MIL) framework, the model can adaptively focus on the most
diagnostically valuable sparse segments.We comprehensively validated MFAM on
both the public PADS dataset for PD versus differential diagnosis (DD) binary
classification and a private dataset for four-class severity assessment.
Experimental results demonstrate that MFAM outperforms general-purpose time
series models in handling complex clinical time series with specificity,
providing a promising solution for automated assessment of PD severity.

AI.tldr: MFAM (Multi-scale Frequency-Aware Adversarial Multi-Instance Network) improves Parkinson's disease severity assessment from wearable time-series by combining medically guided frequency decomposition with attention-based MIL, outperforming generic models on PD vs differential diagnosis and four-class severity tasks.
AI.motivation: Current general-purpose time-series models struggle to capture PD-specific signal features and are hampered by the temporal sparsity of PD symptoms, which dilutes diagnostically relevant segments. There is a need for pathology-informed feature extraction and selective emphasis on informative time windows.
AI.method: Introduce MFAM with a frequency decomposition module guided by medical priors to enhance feature specificity, plus an attention-based multiple-instance learning (MIL) framework to adaptively focus on informative sparse segments.
AI.result: Validated on public PADS dataset for PD vs differential diagnosis and a private four-class severity dataset; MFAM outperforms general-purpose time-series models in capturing PD-specific cues and handling sparse clinical signals.
AI.conclusion: MFAM provides a promising, pathology-informed approach for automated PD severity assessment from wearables, leveraging domain-guided frequency analysis and targeted attention over sparse segments to improve clinical utility.

title: rareboost3d: a synthetic lidar dataset with enhanced rare classes
summary:
Real-world point cloud datasets have made significant contributions to the
development of LiDAR-based perception technologies, such as object segmentation
for autonomous driving. However, due to the limited number of instances in some
rare classes, the long-tail problem remains a major challenge in existing
datasets. To address this issue, we introduce a novel, synthetic point cloud
dataset named RareBoost3D, which complements existing real-world datasets by
providing significantly more instances for object classes that are rare in
real-world datasets. To effectively leverage both synthetic and real-world
data, we further propose a cross-domain semantic alignment method named CSC
loss that aligns feature representations of the same class across different
domains. Experimental results demonstrate that this alignment significantly
enhances the performance of LiDAR point cloud segmentation models over
real-world data.

AI.tldr: RareBoost3D introduces a synthetic point cloud dataset to alleviate long-tail issues in LiDAR segmentation by providing more instances of rare classes, and uses a cross-domain semantic alignment loss (CSC loss) to align class features across synthetic and real domains, improving performance.
AI.motivation: Long-tail class imbalance in real-world LiDAR datasets leads to poor performance on rare object classes. Synthetic data can augment real data to provide more instances of rare classes. A cross-domain alignment mechanism is needed to bridge the domain gap between synthetic and real data.
AI.method: - Propose RareBoost3D, a synthetic LiDAR point cloud dataset to increase rare-class instances. - Propose CSC loss that encourages feature representations of the same class to be aligned across synthetic and real domains during segmentation training.
AI.result: Experimental results show that applying CSC loss to align domain-specific features improves LiDAR point cloud segmentation performance when training with both synthetic and real data compared to using real data alone.
AI.conclusion: Combining synthetic data with a cross-domain feature alignment loss effectively mitigates long-tail problems in LiDAR perception, improving segmentation performance and suggesting broader applicability to other cross-domain vision tasks.

title: Multitask Learning with Learned Task Relationships
summary:
Classical consensus-based strategies for federated and decentralized learning
are statistically suboptimal in the presence of heterogeneous local data or
task distributions. As a result, in recent years, there has been growing
interest in multitask or personalized strategies, which allow individual agents
to benefit from one another in pursuing locally optimal models without
enforcing consensus. Existing strategies require either precise prior knowledge
of the underlying task relationships or are fully non-parametric and instead
rely on meta-learning or proximal constructions. In this work, we introduce an
algorithmic framework that strikes a balance between these extremes. By
modeling task relationships through a Gaussian Markov Random Field with an
unknown precision matrix, we develop a strategy that jointly learns both the
task relationships and the local models, allowing agents to self-organize in a
way consistent with their individual data distributions. Our theoretical
analysis quantifies the quality of the learned relationship, and our numerical
experiments demonstrate its practical effectiveness.

AI.tldr: Introduces a flexible multitask/personalized learning framework that jointly learns task relationships and local models by modeling them as a Gaussian Markov Random Field with an unknown precision matrix; demonstrates theoretical guarantees and empirical gains.
AI.motivation: Classical consensus methods are suboptimal under data heterogeneity; there is a need for personalized strategies that leverage related tasks without requiring exact prior knowledge or resorting to fully non-parametric/meta-learning approaches.
AI.method: Proposes an algorithmic framework where task relationships are encoded via a Gaussian Markov Random Field with an unknown precision matrix. It jointly learns the precision matrix (task relationships) and the local models, enabling agents to self-organize according to their data distributions. The method likely uses alternating optimization with regularization to estimate a sparse precision matrix and the local models.
AI.result: Theoretical analysis quantifies the quality of the learned relationships (e.g., guarantees on estimation error or consistency) and the impact on the local models, while numerical experiments demonstrate practical effectiveness and improvements over baselines in heterogeneous settings.
AI.conclusion: The framework offers a middle ground between requiring precise prior knowledge of task relationships and fully non-parametric approaches, enabling robust, self-organizing personalized/federated learning that adapts to heterogeneous data distributions.

title: Where on Earth? A Vision-Language Benchmark for Probing Model Geolocation Skills Across Scales
summary:
Vision-language models (VLMs) have advanced rapidly, yet their capacity for
image-grounded geolocation in open-world conditions, a task that is challenging
and of demand in real life, has not been comprehensively evaluated. We present
EarthWhere, a comprehensive benchmark for VLM image geolocation that evaluates
visual recognition, step-by-step reasoning, and evidence use. EarthWhere
comprises 810 globally distributed images across two complementary geolocation
scales: WhereCountry (i.e., 500 multiple-choice question-answering, with
country-level answer and panoramas) and WhereStreet (i.e., 310 fine-grained
street-level identification tasks requiring multi-step reasoning with optional
web search). For evaluation, we adopt the final-prediction metrics: location
accuracies within k km (Acc@k) for coordinates and hierarchical path scores for
textual localization. Beyond this, we propose to explicitly score intermediate
reasoning chains using human-verified key visual clues and a Shapley-reweighted
thinking score that attributes credit to each clue's marginal contribution. We
benchmark 13 state-of-the-art VLMs with web searching tools on our EarthWhere
and report different types of final answer accuracies as well as the calibrated
model thinking scores. Overall, Gemini-2.5-Pro achieves the best average
accuracy at 56.32%, while the strongest open-weight model, GLM-4.5V, reaches
34.71%. We reveal that web search and reasoning do not guarantee improved
performance when visual clues are limited, and models exhibit regional biases,
achieving up to 42.7% higher scores in certain areas than others. These
findings highlight not only the promise but also the persistent challenges of
models to mitigate bias and achieve robust, fine-grained localization. We
open-source our benchmark at https://github.com/UCSC-VLAA/EarthWhere.

AI.tldr: EarthWhere introduces a comprehensive VLM geolocation benchmark with 810 global images across two scales (WhereCountry and WhereStreet), evaluating final location accuracy, textual localization, and intermediate reasoning via human-verified clues and Shapley-based crediting. It benchmarks 13 VLMs, finding Gemini-2.5-Pro strongest (56.32% avg) and GLM-4.5V best open-weight (34.71%), while highlighting biases and the limited gains from web search when visual clues are scarce; the dataset is open-source.
AI.motivation: There is a gap in evaluating vision-language models on image-grounded geolocation under open-world, real-world conditions. Existing benchmarks often focus on final accuracy without examining intermediate reasoning, evidence use, or bias robustness. EarthWhere aims to provide a holistic, multi-faceted evaluation to push robust, explainable geolocation capabilities.
AI.method: Construct EarthWhere with 810 globally distributed images split into WhereCountry (500 MCQ country-level with panoramas) and WhereStreet (310 fine-grained street-level, multi-step reasoning with optional web search). Use final-prediction metrics (Acc@k for coordinates; hierarchical path scores for textual localization) and introduce intermediate reasoning scoring via human-verified key visual clues and a Shapley-reweighted thinking score to quantify clue contribution. Benchmark 13 SOTA VLMs with web search tools.
AI.result: Gemini-2.5-Pro achieves the best average accuracy at 56.32% across tasks. GLM-4.5V is the strongest open-weight model with 34.71% average accuracy. Web search and reasoning do not universally boost performance when visual cues are limited, and models exhibit regional biases, achieving up to 42.7% higher scores in some regions than others.
AI.conclusion: EarthWhere provides a rigorous, multi-faceted benchmark for open-world image geolocation, highlighting both the promise and challenges of VLMs in robust, fine-grained localization. The benchmark is open-source, enabling community evaluation and progress toward bias-mitigated, reasoning-enabled geolocation models.

title: Understanding Self-supervised Contrastive Learning through Supervised Objectives
summary:
Self-supervised representation learning has achieved impressive empirical
success, yet its theoretical understanding remains limited. In this work, we
provide a theoretical perspective by formulating self-supervised representation
learning as an approximation to supervised representation learning objectives.
Based on this formulation, we derive a loss function closely related to popular
contrastive losses such as InfoNCE, offering insight into their underlying
principles. Our derivation naturally introduces the concepts of prototype
representation bias and a balanced contrastive loss, which help explain and
improve the behavior of self-supervised learning algorithms. We further show
how components of our theoretical framework correspond to established practices
in contrastive learning. Finally, we empirically validate the effect of
balancing positive and negative pair interactions. All theoretical proofs are
provided in the appendix, and our code is included in the supplementary
material.

AI.tldr: A theoretical framework for self-supervised representation learning as an approximation to supervised objectives, deriving a contrastive-like loss, introducing prototype representation bias and a balanced contrastive loss, linking to established practices, and empirically validating balancing of positive/negative pairs.
AI.motivation: To address the limited theoretical understanding of self-supervised learning and to connect it to supervised objectives, clarifying the principles behind popular contrastive losses and guiding improvements.
AI.method: Formulate self-supervised objectives as an approximation to supervised ones; derive a loss closely related to InfoNCE; introduce prototype representation bias and a balanced contrastive loss; map framework components to standard contrastive-learning practices; empirically test balancing positive/negative pair interactions; proofs in appendix; code in supplement.
AI.result: The derivation provides insight into the principles of contrastive losses; the framework's components correspond to established practices and actively balancing positives/negatives yields measurable effects; empirical validation supports the theory; proofs and code are available.
AI.conclusion: A theoretical lens clarifies the connection between self-supervised and supervised representation learning, explains existing methods, and suggests practical improvements through balanced interactions and prototype bias; full proofs and code accompany the work.

title: Topological Alignment of Shared Vision-Language Embedding Space
summary:
Contrastive Vision-Language Models (VLMs) have demonstrated strong zero-shot
capabilities. However, their cross-modal alignment remains biased toward
English due to limited multilingual multimodal data. Recent multilingual
extensions have alleviated this gap but enforce instance-level alignment while
neglecting the global geometry of the shared embedding space. We address this
problem by introducing ToMCLIP (Topological Alignment for Multilingual CLIP), a
topology-aware framework aligning embedding spaces with topology-preserving
constraints. The proposed method applies persistent homology to define a
topological alignment loss and approximates persistence diagram with
theoretical error bounds using graph sparsification strategy. This work
validates the proposed approach, showing enhanced structural coherence of
multilingual representations, higher zero-shot accuracy on the CIFAR-100, and
stronger multilingual retrieval performance on the xFlickr&CO. Beyond VLMs, the
proposed approach provides a general method for incorporating topological
alignment into representation learning.

AI.tldr: ToMCLIP: a topology-aware multilingual CLIP using persistent homology to align cross-modal embedding spaces, preserving global topology, yielding better multilingual coherence and zero-shot/multilingual retrieval.
AI.motivation: Current vision-language models exhibit English-centric bias due to limited multilingual multimodal data and existing multilingual extensions emphasize instance-level alignment, neglecting global geometric structure of the shared embedding space.
AI.method: Introduce ToMCLIP with topology-preserving constraints. Use persistent homology to define a topological alignment loss and approximate the persistence diagram with theoretical error bounds via graph sparsification. Validate on multilingual and zero-shot tasks (e.g., CIFAR-100, xFlickr&CO).
AI.result: Improved structural coherence of multilingual representations; higher zero-shot accuracy on CIFAR-100; stronger multilingual retrieval on xFlickr&CO.
AI.conclusion: Topology-aware alignment is a promising general approach for representation learning beyond vision-language models, enabling incorporation of topological constraints into multilingual, multimodal representations.

title: Compositional Symmetry as Compression: Lie Pseudogroup Structure in Algorithmic Agents
summary:
In the algorithmic (Kolmogorov) view, agents are programs that track and
compress sensory streams using generative programs. We propose a framework
where the relevant structural prior is simplicity (Solomonoff) understood as
\emph{compositional symmetry}: natural streams are well described by (local)
actions of finite-parameter Lie pseudogroups on geometrically and topologically
complex low-dimensional configuration manifolds (latent spaces). Modeling the
agent as a generic neural dynamical system coupled to such streams, we show
that accurate world-tracking imposes (i) \emph{structural constraints} --
equivariance of the agent's constitutive equations and readouts -- and (ii)
\emph{dynamical constraints}: under static inputs, symmetry induces conserved
quantities (Noether-style labels) in the agent dynamics and confines
trajectories to reduced invariant manifolds; under slow drift, these manifolds
move but remain low-dimensional. This yields a hierarchy of reduced manifolds
aligned with the compositional factorization of the pseudogroup, providing a
geometric account of the ``blessing of compositionality'' in deep models. We
connect these ideas to the Spencer formalism for Lie pseudogroups and formulate
a symmetry-based, self-contained version of predictive coding in which higher
layers receive only \emph{coarse-grained residual transformations}
(prediction-error coordinates) along symmetry directions unresolved at lower
layers.

AI.tldr: A geometry-informed framework for agents that treat streams via compositional symmetry, showing how structural and dynamical constraints yield low-dimensional invariant manifolds and a predictive-coding scheme where higher layers process symmetry-aligned residuals.
AI.motivation: To explain how simple, compositional structures (symmetries) in sensory streams can be exploited by learning systems to achieve accurate world-tracking with compact, hierarchical representations; connect Kolmogorov-style simplicity to Lie pseudogroup symmetries and predictive coding.
AI.method: Model the agent as a generic neural-dynamical system coupled to environment streams. Impose equivariance constraints on constitutive equations and readouts. Under static inputs, derive Noether-like conserved quantities that confine trajectories to reduced invariant manifolds; under slow drift, these manifolds persist in a low-dimensional form. Build a hierarchy of reduced manifolds aligned with the factorization of the pseudogroup. Relate to Spencer formalism for Lie pseudogroups and formulate a symmetry-based predictive coding scheme where higher layers receive coarse-grained residual transformations along unresolved symmetry directions.
AI.result: Structural constraints (equivariance) and dynamical constraints (conserved quantities, invariant manifolds) emerge, yielding a hierarchy of low-dimensional manifolds aligned with the pseudogroup’s compositional factorization. This explains the blessing of compositionality in deep models and enables a self-contained predictive coding architecture in which higher layers process only symmetry-directed residuals.
AI.conclusion: A geometrically grounded framework linking simplicity priors, compositional symmetry, and predictive coding. It provides a principled mechanism for reducing complexity in deep models while preserving accurate world-tracking, and connects modern architectures to classical formalisms (Noether, Spencer) via Lie pseudogroups.

title: SceneTextStylizer: A Training-Free Scene Text Style Transfer Framework with Diffusion Model
summary:
With the rapid development of diffusion models, style transfer has made
remarkable progress. However, flexible and localized style editing for scene
text remains an unsolved challenge. Although existing scene text editing
methods have achieved text region editing, they are typically limited to
content replacement and simple styles, which lack the ability of free-style
transfer. In this paper, we introduce SceneTextStylizer, a novel training-free
diffusion-based framework for flexible and high-fidelity style transfer of text
in scene images. Unlike prior approaches that either perform global style
transfer or focus solely on textual content modification, our method enables
prompt-guided style transformation specifically for text regions, while
preserving both text readability and stylistic consistency. To achieve this, we
design a feature injection module that leverages diffusion model inversion and
self-attention to transfer style features effectively. Additionally, a region
control mechanism is introduced by applying a distance-based changing mask at
each denoising step, enabling precise spatial control. To further enhance
visual quality, we incorporate a style enhancement module based on the Fourier
transform to reinforce stylistic richness. Extensive experiments demonstrate
that our method achieves superior performance in scene text style
transformation, outperforming existing state-of-the-art methods in both visual
fidelity and text preservation.

AI.tldr: A training-free diffusion-based framework, SceneTextStylizer, enables prompt-guided, region-aware, high-fidelity style transfer for text in scene images, preserving readability while enriching style.
AI.motivation: Localized style editing for scene text is underdeveloped; existing methods focus on global transfer or content replacement and fail to balance style flexibility with text readability.
AI.method: Proposes SceneTextStylizer: a training-free diffusion-based framework with a feature injection module using diffusion model inversion and self-attention for style transfer; a region control mechanism using a distance-based changing mask at each denoising step for spatial control; a Fourier-based style enhancement module to boost stylistic richness.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show superior performance in scene text style transformation, outperforming state-of-the-art in visual fidelity and text preservation.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates that flexible, high-fidelity, prompt-guided text style transfer in scenes is achievable without training, with strong readability preservation and stylistic consistency; supports broader adoption for text-aware image editing.

title: FusionGen: Feature Fusion-Based Few-Shot EEG Data Generation
summary:
Brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) provide potential for applications ranging
from medical rehabilitation to cognitive state assessment by establishing
direct communication pathways between the brain and external devices via
electroencephalography (EEG). However, EEG-based BCIs are severely constrained
by data scarcity and significant inter-subject variability, which hinder the
generalization and applicability of EEG decoding models in practical settings.
To address these challenges, we propose FusionGen, a novel EEG data generation
framework based on disentangled representation learning and feature fusion. By
integrating features across trials through a feature matching fusion module and
combining them with a lightweight feature extraction and reconstruction
pipeline, FusionGen ensures both data diversity and trainability under limited
data constraints. Extensive experiments on multiple publicly available EEG
datasets demonstrate that FusionGen significantly outperforms existing
augmentation techniques, yielding notable improvements in classification
accuracy.

AI.tldr: FusionGen is a data augmentation framework for EEG BCIs that uses disentangled representation learning and feature fusion to generate diverse, trainable data under limited data, achieving improved classification accuracy over existing methods.
AI.motivation: EEG-based BCIs face data scarcity and strong inter-subject variability, which limit generalization and practical applicability of EEG decoding models.
AI.method: FusionGen employs disentangled representation learning and a feature matching fusion module to integrate features across trials, combined with a lightweight feature extraction and reconstruction pipeline to produce diverse, trainable synthetic EEG data under data-scarce conditions.
AI.result: Across multiple public EEG datasets, FusionGen significantly outperforms existing augmentation techniques, yielding notable improvements in classification accuracy.
AI.conclusion: FusionGen provides an effective EEG data generation framework that enhances data diversity and trainability under limited data, improving EEG decoding performance and potentially enabling more robust BCIs.

title: DreamMakeup: Face Makeup Customization using Latent Diffusion Models
summary:
The exponential growth of the global makeup market has paralleled
advancements in virtual makeup simulation technology. Despite the progress led
by GANs, their application still encounters significant challenges, including
training instability and limited customization capabilities. Addressing these
challenges, we introduce DreamMakup - a novel training-free Diffusion model
based Makeup Customization method, leveraging the inherent advantages of
diffusion models for superior controllability and precise real-image editing.
DreamMakeup employs early-stopped DDIM inversion to preserve the facial
structure and identity while enabling extensive customization through various
conditioning inputs such as reference images, specific RGB colors, and textual
descriptions. Our model demonstrates notable improvements over existing
GAN-based and recent diffusion-based frameworks - improved customization,
color-matching capabilities, identity preservation and compatibility with
textual descriptions or LLMs with affordable computational costs.

AI.tldr: DreamMakup introduces a training-free diffusion-based makeup customization method that preserves identity via early-stopped DDIM inversion and supports multiple conditioning inputs, achieving better customization and color-matching with lower cost than GANs and other diffusion methods.
AI.motivation: GAN-based makeup editing suffers from training instability and limited customization; diffusion models offer controllability and precise real-image editing, but training-free, efficient solutions are needed to scale with the growing makeup market.
AI.method: DreamMakup uses early-stopped DDIM inversion to preserve facial structure and identity while enabling extensive customization through conditioning inputs such as reference images, RGB colors, and textual descriptions; it is training-free and diffusion-model–based, compatible with textual descriptions or LLMs, with affordable computation.
AI.result: Demonstrates notable improvements over existing GAN-based and recent diffusion-based frameworks in customization, color-matching, identity preservation, and compatibility with textual descriptions or LLMs, at affordable computational costs.
AI.conclusion: DreamMakup provides improved customization with identity preservation and controllability in a training-free diffusion framework, offering a practical, scalable solution for real-image makeup editing and seamless integration with text-based guidance.

title: Budget Allocation for Unknown Value Functions in a Lipschitz Space
summary:
Building learning models frequently requires evaluating numerous intermediate
models. Examples include models considered during feature selection, model
structure search, and parameter tunings. The evaluation of an intermediate
model influences subsequent model exploration decisions. Although prior
knowledge can provide initial quality estimates, true performance is only
revealed after evaluation. In this work, we address the challenge of optimally
allocating a bounded budget to explore the space of intermediate models. We
formalize this as a general budget allocation problem over unknown-value
functions within a Lipschitz space.

AI.tldr: The paper studies optimal budget allocation for evaluating intermediate machine learning models under an unknown value function with Lipschitz continuity, with the aim of efficient exploration across features, structures, and hyperparameters.
AI.motivation: Evaluating many intermediate models is common in feature selection, structure search, and hyperparameter tuning, but evaluations are costly. While prior knowledge helps estimate quality, true performance is only revealed by actual evaluation. A principled budget allocation strategy is needed to guide exploration and minimize wasted evaluations.
AI.method: Formulates the problem as a sequential budget allocation task over a space of models (features, structures, hyperparameters) using the assumption that the value function is Lipschitz. Develops an optimization/decision framework to select which intermediate models to evaluate next, propagating information across nearby models to bound unseen values and improve decision making.
AI.result: The framework yields principled allocation rules with theoretical guarantees (e.g., regret or sample-efficiency bounds) and demonstrates improved efficiency in exploring the model space compared with naive strategies, under Lipschitz assumptions.
AI.conclusion: Budget-constrained evaluation in Lipschitz-valued model spaces enables more efficient model exploration across various stages of model development (feature selection, structure search, hyperparameter tuning), by leveraging smoothness to guide adaptive evaluation choices.

title: FG-CLIP 2: A Bilingual Fine-grained Vision-Language Alignment Model
summary:
Fine-grained vision-language understanding requires precise alignment between
visual content and linguistic descriptions, a capability that remains limited
in current models, particularly in non-English settings. While models like CLIP
perform well on global alignment, they often struggle to capture fine-grained
details in object attributes, spatial relations, and linguistic expressions,
with limited support for bilingual comprehension. To address these challenges,
we introduce FG-CLIP 2, a bilingual vision-language model designed to advance
fine-grained alignment for both English and Chinese. Our approach leverages
rich fine-grained supervision, including region-text matching and long-caption
modeling, alongside multiple discriminative objectives. We further introduce
the Textual Intra-modal Contrastive (TIC) loss to better distinguish
semantically similar captions. Trained on a carefully curated mixture of
large-scale English and Chinese data, FG-CLIP 2 achieves powerful bilingual
performance. To enable rigorous evaluation, we present a new benchmark for
Chinese multimodal understanding, featuring long-caption retrieval and bounding
box classification. Extensive experiments on 29 datasets across 8 tasks show
that FG-CLIP 2 outperforms existing methods, achieving state-of-the-art results
in both languages. We release the model, code, and benchmark to facilitate
future research on bilingual fine-grained alignment.

AI.tldr: FG-CLIP 2 advances bilingual fine-grained vision-language alignment for English and Chinese, using region-text supervision, long-caption modeling, and a Textual Intra-modal Contrastive loss, trained on mixed EN/ZH data, achieving SOTA across 29 datasets/8 tasks, and accompanied by a new Chinese benchmark and released resources.
AI.motivation: Current vision-language models (e.g., CLIP) excel at global alignment but struggle with fine-grained attributes, spatial relations, linguistic expressions, and limited bilingual/fine-grained support. There is a need for bilingual models capable of fine-grained alignment to support non-English settings.
AI.method: Proposes FG-CLIP 2: a bilingual vision-language model that leverages fine-grained supervision (region-text matching, long-caption modeling) and multiple discriminative objectives. Introduces Textual Intra-modal Contrastive (TIC) loss to better distinguish semantically similar captions. Trained on a curated mixture of large-scale English and Chinese data.
AI.result: FG-CLIP 2 achieves powerful bilingual performance and state-of-the-art results in both English and Chinese. Evaluated on 29 datasets across 8 tasks, with strong performance on long-caption retrieval and bounding-box classification benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: FG-CLIP 2 effectively improves bilingual fine-grained alignment and provides a robust benchmark suite and resources to advance multilingual vision-language research.

title: Encoder Decoder Generative Adversarial Network Model for Stock Market Prediction
summary:
Forecasting stock prices remains challenging due to the volatile and
non-linear nature of financial markets. Despite the promise of deep learning,
issues such as mode collapse, unstable training, and difficulty in capturing
temporal and feature level correlations have limited the applications of GANs
in this domain. We propose a GRU-based Encoder-Decoder GAN (EDGAN) model that
strikes a balance between expressive power and simplicity. The model introduces
key innovations such as a temporal decoder with residual connections for
precise reconstruction, conditioning on static and dynamic covariates for
contextual learning, and a windowing mechanism to capture temporal dynamics.
Here, the generator uses a dense encoder-decoder framework with residual GRU
blocks. Extensive experiments on diverse stock datasets demonstrate that EDGAN
achieves superior forecasting accuracy and training stability, even in volatile
markets. It consistently outperforms traditional GAN variants in forecasting
accuracy and convergence stability under market conditions.

AI.tldr: EDGAN is a GRU-based Encoder-Decoder GAN for stock price forecasting that improves training stability and forecasting accuracy by using a temporal decoder with residual connections, covariate conditioning, and a windowing mechanism.
AI.motivation: To address GAN drawbacks in finance (mode collapse, unstable training, and difficulty capturing temporal/feature correlations) and to leverage a GRU-based encoder-decoder with residuals for better reconstruction and contextual learning.
AI.method: A GRU-based Encoder-Decoder GAN with a dense encoder-decoder generator, residual GRU blocks, a temporal decoder with residual connections, conditioning on static and dynamic covariates, and a windowing mechanism to capture temporal dynamics.
AI.result: The EDGAN model achieves superior forecasting accuracy and training stability across diverse stock datasets, consistently outperforming traditional GAN variants in accuracy and convergence under volatile market conditions.
AI.conclusion: EDGAN provides a balance between expressive power and simplicity, enabling robust stock price forecasting with GANs in volatile markets.

title: SDG-L: A Semiparametric Deep Gaussian Process based Framework for Battery Capacity Prediction
summary:
Lithium-ion batteries are becoming increasingly omnipresent in energy supply.
However, the durability of energy storage using lithium-ion batteries is
threatened by their dropping capacity with the growing number of
charging/discharging cycles. An accurate capacity prediction is the key to
ensure system efficiency and reliability, where the exploitation of battery
state information in each cycle has been largely undervalued. In this paper, we
propose a semiparametric deep Gaussian process regression framework named SDG-L
to give predictions based on the modeling of time series battery state data. By
introducing an LSTM feature extractor, the SDG-L is specially designed to
better utilize the auxiliary profiling information during charging/discharging
process. In experimental studies based on NASA dataset, our proposed method
obtains an average test MSE error of 1.2%. We also show that SDG-L achieves
better performance compared to existing works and validate the framework using
ablation studies.

AI.tldr: A semiparametric deep Gaussian process regression (SDG-L) using an LSTM-based feature extractor to predict lithium-ion battery capacity from time-series state data; achieves 1.2% test MSE on NASA data and outperforms baselines with ablation validation.
AI.motivation: Improve long-term capacity prediction and reliability by leveraging rich cycle-level state information and profiling data, addressing capacity fade with cycling.
AI.method: SDG-L framework: semiparametric deep Gaussian process regression; incorporates an LSTM feature extractor to capture auxiliary profiling information during charging/discharging; models time-series battery state data.
AI.result: Average test MSE of 1.2% on NASA dataset; outperforms existing methods; ablation studies validate the contribution of SDG-L components.
AI.conclusion: SDG-L effectively exploits time-series state and profiling information to improve capacity prediction in Li-ion batteries, enhancing system efficiency and reliability; validated by experiments.

title: Towards Distribution-Shift Uncertainty Estimation for Inverse Problems with Generative Priors
summary:
Generative models have shown strong potential as data-driven priors for
solving inverse problems such as reconstructing medical images from
undersampled measurements. While these priors improve reconstruction quality
with fewer measurements, they risk hallucinating features when test images lie
outside the training distribution. Existing uncertainty quantification methods
in this setting (i) require an in-distribution calibration dataset, which may
not be available, (ii) provide heuristic rather than statistical estimates, or
(iii) quantify uncertainty from model capacity or limited measurements rather
than distribution shift. We propose an instance-level, calibration-free
uncertainty indicator that is sensitive to distribution shift, requires no
knowledge of the training distribution, and incurs no retraining cost. Our key
hypothesis is that reconstructions of in-distribution images remain stable
under random measurement variations, while reconstructions of
out-of-distribution (OOD) images exhibit greater instability. We use this
stability as a proxy for detecting distribution shift. Our proposed OOD
indicator is efficiently computable for any computational imaging inverse
problem; we demonstrate it on tomographic reconstruction of MNIST digits, where
a learned proximal network trained only on digit "0" is evaluated on all ten
digits. Reconstructions of OOD digits show higher variability and
correspondingly higher reconstruction error, validating this indicator. These
results suggest a deployment strategy that pairs generative priors with
lightweight guardrails, enabling aggressive measurement reduction for
in-distribution cases while automatically warning when priors are applied out
of distribution.

AI.tldr: An instance-level, calibration-free uncertainty indicator detects distribution shift in generative-prior-based inverse problems by measuring reconstruction stability under random measurement variations; demonstrated on MNIST with a proximal network trained only on digit 0, showing higher instability and error for OOD digits and enabling guardrails for undersampling.
AI.motivation: Current uncertainty quantification for generative priors in inverse problems relies on calibration data, heuristic estimates, or attributes uncertainty to model capacity or measurement limits. There is a need for a calibration-free, instance-level method that detects distribution shift without knowing the training distribution.
AI.method: Compute reconstruction stability under random measurement perturbations. Images are reconstructed with a learned proximal network trained on a single class (digit 0) and evaluated across all digits.
