The instability of reconstructions serves as an OOD indicator, requiring no retraining and applicable to any computational imaging inverse problem.
AI.result: Reconstructions of out-of-distribution digits exhibit higher variability (instability) and higher reconstruction error compared to in-distribution digits, validating the proposed OOD indicator.
AI.conclusion: The instability-based OOD indicator offers calibration-free, instance-level detection of distribution shift, enabling a deployment strategy that uses generative priors with lightweight guardrails: aggressive undersampling for in-distribution cases and automatic warning when priors are applied out of distribution.

title: ImpMIA: Leveraging Implicit Bias for Membership Inference Attack under Realistic Scenarios
summary:
Determining which data samples were used to train a model-known as Membership
Inference Attack (MIA)-is a well-studied and important problem with
implications for data privacy. Black-box methods presume access only to the
model's outputs and often rely on training auxiliary reference models. While
they have shown strong empirical performance, they rely on assumptions that
rarely hold in real-world settings: (i) the attacker knows the training
hyperparameters; (ii) all available non-training samples come from the same
distribution as the training data; and (iii) the fraction of training data in
the evaluation set is known. In this paper, we demonstrate that removing these
assumptions leads to a significant drop in the performance of black-box
attacks. We introduce ImpMIA, a Membership Inference Attack that exploits the
Implicit Bias of neural networks, hence removes the need to rely on any
reference models and their assumptions. ImpMIA is a white-box attack -- a
setting which assumes access to model weights and is becoming increasingly
realistic given that many models are publicly available (e.g., via Hugging
Face). Building on maximum-margin implicit bias theory, ImpMIA uses the
Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) optimality conditions to identify training samples.
This is done by finding the samples whose gradients most strongly reconstruct
the trained model's parameters. As a result, ImpMIA achieves state-of-the-art
performance compared to both black and white box attacks in realistic settings
where only the model weights and a superset of the training data are available.

AI.tldr: White-box membership inference attack (ImpMIA) using maximum-margin implicit bias with KKT conditions to identify training samples, removing reliance on reference models; achieves state-of-the-art performance in realistic settings where only model weights and a superset of training data are available.
AI.motivation: Membership inference attacks threaten data privacy; black-box MIAs rely on assumptions (training hyperparameters, data distribution, known training fraction) that rarely hold in practice. There is a need for attacks that do not depend on reference models and operate under more realistic threat models.
AI.method: ImpMIA is a white-box attack that leverages implicit bias theory. It applies Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) optimality conditions to identify training samples by finding those samples whose gradients most strongly reconstruct the trained model parameters. It does not require reference models and uses only the model weights (and a superset of the training data).
AI.result: Empirically achieves state-of-the-art performance compared to both black-box and white-box attacks in realistic settings where only model weights and a superset of the training data are available.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates a more realistic and potent threat to privacy by removing reliance on reference models and common assumptions. Highlights the potential vulnerability of publicly available models and underscores the need for defense mechanisms against white-box MIAs.

title: IUT-Plug: A Plug-in tool for Interleaved Image-Text Generation
summary:
Existing vision language models (VLMs), including GPT-4 and DALL-E, often
struggle to preserve logic, object identity, and style in multimodal image-text
generation. This limitation significantly hinders the generalization capability
of VLMs in complex image-text input-output scenarios. To address this issue, we
propose IUT-Plug, a module grounded in an Image Understanding Tree (IUT), which
enhances existing interleaved VLMs through explicit structured reasoning,
thereby mitigating context drift in logic, entity identity, and style. The
proposed framework operates in two stages. (1) A dynamic IUT-Plug extraction
module parses visual scenes into hierarchical symbolic structures. (2) A
coordinated narrative-flow and image synthesis mechanism ensures cross-modal
consistency. To evaluate our approach, we construct a novel benchmark based on
3,000 real human-generated question-answer pairs over fine-tuned large models,
introducing a dynamic evaluation protocol for quantifying context drift in
interleaved VLMs. Experimental results demonstrate that IUT-Plug not only
improves accuracy on established benchmarks but also effectively alleviates the
three critical forms of context drift across diverse multimodal question
answering (QA) scenarios.

AI.tldr: Introduces IUT-Plug with an Image Understanding Tree to enforce structured reasoning in interleaved VLMs, reducing context drift in logic, object identity, and style, and improving QA performance.
AI.motivation: Current vision-language models struggle to preserve logical consistency, object identity, and style when generating text from images, limiting generalization in complex multimodal tasks.
AI.method: Two-stage approach: (1) dynamic IUT-Plug extraction parses scenes into hierarchical symbolic structures (IUT); (2) a coordinated narrative-flow and image synthesis mechanism enforces cross-modal consistency. A dynamic benchmark with 3,000 real human-generated QA pairs evaluates context drift in interleaved VLMs.
AI.result: Empirical results show higher accuracy on standard benchmarks and reduced context drift across logic, identity, and style in diverse multimodal QA scenarios.
AI.conclusion: IUT-Plug provides a viable path to explicit structured reasoning in VLMs, improving generalization and cross-modal consistency; future work could scale the IUT and extend evaluation.

title: ProteinAE: Protein Diffusion Autoencoders for Structure Encoding
summary:
Developing effective representations of protein structures is essential for
advancing protein science, particularly for protein generative modeling.
Current approaches often grapple with the complexities of the SE(3) manifold,
rely on discrete tokenization, or the need for multiple training objectives,
all of which can hinder the model optimization and generalization. We introduce
ProteinAE, a novel and streamlined protein diffusion autoencoder designed to
overcome these challenges by directly mapping protein backbone coordinates from
E(3) into a continuous, compact latent space. ProteinAE employs a
non-equivariant Diffusion Transformer with a bottleneck design for efficient
compression and is trained end-to-end with a single flow matching objective,
substantially simplifying the optimization pipeline. We demonstrate that
ProteinAE achieves state-of-the-art reconstruction quality, outperforming
existing autoencoders. The resulting latent space serves as a powerful
foundation for a latent diffusion model that bypasses the need for explicit
equivariance. This enables efficient, high-quality structure generation that is
competitive with leading structure-based approaches and significantly
outperforms prior latent-based methods. Code is available at
https://github.com/OnlyLoveKFC/ProteinAE_v1.

AI.tldr: ProteinAE introduces a diffusion autoencoder that maps protein backbone coordinates from E(3) into a continuous latent space using a non-equivariant diffusion transformer with a bottleneck, enabling state-of-the-art reconstruction and efficient latent-diffusion–based structure generation without relying on SE(3) equivariance.
AI.motivation: Current protein representation approaches struggle with the SE(3) manifold, discrete tokenization, and the need for multiple training objectives, which hinder optimization and generalization for protein generative modeling.
AI.method: End-to-end training of a bottleneck, non-equivariant Diffusion Transformer that directly compresses backbone coordinates into a latent space via a single flow-matching objective; the latent space supports a latent diffusion model for high-quality generation, bypassing explicit equivariance.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art reconstruction quality compared with existing autoencoders; the latent space enables efficient, high-quality structure generation competitive with leading structure-based methods and significantly outperforming prior latent-based methods.
AI.conclusion: Provides a streamlined pipeline with reduced optimization complexity and strong generation performance; bypasses the need for explicit SE(3) equivariance; code is released for community use.

title: Chart-RVR: Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards for Explainable Chart Reasoning
summary:
The capabilities of Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) have reached
state-of-the-art on many visual reasoning tasks, including chart reasoning, yet
they still falter on out-of-distribution (OOD) data, and degrade further when
asked to produce their chain-of-thought (CoT) rationales, limiting
explainability. We present Chart-RVR, a general framework that fine-tunes LVLMs
to be more robust and explainable for chart reasoning by coupling Group
Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) with automatically verifiable rewards. Our
framework comprises of three rewards that maximize: (i) correct chart-type
classification, (ii) faithful chart table reconstruction, and (iii) process
conformity. Applied to 3-billion-parameter LVLMs, Chart-RVR consistently
outperforms standard supervised fine-tuning (SFT) on both in-distribution and
out-of-distribution datasets, closing the OOD performance gap while improving
rationale fidelity. The resulting models, the Chart-RVR-3B series, achieve
state-of-the-art results on six chart-reasoning benchmarks spanning in-domain
and OOD settings, surpassing all existing models of comparable size. Beyond
accuracy, Chart-RVR yields more interpretable CoT rationales, strengthening
trust and reliability - showcasing the power of verifiable rewards with GRPO
for training reliable, interpretable chart-reasoning models.

AI.tldr: Chart-RVR fine-tunes LVLMs with GRPO and verifiable rewards to improve chart reasoning, boosting robustness to OOD data and making chain-of-thought rationales more faithful; 3B-parameter models achieve state-of-the-art on six benchmarks, surpassing comparable-size models.
AI.motivation: LVLMs excel at chart reasoning but struggle with out-of-distribution data and degrade when CoT rationales are required, hindering explainability. There is a need for training frameworks that yield robust, faithful explanations.
AI.method: Fine-tune LVLMs using Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) guided by three automatically verifiable rewards: (1) correct chart-type classification, (2) faithful reconstruction of the chart table, (3) process conformity. The approach targets 3B-parameter LVLMs to improve both accuracy and rationale fidelity under in-domain and OOD conditions.
AI.result: Chart-RVR-3B models outperform standard supervised fine-tuning on both in-distribution and out-of-distribution data, closing the OOD gap and achieving state-of-the-art results on six chart-reasoning benchmarks for models of comparable size. Rationale explanations (CoT) are more faithful and interpretable.
AI.conclusion: Verifiable rewards with GRPO can train reliable, interpretable chart-reasoning models, demonstrating that structured incentive design improves robustness and explanation quality in LVLMs.

title: Trustworthy Retrosynthesis: Eliminating Hallucinations with a Diverse Ensemble of Reaction Scorers
summary:
Retrosynthesis is one of the domains transformed by the rise of generative
models, and it is one where the problem of nonsensical or erroneous outputs
(hallucinations) is particularly insidious: reliable assessment of synthetic
plans is time-consuming, with automatic methods lacking. In this work, we
present RetroTrim, a retrosynthesis system that successfully avoids nonsensical
plans on a set of challenging drug-like targets. Compared to common baselines
in the field, our system is not only the sole method that succeeds in filtering
out hallucinated reactions, but it also results in the highest number of
high-quality paths overall. The key insight behind RetroTrim is the combination
of diverse reaction scoring strategies, based on machine learning models and
existing chemical databases. We show that our scoring strategies capture
different classes of hallucinations by analyzing them on a dataset of labeled
retrosynthetic intermediates. To measure the performance of retrosynthesis
systems, we propose a novel evaluation protocol for reactions and synthetic
paths based on a structured review by expert chemists. Using this protocol, we
compare systems on a set of 32 novel targets, curated to reflect recent trends
in drug structures. While the insights behind our methodology are broadly
applicable to retrosynthesis, our focus is on targets in the drug-like domain.
By releasing our benchmark targets and the details of our evaluation protocol,
we hope to inspire further research into reliable retrosynthesis.

AI.tldr: RetroTrim introduces a multi-score filtering approach for retrosynthesis to curb hallucinations; it outperforms baselines, filters nonsensical reactions, and provides a new expert-reviewed evaluation protocol with 32 drug-like targets.
AI.motivation: Hallucinations in generative retrosynthesis make automatic evaluation slow and unreliable; there is a need for reliable filtering and standardized benchmarks.
AI.method: Combine diverse reaction scoring strategies leveraging machine learning models and chemical databases; analyze hallucinations via labeled intermediates; propose an expert-structured evaluation protocol; benchmark on 32 novel targets.
AI.result: Succeeds in filtering hallucinated reactions; yields the highest number of high-quality synthesis paths among baselines; demonstrates that different scoring strategies cover different hallucination classes; releases benchmark and protocol.
AI.conclusion: RetroTrim offers a practical solution to hallucinations in retrosynthesis and contributes an evaluation framework and dataset to spur further research; broadly applicable to drug-like targets.

title: Mixup Helps Understanding Multimodal Video Better
summary:
Multimodal video understanding plays a crucial role in tasks such as action
recognition and emotion classification by combining information from different
modalities. However, multimodal models are prone to overfitting strong
modalities, which can dominate learning and suppress the contributions of
weaker ones. To address this challenge, we first propose Multimodal Mixup (MM),
which applies the Mixup strategy at the aggregated multimodal feature level to
mitigate overfitting by generating virtual feature-label pairs. While MM
effectively improves generalization, it treats all modalities uniformly and
does not account for modality imbalance during training. Building on MM, we
further introduce Balanced Multimodal Mixup (B-MM), which dynamically adjusts
the mixing ratios for each modality based on their relative contributions to
the learning objective. Extensive experiments on several datasets demonstrate
the effectiveness of our methods in improving generalization and multimodal
robustness.

AI.tldr: Proposes Multimodal Mixup (MM) and Balanced Multimodal Mixup (B-MM) to mitigate overfitting and modality imbalance in multimodal video understanding by performing mixup at the aggregated feature level and dynamically balancing modality contributions; shows improved generalization.
AI.motivation: Multimodal models tend to overfit strong modalities, which can dominate learning and suppress weaker ones. There is a need to account for modality imbalance during training to achieve robust multimodal fusion.
AI.method: 1) Multimodal Mixup (MM) applies the Mixup strategy at the aggregated multimodal feature level to create virtual feature-label pairs and improve generalization. 2) Balanced Multimodal Mixup (B-MM) extends MM by dynamically adjusting the mixing ratios for each modality based on their relative contributions to the learning objective, addressing modality imbalance.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on several datasets show improved generalization and multimodal robustness due to the proposed methods.
AI.conclusion: MM enhances generalization in multimodal video understanding; B-MM further mitigates modality imbalance during training, offering more robust multimodal learning.

title: Digital Twin-enabled Multi-generation Control Co-Design with Deep Reinforcement Learning
comment: to be published in Journal of Mechanical Design
summary:
Control Co-Design (CCD) integrates physical and control system design to
improve the performance of dynamic and autonomous systems. Despite advances in
uncertainty-aware CCD methods, real-world uncertainties remain highly
unpredictable. Multi-generation design addresses this challenge by considering
the full lifecycle of a product: data collected from each generation informs
the design of subsequent generations, enabling progressive improvements in
robustness and efficiency. Digital Twin (DT) technology further strengthens
this paradigm by creating virtual representations that evolve over the
lifecycle through real-time sensing, model updating, and adaptive
re-optimization. This paper presents a DT-enabled CCD framework that integrates
Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) to jointly optimize physical design and
controller. DRL accelerates real-time decision-making by allowing controllers
to continuously learn from data and adapt to uncertain environments. Extending
this approach, the framework employs a multi-generation paradigm, where each
cycle of deployment, operation, and redesign uses collected data to refine DT
models, improve uncertainty quantification through quantile regression, and
inform next-generation designs of both physical components and controllers. The
framework is demonstrated on an active suspension system, where DT-enabled
learning from road conditions and driving behaviors yields smoother and more
stable control trajectories. Results show that the method significantly
enhances dynamic performance, robustness, and efficiency. Contributions of this
work include: (1) extending CCD into a lifecycle-oriented multi-generation
framework, (2) leveraging DTs for continuous model updating and informed
design, and (3) employing DRL to accelerate adaptive real-time decision-making.

AI.tldr: A digital-twin-enabled, multi-generation control co-design framework that uses deep reinforcement learning to jointly optimize physical design and control, improving robustness and efficiency for dynamic systems, demonstrated on active suspension.
AI.motivation: Real-world uncertainties in CCD remain unpredictable; lifecycle data across generations can progressively improve robustness and efficiency; digital twins enable continuous model updates and informed redesign.
AI.method: Integrate DT with CCD; use DRL to jointly optimize physical design and controller; multi-generation cycle: deployment, operation, redesign; quantile regression for uncertainty quantification; DT models updated from real-time sensing and data to inform next-generation designs.
AI.result: Applied to active suspension; learning from road conditions and driving behavior yields smoother, more stable control trajectories; noticeable improvements in dynamic performance, robustness, and efficiency.
AI.conclusion: Proposes lifecycle-oriented, multi-generation CCD framework powered by DTs and DRL; benefits include continuous model updates, informed design decisions, and faster adaptive control.

title: A Survey on Agentic Multimodal Large Language Models
summary:
With the recent emergence of revolutionary autonomous agentic systems,
research community is witnessing a significant shift from traditional static,
passive, and domain-specific AI agents toward more dynamic, proactive, and
generalizable agentic AI. Motivated by the growing interest in agentic AI and
its potential trajectory toward AGI, we present a comprehensive survey on
Agentic Multimodal Large Language Models (Agentic MLLMs). In this survey, we
explore the emerging paradigm of agentic MLLMs, delineating their conceptual
foundations and distinguishing characteristics from conventional MLLM-based
agents. We establish a conceptual framework that organizes agentic MLLMs along
three fundamental dimensions: (i) Agentic internal intelligence functions as
the system's commander, enabling accurate long-horizon planning through
reasoning, reflection, and memory; (ii) Agentic external tool invocation,
whereby models proactively use various external tools to extend their
problem-solving capabilities beyond their intrinsic knowledge; and (iii)
Agentic environment interaction further situates models within virtual or
physical environments, allowing them to take actions, adapt strategies, and
sustain goal-directed behavior in dynamic real-world scenarios. To further
accelerate research in this area for the community, we compile open-source
training frameworks, training and evaluation datasets for developing agentic
MLLMs. Finally, we review the downstream applications of agentic MLLMs and
outline future research directions for this rapidly evolving field. To
continuously track developments in this rapidly evolving field, we will also
actively update a public repository at
https://github.com/HJYao00/Awesome-Agentic-MLLMs.

AI.tldr: This paper surveys Agentic Multimodal LLMs (Agentic MLLMs), proposing a three‑dimensional framework and providing resources, datasets, and directions to accelerate research, with a public repo for updates.
AI.motivation: Motivated by the rise of agentic AI and its potential trajectory toward AGI, the work clarifies concepts, distinguishes agentic MLLMs from conventional MLLMs, and aims to accelerate research through shared resources and evaluation pipelines.
AI.method: The authors present a conceptual framework organized along three dimensions: (i) internal intelligence as the system's commander for long-horizon planning via reasoning, reflection, and memory; (ii) external tool invocation for proactive use of external tools; and (iii) environment interaction enabling action in virtual/physical settings. They compile open-source training frameworks and datasets, review downstream applications, and outline future directions, plus maintain a public repository.
AI.result: The paper establishes a structured framework for agentic MLLMs, curates open-source resources and datasets, surveys applications, and outlines future research directions, aiming to standardize and accelerate progress in the field.
AI.conclusion: Agentic MLLMs constitute a rapidly evolving research area with strong prospects toward AGI; ongoing community collaboration and resource sharing (e.g., the public repo) will be crucial to track developments and advance capabilities.

title: Stock Prediction via a Dual Relation Fusion Network incorporating Static and Dynamic Relations
summary:
Accurate modeling of inter-stock relationships is critical for stock price
forecasting. However, existing methods predominantly focus on single-state
relationships, neglecting the essential complementarity between dynamic and
static inter-stock relations. To solve this problem, we propose a Dual Relation
Fusion Network (DRFN) to capture the long-term relative stability of stock
relation structures while retaining the flexibility to respond to sudden market
shifts. Our approach features a novel relative static relation component that
models time-varying long-term patterns and incorporates overnight informational
influences. We capture dynamic inter-stock relationships through distance-aware
mechanisms, while evolving long-term structures via recurrent fusion of dynamic
relations from the prior day with the pre-defined static relations. Experiments
demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms the baselines across
different markets, with high sensitivity to the co-movement of relational
strength and stock price.

AI.tldr: DRFN unifies static long-term and dynamic short-term inter-stock relations for price forecasting by using a relative static relation component and distance-aware dynamic relations, fused recurrently with prior-day dynamics.
AI.motivation: To address the gap where existing methods model only single-state inter-stock relations, ignoring the complementarity and overnight information that links stocks.
AI.method: Introduce Dual Relation Fusion Network (DRFN) consisting of a relative static relation component capturing time-varying long-term patterns and overnight effects, distance-aware dynamic relation modules, and a recurrent fusion mechanism that blends prior-day dynamic relations with predefined static relations to adapt to market shifts.
AI.result: Empirical results show significant improvements over strong baselines across multiple markets, with performance correlating to how closely relational strength co-moves with stock price.
AI.conclusion: DRFN provides a balanced, adaptable framework that preserves structural stability while remaining responsive to abrupt market changes, yielding robust stock price forecasting.

title: Perspective-aware 3D Gaussian Inpainting with Multi-view Consistency
summary:
3D Gaussian inpainting, a critical technique for numerous applications in
virtual reality and multimedia, has made significant progress with pretrained
diffusion models. However, ensuring multi-view consistency, an essential
requirement for high-quality inpainting, remains a key challenge. In this work,
we present PAInpainter, a novel approach designed to advance 3D Gaussian
inpainting by leveraging perspective-aware content propagation and consistency
verification across multi-view inpainted images. Our method iteratively refines
inpainting and optimizes the 3D Gaussian representation with multiple views
adaptively sampled from a perspective graph. By propagating inpainted images as
prior information and verifying consistency across neighboring views,
PAInpainter substantially enhances global consistency and texture fidelity in
restored 3D scenes. Extensive experiments demonstrate the superiority of
PAInpainter over existing methods. Our approach achieves superior 3D inpainting
quality, with PSNR scores of 26.03 dB and 29.51 dB on the SPIn-NeRF and
NeRFiller datasets, respectively, highlighting its effectiveness and
generalization capability.

AI.tldr: PAInpainter improves 3D Gaussian inpainting with perspective-aware content propagation and multi-view consistency verification, outperforming prior methods on SPIn-NeRF and NeRFiller datasets.
AI.motivation: To achieve robust multi-view consistency and high texture fidelity in 3D Gaussian inpainting, addressing limitations of current diffusion-based methods.
AI.method: Iteratively refine inpainting and optimize 3D Gaussian representation using adaptively sampled multiple views from a perspective graph; propagate inpainted images as priors and verify cross-view consistency with neighboring views.
AI.result: Significant gains in 3D inpainting quality, with PSNR 26.03 dB on SPIn-NeRF and 29.51 dB on NeRFiller; outperforming existing methods; improved global consistency and texture fidelity; generalization demonstrated.
AI.conclusion: PAInpainter advances practical 3D Gaussian inpainting by combining perspective-aware propagation and cross-view verification, enabling better VR/multimedia inpainting results and broader applicability.

title: Attention-Enhanced LSTM Modeling for Improved Temperature and Rainfall Forecasting in Bangladesh
summary:
Accurate climate forecasting is vital for Bangladesh, a region highly
susceptible to climate change impacts on temperature and rainfall. Existing
models often struggle to capture long-range dependencies and complex temporal
patterns in climate data. This study introduces an advanced Long Short-Term
Memory (LSTM) model integrated with an attention mechanism to enhance the
prediction of temperature and rainfall dynamics. Utilizing comprehensive
datasets from 1901-2023, sourced from NASA's POWER Project for temperature and
the Humanitarian Data Exchange for rainfall, the model effectively captures
seasonal and long-term trends. It outperforms baseline models, including
XGBoost, Simple LSTM, and GRU, achieving a test MSE of 0.2411 (normalized
units), MAE of 0.3860 degrees C, R^2 of 0.9834, and NRMSE of 0.0370 for
temperature, and MSE of 1283.67 mm^2, MAE of 22.91 mm, R^2 of 0.9639, and NRMSE
of 0.0354 for rainfall on monthly forecasts. The model demonstrates improved
robustness with only a 20 percent increase in MSE under simulated climate
trends (compared to an approximately 2.2-fold increase in baseline models
without trend features) and a 50 percent degradation under regional variations
(compared to an approximately 4.8-fold increase in baseline models without
enhancements). These results highlight the model's ability to improve
forecasting precision and offer potential insights into the physical processes
governing climate variability in Bangladesh, supporting applications in
climate-sensitive sectors.

AI.tldr: An attention-augmented LSTM improves monthly temperature and rainfall forecasts for Bangladesh, beating baselines and showing strong accuracy and robustness to climate trends and regional variations.
AI.motivation: Bangladesh is highly vulnerable to climate change, with complex temporal patterns in temperature and rainfall that are difficult for traditional models to capture; improving forecast accuracy supports climate-sensitive planning.
AI.method: Develop an attention-enabled LSTM model trained on 1901–2023 monthly data from NASA POWER (temperature) and HDX (rainfall), compare against XGBoost, Simple LSTM, and GRU, and test robustness to simulated climate trends and regional variations.
AI.result: The proposed model achieves a test MSE of 0.2411 (temp) and 1283.67 (rainfall) with R^2 of 0.9834 (temp) and 0.9639 (rainfall); MAE of 0.3860°C (temp) and 22.91 mm (rainfall); NRMSE of 0.0370 (temp) and 0.0354 (rainfall). It outperforms baselines, and exhibits only 20% MSE growth under climate trends (vs ~2.2x for baselines) and 50% degradation under regional variations (vs ~4.8x for baselines).
AI.conclusion: The attention-based LSTM enhances forecasting precision for temperature and rainfall in Bangladesh and offers insights into governing climate processes, with practical value for climate-sensitive sectors.

title: ContextGen: Contextual Layout Anchoring for Identity-Consistent Multi-Instance Generation
summary:
Multi-instance image generation (MIG) remains a significant challenge for
modern diffusion models due to key limitations in achieving precise control
over object layout and preserving the identity of multiple distinct subjects.
To address these limitations, we introduce ContextGen, a novel Diffusion
Transformer framework for multi-instance generation that is guided by both
layout and reference images. Our approach integrates two key technical
contributions: a Contextual Layout Anchoring (CLA) mechanism that incorporates
the composite layout image into the generation context to robustly anchor the
objects in their desired positions, and Identity Consistency Attention (ICA),
an innovative attention mechanism that leverages contextual reference images to
ensure the identity consistency of multiple instances. Recognizing the lack of
large-scale, hierarchically-structured datasets for this task, we introduce
IMIG-100K, the first dataset with detailed layout and identity annotations.
Extensive experiments demonstrate that ContextGen sets a new state-of-the-art,
outperforming existing methods in control precision, identity fidelity, and
overall visual quality.

AI.tldr: Proposes ContextGen, a Diffusion Transformer for multi-instance image generation guided by layout and references; introduces CLA and ICA; releases IMIG-100K; reports state-of-the-art results in control precision, identity fidelity, and visual quality.
AI.motivation: Multi-instance image generation with diffusion models struggles to precisely position and preserve identities of multiple subjects. There is a lack of robust layout anchoring mechanisms and identity-consistent attention, and a lack of large, annotated datasets for this task.
AI.method: ContextGen introduces two main components: (1) Contextual Layout Anchoring (CLA) that injects the composite layout image into the generation context to robustly anchor objects at desired positions, and (2) Identity Consistency Attention (ICA) that uses contextual reference images to maintain identity fidelity across multiple instances. It also introduces IMIG-100K, a large dataset with detailed layout and identity annotations for training and evaluation.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show ContextGen achieves state-of-the-art performance, surpassing existing methods in control precision, identity fidelity, and overall visual quality.
AI.conclusion: ContextGen advances multi-instance diffusion-based generation by providing precise layout control and reliable identity preservation, supported by a new, richly annotated dataset (IMIG-100K).

title: Designing ReLU Generative Networks to Enumerate Trees with a Given Tree Edit Distance
summary:
The generation of trees with a specified tree edit distance has significant
applications across various fields, including computational biology, structured
data analysis, and image processing. Recently, generative networks have been
increasingly employed to synthesize new data that closely resembles the
original datasets. However, the appropriate size and depth of generative
networks required to generate data with a specified tree edit distance remain
unclear. In this paper, we theoretically establish the existence and
construction of generative networks capable of producing trees similar to a
given tree with respect to the tree edit distance. Specifically, for a given
rooted, ordered, and vertex-labeled tree T of size n + 1 with labels from an
alphabet \Sigma, and a non-negative integer d, we prove that all rooted,
ordered, and vertex-labeled trees over \Sigma with tree edit distance at most d
from T can be generated using a ReLU-based generative network with size O(n^3 )
and constant depth. The proposed networks were implemented and evaluated for
generating trees with up to 21 nodes. Due to their deterministic architecture,
the networks successfully generated all valid trees within the specified tree
edit distance. In contrast, state-of-the-art graph generative models GraphRNN
and GraphGDP, which rely on non-deterministic mechanisms, produced
significantly fewer valid trees, achieving validation rates of only up to 35%
and 48%, respectively. These findings provide a theoretical foundation towards
construction of compact generative models and open new directions for exact and
valid tree-structured data generation. An implementation of the proposed
networks is available at https://github.com/MGANN-KU/TreeGen_ReLUNetworks.

AI.tldr: The paper proves and demonstrates a deterministic ReLU-based generative network that can generate all rooted, ordered, vertex-labeled trees within a given tree edit distance d from a fixed tree T, with size O(n^3) and constant depth, and shows exact generation up to 21-node trees, outperforming GraphRNN/GraphGDP in validity.
AI.motivation: Generating tree-structured data with precise similarity constraints is important across domains (bio, structured data, image processing). Prior networks are often non-deterministic or cannot guarantee coverage within a specified distance; there is a gap in understanding how large a network must be to guarantee generation within tree edit distance.
AI.method: The authors prove the existence and provide a constructive method for ReLU-based generative networks. Given a rooted, ordered, vertex-labeled tree T of size n+1 over alphabet Σ and a distance d, the network can generate all trees within tree edit distance ≤ d from T. The construction has size O(n^3) and constant depth. Empirically, networks are implemented for trees up to 21 nodes and are deterministic, guaranteeing generation of all valid trees within the distance; comparisons with GraphRNN and GraphGDP show higher validity (up to 100% in tested cases for their deterministic model) versus 35% and 48%.
AI.result: The networks successfully generate all valid trees within the specified distance for the tested sizes. Relative to non-deterministic baselines (GraphRNN, GraphGDP), the deterministic approach achieves higher validity. An implementation is provided at the GitHub repository.
AI.conclusion: This work provides a theoretical foundation for compact, exact tree-generation models and opens new directions for exact generation of tree-structured data; it demonstrates the viability of deterministic ReLU-based networks for precise proximity-based tree generation and offers a practical implementation, albeit evaluated on relatively small trees (≤21 nodes).

title: Frequency Domain Unlocks New Perspectives for Abdominal Medical Image Segmentation
summary:
Accurate segmentation of tumors and adjacent normal tissues in medical images
is essential for surgical planning and tumor staging. Although foundation
models generally perform well in segmentation tasks, they often struggle to
focus on foreground areas in complex, low-contrast backgrounds, where some
malignant tumors closely resemble normal organs, complicating contextual
differentiation. To address these challenges, we propose the Foreground-Aware
Spectrum Segmentation (FASS) framework. First, we introduce a foreground-aware
module to amplify the distinction between background and the entire volume
space, allowing the model to concentrate more effectively on target areas.
Next, a feature-level frequency enhancement module, based on wavelet transform,
extracts discriminative high-frequency features to enhance boundary recognition
and detail perception. Eventually, we introduce an edge constraint module to
preserve geometric continuity in segmentation boundaries. Extensive experiments
on multiple medical datasets demonstrate superior performance across all
metrics, validating the effectiveness of our framework, particularly in
robustness under complex conditions and fine structure recognition. Our
framework significantly enhances segmentation of low-contrast images, paving
the way for applications in more diverse and complex medical imaging scenarios.

AI.tldr: The Foreground-Aware Spectrum Segmentation (FASS) framework improves tumor/normal tissue segmentation in low-contrast medical images by (1) emphasizing foreground separation, (2) using wavelet-based high-frequency features for boundary/detail recognition, and (3) enforcing edge continuity; yielding superior, robust performance across diverse datasets.
AI.motivation: Medical image segmentation often fails to differentiate foreground tumors from closely resembling normal tissues in low-contrast backgrounds. Foundation models struggle to focus on foreground areas amid complex context, necessitating mechanisms to amplify foreground, sharpen boundaries, and preserve geometric continuity.
AI.method: Introduce a foreground-aware module to enhance foreground-background separation. Apply a feature-level frequency enhancement module using wavelet transforms to extract discriminative high-frequency features for boundary delineation. Include an edge constraint module to enforce geometric continuity of segmentation boundaries.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on multiple medical datasets show superior performance across metrics, with robust results in complex conditions and improved fine-structure recognition, particularly improving performance on low-contrast images.
AI.conclusion: FASS effectively boosts segmentation accuracy for challenging low-contrast medical images and is likely beneficial for broader, more complex imaging scenarios.

title: Provable Anytime Ensemble Sampling Algorithms in Nonlinear Contextual Bandits
summary:
We provide a unified algorithmic framework for ensemble sampling in nonlinear
contextual bandits and develop corresponding regret bounds for two most common
nonlinear contextual bandit settings: Generalized Linear Ensemble Sampling
(\texttt{GLM-ES}) for generalized linear bandits and Neural Ensemble Sampling
(\texttt{Neural-ES}) for neural contextual bandits. Both methods maintain
multiple estimators for the reward model parameters via maximum likelihood
estimation on randomly perturbed data. We prove high-probability frequentist
regret bounds of $\mathcal{O}(d^{3/2} \sqrt{T} + d^{9/2})$ for \texttt{GLM-ES}
and $\mathcal{O}(\widetilde{d} \sqrt{T})$ for \texttt{Neural-ES}, where $d$ is
the dimension of feature vectors, $\widetilde{d}$ is the effective dimension of
a neural tangent kernel matrix, and $T$ is the number of rounds. These regret
bounds match the state-of-the-art results of randomized exploration algorithms
in nonlinear contextual bandit settings. In the theoretical analysis, we
introduce techniques that address challenges specific to nonlinear models.
Practically, we remove fixed-time horizon assumptions by developing anytime
versions of our algorithms, suitable when $T$ is unknown. Finally, we
empirically evaluate \texttt{GLM-ES}, \texttt{Neural-ES}, and their anytime
variants, demonstrating strong performance. Overall, our results establish
ensemble sampling as a provable and practical randomized exploration approach
for nonlinear contextual bandits.

AI.tldr: Proposes an ensemble sampling framework for nonlinear contextual bandits, providing GLM-ES and Neural-ES, with high-probability regret bounds and anytime variants, plus empirical validation.
AI.motivation: To achieve principled, efficient exploration in nonlinear contextual bandits where traditional methods struggle; leverage ensemble sampling to capture model uncertainty and provide strong regret guarantees across generalized linear and neural settings.
AI.method: Maintain multiple estimators of the reward model parameters by maximum likelihood on randomly perturbed data; develop GLM-ES for generalized linear bandits and Neural-ES for neural contextual bandits; derive high-probability regret bounds; create anytime (unknown horizon) variants; provide empirical evaluation.
AI.result: Regret bounds: O(d^{3/2} sqrt(T) + d^{9/2}) for GLM-ES and O(~d sqrt(T)) for Neural-ES; bounds match state-of-the-art for nonlinear exploration; anytime variants; empirical results show strong performance across GLM-ES, Neural-ES, and their variants.
AI.conclusion: Ensemble sampling is a provable and practical randomized exploration approach for nonlinear contextual bandits, valid across GLM and neural models, with effective handling of unknown horizon via anytime algorithms and solid empirical support.

title: COCO-Tree: Compositional Hierarchical Concept Trees for Enhanced Reasoning in Vision Language Models
summary:
Compositional reasoning remains a persistent weakness of modern vision
language models (VLMs): they often falter when a task hinges on understanding
how multiple objects, attributes, and relations interact within an image.
Multiple research works have attempted to improve compositionality performance
by creative tricks such as improving prompt structure, chain of thought
reasoning, etc. A more recent line of work attempts to impart additional
reasoning in VLMs using well-trained Large Language Models (LLMs), which are
far superior in linguistic understanding than VLMs to compensate for the
limited linguistic prowess of VLMs. However, these approaches are either
resource-intensive or do not provide an interpretable reasoning process. In
this paper, we present 'COCO-Tree' - a novel approach that augments VLM outputs
with carefully designed neurosymbolic concept trees learned from LLMs to
improve VLM's linguistic reasoning. COCO-Tree's beam search-inspired reasoning
process boosts compositionality performance and provides a rationale behind VLM
predictions. Empirical results on four compositionality benchmarks, Winoground,
EqBench, ColorSwap, and SugarCrepe, in seven different open-source VLMs with
varying sizes, demonstrate that COCO-Tree significantly improves compositional
generalization by 5-10% over baselines.

AI.tldr: COCO-Tree adds neurosymbolic concept trees learned from LLMs to augment VLM outputs and enable beam-search–like, interpretable reasoning to improve compositional generalization.
AI.motivation: Compositional reasoning remains a weakness in vision-language models. Existing tricks (prompt design, chain-of-thought) or heavy LLM augmentation either lack interpretability or are resource-intensive. There is a need for an efficient, interpretable method to enhance linguistic reasoning in VLMs.
AI.method: Introduce COCO-Tree: neurosymbolic concept trees learned from LLMs that augment VLM outputs. Employ a beam-search–inspired reasoning process over the trees to derive a rationale and improve compositionality. Evaluate across multiple VLMs and benchmarks.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on four compositionality benchmarks (Winoground, EqBench, ColorSwap, SugarCrepe) across seven open-source VLMs shows COCO-Tree yields 5–10% improvements in compositional generalization over baselines.
AI.conclusion: COCO-Tree provides a scalable, interpretable neurosymbolic augmentation that enhances linguistic reasoning in VLMs and improves compositional generalization without prohibitive resource demands; performance gains are demonstrated across diverse models and datasets.

title: A Stochastic Differential Equation Framework for Multi-Objective LLM Interactions: Dynamical Systems Analysis with Code Generation Applications
comment:
Peer-reviewed and accepted to the 39th Conference on Neural
  Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS 2025) DynaFront 2025 Workshop
  (https://sites.google.com/view/dynafrontneurips25)
summary:
We introduce a general stochastic differential equation framework for
modelling multiobjective optimization dynamics in iterative Large Language
Model (LLM) interactions. Our framework captures the inherent stochasticity of
LLM responses through explicit diffusion terms and reveals systematic
interference patterns between competing objectives via an interference matrix
formulation. We validate our theoretical framework using iterative code
generation as a proof-of-concept application, analyzing 400 sessions across
security, efficiency, and functionality objectives. Our results demonstrate
strategy-dependent convergence behaviors with rates ranging from 0.33 to 1.29,
and predictive accuracy achieving R2 = 0.74 for balanced approaches. This work
proposes the feasibility of dynamical systems analysis for multi-objective LLM
interactions, with code generation serving as an initial validation domain.

AI.tldr: Introduces a stochastic differential equation framework to model multiobjective LLM interactions, with diffusion and interference, validated on 400 iterative code-generation sessions; shows strategy-dependent convergence (0.33–1.29) and R2=0.74; demonstrates dynamical systems analysis as feasible for MO-LM interactions.
AI.motivation: Address stochasticity and cross-objective interference in iterative LLM optimization; provide a rigorous dynamical framework to study multi-objective LLM interactions.
AI.method: Develops an SDE with explicit diffusion terms; uses an interference matrix to capture cross-objective interactions; applies to 400 code-generation sessions across security, efficiency, and functionality; estimates convergence rates and predictive accuracy.
AI.result: The framework captures inherent stochasticity, reveals interference patterns, shows strategy-dependent convergence with rates 0.33–1.29; predictive accuracy R^2 = 0.74 for balanced approaches.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates feasibility of dynamical systems analysis for multi-objective LLM interactions; code generation serves as an initial validation domain; suggests applicability to broader MO-LM tasks.

title: High-Resolution Spatiotemporal Modeling with Global-Local State Space Models for Video-Based Human Pose Estimation
comment: This paper is accepted to ICCV 2025
summary:
Modeling high-resolution spatiotemporal representations, including both
global dynamic contexts (e.g., holistic human motion tendencies) and local
motion details (e.g., high-frequency changes of keypoints), is essential for
video-based human pose estimation (VHPE). Current state-of-the-art methods
typically unify spatiotemporal learning within a single type of modeling
structure (convolution or attention-based blocks), which inherently have
difficulties in balancing global and local dynamic modeling and may bias the
network to one of them, leading to suboptimal performance. Moreover, existing
VHPE models suffer from quadratic complexity when capturing global
dependencies, limiting their applicability especially for high-resolution
sequences. Recently, the state space models (known as Mamba) have demonstrated
significant potential in modeling long-range contexts with linear complexity;
however, they are restricted to 1D sequential data. In this paper, we present a
novel framework that extends Mamba from two aspects to separately learn global
and local high-resolution spatiotemporal representations for VHPE.
Specifically, we first propose a Global Spatiotemporal Mamba, which performs 6D
selective space-time scan and spatial- and temporal-modulated scan merging to
efficiently extract global representations from high-resolution sequences. We
further introduce a windowed space-time scan-based Local Refinement Mamba to
enhance the high-frequency details of localized keypoint motions. Extensive
experiments on four benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed model
outperforms state-of-the-art VHPE approaches while achieving better
computational trade-offs.

AI.tldr: A novel VHPE framework that combines global 6D spatiotemporal Mamba with a windowed local refinement Mamba to jointly model global dynamics and local high-frequency keypoint motion, achieving linear-complexity scaling and state-of-the-art performance on four benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Current VHPE models typically rely on a single modeling structure (convolution or attention) which biases toward either global or local dynamics and suffer from quadratic complexity when modeling global dependencies. Extending Mamba (a linear-complexity state-space model) to 2D spatiotemporal domains enables scalable, long-range dependencies and a principled separation of global vs. local representations.
AI.method: 1) Global Spatiotemporal Mamba: 6D selective space-time scan with spatial- and temporal-modulated scan merging to extract global representations from high-resolution sequences. 2) Local Refinement Mamba: windowed space-time scan-based module to enhance high-frequency local keypoint motion details. The two modules are designed to complement each other in an end-to-end VHPE framework.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on four benchmark VHPE datasets shows the proposed framework outperforms state-of-the-art approaches while offering better computational trade-offs, particularly in capturing both global dynamics and local motion details at high resolution.
AI.conclusion: The proposed global+local Mamba framework effectively balances global and local high-resolution spatiotemporal modeling in video-based human pose estimation with scalable linear complexity, delivering superior accuracy and efficiency.

title: Optimally Deep Networks -- Adapting Model Depth to Datasets for Superior Efficiency
summary:
Deep neural networks (DNNs) have provided brilliant performance across
various tasks. However, this success often comes at the cost of unnecessarily
large model sizes, high computational demands, and substantial memory
footprints. Typically, powerful architectures are trained at full depths but
not all datasets or tasks require such high model capacity. Training very deep
architectures on relatively low-complexity datasets frequently leads to wasted
computation, unnecessary energy consumption, and excessive memory usage, which
in turn makes deployment of models on resource-constrained devices impractical.
To address this problem, we introduce Optimally Deep Networks (ODNs), which
provide a balance between model depth and task complexity. Specifically, we
propose a NAS like training strategy called progressive depth expansion, which
begins by training deep networks at shallower depths and incrementally
increases their depth as the earlier blocks converge, continuing this process
until the target accuracy is reached. ODNs use only the optimal depth for the
given datasets, removing redundant layers. This cuts down future training and
inference costs, lowers the memory footprint, enhances computational
efficiency, and facilitates deployment on edge devices. Empirical results show
that the optimal depths of ResNet-18 and ResNet-34 for MNIST and SVHN, achieve
up to 98.64 % and 96.44 % reduction in memory footprint, while maintaining a
competitive accuracy of 99.31 % and 96.08 %, respectively.

AI.tldr: Opt for Optimally Deep Networks (ODNs) with progressive depth expansion to automatically find the optimal depth for a task, reducing memory and computation while keeping accuracy.
AI.motivation: Large models offer strong performance but are often over-parameterized for simpler tasks, leading to wasted computation, high memory usage, and energy consumption. Optimizing depth can enable deployment on resource-constrained devices.
AI.method: Progressive depth expansion: train deep networks at shallow depths first and incrementally increase depth as earlier blocks converge, stopping when target accuracy is reached. This NAS-like strategy identifies and uses the optimal depth for a given dataset, effectively removing redundant layers. Applied to ResNet-18/ResNet-34 on MNIST and SVHN.
AI.result: Memory footprint reductions up to 98.64% for MNIST and 96.44% for SVHN, while achieving competitive accuracies of 99.31% (MNIST) and 96.08% (SVHN).
AI.conclusion: ODNs balance depth with task complexity, reducing training/inference costs and memory footprint, enabling edge deployment, and potentially generalizing to other architectures and datasets.

title: GeoVLMath: Enhancing Geometry Reasoning in Vision-Language Models via Cross-Modal Reward for Auxiliary Line Creation
summary:
Auxiliary lines are essential for solving complex geometric problems but
remain challenging for large vision-language models (LVLMs). Rather than
editing diagrams to draw auxiliary lines, which current image editing models
struggle to render with geometric precision, we generate textual descriptions
of auxiliary-line constructions to better align with the representational
strengths of LVLMs. To bridge the gap between textual descriptions and spatial
structure, we propose a reinforcement learning framework that enhances
diagram-text alignment. At the core of our approach is a cross-modal reward
that evaluates how well the generated auxiliary-line description for an
original diagram matches a ground-truth auxiliary-line diagram. Built on this
reward, we present GeoVLMath, an open-source LVLM tailored to auxiliary-line
reasoning in solid geometry. This fine-grained signal drives a GRPO-based RL
stage, yielding precise diagram-text alignment. To support training, we develop
a scalable data creation pipeline and construct AuxSolidMath, a dataset of
3,018 real-exam geometry problems with paired diagrams and aligned textual
fields. At the 3B and 7B scales, GeoVLMath achieves competitive and often
superior performance compared with strong open-source and proprietary LVLMs on
auxiliary-line reasoning benchmarks.

AI.tldr: An open-source LVLM, GeoVLMath, learns auxiliary-line reasoning in solid geometry by generating textual auxiliary-line constructions and aligning them with diagrams via a cross-modal RL reward, fueled by the AuxSolidMath dataset; it achieves strong performance at 3B/7B scales on auxiliary-line benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Auxiliary lines are central to solving geometric problems but are hard for large vision-language models to handle. Editing diagrams is impractical; textual constructions can leverage LVLM strengths, but require alignment between text and spatial structure.
AI.method: Introduce a cross-modal reward that measures how well the generated auxiliary-line description matches the ground-truth diagram. Train GeoVLMath with a GRPO-based RL stage to optimize diagram-text alignment. Build a scalable data pipeline and AuxSolidMath (3,018 problems) with diagrams and aligned textual fields.
AI.result: GeoVLMath at 3B and 7B scales achieves competitive or superior performance on auxiliary-line reasoning benchmarks compared with strong open-source and proprietary LVLMs.
AI.conclusion: Text-based auxiliary-line reasoning, guided by a cross-modal RL signal, effectively enhances geometry problem solving. The open-source GeoVLMath and AuxSolidMath dataset provide a reproducible foundation for future research in diagram-text alignment and geometry reasoning.

title: Understanding Sampler Stochasticity in Training Diffusion Models for RLHF
summary:
Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF) is increasingly used to
fine-tune diffusion models, but a key challenge arises from the mismatch
between stochastic samplers used during training and deterministic samplers
used during inference. In practice, models are fine-tuned using stochastic SDE
samplers to encourage exploration, while inference typically relies on
deterministic ODE samplers for efficiency and stability. This discrepancy
induces a reward gap, raising concerns about whether high-quality outputs can
be expected during inference. In this paper, we theoretically characterize this
reward gap and provide non-vacuous bounds for general diffusion models, along
with sharper convergence rates for Variance Exploding (VE) and Variance
Preserving (VP) Gaussian models. Methodologically, we adopt the generalized
denoising diffusion implicit models (gDDIM) framework to support arbitrarily
high levels of stochasticity, preserving data marginals throughout.
Empirically, our findings through large-scale experiments on text-to-image
models using denoising diffusion policy optimization (DDPO) and mixed group
relative policy optimization (MixGRPO) validate that reward gaps consistently
narrow over training, and ODE sampling quality improves when models are updated
using higher-stochasticity SDE training.

AI.tldr: RLHF-tuned diffusion models suffer a gap between stochastic training (SDE) and deterministic inference (ODE); the paper provides theoretical reward-gap bounds, sharper convergence rates for VE/VP Gaussian models, and empirical evidence that training with higher stochasticity narrows the gap and improves ODE-sampling quality using gDDIM.
AI.motivation: Address the mismatch between training-time stochastic samplers and inference-time deterministic samplers in RLHF-tuned diffusion models, which can degrade output quality during inference; establish theoretical guarantees and practical remedies.
AI.method: The authors characterize the reward gap theoretically, deriving non-vacuous bounds for general diffusion models and sharper convergence rates for VE/VP Gaussian models. They use the generalized denoising diffusion implicit models (gDDIM) to enable arbitrarily high stochasticity while preserving data marginals. Empirically, they evaluate on large-scale text-to-image models with denoising diffusion policy optimization (DDPO) and MixGRPO.
AI.result: They obtain non-vacuous reward-gap bounds and sharper convergence rates for VE/VP models. Empirically, reward gaps shrink as training proceeds, and higher-stochasticity SDE training improves ODE-sampling quality at inference.
AI.conclusion: The reward gap is both theoretically bounded and practically reducible; employing higher stochasticity during RLHF training, facilitated by gDDIM, aligns training and inference dynamics and enhances the quality of deterministic samplers in diffusion-model RLHF systems.

title: GIR-Bench: Versatile Benchmark for Generating Images with Reasoning
summary:
Unified multimodal models integrate the reasoning capacity of large language
models with both image understanding and generation, showing great promise for
advanced multimodal intelligence. However, the community still lacks a rigorous
reasoning-centric benchmark to systematically evaluate the alignment between
understanding and generation, and their generalization potential in complex
visual tasks. To this end, we introduce \textbf{GIR-Bench}, a comprehensive
benchmark that evaluates unified models across three complementary
perspectives. Firstly, we investigate understanding-generation consistency
(GIR-Bench-UGC), asking whether models can consistently leverage the same
knowledge in both understanding and generation tasks. Secondly, we investigate
whether models can perform reasoning-centric text-to-image generation that
requires applying logical constraints and implicit knowledge to generate
faithful visual content (GIR-Bench-T2I). Thirdly, we evaluate whether models
can handle multi-step reasoning in editing (GIR-Bench-Edit). For each subset,
we carefully design different task-specific evaluation pipelines tailored for
each task. This enables fine-grained and interpretable evaluation while
mitigating biases from the prevalent MLLM-as-a-Judge paradigm. Extensive
ablations over various unified models and generation-only systems have shown
that: Although unified models are more capable of reasoning-driven visual
tasks, they still exhibit a persistent gap between understanding and
generation. The data and code for GIR-Bench are available at
\href{https://hkust-longgroup.github.io/GIR-Bench}{https://hkust-longgroup.github.io/GIR-Bench}.

AI.tldr: GIR-Bench is a reasoning-centric, multimodal benchmark for unified models, with three evaluation pillars—understanding-generation consistency (UGC), reasoning-based text-to-image generation (T2I), and multi-step editing—showing a persistent gap between understanding and generation but enabling fine-grained, interpretable evaluation with public data/code.
AI.motivation: There is a need for a rigorous benchmark that focuses on reasoning-centric alignment between understanding and generation in multimodal models and their generalization to complex visual tasks, beyond relying on LLM judges.
AI.method: Introduce three task-specific evaluation pipelines: GIR-Bench-UGC (consistency between understanding and generation), GIR-Bench-T2I (reasoning-centric, constraint-driven text-to-image generation), and GIR-Bench-Edit (multi-step editing). Each subset uses tailored evaluation protocols to enable fine-grained, bias-mitigated assessment; ablations are performed across unified models and generation-only systems; data and code are released at the project site.
AI.result: Experiments show unified models are stronger at reasoning-driven visual tasks but still exhibit a gap between understanding and generation; the benchmark reveals persistent misalignment between the two capabilities.
AI.conclusion: GIR-Bench provides a rigorous, interpretable framework to evaluate alignment and generalization of understanding and generation in unified multimodal models, facilitating targeted improvements, with resources publicly available.

title: Structure Over Signal: A Globalized Approach to Multi-relational GNNs for Stock Prediction
summary:
In financial markets, Graph Neural Networks have been successfully applied to
modeling relational data, effectively capturing nonlinear inter-stock
dependencies. Yet, existing models often fail to efficiently propagate messages
during macroeconomic shocks. In this paper, we propose OmniGNN, an
attention-based multi-relational dynamic GNN that integrates macroeconomic
context via heterogeneous node and edge types for robust message passing.
Central to OmniGNN is a sector node acting as a global intermediary, enabling
rapid shock propagation across the graph without relying on long-range
multi-hop diffusion. The model leverages Graph Attention Networks (GAT) to
weigh neighbor contributions and employs Transformers to capture temporal
dynamics across multiplex relations. Experiments show that OmniGNN outperforms
existing stock prediction models on public datasets, particularly demonstrating
strong robustness during the COVID-19 period.

AI.tldr: OmniGNN is an attention-based, multi-relational dynamic GNN for stock prediction that incorporates macroeconomic context via heterogeneous node/edge types and a global sector node, using GATs and Transformers to achieve robust shock propagation and improved performance, especially during COVID-19.
AI.motivation: Current graph-based finance models struggle to propagate macroeconomic shocks efficiently across a stock network; there is a need to incorporate macro context and a fast diffusion mechanism to improve robustness under macro shocks.
AI.method: Proposes OmniGNN: an attention-based multi-relational dynamic GNN with heterogeneous node and edge types; introduces a sector node as a global intermediary to facilitate rapid shock propagation; uses Graph Attention Networks to weigh neighbor contributions; Transformers capture temporal dynamics across multiplex relations; trained and evaluated on public stock datasets; designed to be robust during macro shocks such as the COVID-19 period.
AI.result: OmniGNN outperforms existing stock prediction models on public datasets and demonstrates strong robustness during the COVID-19 period.
AI.conclusion: The sector node and heterogeneous relational design enable faster diffusion of shocks and more robust predictions, highlighting the value of incorporating macroeconomic context in dynamic GNNs for finance.

title: Vlaser: Vision-Language-Action Model with Synergistic Embodied Reasoning
summary:
While significant research has focused on developing embodied reasoning
capabilities using Vision-Language Models (VLMs) or integrating advanced VLMs
into Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models for end-to-end robot control, few
studies directly address the critical gap between upstream VLM-based reasoning
and downstream VLA policy learning. In this work, we take an initial step
toward bridging embodied reasoning with VLA policy learning by introducing
Vlaser - a Vision-Language-Action Model with synergistic embodied reasoning
capability, which is a foundational vision-language model designed to integrate
high-level reasoning with low-level control for embodied agents. Built upon the
high-quality Vlaser-6M dataset, Vlaser achieves state-of-the-art performance
across a range of embodied reasoning benchmarks - including spatial reasoning,
embodied grounding, embodied QA, and task planning. Furthermore, we
systematically examine how different VLM initializations affect supervised VLA
fine-tuning, offering novel insights into mitigating the domain shift between
internet-scale pre-training data and embodied-specific policy learning data.
Based on these insights, our approach achieves state-of-the-art results on the
WidowX benchmark and competitive performance on the Google Robot benchmark.

AI.tldr: Introduces Vlaser, a Vision-Language-Action Model that fuses high-level embodied reasoning with low-level control, trained on the Vlaser-6M dataset; claims state-of-the-art performance on embodied reasoning benchmarks and strong results on WidowX and Google Robot, with analysis of VLM initialization effects.
AI.motivation: Bridges the gap between upstream Vision-Language Model (VLM) based reasoning and downstream Vision-Language-Action (VLA) policy learning for embodied agents; addresses domain shift between internet-scale pretraining and embodied-specific policy data.
AI.method: Proposes Vlaser, a foundational VLM designed to integrate high-level reasoning with low-level control for embodied agents, built on the Vlaser-6M dataset; evaluates on embodied reasoning benchmarks (spatial reasoning, embodied grounding, embodied QA, task planning); systematically examines how different VLM initializations affect supervised VLA fine-tuning to mitigate domain shift.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance across embodied reasoning benchmarks; sets new SOTA on WidowX; shows competitive performance on Google Robot.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates that integrating embodied reasoning with VLA policy learning is effective; provides insights into the role of VLM initialization in reducing domain gap, and establishes Vlaser as a strong foundation for embodied AI tasks.

title: Preconditioned Norms: A Unified Framework for Steepest Descent, Quasi-Newton and Adaptive Methods
summary:
Optimization lies at the core of modern deep learning, yet existing methods
often face a fundamental trade-off between adapting to problem geometry and
leveraging curvature utilization. Steepest descent algorithms adapt to
different geometries through norm choices but remain strictly first-order,
whereas quasi-Newton and adaptive optimizers incorporate curvature information
but are restricted to Frobenius geometry, limiting their applicability across
diverse architectures. In this work, we propose a unified framework
generalizing steepest descent, quasi-Newton methods, and adaptive methods
through the novel notion of preconditioned matrix norms. This abstraction
reveals that widely used optimizers such as SGD and Adam, as well as more
advanced approaches like Muon and KL-Shampoo, and recent hybrids including SOAP
and SPlus, all emerge as special cases of the same principle. Within this
framework, we provide the first systematic treatment of affine and scale
invariance in the matrix-parameterized setting, establishing necessary and
sufficient conditions under generalized norms. Building on this foundation, we
introduce two new methods, $\texttt{MuAdam}$ and $\texttt{MuAdam-SANIA}$, which
combine the spectral geometry of Muon with Adam-style preconditioning. Our
experiments demonstrate that these optimizers are competitive with, and in some
cases outperform, existing state-of-the-art methods. Our code is available at
https://github.com/brain-lab-research/LIB/tree/quasi_descent

AI.tldr: A unified optimization framework based on preconditioned matrix norms generalizes steepest descent, quasi-Newton, and adaptive methods, revealing SGD/Adam/Muon/KO-based hybrids as special cases; it analyzes affine/scale invariance and introduces two new methods, MuAdam and MuAdam-SANIA, with competitive empirical performance and open-source code.
AI.motivation: To overcome the trade-off between adapting to problem geometry (first-order steepest descent) and exploiting curvature (quasi-Newton/adaptive methods) by moving beyond Frobenius geometry toward a unified preconditioned matrix-norm framework; to enable affine/scale invariance analysis in matrix-parameterized settings.
AI.method: Introduce preconditioned matrix norms to unify optimization algorithms. Show common optimizers (SGD, Adam, Muon, KL-Shampoo, SOAP, SPlus) as special cases within this framework. Perform theoretical treatment of affine and scale invariance under generalized norms with necessary/sufficient conditions. Propose two new methods, MuAdam and MuAdam-SANIA, combining Muon spectral geometry with Adam-style preconditioning. Validate via experiments and provide code release.
AI.result: Establishes a broad unifying framework linking diverse optimizers under preconditioned matrix norms. Delivers invariance theory with complete conditions and demonstrates that MuAdam variants are competitive with or surpass state-of-the-art methods in various settings. Code available at the provided repository.
AI.conclusion: The preconditioned matrix-norm framework offers a principled, extensible lens for optimization across architectures, enabling principled derivation of known optimizers and the design of new ones (MuAdam, MuAdam-SANIA). It advances understanding of affine/scale invariance in matrix-parametrized problems and shows practical performance gains in experiments.

title: Enhancing Zero-Shot Anomaly Detection: CLIP-SAM Collaboration with Cascaded Prompts
summary:
Recently, the powerful generalization ability exhibited by foundation models
has brought forth new solutions for zero-shot anomaly segmentation tasks.
However, guiding these foundation models correctly to address downstream tasks
remains a challenge. This paper proposes a novel two-stage framework, for
zero-shot anomaly segmentation tasks in industrial anomaly detection. This
framework excellently leverages the powerful anomaly localization capability of
CLIP and the boundary perception ability of SAM.(1) To mitigate SAM's
inclination towards object segmentation, we propose the Co-Feature Point Prompt
Generation (PPG) module. This module collaboratively utilizes CLIP and SAM to
generate positive and negative point prompts, guiding SAM to focus on
segmenting anomalous regions rather than the entire object. (2) To further
optimize SAM's segmentation results and mitigate rough boundaries and isolated
noise, we introduce the Cascaded Prompts for SAM (CPS) module. This module
employs hybrid prompts cascaded with a lightweight decoder of SAM, achieving
precise segmentation of anomalous regions. Across multiple datasets, consistent
experimental validation demonstrates that our approach achieves
state-of-the-art zero-shot anomaly segmentation results. Particularly
noteworthy is our performance on the Visa dataset, where we outperform the
state-of-the-art methods by 10.3\% and 7.7\% in terms of {$F_1$-max} and AP
metrics, respectively.

AI.tldr: Two-stage framework for zero-shot anomaly segmentation leveraging CLIP for localization and SAM for segmentation, with Co-Feature Point Prompt Generation and Cascaded Prompts for SAM; achieves state-of-the-art on Visa dataset, notably +10.3% F1-max and +7.7% AP.
AI.motivation: Foundation models show strong generalization but guiding them for specific tasks like anomaly segmentation is difficult; need targeted prompts to focus on anomalous areas and refine boundaries.
AI.method: Stage 1 PPG: co-uses CLIP and SAM to create positive/negative prompts guiding SAM to segment anomalous regions rather than whole objects. Stage 2 CPS: cascaded hybrid prompts + lightweight decoder to refine segmentation, reducing rough edges and noise.
AI.result: State-of-the-art zero-shot anomaly segmentation across multiple datasets; notably on Visa dataset, F1-max improved by 10.3 percentage points and AP by 7.7 percentage points over prior SOTA.
AI.conclusion: PPG and CPS effectively combine CLIP and SAM for precise zero-shot anomaly segmentation, demonstrating a strong, scalable approach for industrial anomaly detection with foundation models.

title: BioOSS: A Bio-Inspired Oscillatory State System with Spatio-Temporal Dynamics
summary:
Today's deep learning architectures are primarily based on perceptron models,
which do not capture the oscillatory dynamics characteristic of biological
neurons. Although oscillatory systems have recently gained attention for their
closer resemblance to neural behavior, they still fall short of modeling the
intricate spatio-temporal interactions observed in natural neural circuits. In
this paper, we propose a bio-inspired oscillatory state system (BioOSS)
designed to emulate the wave-like propagation dynamics critical to neural
processing, particularly in the prefrontal cortex (PFC), where complex activity
patterns emerge. BioOSS comprises two interacting populations of neurons: p
neurons, which represent simplified membrane-potential-like units inspired by
pyramidal cells in cortical columns, and o neurons, which govern propagation
velocities and modulate the lateral spread of activity. Through local
interactions, these neurons produce wave-like propagation patterns. The model
incorporates trainable parameters for damping and propagation speed, enabling
flexible adaptation to task-specific spatio-temporal structures. We evaluate
BioOSS on both synthetic and real-world tasks, demonstrating superior
performance and enhanced interpretability compared to alternative
architectures.

AI.tldr: BioOSS: a bio-inspired oscillatory network with two neuron populations (p and o) that generate wave-like neural propagation. Trainable damping and speed enable adaptation to spatio-temporal tasks; shows superior performance and interpretability on synthetic and real data.
AI.motivation: Current deep learning models rely on static perceptrons and fail to capture oscillatory, spatio-temporal neural dynamics observed in biological circuits, particularly in the prefrontal cortex. A wave-propagation based system could better model neural processing and provide interpretability.
AI.method: Two interacting populations: p neurons (membrane-potential-like units) and o neurons (control propagation velocity and lateral spread). Local interactions yield wave-like propagation; trainable parameters for damping and speed allow adaptation to task structure. Evaluation on synthetic and real-world tasks with comparisons to alternative architectures.
AI.result: BioOSS demonstrates superior performance and enhanced interpretability relative to alternative architectures on both synthetic and real-world tasks.
AI.conclusion: A biologically inspired oscillatory state system can capture spatio-temporal neural dynamics more effectively, offering flexible control over propagation and interpretability for PFC-like processing tasks.

title: Benchmarking Deep Learning Models for Laryngeal Cancer Staging Using the LaryngealCT Dataset
summary:
Laryngeal cancer imaging research lacks standardised datasets to enable
reproducible deep learning (DL) model development. We present LaryngealCT, a
curated benchmark of 1,029 computed tomography (CT) scans aggregated from six
collections from The Cancer Imaging Archive (TCIA). Uniform 1 mm isotropic
volumes of interest encompassing the larynx were extracted using a weakly
supervised parameter search framework validated by clinical experts. 3D DL
architectures (3D CNN, ResNet18,50,101, DenseNet121) were benchmarked on (i)
early (Tis,T1,T2) vs. advanced (T3,T4) and (ii) T4 vs. non-T4 classification
tasks. 3D CNN (AUC-0.881, F1-macro-0.821) and ResNet18 (AUC-0.892,
F1-macro-0.646) respectively outperformed the other models in the two tasks.
Model explainability assessed using 3D GradCAMs with thyroid cartilage overlays
revealed greater peri-cartilage attention in non-T4 cases and focal activations
in T4 predictions. Through open-source data, pretrained models, and integrated
explainability tools, LaryngealCT offers a reproducible foundation for
AI-driven research to support clinical decisions in laryngeal oncology.

AI.tldr: LaryngealCT provides a standardized, open benchmark of 1,029 laryngeal CT scans with uniform 1 mm VOIs, enabling reproducible deep learning research; 3D CNNs and ResNet variants outperform baselines, with GradCAM-based explanations, offering pretrained models and tools for clinical AI in laryngeal oncology.
AI.motivation: Address the lack of standardized, reproducible datasets for DL in laryngeal cancer imaging and provide a benchmark for model development, evaluation, and explainability.
