difficulties due to ineffective ego-exo feature fusion and limited long-term
memory capacity, especially for long videos. Addressing these problems, we
propose a novel EEC framework based on SAM 2 with long-term memories by
presenting a dual-memory architecture and an adaptive feature routing module
inspired by Mixture-of-Experts (MoE). Compared to SAM 2, our approach features
(i) a Memory-View MoE module which consists of a dual-branch routing mechanism
to adaptively assign contribution weights to each expert feature along both
channel and spatial dimensions, and (ii) a dual-memory bank system with a
simple yet effective compression strategy to retain critical long-term
information while eliminating redundancy. In the extensive experiments on the
challenging EgoExo4D benchmark, our method, dubbed LM-EEC, achieves new
state-of-the-art results and significantly outperforms existing methods and the
SAM 2 baseline, showcasing its strong generalization across diverse scenarios.
Our code and model are available at https://github.com/juneyeeHu/LM-EEC.

AI.tldr: LM-EEC: a SAM 2-based ego-exo correspondence method with long-term memories using a dual-memory MoE and a dual-memory bank, achieving state-of-the-art on EgoExo4D.
AI.motivation: To establish robust object-level correspondences between egocentric and exocentric views for better visual guidance, addressing challenges like extreme viewpoint changes, occlusions, and small objects, by leveraging long-term memory and adaptive feature fusion.
AI.method: Introduce a dual-memory architecture and an adaptive Memory-View MoE module. The MoE has a dual-branch routing mechanism that weights expert features along channel and spatial dimensions. A dual-memory bank compresses and stores long-term information, reducing redundancy while preserving critical content.
AI.result: On EgoExo4D, LM-EEC achieves state-of-the-art performance, significantly surpassing existing methods and the SAM 2 baseline, demonstrating strong generalization across diverse scenarios.
AI.conclusion: The proposed LM-EEC framework effectively addresses ego-exo correspondence by combining adaptive feature fusion with long-term memory, enabling robust performance in challenging egocentric-exocentric settings and highlighting SAM 2’s potential when augmented with memory mechanisms.

title: Cross-Scale Reservoir Computing for large spatio-temporal forecasting and modeling
summary:
We propose a new reservoir computing method for forecasting high-resolution
spatiotemporal datasets. By combining multi-resolution inputs from coarser to
finer layers, our architecture better captures both local and global dynamics.
Applied to Sea Surface Temperature data, it outperforms standard parallel
reservoir models in long-term forecasting, demonstrating the effectiveness of
cross-layers coupling in improving predictive accuracy. Finally, we show that
the optimal network dynamics in each layer become increasingly linear,
revealing the slow modes propagated to subsequent layers.

AI.tldr: A multi-resolution cross-layer reservoir computing scheme improves long-term forecasting of high-resolution spatiotemporal data, outperforming parallel reservoirs, demonstrated on Sea Surface Temperature with linearizing layer dynamics.
AI.motivation: To overcome limitations of standard parallel reservoir models in capturing multi-scale spatiotemporal dynamics by integrating coarse-to-fine inputs and cross-layer interactions.
AI.method: A multi-layer reservoir computing architecture that ingests inputs across coarser to finer resolutions and couples layers crosswise to share information, applied to Sea Surface Temperature data for long-horizon forecasting; compared against standard parallel reservoir models.
AI.result: The proposed cross-layer, multi-resolution reservoir outperforms standard parallel reservoirs in long-term forecasting on SST data; cross-layer coupling yields improved predictive accuracy.
AI.conclusion: Optimal dynamics in each layer trend toward more linear behavior, indicating the slow modes are propagated through the network layers, validating the multi-resolution cross-layer approach.

title: Enhancing Maritime Domain Awareness on Inland Waterways: A YOLO-Based Fusion of Satellite and AIS for Vessel Characterization
summary:
Maritime Domain Awareness (MDA) for inland waterways remains challenged by
cooperative system vulnerabilities. This paper presents a novel framework that
fuses high-resolution satellite imagery with vessel trajectory data from the
Automatic Identification System (AIS). This work addresses the limitations of
AIS-based monitoring by leveraging non-cooperative satellite imagery and
implementing a fusion approach that links visual detections with AIS data to
identify dark vessels, validate cooperative traffic, and support advanced MDA.
The You Only Look Once (YOLO) v11 object detection model is used to detect and
characterize vessels and barges by vessel type, barge cover, operational
status, barge count, and direction of travel. An annotated data set of 4,550
instances was developed from $5{,}973~\mathrm{mi}^2$ of Lower Mississippi River
imagery. Evaluation on a held-out test set demonstrated vessel classification
(tugboat, crane barge, bulk carrier, cargo ship, and hopper barge) with an F1
score of 95.8\%; barge cover (covered or uncovered) detection yielded an F1
score of 91.6\%; operational status (staged or in motion) classification
reached an F1 score of 99.4\%. Directionality (upstream, downstream) yielded
93.8\% accuracy. The barge count estimation resulted in a mean absolute error
(MAE) of 2.4 barges. Spatial transferability analysis across geographically
disjoint river segments showed accuracy was maintained as high as 98\%. These
results underscore the viability of integrating non-cooperative satellite
sensing with AIS fusion. This approach enables near-real-time fleet
inventories, supports anomaly detection, and generates high-quality data for
inland waterway surveillance. Future work will expand annotated datasets,
incorporate temporal tracking, and explore multi-modal deep learning to further
enhance operational scalability.

AI.tldr: Fusion of high-resolution satellite imagery with AIS using YOLOv11 enables near-real-time inland vessel detection and tracking, addressing AIS gaps by identifying non-cooperative targets and validating cooperative traffic.
AI.motivation: AIS-based inland waterway monitoring is vulnerable to non-cooperative targets; leveraging non-cooperative satellite imagery and data fusion can improve Maritime Domain Awareness by providing fleet inventories, anomaly detection, and higher-quality data for surveillance.
AI.method: Utilizes YOLO v11 to detect and classify vessels from satellite imagery; annotates a dataset of 4,550 instances from 5,973 mi^2 of the Lower Mississippi River, capturing vessel type, barge cover, operational status, barge count, and direction. Fuses detections with AIS data to identify dark vessels and validate traffic. Evaluates on a held-out test set and conducts spatial transferability analysis across river segments.
AI.result: Vessel classification (tugboat, crane barge, bulk carrier, cargo ship, hopper barge): F1 = 95.8%. Barge cover (covered/uncovered): F1 = 91.6%. Operational status (staged/in motion): F1 = 99.4%. Directionality (upstream/downstream): 93.8% accuracy. Barge count MAE = 2.4. Spatial transferability accuracy across segments up to 98%.
AI.conclusion: The study demonstrates the viability of integrating non-cooperative satellite sensing with AIS fusion for inland waterway surveillance, enabling near-real-time fleet inventories and anomaly detection. Future work includes expanding annotated datasets, incorporating temporal tracking, and exploring multi-modal deep learning to enhance scalability.

title: Enforcing convex constraints in Graph Neural Networks
summary:
Many machine learning applications require outputs that satisfy complex,
dynamic constraints. This task is particularly challenging in Graph Neural
Network models due to the variable output sizes of graph-structured data. In
this paper, we introduce ProjNet, a Graph Neural Network framework which
satisfies input-dependant constraints. ProjNet combines a sparse vector
clipping method with the Component-Averaged Dykstra (CAD) algorithm, an
iterative scheme for solving the best-approximation problem. We establish a
convergence result for CAD and develop a GPU-accelerated implementation capable
of handling large-scale inputs efficiently. To enable end-to-end training, we
introduce a surrogate gradient for CAD that is both computationally efficient
and better suited for optimization than the exact gradient. We validate ProjNet
on four classes of constrained optimisation problems: linear programming, two
classes of non-convex quadratic programs, and radio transmit power
optimization, demonstrating its effectiveness across diverse problem settings.

AI.tldr: ProjNet is a Graph Neural Network framework that enforces input-dependent constraints via sparse vector clipping and the CAD algorithm, with convergence guarantees, GPU acceleration, and a surrogate gradient for end-to-end training, applicable to LPs, non-convex QPs, and radio power optimization.
AI.motivation: Many ML applications require outputs satisfying complex, dynamic constraints, and graph-structured data pose extra challenges due to variable output sizes. There is a need for scalable, trainable methods that can enforce constraints in GNNs.
AI.method: Combine sparse vector clipping with Component-Averaged Dykstra (CAD) to solve the best-approximation problem; prove convergence of CAD; implement a GPU-accelerated version; introduce a surrogate gradient for CAD to enable end-to-end training; validate on multiple constrained optimization problems.
AI.result: Demonstrates effectiveness across four problem classes: linear programming, two non-convex quadratic program families, and radio transmit power optimization; shows scalability to large-scale inputs and improved optimization friendliness via the surrogate gradient.
AI.conclusion: ProjNet provides a scalable, trainable approach for constraint-satisfying GNNs, combining a principled optimization solver with efficient gradients, suitable for diverse constrained problems.

title: Coupled Degradation Modeling and Fusion: A VLM-Guided Degradation-Coupled Network for Degradation-Aware Infrared and Visible Image Fusion
summary:
Existing Infrared and Visible Image Fusion (IVIF) methods typically assume
high-quality inputs. However, when handing degraded images, these methods
heavily rely on manually switching between different pre-processing techniques.
This decoupling of degradation handling and image fusion leads to significant
performance degradation. In this paper, we propose a novel VLM-Guided
Degradation-Coupled Fusion network (VGDCFusion), which tightly couples
degradation modeling with the fusion process and leverages vision-language
models (VLMs) for degradation-aware perception and guided suppression.
Specifically, the proposed Specific-Prompt Degradation-Coupled Extractor
(SPDCE) enables modality-specific degradation awareness and establishes a joint
modeling of degradation suppression and intra-modal feature extraction. In
parallel, the Joint-Prompt Degradation-Coupled Fusion (JPDCF) facilitates
cross-modal degradation perception and couples residual degradation filtering
with complementary cross-modal feature fusion. Extensive experiments
demonstrate that our VGDCFusion significantly outperforms existing
state-of-the-art fusion approaches under various degraded image scenarios. Our
code is available at https://github.com/Lmmh058/VGDCFusion.

AI.tldr: A VLM-guided degradation-coupled fusion network (VGDCFusion) jointly models image degradation and fusion for infrared/visible image fusion, using SPDCE and JPDCF modules and vision-language models to handle degraded inputs, outperforming state-of-the-art methods with code released.
AI.motivation: To address the failure of existing IVIF methods under degraded inputs due to the decoupling of degradation handling and image fusion, which requires manual pre-processing and degrades performance.
AI.method: Propose VGDCFusion, a degradation-coupled fusion network guided by vision-language models. It includes Specific-Prompt Degradation-Coupled Extractor (SPDCE) for modality-specific degradation awareness and joint degradation suppression with intra-modal feature extraction, and Joint-Prompt Degradation-Coupled Fusion (JPDCF) for cross-modal degradation perception and fused residual degradation filtering with cross-modal feature fusion.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show VGDCFusion significantly outperforms existing state-of-the-art fusion approaches under various degraded image scenarios.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates effective degradation-aware fusion via tight coupling of degradation modeling and fusion, guided by VLMs, with open-source implementation available.

title: Neural Weight Compression for Language Models
summary:
The efficient storage and transmission of language model weights is becoming
increasingly important, as their scale and adoption continue to grow. However,
as our understanding of this new data modality is limited, designing a good
compression algorithm for language model weights heavily relies on manual,
trial-and-error approaches. In this paper, we propose a learned compression
framework that trains neural codecs directly from pretrained language model
weights. Unlike conventional data (e.g., images), language model weights pose
unique challenges: the sizes and shapes of weight tensors vary significantly,
and the reconstruction quality must be judged by downstream model predictions
rather than na\"ive MSE loss. To address this, we introduce Neural Weight
Compression (NWC), a novel autoencoder-based neural codec tailored to model
weight compression. The proposed method inherits the advantages of
autoencoder-based codecs while incorporating three technical components: (1)
column-wise tensor chunking and normalization; (2) an importance-aware training
loss; (3) an inference-time error compensation mechanism guided by model
outputs. Experiments on open-weight language models show that NWC achieves
competitive or state-of-the-art accuracy-compression tradeoffs, with
particularly strong results at 4-6 bit precisions where accuracy remains nearly
on par with FP16 models.

AI.tldr: NWC proposes a learned, autoencoder-based neural codec to compress LM weights, addressing variable tensor shapes and downstream-task accuracy, achieving competitive to state-of-the-art performance, especially at 4–6 bit quantization.
AI.motivation: Efficiently storing and transmitting very large language model weights is increasingly important, but traditional compression is manual and brittle due to weight diversity and the need to preserve downstream performance rather than pixel-like MSE.
AI.method: An autoencoder-based neural codec with three innovations: (1) column-wise tensor chunking and normalization to handle varied weight shapes; (2) an importance-aware training loss that aligns compression with downstream impact; (3) an inference-time error compensation mechanism guided by model outputs to correct reconstruction errors.
AI.result: On open-weight LMs, NWC achieves competitive or state-of-the-art accuracy–compression tradeoffs, notably strong performance at 4–6 bit precision with accuracy close to FP16 baselines.
AI.conclusion: Neural Weight Compression (NWC) is a viable learned compression framework for LM weights that leverages autoencoder codecs and targeted design choices to handle shape variability and task-specific evaluation, enabling efficient storage/transmission without substantial degradation at moderate-bit quantization.

title: VA-GS: Enhancing the Geometric Representation of Gaussian Splatting via View Alignment
summary:
3D Gaussian Splatting has recently emerged as an efficient solution for
high-quality and real-time novel view synthesis. However, its capability for
accurate surface reconstruction remains underexplored. Due to the discrete and
unstructured nature of Gaussians, supervision based solely on image rendering
loss often leads to inaccurate geometry and inconsistent multi-view alignment.
In this work, we propose a novel method that enhances the geometric
representation of 3D Gaussians through view alignment (VA). Specifically, we
incorporate edge-aware image cues into the rendering loss to improve surface
boundary delineation. To enforce geometric consistency across views, we
introduce a visibility-aware photometric alignment loss that models occlusions
and encourages accurate spatial relationships among Gaussians. To further
mitigate ambiguities caused by lighting variations, we incorporate normal-based
constraints to refine the spatial orientation of Gaussians and improve local
surface estimation. Additionally, we leverage deep image feature embeddings to
enforce cross-view consistency, enhancing the robustness of the learned
geometry under varying viewpoints and illumination. Extensive experiments on
standard benchmarks demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art
performance in both surface reconstruction and novel view synthesis. The source
code is available at https://github.com/LeoQLi/VA-GS.

AI.tldr: A novel VA-GS framework enhances 3D Gaussian Splatting geometry for better surface reconstruction and view synthesis by integrating edge-aware cues, visibility-aware photometric alignment, normal-based constraints, and deep feature embeddings, achieving state-of-the-art on standard benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Discrete and unstructured Gaussians with image-rendering losses can yield inaccurate geometry and misaligned views. There is a need for explicit geometric consistency across views and better handling of occlusions and lighting variations to improve surface reconstruction.
AI.method: Introduce view alignment (VA) for 3D Gaussian Splatting by (1) edge-aware rendering loss to sharpen boundaries, (2) visibility-aware photometric alignment to model occlusions and enforce spatial relationships among Gaussians, (3) normal-based constraints to refine Gaussian orientation for local surface estimation, and (4) deep image feature embeddings to enforce cross-view consistency across viewpoints and illumination conditions.
AI.result: Demonstrates state-of-the-art performance on surface reconstruction and novel view synthesis on standard benchmarks; comprehensive ablations validate the contribution of each component; code is released at the provided GitHub link.
AI.conclusion: The proposed VA-GS framework significantly improves geometric fidelity and cross-view consistency in 3D Gaussian Splatting, enabling more accurate surface reconstruction and robust novel view synthesis under varying lighting.

title: Learning the Structure of Connection Graphs
summary:
Connection graphs (CGs) extend traditional graph models by coupling network
topology with orthogonal transformations, enabling the representation of global
geometric consistency. They play a key role in applications such as
synchronization, Riemannian signal processing, and neural sheaf diffusion. In
this work, we address the inverse problem of learning CGs directly from
observed signals. We propose a principled framework based on maximum
pseudo-likelihood under a consistency assumption, which enforces spectral
properties linking the connection Laplacian to the underlying combinatorial
Laplacian. Based on this formulation, we introduce the Structured Connection
Graph Learning (SCGL) algorithm, a block-optimization procedure over Riemannian
manifolds that jointly infers network topology, edge weights, and geometric
structure. Our experiments show that SCGL consistently outperforms existing
baselines in both topological recovery and geometric fidelity, while remaining
computationally efficient.

AI.tldr: SCGL is a principled method to learn connection graphs (CGs) from signals using maximum pseudo-likelihood with a spectral consistency constraint, jointly estimating topology, weights, and geometry via a Riemannian-manifold block-optimizer, yielding better topological and geometric accuracy and good efficiency.
AI.motivation: To recover structure and geometry of connection graphs directly from observed signals, addressing the inverse problem in CGs where topology must be inferred while enforcing global geometric consistency through spectral properties.
AI.method: Formulates learning as maximum pseudo-likelihood under a consistency assumption tying the connection Laplacian to the combinatorial Laplacian. Introduces Structured Connection Graph Learning (SCGL), a block-optimization algorithm on Riemannian manifolds that jointly infers network topology, edge weights, and geometric structure.
AI.result: SCGL consistently outperforms existing baselines in both topological recovery and geometric fidelity, while remaining computationally efficient.
AI.conclusion: The paper provides a principled framework and scalable algorithm for learning CGs from signals, achieving accurate reconstruction of both network topology and geometric structure, demonstrated via empirical improvements over baselines.

title: AndesVL Technical Report: An Efficient Mobile-side Multimodal Large Language Model
comment: Tech report of OPPO AndesVL Team
summary:
In recent years, while cloud-based MLLMs such as QwenVL, InternVL, GPT-4o,
Gemini, and Claude Sonnet have demonstrated outstanding performance with
enormous model sizes reaching hundreds of billions of parameters, they
significantly surpass the limitations in memory, power consumption, and
computing capacity of edge devices such as mobile phones. This paper introduces
AndesVL, a suite of mobile-side MLLMs with 0.6B to 4B parameters based on
Qwen3's LLM and various visual encoders. We comprehensively outline the model
architectures, training pipeline, and training data of AndesVL, which achieves
first-tier performance across a wide range of open-source benchmarks, including
fields such as text-rich image understanding, reasoning and math, multi-image
comprehension, general VQA, hallucination mitigation, multilingual
understanding, and GUI-related tasks when compared with state-of-the-art models
of a similar scale. Furthermore, we introduce a 1+N LoR

AI.tldr: AndesVL is a mobile-side family of MLLMs with 0.6B–4B parameters, built on Qwen3, offering competitive, edge-friendly performance across diverse open-source benchmarks and tasks; includes a 1+N LoR adaptation.
AI.motivation: To overcome memory, power, and compute constraints of edge devices and close the performance gap between on-device models and cloud-based MLLMs like QwenVL, GPT-4o, etc.
AI.method: Describes model architectures and training pipeline; uses Qwen3 LLM as base with various visual encoders; trains a 0.6–4B parameter family; introduces a 1+N LoR technique.
AI.result: Achieves first-tier performance on a wide range of open-source benchmarks including text-rich image understanding, reasoning and math, multi-image comprehension, general VQA, hallucination mitigation, multilingual understanding, and GUI tasks, compared to state-of-the-art models of similar scale.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates the viability of compact mobile MLLMs that approach cloud-model performance; supports scalable on-device LLMs with competitive capabilities and tasks; establishes a foundation for broader deployment.

title: FUSE: Fast Semi-Supervised Node Embedding Learning via Structural and Label-Aware Optimization
summary:
Graph-based learning is a cornerstone for analyzing structured data, with
node classification as a central task. However, in many real-world graphs,
nodes lack informative feature vectors, leaving only neighborhood connectivity
and class labels as available signals. In such cases, effective classification
hinges on learning node embeddings that capture structural roles and
topological context. We introduce a fast semi-supervised embedding framework
that jointly optimizes three complementary objectives: (i) unsupervised
structure preservation via scalable modularity approximation, (ii) supervised
regularization to minimize intra-class variance among labeled nodes, and (iii)
semi-supervised propagation that refines unlabeled nodes through
random-walk-based label spreading with attention-weighted similarity. These
components are unified into a single iterative optimization scheme, yielding
high-quality node embeddings. On standard benchmarks, our method consistently
achieves classification accuracy at par with or superior to state-of-the-art
approaches, while requiring significantly less computational cost.

AI.tldr: A fast semi-supervised graph embedding framework that jointly optimizes three objectives to produce high-quality node embeddings for node classification, achieving SOTA-like accuracy with lower computational cost.
AI.motivation: In many real-world graphs, nodes lack informative feature vectors; only neighborhood connectivity and labels are available signals. Effective classification requires embeddings that capture structural roles and topological context.
AI.method: Jointly optimize three objectives: (i) unsupervised structure preservation via scalable modularity approximation, (ii) supervised regularization to minimize intra-class variance among labeled nodes, and (iii) semi-supervised propagation that refines unlabeled nodes through random-walk-based label spreading with attention-weighted similarity; unified into a single iterative optimization scheme.
AI.result: On standard benchmarks, the method achieves classification accuracy at parity with or better than state-of-the-art approaches, while significantly reducing computational cost.
AI.conclusion: The proposed fast semi-supervised embedding framework yields high-quality node embeddings for graph-based classification with improved efficiency, making it practical for large-scale graphs.

title: Towards Fast and Scalable Normal Integration using Continuous Components
comment:
Accepted by the IEEE/CVF Winter Conference on Applications of
  Computer Vision (WACV) 2026, first round. 17 pages, 9 figures, 6 tables
summary:
Surface normal integration is a fundamental problem in computer vision,
dealing with the objective of reconstructing a surface from its corresponding
normal map. Existing approaches require an iterative global optimization to
jointly estimate the depth of each pixel, which scales poorly to larger normal
maps. In this paper, we address this problem by recasting normal integration as
the estimation of relative scales of continuous components. By constraining
pixels belonging to the same component to jointly vary their scale, we
drastically reduce the number of optimization variables. Our framework includes
a heuristic to accurately estimate continuous components from the start, a
strategy to rebalance optimization terms, and a technique to iteratively merge
components to further reduce the size of the problem. Our method achieves
state-of-the-art results on the standard normal integration benchmark in as
little as a few seconds and achieves one-order-of-magnitude speedup over
pixel-level approaches on large-resolution normal maps.

AI.tldr: A scalable surface normal integration method that treats the problem as estimating relative scales of continuous components, dramatically reducing optimization variables and enabling fast, high-quality reconstructions.
AI.motivation: Surface normal integration reconstructs depth from normals but current methods require heavy global optimization, which does not scale to large normal maps.
AI.method: Recast the problem as estimating relative scales across continuous components; enforce that pixels in the same component share a scale; introduce a heuristic to detect components, a rebalancing strategy for optimization terms, and an iterative merge process to further reduce variables.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art on standard normal integration benchmark in a few seconds and yields about an order-of-magnitude speedup over pixel-level approaches on large-resolution normal maps.
AI.conclusion: Component-based relative-scale estimation provides a scalable, accurate solution for surface normal integration, enabling fast processing of large-scale normal maps.

title: MIEO: encoding clinical data to enhance cardiovascular event prediction
comment:
Presented in the Poster Session of Computational Intelligence methods
  for Bioinformatics and Biostatistics (CIBB) 2025
summary:
As clinical data are becoming increasingly available, machine learning
methods have been employed to extract knowledge from them and predict clinical
events. While promising, approaches suffer from at least two main issues: low
availability of labelled data and data heterogeneity leading to missing values.
This work proposes the use of self-supervised auto-encoders to efficiently
address these challenges. We apply our methodology to a clinical dataset from
patients with ischaemic heart disease. Patient data is embedded in a latent
space, built using unlabelled data, which is then used to train a neural
network classifier to predict cardiovascular death. Results show improved
balanced accuracy compared to applying the classifier directly to the raw data,
demonstrating that this solution is promising, especially in conditions where
availability of unlabelled data could increase.

AI.tldr: Self-supervised auto-encoders learn latent representations from unlabeled clinical data to handle missing values and data heterogeneity, then train a classifier on the latent space to predict cardiovascular death in ischemic heart disease patients; shows improved balanced accuracy over raw-data classifier.
AI.motivation: Address limited labeled data and heterogeneous clinical data with missing values; exploit unlabeled data to build robust representations for prediction.
AI.method: Train a self-supervised auto-encoder on unlabeled clinical data to learn a latent embedding; then train a neural network classifier on the latent representations to predict cardiovascular death; evaluate on ischemic heart disease dataset; compare against a classifier trained on raw data.
AI.result: Classifier on latent space achieved higher balanced accuracy than classifier on raw data, indicating better handling of class imbalance and data heterogeneity; benefit grows with more unlabeled data.
AI.conclusion: Self-supervised auto-encoders are a promising approach for clinical predictive tasks with limited labels and missing data, enabling leveraging unlabeled data to improve performance in ischemic heart disease outcomes.

title: Situat3DChange: Situated 3D Change Understanding Dataset for Multimodal Large Language Model
comment:
Accepted to NeurIPS 2025 Datasets and Benchmarks Track. Dataset and
  Code: https://github.com/RuipingL/Situat3DChange
summary:
Physical environments and circumstances are fundamentally dynamic, yet
current 3D datasets and evaluation benchmarks tend to concentrate on either
dynamic scenarios or dynamic situations in isolation, resulting in incomplete
comprehension. To overcome these constraints, we introduce Situat3DChange, an
extensive dataset supporting three situation-aware change understanding tasks
following the perception-action model: 121K question-answer pairs, 36K change
descriptions for perception tasks, and 17K rearrangement instructions for the
action task. To construct this large-scale dataset, Situat3DChange leverages
11K human observations of environmental changes to establish shared mental
models and shared situational awareness for human-AI collaboration. These
observations, enriched with egocentric and allocentric perspectives as well as
categorical and coordinate spatial relations, are integrated using an LLM to
support understanding of situated changes. To address the challenge of
comparing pairs of point clouds from the same scene with minor changes, we
propose SCReasoner, an efficient 3D MLLM approach that enables effective point
cloud comparison with minimal parameter overhead and no additional tokens
required for the language decoder. Comprehensive evaluation on Situat3DChange
tasks highlights both the progress and limitations of MLLMs in dynamic scene
and situation understanding. Additional experiments on data scaling and
cross-domain transfer demonstrate the task-agnostic effectiveness of using
Situat3DChange as a training dataset for MLLMs.

AI.tldr: Situat3DChange introduces a large-scale, situation-aware 3D dataset and an efficient 3D MLLM (SCReasoner) to advance perception–action understanding in dynamic scenes, with promising cross-domain transfer but notable limitations remaining.
AI.motivation: Current 3D benchmarks isolate dynamicity (scene changes or situational context) and fail to support joint perception and action understanding. A unified, situation-aware dataset and lightweight MLLM reasoning are needed to enable robust human–AI collaboration in dynamic environments.
AI.method: Situat3DChange compiles 121K QA pairs, 36K change descriptions, and 17K rearrangement instructions across 11K human-observed changes, incorporating egocentric/allocentric views and categorical/coordinate spatial relations, aided by an LLM to fuse these observations into shared situational models. It also introduces SCReasoner, a parameter-efficient 3D MLLM that performs point-cloud comparison with minimal extra tokens and no language-decoder expansion. Evaluation examines dynamic scene and situation understanding, data scaling, and cross-domain transfer.
AI.result: Comprehensive evaluation reveals progress and remaining limitations of MLLMs for dynamic scene/situation understanding. Scaling data and cross-domain transfer demonstrate task-agnostic effectiveness of Situat3DChange as training data for MLLMs.
AI.conclusion: Situat3DChange enables three situation-aware tasks and, with SCReasoner, supports efficient, cross-domain 3D multi-modal understanding; the work highlights potential for improved human–AI collaboration in dynamic environments while signaling areas for further improvement (e.g., richer reasoning, generalization).

title: FedLoRA-Optimizer: Federated LoRA Fine-Tuning with Global and Local Optimization in Heterogeneous Data Scenarios
summary:
Federated efficient fine-tuning has emerged as an approach that leverages
distributed data and computational resources across nodes to address the
challenges of large-scale fine-tuning and privacy preservation. The Low-Rank
Adaptation (LoRA) enables efficient fine-tuning of large-scale pre-trained
models by introducing trainable low-rank matrices into weight updates.However,
in heterogeneous data scenarios, client drift weakens the generalization of the
global model, and local models often fail to meet the personalized needs of
individual clients.Moreover, existing federated LoRA efficient fine-tuning
techniques overlook fine-grained analysis of the tuning matrices. To address
this, we conducted preliminary experiments and found that different LoRA
matrices exhibit different sensitivity to changes in the direction and
magnitude of their vectors.We thus propose a fine-grained federated LoRA tuning
method. By fine-tuning the more sensitive directional vectors in the A matrix,
which encode shared knowledge, our method learns shared features more
effectively across clients and enhances global generalization. Simultaneously,
by fine-tuning the more sensitive magnitude vectors in the B matrix, which
encode personalized knowledge, our method better captures personalized
knowledge, enabling detailed adaptation to local data. The method uses a
pipeline combining global and local optimizers. Global optimization further
improves local models, achieving collaborative optimization between global and
local levels. This improves both the generalization ability of the global model
and the personalized adaptation of local models under heterogeneous data
scenarios. Experiments on Databricks-Dolly-15k and Natural Instructions with
LLaMA2-7B and Deepseek-7B confirm that our method improves global performance
by 0.39% and local performance by 0.59%.

AI.tldr: A fine-grained federated LoRA tuning framework that separates directional (A) and magnitude (B) vectors for shared vs. personalized knowledge, using a global-local optimizer mix to mitigate client drift and improve both global generalization and local adaptation in heterogeneous data; shows modest gains on LLama2/Deepseek models.
AI.motivation: Federated learning with heterogeneous data suffers from client drift; while LoRA enables efficient fine-tuning, lack of fine-grained analysis of LoRA matrices limits performance; there is a need to tailor updates to shared vs. personalized knowledge.
AI.method: Diagnose sensitivity of LoRA matrices; fine-tune sensitive directional vectors in A (shared knowledge) and magnitude vectors in B (personalized knowledge); employ a pipeline combining global and local optimizers to coordinate updates across clients.
AI.result: Empirical results on Databricks-Dolly-15k and Natural Instructions with LLaMA2-7B and Deepseek-7B show improvements in global performance by 0.39% and local performance by 0.59%.
AI.conclusion: Fine-grained LoRA adjustments in federated fine-tuning can enhance both global generalization and client-specific adaptation under heterogeneous data conditions.

title: LikePhys: Evaluating Intuitive Physics Understanding in Video Diffusion Models via Likelihood Preference
summary:
Intuitive physics understanding in video diffusion models plays an essential
role in building general-purpose physically plausible world simulators, yet
accurately evaluating such capacity remains a challenging task due to the
difficulty in disentangling physics correctness from visual appearance in
generation. To the end, we introduce LikePhys, a training-free method that
evaluates intuitive physics in video diffusion models by distinguishing
physically valid and impossible videos using the denoising objective as an
ELBO-based likelihood surrogate on a curated dataset of valid-invalid pairs. By
testing on our constructed benchmark of twelve scenarios spanning over four
physics domains, we show that our evaluation metric, Plausibility Preference
Error (PPE), demonstrates strong alignment with human preference, outperforming
state-of-the-art evaluator baselines. We then systematically benchmark
intuitive physics understanding in current video diffusion models. Our study
further analyses how model design and inference settings affect intuitive
physics understanding and highlights domain-specific capacity variations across
physical laws. Empirical results show that, despite current models struggling
with complex and chaotic dynamics, there is a clear trend of improvement in
physics understanding as model capacity and inference settings scale.

AI.tldr: Introduces LikePhys, a training-free metric to evaluate intuitive physics in video diffusion models by using a denoising objective as an ELBO-like likelihood on valid/invalid video pairs, producing a Plausibility Preference Error (PPE) that aligns with human preferences and benchmarks model physics understanding across 12 scenarios in 4 physics domains.
AI.motivation: To reliably assess intuitive physics understanding in video diffusion models separately from visual appearance, addressing the challenge of disentangling physics correctness from stylistic generation quality.
AI.method: LikePhys evaluates physically valid vs. impossible videos with the denoising objective treated as an ELBO-based likelihood surrogate on a curated valid-invalid dataset. It defines PPE (Plausibility Preference Error) as the evaluation metric and benchmarks twelve scenarios across four physics domains on current video diffusion models.
AI.result: PPE shows strong alignment with human preference and outperforms baselines. Systematic benchmarks reveal how model design and inference settings affect physics understanding, with capacity scaling improving performance; complex/chaotic dynamics remain challenging and there are domain-specific variations in physical law understanding.
AI.conclusion: Provides a training-free, principled evaluation framework for intuitive physics in video diffusion models and emphasizes capacity- and inference-driven improvements, while highlighting persistent difficulties with chaotic dynamics and domain-specific variations.

title: ENIGMA: The Geometry of Reasoning and Alignment in Large-Language Models
summary:
We present Entropic Mutual-Information Geometry Large-Language Model
Alignment (ENIGMA), a novel approach to Large-Language Model (LLM) training
that jointly improves reasoning, alignment and robustness by treating an
organisation's policies/principles as directions to move on a model's
information manifold. Our single-loop trainer combines Group-Relative Policy
Optimisation (GRPO), an on-policy, critic-free RL method with Chain-of-Thought
(CoT)-format only rewards; a Self-Supervised Alignment with Mutual Information
(SAMI)-style symmetric InfoNCE auxiliary; and an entropic Sinkhorn
optimal-transport regulariser on hidden-state distributions to bound geometry
drift. We also introduce infoNCE metrics that specialise to a standard MI lower
bound under matched negatives to measure how strongly a model's CoT encodes
these policies. These metrics include a Sufficiency Index (SI) that enables the
selection and creation of principles that maximise downstream performance prior
to training. In our experiments using small (1B) LLMs, high-SI principles
predict steadier training dynamics and improved benchmark performance over GRPO
ablations. Our information-geometry analysis of trained models validates
desirable structural change in the manifold. These results support our
hypothesis that reasoning, alignment, and robustness are projections of a
single informationgeometric objective, and that models trained using ENIGMA
demonstrate principled reasoning without the use of a reward model, offering a
path to trusted capability

AI.tldr: ENIGMA introduces an information-geometric framework for LLM training that jointly improves reasoning, alignment, and robustness by steering training along policy-informed directions on the model's information manifold. It uses a single-loop trainer combining GRPO (on-policy, critic-free RL with CoT-format rewards only), a SAMI-style symmetric InfoNCE auxiliary, and an entropic Sinkhorn regulariser on hidden-state distributions. The approach also defines infoNCE-based metrics, including a Sufficiency Index (SI), to predict downstream performance and select principles. In 1B LLM experiments, high-SI principles yield steadier training and better benchmarks than GRPO ablations, and an information-geometry analysis shows desirable manifold changes. The authors claim a single information-geometric objective underlies reasoning, alignment, and robustness and that ENIGMA enables principled reasoning without a reward model, suggesting a path to trusted capability.
AI.motivation: The authors aim to unify reasoning, alignment, and robustness in LLMs by framing organisational policies as directions on the model's information manifold, enabling principled regulation of learning dynamics and reduced reliance on external reward models. They also seek to quantify how CoT encodes policies via MI bounds and to pre-select guiding principles using a Sufficiency Index.
AI.method: A single-loop trainer that combines GRPO (on-policy, critic-free RL with CoT-only rewards), a SAMI-style symmetric InfoNCE auxiliary for mutual information estimation, and an entropic Sinkhorn regulariser on hidden-state distributions to bound geometry drift. The approach introduces infoNCE-based metrics that reduce to a standard MI lower bound under matched negatives, including a Sufficiency Index (SI) for principle selection. Evaluations are conducted on small 1B LLMs.
AI.result: High-SI principles lead to steadier training dynamics and improved benchmark performance over GRPO ablations. An information-geometry analysis of trained models indicates desirable structural changes in the information manifold.
AI.conclusion: Reasoning, alignment, and robustness may be projections of a single information-geometric objective. ENIGMA-trained models reportedly achieve principled reasoning without a reward model, suggesting a path to trusted capability.

title: mmWalk: Towards Multi-modal Multi-view Walking Assistance
comment:
Accepted by NeurIPS 2025 Datasets and Benchmarks Track. Data and
  Code: https://github.com/KediYing/mmWalk
summary:
Walking assistance in extreme or complex environments remains a significant
challenge for people with blindness or low vision (BLV), largely due to the
lack of a holistic scene understanding. Motivated by the real-world needs of
the BLV community, we build mmWalk, a simulated multi-modal dataset that
integrates multi-view sensor and accessibility-oriented features for outdoor
safe navigation. Our dataset comprises 120 manually controlled,
scenario-categorized walking trajectories with 62k synchronized frames. It
contains over 559k panoramic images across RGB, depth, and semantic modalities.
Furthermore, to emphasize real-world relevance, each trajectory involves
outdoor corner cases and accessibility-specific landmarks for BLV users.
Additionally, we generate mmWalkVQA, a VQA benchmark with over 69k visual
question-answer triplets across 9 categories tailored for safe and informed
walking assistance. We evaluate state-of-the-art Vision-Language Models (VLMs)
using zero- and few-shot settings and found they struggle with our risk
assessment and navigational tasks. We validate our mmWalk-finetuned model on
real-world datasets and show the effectiveness of our dataset for advancing
multi-modal walking assistance.

AI.tldr: mmWalk is a large simulated multi-modal dataset and VQA benchmark designed to enable outdoor safe walking assistance for blind/low-vision users. It includes 120 trajectories with 62k frames and 559k panoramic images across RGB, depth, and semantic modalities, plus mmWalkVQA with 69k QA triplets. State-of-the-art Vision-Language Models underperform on risk assessment and navigation tasks; a mmWalk-finetuned model shows effectiveness on real-world data, demonstrating dataset utility for advancing multi-modal walking assistance.
AI.motivation: Address the lack of holistic scene understanding and real-world navigation support for visually impaired individuals. Create realistic, accessibility-focused data to drive progress in safe outdoor walking assistance.
AI.method: Develop mmWalk, a simulated multi-modal dataset with 120 manually controlled, scenario-categorized walking trajectories, totaling 62k synchronized frames and 559k panoramic images across RGB, depth, and semantic modalities. Include outdoor corner cases and accessibility-specific landmarks. Create mmWalkVQA with 69k visual QA triplets across 9 categories relevant to safe walking. Evaluate state-of-the-art Vision-Language Models in zero- and few-shot settings; fine-tune mmWalk on data and validate on real-world datasets.
AI.result: Current VLMs struggle with risk assessment and navigational tasks in this domain. A mmWalk-finetuned model performs better on real-world data, demonstrating the dataset’s effectiveness for advancing multi-modal walking assistance.
AI.conclusion: mmWalk provides realistic, task-relevant benchmarks for multi-modal navigation assistance, highlighting gaps in existing VLMs and offering a path toward more robust, accessible outdoor navigation tools for BLV users.

title: Vision-LLMs for Spatiotemporal Traffic Forecasting
summary:
Accurate spatiotemporal traffic forecasting is a critical prerequisite for
proactive resource management in dense urban mobile networks. While Large
Language Models (LLMs) have shown promise in time series analysis, they
inherently struggle to model the complex spatial dependencies of grid-based
traffic data. Effectively extending LLMs to this domain is challenging, as
representing the vast amount of information from dense geographical grids can
be inefficient and overwhelm the model's context. To address these challenges,
we propose ST-Vision-LLM, a novel framework that reframes spatiotemporal
forecasting as a vision-language fusion problem. Our approach leverages a
Vision-LLM visual encoder to process historical global traffic matrices as
image sequences, providing the model with a comprehensive global view to inform
cell-level predictions. To overcome the inefficiency of LLMs in handling
numerical data, we introduce an efficient encoding scheme that represents
floating-point values as single tokens via a specialized vocabulary, coupled
with a two-stage numerical alignment fine-tuning process. The model is first
trained with Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) and then further optimized for
predictive accuracy using Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO), a
memory-efficient reinforcement learning method. Evaluations on real-world
mobile traffic datasets demonstrate that ST-Vision-LLM outperforms existing
methods by 15.6% in long-term prediction accuracy and exceeds the second-best
baseline by over 30.04% in cross-domain few-shot scenarios. Our extensive
experiments validate the model's strong generalization capabilities across
various data-scarce environments.

AI.tldr: Framing spatiotemporal traffic forecasting as a vision-language task, ST-Vision-LLM uses a Vision-LLM image encoder and tokenized numeric data with two-stage fine-tuning (SFT then GRPO) to achieve strong cross-domain and long-term prediction performance.
AI.motivation: Accurate, scalable spatiotemporal traffic forecasting in dense urban networks is essential for proactive resource management. LLMs struggle with spatial dependencies and dense grid data, necessitating an efficient, generalizable approach.
AI.method: Process historical global traffic matrices as image sequences via a Vision-LLM visual encoder; encode floating-point values into tokens with a custom vocabulary; two-stage fine-tuning (Supervised Fine-Tuning followed by Group Relative Policy Optimization) to optimize predictive accuracy with memory efficiency.
AI.result: ST-Vision-LLM outperforms baselines by 15.6% in long-term predictions and exceeds the second-best baseline by over 30.04% in cross-domain few-shot scenarios, with strong generalization in data-scarce environments.
AI.conclusion: Recasting spatiotemporal forecasting as a vision-language fusion problem yields strong predictive accuracy and cross-domain generalization, offering an efficient, scalable framework for dense urban traffic forecasting.

title: Massive Activations are the Key to Local Detail Synthesis in Diffusion Transformers
summary:
Diffusion Transformers (DiTs) have recently emerged as a powerful backbone
for visual generation. Recent observations reveal \emph{Massive Activations}
(MAs) in their internal feature maps, yet their function remains poorly
understood. In this work, we systematically investigate these activations to
elucidate their role in visual generation. We found that these massive
activations occur across all spatial tokens, and their distribution is
modulated by the input timestep embeddings. Importantly, our investigations
further demonstrate that these massive activations play a key role in local
detail synthesis, while having minimal impact on the overall semantic content
of output. Building on these insights, we propose \textbf{D}etail
\textbf{G}uidance (\textbf{DG}), a MAs-driven, training-free self-guidance
strategy to explicitly enhance local detail fidelity for DiTs. Specifically, DG
constructs a degraded ``detail-deficient'' model by disrupting MAs and
leverages it to guide the original network toward higher-quality detail
synthesis. Our DG can seamlessly integrate with Classifier-Free Guidance (CFG),
enabling further refinements of fine-grained details. Extensive experiments
demonstrate that our DG consistently improves fine-grained detail quality
across various pre-trained DiTs (\eg, SD3, SD3.5, and Flux).

AI.tldr: Massive Activations (MAs) in Diffusion Transformers govern local detail synthesis with minimal impact on overall semantics. The paper introduces Detail Guidance (DG), a training-free self-guidance method that degrades MAs to steer the model toward higher-fidelity local details, and can be combined with Classifier-Free Guidance (CFG). DG consistently improves fine-grained details across multiple pre-trained DiTs (e.g., SD3, SD3.5, Flux).
AI.motivation: Understand the role of internal Massive Activations (MAs) in diffusion transformers and improve local detail fidelity in generated visuals.
AI.method: Systematic analysis of MA distributions across spatial tokens and timesteps; show MAs’ connection to local detail; devise DG by creating a degraded 'detail-deficient' model via MA disruption; apply DG as a self-guidance signal to the original network; can be combined with predicted CFG guidance for further refinement.
AI.result: DG consistently enhances fine-grained detail quality across multiple pre-trained DiTs (including SD3, SD3.5, and Flux).
AI.conclusion: Massive Activations are key to local detail synthesis in DiTs; a simple, training-free DG approach can boost detail fidelity and complements existing CFG-based methods.

title: Gym-TORAX: Open-source software for integrating RL with plasma control simulators
summary:
This paper presents Gym-TORAX, a Python package enabling the implementation
of Reinforcement Learning (RL) environments for simulating plasma dynamics and
control in tokamaks. Users define succinctly a set of control actions and
observations, and a control objective from which Gym-TORAX creates a Gymnasium
environment that wraps TORAX for simulating the plasma dynamics. The objective
is formulated through rewards depending on the simulated state of the plasma
and control action to optimize specific characteristics of the plasma, such as
performance and stability. The resulting environment instance is then
compatible with a wide range of RL algorithms and libraries and will facilitate
RL research in plasma control. In its current version, one environment is
readily available, based on a ramp-up scenario of the International
Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor (ITER).

AI.tldr: Gym-TORAX is a Python package that wraps TORAX to create RL-ready, Gymnasium environments for simulating tokamak plasma dynamics and control. Users specify control actions, observations, and a reward-based objective; the package currently provides an ITER ramp-up scenario.
AI.motivation: To enable reinforcement learning (RL) research in plasma control by offering a configurable, physics-based simulator interface that integrates TORAX with Gymnasium, making it easier to develop and compare RL strategies.
AI.method: Define a control action space, observation space, and objective rewards; Gym-TORAX generates a Gymnasium environment that wraps TORAX to simulate plasma dynamics and compute rewards, compatible with standard RL libraries; includes at least one ready-to-use environment based on ITER ramp-up.
AI.result: A ready-to-use RL environment instance that integrates TORAX with Gym-TORAX; currently one available environment based on the ITER ramp-up scenario, enabling RL experimentation in plasma control.
AI.conclusion: Gym-TORAX provides a practical bridge between physics-based plasma simulators and RL research, offering a configurable, RL-friendly interface to TORAX with an ITER ramp-up scenario and potential for additional environments in the future.

title: ODI-Bench: Can MLLMs Understand Immersive Omnidirectional Environments?
summary:
Omnidirectional images (ODIs) provide full 360x180 view which are widely
adopted in VR, AR and embodied intelligence applications. While multi-modal
large language models (MLLMs) have demonstrated remarkable performance on
conventional 2D image and video understanding benchmarks, their ability to
comprehend the immersive environments captured by ODIs remains largely
unexplored. To address this gap, we first present ODI-Bench, a novel
comprehensive benchmark specifically designed for omnidirectional image
understanding. ODI-Bench contains 2,000 high-quality omnidirectional images and
over 4,000 manually annotated question-answering (QA) pairs across 10
fine-grained tasks, covering both general-level and spatial-level ODI
understanding. Extensive experiments are conducted to benchmark 20
representative MLLMs, including proprietary and open-source models, under both
close-ended and open-ended settings. Experimental results reveal that current
MLLMs still struggle to capture the immersive context provided by ODIs. To this
end, we further introduce Omni-CoT, a training-free method which significantly
enhances MLLMs' comprehension ability in the omnidirectional environment
through chain-of-thought reasoning across both textual information and visual
cues. Both the benchmark and the code will be released upon the publication.

AI.tldr: Introduces ODI-Bench, a 2k-ODI, 4k QA benchmark for 10 tasks to evaluate MLLMs on omnidirectional images; shows current models underperform and introduces Omni-CoT, a training-free chain-of-thought method to boost ODI understanding, with results suggesting improvement and code release.
AI.motivation: MLLMs excel on conventional 2D data but struggle with immersive omnidirectional environments; a dedicated benchmark and a training-free method are needed to push understanding of ODIs.
AI.method: Construct ODI-Bench with 2,000 high-quality omnidirectional images and 4,000 manually annotated QA pairs across 10 fine-grained tasks (general and spatial understanding). Benchmark 20 representative MLLMs under close-ended and open-ended settings. Propose Omni-CoT, a training-free chain-of-thought approach that combines textual information and visual cues to enhance ODI comprehension.
AI.result: Experimental results show current MLLMs struggle to capture immersive context in ODIs. Omni-CoT significantly enhances MLLMs' comprehension in omnidirectional environments. The benchmark and code will be released.
AI.conclusion: ODI understanding remains challenging, but ODI-Bench provides a targeted evaluation platform and Omni-CoT offers a promising direction to improve MLLM performance in immersive ODI scenarios; future work may extend tasks and models and release resources.

title: LouisKV: Efficient KV Cache Retrieval for Long Input-Output Sequences
summary:
While Key-Value (KV) cache succeeds in reducing redundant computations in
auto-regressive models, it introduces significant memory overhead, limiting its
practical deployment in long-sequence scenarios. Existing KV retrieval methods
mitigate this by dynamically retaining only a subset of KV entries on the GPU.
However, they still suffer from notable efficiency and accuracy bottlenecks due
to per-token retrieval and coarse-grained page-level KV management, especially
in long-output reasoning scenarios. With the emergence of large reasoning
models, efficiently handling such scenarios has become increasingly important.
To address this issue, we present two key observations: (1) critical KVs
exhibit strong temporal locality during decoding, and (2) these KVs exhibit
distinct distribution patterns across the input prompt and generated output.
Building on these observations, we propose LouisKV, an efficient KV cache
retrieval framework designed for various long-sequence scenarios. Specifically,
LouisKV introduces a semantic-aware retrieval strategy leveraging temporal
locality to trigger retrieval only at semantic boundaries, drastically reducing
computation and data transfer overhead. LouisKV also designs a decoupled,
fine-grained management scheme that tailors differentiated strategies for input
and output sequences to create retrieval units that better match the model's
attention patterns, enabling precise identification of critical KVs.
Furthermore, to boost efficiency, LouisKV incorporates several kernel-level
optimizations, including custom Triton and CUDA kernels to accelerate the KV
clustering and retrieval. Evaluations show that LouisKV achieves up to
4.7$\times$ speedup over state-of-the-art KV retrieval methods while
maintaining near-lossless accuracy across diverse long-sequence tasks,
including long-input short-output, short-input long-output, and long-input
long-output scenarios.

AI.tldr: LouisKV is an efficient KV cache retrieval framework for long-sequence auto-regressive tasks, achieving up to 4.7x speedup with near-lossless accuracy by leveraging semantic-boundary retrieval, temporal locality, and input/output-aware retrieval units plus kernel optimizations.
AI.motivation: KV caches reduce redundant computations but incur memory overhead. Existing KV retrieval methods still suffer from per-token retrieval and coarse-grained, page-level KV management, which hurts efficiency and accuracy in long-sequence or long-reasoning scenarios. Efficient KV retrieval is increasingly important for large reasoning models.
AI.method: The paper makes two key observations: (1) critical KVs exhibit strong temporal locality during decoding, and (2) these KVs have distinct distribution patterns across the input prompt and generated output. Building on this, LouisKV proposes: a semantic-aware retrieval strategy that triggers retrieval only at semantic boundaries to reduce computation and data transfer; a decoupled, fine-grained management scheme that uses differentiated strategies for input and output sequences to create retrieval units aligned with the model's attention; retrieval units tailored to identify critical KVs more precisely; kernel-level optimizations including custom Triton and CUDA kernels for KV clustering and retrieval.
AI.result: LouisKV achieves up to 4.7x speedup over state-of-the-art KV retrieval methods while maintaining near-lossless accuracy across diverse long-sequence tasks, including long-input short-output, short-input long-output, and long-input long-output scenarios.
AI.conclusion: LouisKV provides an efficient and accurate KV cache retrieval framework for long sequences by exploiting temporal locality and distribution patterns, with effective retrieval unit design and low-level kernel optimizations, enabling practical long-sequence reasoning.

title: How many samples to label for an application given a foundation model? Chest X-ray classification study
summary:
Chest X-ray classification is vital yet resource-intensive, typically
demanding extensive annotated data for accurate diagnosis. Foundation models
mitigate this reliance, but how many labeled samples are required remains
unclear. We systematically evaluate the use of power-law fits to predict the
training size necessary for specific ROC-AUC thresholds. Testing multiple
pathologies and foundation models, we find XrayCLIP and XraySigLIP achieve
strong performance with significantly fewer labeled examples than a ResNet-50
baseline. Importantly, learning curve slopes from just 50 labeled cases
accurately forecast final performance plateaus. Our results enable
practitioners to minimize annotation costs by labeling only the essential
samples for targeted performance.

AI.tldr: Power-law learning curves predict the labeling needed to reach target ROC-AUC in chest X-ray classification. Foundation models XrayCLIP and XraySigLIP achieve strong performance with far fewer labeled examples than a ResNet-50 baseline, and learning-curve slopes from just 50 labeled cases can forecast the final performance plateau, enabling annotation-cost minimization.
AI.motivation: Medical imaging models typically require large labeled datasets. This work investigates whether power-law fits can forecast the amount of labeled data needed to reach specified diagnostic performance, helping practitioners budget annotation efforts when using foundation models.
AI.method: Fit power-law learning curves to ROC-AUC as a function of labeled sample size across multiple chest X-ray pathologies and foundation models (XrayCLIP, XraySigLIP, and ResNet-50). Compare performance with varying label counts and assess whether early slopes (from 50 labeled cases) predict the eventual performance plateau.
AI.result: XrayCLIP and XraySigLIP reach strong ROC-AUC with substantially fewer labeled samples than ResNet-50. Slopes estimated from 50 labeled cases accurately forecast the final performance plateau, enabling early budgeting of annotation efforts.
AI.conclusion: Power-law-based data budgeting can significantly reduce annotation costs for chest X-ray classification using foundation models by identifying the essential labeled samples needed to achieve target performance.

title: DiffStyleTS: Diffusion Model for Style Transfer in Time Series
summary:
Style transfer combines the content of one signal with the style of another.
It supports applications such as data augmentation and scenario simulation,
helping machine learning models generalize in data-scarce domains. While well
developed in vision and language, style transfer methods for time series data
remain limited. We introduce DiffTSST, a diffusion-based framework that
disentangles a time series into content and style representations via
convolutional encoders and recombines them through a self-supervised
attention-based diffusion process. At inference, encoders extract content and
style from two distinct series, enabling conditional generation of novel
samples to achieve style transfer. We demonstrate both qualitatively and
quantitatively that DiffTSST achieves effective style transfer. We further
validate its real-world utility by showing that data augmentation with DiffTSST
improves anomaly detection in data-scarce regimes.

AI.tldr: A diffusion-based time-series style transfer framework (DiffTSST) that disentangles content and style via encoders and reconstitutes them with a self-supervised, attention-guided diffusion process; enables conditional generation and boosts anomaly detection with data augmentation in scarce-data settings.
AI.motivation: Style transfer for time series is underdeveloped compared to vision and language, hindering data augmentation and scenario simulation in data-scarce domains. There is a need for robust methods to separate content and style in time series to improve generalization.
AI.method: Propose DiffTSST: convolutional encoders disentangle content and style; a self-supervised, attention-based diffusion process recombines them. At inference, content and style are extracted from two Series to generate samples with a targeted style for transfer; trained in a self-supervised manner.
AI.result: Qualitative and quantitative evidence shows effective style transfer. Data augmentation with DiffTSST improves anomaly detection in data-scarce regimes.
AI.conclusion: DiffTSST provides a viable diffusion-based approach to time-series style transfer, enabling conditional generation and practical gains in anomaly detection when data are limited.

title: SNAP: Towards Segmenting Anything in Any Point Cloud
summary:
Interactive 3D point cloud segmentation enables efficient annotation of
complex 3D scenes through user-guided prompts. However, current approaches are
typically restricted in scope to a single domain (indoor or outdoor), and to a
single form of user interaction (either spatial clicks or textual prompts).
Moreover, training on multiple datasets often leads to negative transfer,
resulting in domain-specific tools that lack generalizability. To address these
limitations, we present \textbf{SNAP} (\textbf{S}egment a\textbf{N}ything in
\textbf{A}ny \textbf{P}oint cloud), a unified model for interactive 3D
segmentation that supports both point-based and text-based prompts across
diverse domains. Our approach achieves cross-domain generalizability by
training on 7 datasets spanning indoor, outdoor, and aerial environments, while
employing domain-adaptive normalization to prevent negative transfer. For
text-prompted segmentation, we automatically generate mask proposals without
human intervention and match them against CLIP embeddings of textual queries,
enabling both panoptic and open-vocabulary segmentation. Extensive experiments
demonstrate that SNAP consistently delivers high-quality segmentation results.
We achieve state-of-the-art performance on 8 out of 9 zero-shot benchmarks for
spatial-prompted segmentation and demonstrate competitive results on all 5
text-prompted benchmarks. These results show that a unified model can match or
exceed specialized domain-specific approaches, providing a practical tool for
scalable 3D annotation. Project page is at, https://neu-vi.github.io/SNAP/

AI.tldr: SNAP is a unified, cross-domain interactive 3D segmentation model that supports both point-based and text-based prompts. Trained on 7 diverse datasets (indoor, outdoor, aerial) with domain-adaptive normalization to prevent negative transfer, it generates text-prompt proposals via CLIP and achieves strong zero-shot performance across most benchmarks, matching or exceeding domain-specific methods.
AI.motivation: Current 3D segmentation methods are often domain-specific, rely on a single type of user interaction, and suffer from negative transfer when trained on multiple datasets. A unified, generalizable tool is needed for scalable 3D annotation across varied environments and prompting modalities.
AI.method: Introduce SNAP, a unified model for interactive 3D segmentation that supports both point-based and text-based prompts across domains. Train on 7 datasets spanning indoor, outdoor, and aerial scenes with domain-adaptive normalization to mitigate negative transfer. For text prompts, automatically generate mask proposals and match them to CLIP embeddings of textual queries to enable panoptic and open-vocabulary segmentation.
AI.result: SNAP achieves state-of-the-art performance on 8 of 9 zero-shot benchmarks for spatial-prompted segmentation and matches or competes well on all 5 text-prompted benchmarks, demonstrating strong cross-domain generalization and the benefit of a unified approach.
AI.conclusion: A single, domain-aware yet generalizable model can deliver high-quality 3D segmentation across diverse environments and prompting modalities, offering a practical, scalable tool for 3D annotation.

title: Event-Aware Prompt Learning for Dynamic Graphs
summary:
Real-world graph typically evolve via a series of events, modeling dynamic
interactions between objects across various domains. For dynamic graph
learning, dynamic graph neural networks (DGNNs) have emerged as popular
solutions. Recently, prompt learning methods have been explored on dynamic
graphs. However, existing methods generally focus on capturing the relationship
between nodes and time, while overlooking the impact of historical events. In
this paper, we propose EVP, an event-aware dynamic graph prompt learning
framework that can serve as a plug-in to existing methods, enhancing their
ability to leverage historical events knowledge. First, we extract a series of
historical events for each node and introduce an event adaptation mechanism to
align the fine-grained characteristics of these events with downstream tasks.
Second, we propose an event aggregation mechanism to effectively integrate
historical knowledge into node representations. Finally, we conduct extensive
experiments on four public datasets to evaluate and analyze EVP.

AI.tldr: EVP is an event-aware dynamic graph prompt learning framework that can be plugged into existing dynamic graph neural networks to leverage historical events, improving representation learning. It demonstrates effectiveness on four public datasets.
AI.motivation: Dynamic graphs evolve through events, and historical events carry valuable knowledge that is not fully captured by existing node-time or prompt-based methods. There is a gap in leveraging historical events to improve downstream tasks in dynamic graph learning.
AI.method: EVP extracts a sequence of historical events per node, introduces an event adaptation module to align event features with downstream tasks, and uses an event aggregation mechanism to integrate this historical knowledge into node representations. It is designed as a plug-in to existing DGNNs and prompt learning pipelines.
AI.result: Experiments on four public datasets show that EVP improves performance over baselines. Ablation studies confirm the contributions of the event adaptation and event aggregation components and demonstrate compatibility with different DGNNs.
AI.conclusion: EVP offers a flexible plug-in to incorporate historical events knowledge into dynamic graph learning, enhancing performance and generalization. The approach can be extended to broader settings and could explore richer event types and efficiency optimizations.

title: A Framework for Low-Effort Training Data Generation for Urban Semantic Segmentation
summary:
Synthetic datasets are widely used for training urban scene recognition
models, but even highly realistic renderings show a noticeable gap to real
imagery. This gap is particularly pronounced when adapting to a specific target
domain, such as Cityscapes, where differences in architecture, vegetation,
object appearance, and camera characteristics limit downstream performance.
Closing this gap with more detailed 3D modelling would require expensive asset
and scene design, defeating the purpose of low-cost labelled data. To address
this, we present a new framework that adapts an off-the-shelf diffusion model
to a target domain using only imperfect pseudo-labels. Once trained, it
generates high-fidelity, target-aligned images from semantic maps of any
synthetic dataset, including low-effort sources created in hours rather than
months. The method filters suboptimal generations, rectifies image-label
misalignments, and standardises semantics across datasets, transforming weak
synthetic data into competitive real-domain training sets. Experiments on five
synthetic datasets and two real target datasets show segmentation gains of up
to +8.0%pt. mIoU over state-of-the-art translation methods, making rapidly
constructed synthetic datasets as effective as high-effort, time-intensive
synthetic datasets requiring extensive manual design. This work highlights a
valuable collaborative paradigm where fast semantic prototyping, combined with
generative models, enables scalable, high-quality training data creation for
urban scene understanding.

AI.tldr: A diffusion-model-based framework adapts an off-the-shelf diffusion model to a target urban domain using imperfect pseudo-labels, producing high-fidelity, domain-aligned images from semantic maps to improve segmentation. It filters poor generations, fixes image-label misalignments, and standardizes semantics, enabling weak synthetic data to rival real-domain training sets.
AI.motivation: Synthetic data lag behind real imagery, especially for domain-specific adaptation like Cityscapes. Differences in architecture, vegetation, object appearance, and camera characteristics limit downstream performance; expensive 3D modeling for better realism undermines the low-cost benefits of synthetic data.
AI.method: Fine-tune/adapt a pre-trained diffusion model to a target domain using imperfect pseudo-labels. At inference, generate target-aligned images from semantic maps of any synthetic dataset. Apply filtering of suboptimal generations, rectify image-label misalignments, and standardize semantics across datasets to produce high-quality, domain-aligned training data.
AI.result: Across five synthetic datasets and two real target datasets, achieved segmentation gains up to 8.0 percentage points in mIoU over state-of-the-art translation methods. Demonstrates that rapidly constructed synthetic data can be competitive with more expensive, manually designed synthetic datasets.
AI.conclusion: The approach enables fast, scalable creation of high-quality, target-aligned training data for urban-scene understanding by combining rapid semantic prototyping with generative models, reducing cost and time while maintaining performance gains.

title: Part II: ROLL Flash -- Accelerating RLVR and Agentic Training with Asynchrony
summary:
Synchronous Reinforcement Learning (RL) post-training has emerged as a
crucial step for enhancing Large Language Models (LLMs) with diverse
capabilities. However, many systems designed to accelerate RL post-training
still suffer from low resource utilization and limited scalability. We present
ROLL Flash, a system that extends ROLL with native support for asynchronous RL
post-training. ROLL Flash is built upon two core design principles:
fine-grained parallelism and rollout-train decoupling. Guided by these
principles, ROLL Flash provides flexible programming interfaces that enable a
fully asynchronous training architecture and support efficient rollout
mechanisms, including queue scheduling and environment-level asynchronous
execution. Through comprehensive theoretical analysis and extensive
experiments, we demonstrate that ROLL Flash significantly improves resource
utilization and scalability over synchronous RL post-training. ROLL Flash
achieves up to 2.24x speedup on RLVR tasks and 2.72x on agentic tasks, using
the same GPU budget as synchronous baselines. Furthermore, we implement several
popular off-policy algorithms and verify that asynchronous training can achieve
performance on par with synchronous training.

AI.tldr: ROLL Flash enables asynchronous RL post-training for LLMs, improving resource utilization and scalability over synchronous baselines, with substantial speedups while maintaining performance.
AI.motivation: Synchronous RL post-training often suffers from underutilized resources and limited scalability when enhancing LLMs. The paper proposes ROLL Flash to extend ROLL with native asynchronous RL post-training.
AI.method: Two core design principles—fine-grained parallelism and rollout-train decoupling—drive a fully asynchronous training architecture with flexible interfaces, queue scheduling, and environment-level asynchronous execution. The system supports efficient rollout mechanisms and implements several off-policy algorithms.
AI.result: Theoretical analysis and extensive experiments show improved resource utilization and scalability over synchronous RL post-training. Achieves up to 2.24x speedup on RLVR tasks and 2.72x on agentic tasks using the same GPU budget. Asynchronous training attains performance on par with synchronous training.
AI.conclusion: Asynchronous RL post-training via ROLL Flash is effective and scalable, achieving substantial efficiency gains without sacrificing performance compared to synchronous training.

title: Benchmarking foundation models for hyperspectral image classification: Application to cereal crop type mapping
comment:
Being reviewed for WHISPERS conference ( Workshop on Hyperspectral
  Image and Signal Processing: Evolution in Remote Sensing )
summary:
Foundation models are transforming Earth observation, but their potential for
hyperspectral crop mapping remains underexplored. This study benchmarks three
foundation models for cereal crop mapping using hyperspectral imagery:
HyperSigma, DOFA, and Vision Transformers pre-trained on the SpectralEarth
dataset (a large multitemporal hyperspectral archive). Models were fine-tuned
on manually labeled data from a training region and evaluated on an independent
test region. Performance was measured with overall accuracy (OA), average
accuracy (AA), and F1-score. HyperSigma achieved an OA of 34.5% (+/- 1.8%),
DOFA reached 62.6% (+/- 3.5%), and the SpectralEarth model achieved an OA of
93.5% (+/- 0.8%). A compact SpectralEarth variant trained from scratch achieved
91%, highlighting the importance of model architecture for strong
generalization across geographic regions and sensor platforms. These results
