provide a systematic evaluation of foundation models for operational
hyperspectral crop mapping and outline directions for future model development.

AI.tldr: Foundation models can map cereals from hyperspectral data, with SpectralEarth pre-trained ViT achieving the highest accuracy (~93.5% OA), outperforming DOFA (~62.6%) and HyperSigma (~34.5%); a scratch SpectralEarth variant ~91% emphasizes architecture’s role in cross-region generalization.
AI.motivation: To systematically evaluate how foundation models perform on hyperspectral cereal crop mapping, across different architectures and pre-training datasets, and to assess generalization across geographic regions and sensor platforms.
AI.method: Benchmark three foundation models (HyperSigma, DOFA, SpectralEarth ViT) pre-trained on the SpectralEarth hyperspectral archive; fine-tune on labeled data from a training region; evaluate on an independent test region using OA, AA, and F1-score (mean ± standard deviation); compare with a compact SpectralEarth model trained from scratch.
AI.result: HyperSigma: OA 34.5% ±1.8%; DOFA: OA 62.6% ±3.5%; SpectralEarth ViT: OA 93.5% ±0.8%. A compact SpectralEarth variant trained from scratch achieved 91% OA. AA and F1-score are evaluated but specific values are not reported in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: The study provides a systematic evaluation of foundation models for operational hyperspectral crop mapping and highlights the importance of model architecture for strong cross-regional and cross-sensor generalization, outlining directions for future model development.

title: Multi-View Graph Feature Propagation for Privacy Preservation and Feature Sparsity
summary:
Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have demonstrated remarkable success in node
classification tasks over relational data, yet their effectiveness often
depends on the availability of complete node features. In many real-world
scenarios, however, feature matrices are highly sparse or contain sensitive
information, leading to degraded performance and increased privacy risks.
Furthermore, direct exposure of information can result in unintended data
leakage, enabling adversaries to infer sensitive information. To address these
challenges, we propose a novel Multi-view Feature Propagation (MFP) framework
that enhances node classification under feature sparsity while promoting
privacy preservation. MFP extends traditional Feature Propagation (FP) by
dividing the available features into multiple Gaussian-noised views, each
propagating information independently through the graph topology. The
aggregated representations yield expressive and robust node embeddings. This
framework is novel in two respects: it introduces a mechanism that improves
robustness under extreme sparsity, and it provides a principled way to balance
utility with privacy. Extensive experiments conducted on graph datasets
demonstrate that MFP outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in node
classification while substantially reducing privacy leakage. Moreover, our
analysis demonstrates that propagated outputs serve as alternative imputations
rather than reconstructions of the original features, preserving utility
without compromising privacy. A comprehensive sensitivity analysis further
confirms the stability and practical applicability of MFP across diverse
scenarios. Overall, MFP provides an effective and privacy-aware framework for
graph learning in domains characterized by missing or sensitive features.

AI.tldr: MFP provides a privacy-aware enhancement to graph neural networks under sparse feature conditions by constructing multiple Gaussian-noised feature views, propagating them independently over the graph, and aggregating the results to yield robust node embeddings that preserve utility while reducing privacy leakage.
AI.motivation: GNNs depend on abundant feature information; in real-world graphs features are often sparse or sensitive, causing performance drop and privacy risks; need a method that improves robustness to sparsity and protects privacy.
AI.method: Divide available features into several Gaussian-noised views; for each view perform feature propagation through the graph topology; aggregate multiple propagated representations into final node embeddings; analyze that outputs act as imputations rather than reconstructions; conduct sensitivity analysis.
AI.result: MFP outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in node classification under feature sparsity; substantially reduces privacy leakage; propagation outputs serve as imputations preserving utility; robust across diverse scenarios.
AI.conclusion: MFP offers an effective, privacy-aware framework for graph learning in domains with missing or sensitive features, balancing utility and privacy while enhancing robustness to sparsity.

title: MS-Mix: Unveiling the Power of Mixup for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
summary:
Multimodal Sentiment Analysis (MSA) aims to identify and interpret human
emotions by integrating information from heterogeneous data sources such as
text, video, and audio. While deep learning models have advanced in network
architecture design, they remain heavily limited by scarce multimodal annotated
data. Although Mixup-based augmentation improves generalization in unimodal
tasks, its direct application to MSA introduces critical challenges: random
mixing often amplifies label ambiguity and semantic inconsistency due to the
lack of emotion-aware mixing mechanisms. To overcome these issues, we propose
MS-Mix, an adaptive, emotion-sensitive augmentation framework that
automatically optimizes sample mixing in multimodal settings. The key
components of MS-Mix include: (1) a Sentiment-Aware Sample Selection (SASS)
strategy that effectively prevents semantic confusion caused by mixing samples
with contradictory emotions. (2) a Sentiment Intensity Guided (SIG) module
using multi-head self-attention to compute modality-specific mixing ratios
dynamically based on their respective emotional intensities. (3) a Sentiment
Alignment Loss (SAL) that aligns the prediction distributions across
modalities, and incorporates the Kullback-Leibler-based loss as an additional
regularization term to train the emotion intensity predictor and the backbone
network jointly. Extensive experiments on three benchmark datasets with six
state-of-the-art backbones confirm that MS-Mix consistently outperforms
existing methods, establishing a new standard for robust multimodal sentiment
augmentation. The source code is available at:
https://github.com/HongyuZhu-s/MS-Mix.

AI.tldr: MS-Mix introduces emotion-aware Mixup for multimodal sentiment analysis to address semantic confusion from naive mixing; it uses SASS for sample selection, SIG to compute modality-specific mixing ratios via sentiment intensities, and SAL with KL regularization to align predictions; results show consistent improvements across three datasets and six backbones; code available at GitHub.
AI.motivation: Scarcity of multimodal annotated data; naive Mixup amplifies label ambiguity and semantic inconsistency when mixing samples from different modalities/emotions.
AI.method: Three components: SASS selects samples to avoid contradictory emotions; SIG uses multi-head self-attention to compute mixing ratios per modality based on emotional intensity; SAL aligns distributions across modalities and includes KL-based regularization to train intensity predictor and backbone.
AI.result: Three benchmark datasets, six backbones; MS-Mix outperforms existing methods; establishes new standard for robust multimodal augmentation.
AI.conclusion: Emotion-aware augmentation via MS-Mix effectively improves MSA performance; provides adaptable, interpretable mixing and alignment; code released.”

title: Understanding the Generalization of Stochastic Gradient Adam in Learning Neural Networks
summary:
Adam is a popular and widely used adaptive gradient method in deep learning,
which has also received tremendous focus in theoretical research. However, most
existing theoretical work primarily analyzes its full-batch version, which
differs fundamentally from the stochastic variant used in practice. Unlike SGD,
stochastic Adam does not converge to its full-batch counterpart even with
infinitesimal learning rates. We present the first theoretical characterization
of how batch size affects Adam's generalization, analyzing two-layer
over-parameterized CNNs on image data. Our results reveal that while both Adam
and AdamW with proper weight decay $\lambda$ converge to poor test error
solutions, their mini-batch variants can achieve near-zero test error. We
further prove Adam has a strictly smaller effective weight decay bound than
AdamW, theoretically explaining why Adam requires more sensitive $\lambda$
tuning. Extensive experiments validate our findings, demonstrating the critical
role of batch size and weight decay in Adam's generalization performance.

AI.tldr: Two-layer over-parameterized CNNs show batch size and weight decay crucially shape Adam's generalization: mini-batch Adam/AdamW can reach near-zero test error while full-batch Adam converges to poor test error; Adam has a smaller effective weight decay bound than AdamW, explaining tougher λ tuning.
AI.motivation: Address the gap between theory and practice by characterizing how stochastic batch size affects Adam's generalization, and why mini-batch Adam can outperform its full-batch counterpart.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis of Adam/AdamW on two-layer over-parameterized CNNs trained on image data; derivation of how batch size and weight decay influence generalization; comparison of effective weight-decay bounds; extensive experiments validating predictions.
AI.result: Mini-batch variants achieve near-zero test error; full-batch version yields poor test error; Adam's effective weight decay bound is strictly smaller than AdamW; results demonstrate critical role of batch size and weight decay.
AI.conclusion: Batch size and weight decay are central to Adam's generalization; results explain why Adam requires more sensitive λ tuning and provide guidance on setting batch size and weight decay for better generalization.

title: ACE-G: Improving Generalization of Scene Coordinate Regression Through Query Pre-Training
summary:
Scene coordinate regression (SCR) has established itself as a promising
learning-based approach to visual relocalization. After mere minutes of
scene-specific training, SCR models estimate camera poses of query images with
high accuracy. Still, SCR methods fall short of the generalization capabilities
of more classical feature-matching approaches. When imaging conditions of query
images, such as lighting or viewpoint, are too different from the training
views, SCR models fail. Failing to generalize is an inherent limitation of
previous SCR frameworks, since their training objective is to encode the
training views in the weights of the coordinate regressor itself. The regressor
essentially overfits to the training views, by design. We propose to separate
the coordinate regressor and the map representation into a generic transformer
and a scene-specific map code. This separation allows us to pre-train the
transformer on tens of thousands of scenes. More importantly, it allows us to
train the transformer to generalize from mapping images to unseen query images
during pre-training. We demonstrate on multiple challenging relocalization
datasets that our method, ACE-G, leads to significantly increased robustness
while keeping the computational footprint attractive.

AI.tldr: ACE-G splits the SCR pipeline into a generic transformer-based map and a scene-specific map code, enabling pre-training on many scenes to improve generalization and robustness in visual relocalization.
AI.motivation: SCR models overfit to training views and struggle with different lighting/viewpoints; a generalizable mapping from images to scene coordinates is needed.
AI.method: Replace the coordinate regressor with a generic transformer and a scene-specific map code; pre-train the transformer on tens of thousands of scenes and train it to generalize to unseen query images during pre-training; keep computation efficient.
AI.result: ACE-G demonstrates significantly improved robustness to appearance and viewpoint changes across multiple relocalization datasets, while maintaining an attractive computational footprint.
AI.conclusion: Separating map representation from the regressor enables better generalization in SCR, making SCR more competitive with classical feature-based relocalization.

title: Medical Interpretability and Knowledge Maps of Large Language Models
summary:
We present a systematic study of medical-domain interpretability in Large
Language Models (LLMs). We study how the LLMs both represent and process
medical knowledge through four different interpretability techniques: (1) UMAP
projections of intermediate activations, (2) gradient-based saliency with
respect to the model weights, (3) layer lesioning/removal and (4) activation
patching. We present knowledge maps of five LLMs which show, at a
coarse-resolution, where knowledge about patient's ages, medical symptoms,
diseases and drugs is stored in the models. In particular for Llama3.3-70B, we
find that most medical knowledge is processed in the first half of the model's
layers. In addition, we find several interesting phenomena: (i) age is often
encoded in a non-linear and sometimes discontinuous manner at intermediate
layers in the models, (ii) the disease progression representation is
non-monotonic and circular at certain layers of the model, (iii) in
Llama3.3-70B, drugs cluster better by medical specialty rather than mechanism
of action, especially for Llama3.3-70B and (iv) Gemma3-27B and MedGemma-27B
have activations that collapse at intermediate layers but recover by the final
layers. These results can guide future research on fine-tuning, un-learning or
de-biasing LLMs for medical tasks by suggesting at which layers in the model
these techniques should be applied.

AI.tldr: A multi-model interpretability study of medical-domain knowledge in LLMs using four techniques (UMAP activation projections, gradient saliency, layer lesioning/removal, and activation patching) across five models. It maps where knowledge about patient age, symptoms, diseases, and drugs is stored, finds that most medical knowledge in Llama3.3-70B is processed in the first half of its layers, and reveals non-linear/non-monotonic patterns in age encoding and disease progression, with drug clustering by specialty rather than mechanism of action. Some models show activation collapse mid-network but recover later. The work suggests layer-targeted fine-tuning, un-learning, or debiasing strategies for medical tasks.
AI.motivation: To uncover how medical knowledge is represented and processed in large language models, so that targeted interventions (fine-tuning, un-learning, debiasing) can be applied at appropriate network layers to improve medical reliability and reduce biases.
AI.method: Apply four interpretability techniques across five LLMs: (1) UMAP projections of intermediate activations, (2) gradient-based saliency with respect to model weights, (3) layer lesioning/removal, and (4) activation patching. Construct coarse-resolution knowledge maps for patient attributes (ages, symptoms, diseases, drugs) and analyze layer-wise storage and processing, with detailed observations for Llama3.3-70B and notes on Gemma3-27B / MedGemma-27B.
AI.result: Findings include: most medical knowledge in Llama3.3-70B is processed in the first half of the model; age is encoded in non-linear and sometimes discontinuous ways at intermediate layers; disease progression representation is non-monotonic and circular at certain layers; drugs cluster more by medical specialty than mechanism of action for Llama3.3-70B; Gemma3-27B and MedGemma-27B show activations that collapse at intermediate layers but recover by final layers.
AI.conclusion: These results can guide targeted interventions during fine-tuning, un-learning, or debiasing for medical tasks by indicating which layers are most relevant for different types of medical knowledge and biases.

title: ExpVid: A Benchmark for Experiment Video Understanding & Reasoning
summary:
Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) hold promise for accelerating
scientific discovery by interpreting complex experimental procedures. However,
their true capabilities are poorly understood, as existing benchmarks neglect
the fine-grained and long-horizon nature of authentic laboratory work,
especially in wet-lab settings. To bridge this gap, we introduce ExpVid, the
first benchmark designed to systematically evaluate MLLMs on scientific
experiment videos. Curated from peer-reviewed video publications, ExpVid
features a new three-level task hierarchy that mirrors the scientific process:
(1) Fine-grained Perception of tools, materials, and actions; (2) Procedural
Understanding of step order and completeness; and (3) Scientific Reasoning that
connects the full experiment to its published conclusions. Our vision-centric
annotation pipeline, combining automated generation with multi-disciplinary
expert validation, ensures that tasks require visual grounding. We evaluate 19
leading MLLMs on ExpVid and find that while they excel at coarse-grained
recognition, they struggle with disambiguating fine details, tracking state
changes over time, and linking experimental procedures to scientific outcomes.
Our results reveal a notable performance gap between proprietary and
open-source models, particularly in high-order reasoning. ExpVid not only
provides a diagnostic tool but also charts a roadmap for developing MLLMs
capable of becoming trustworthy partners in scientific experimentation.

AI.tldr: ExpVid introduces the first benchmark to evaluate multimodal LLMs on scientific experiment videos, revealing gaps in fine-grained perception, state-tracking, and reasoning with a roadmap for future development.
AI.motivation: To address the gap that existing benchmarks overlook the fine-grained, long-horizon nature of wet-lab work, and to enable trustworthy MLLMs that can interpret experimental procedures and connect them to published conclusions.
AI.method: A vision-centric annotation pipeline and three-level task hierarchy (perception, procedural understanding, scientific reasoning); curated from peer-reviewed videos; automated generation plus multidisciplinary expert validation.
AI.result: Evaluated 19 leading MLLMs; models perform well on coarse recognition but struggle with fine details, state changes, and linking procedures to outcomes; proprietary models outperform open-source in high-level reasoning.
AI.conclusion: ExpVid serves as a diagnostic tool and roadmap to develop MLLMs capable of assisting scientific experimentation with trustworthy, explainable reasoning.

title: FedHybrid: Breaking the Memory Wall of Federated Learning via Hybrid Tensor Management
summary:
Federated Learning (FL) emerges as a new learning paradigm that enables
multiple devices to collaboratively train a shared model while preserving data
privacy. However, one fundamental and prevailing challenge that hinders the
deployment of FL on mobile devices is the memory limitation. This paper
proposes \textit{FedHybrid}, a novel framework that effectively reduces the
memory footprint during the training process while guaranteeing the model
accuracy and the overall training progress. Specifically, \textit{FedHybrid}
first selects the participating devices for each training round by jointly
evaluating their memory budget, computing capability, and data diversity. After
that, it judiciously analyzes the computational graph and generates an
execution plan for each selected client in order to meet the corresponding
memory budget while minimizing the training delay through employing a hybrid of
recomputation and compression techniques according to the characteristic of
each tensor. During the local training process, \textit{FedHybrid} carries out
the execution plan with a well-designed activation compression technique to
effectively achieve memory reduction with minimum accuracy loss. We conduct
extensive experiments to evaluate \textit{FedHybrid} on both simulation and
off-the-shelf mobile devices. The experiment results demonstrate that
\textit{FedHybrid} achieves up to a 39.1\% increase in model accuracy and a
15.5$\times$ reduction in wall clock time under various memory budgets compared
with the baselines.

AI.tldr: FedHybrid reduces memory footprint in federated learning on mobile devices by jointly selecting participating clients and planning execution to fit memory budgets using a hybrid of recomputation and tensor-wise compression, including activation compression during local training. This yields substantial gains in accuracy and wall-clock time compared with baselines across memory budgets.
AI.motivation: Memory limitations on mobile devices hinder Federated Learning: devices are heterogeneous in memory, compute, and data distribution. The goal is to maintain or improve model accuracy and training progress while reducing memory usage and delay.
AI.method: 1) Per-round client selection considering memory budget, compute capability, and data diversity; 2) Construct an execution plan for each selected client by analyzing the computational graph to meet memory budgets while minimizing training delay using a hybrid of recomputation and compression tailored to each tensor; 3) During local training, apply activation compression to further memory reduction with minimal accuracy loss.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on both simulation and real mobiles show FedHybrid achieving up to 39.1% improvement in model accuracy and a 15.5x reduction in wall clock time under various memory budgets compared to baselines.
AI.conclusion: FedHybrid effectively reduces memory footprint in federated learning on mobile devices without sacrificing, and in some cases improving, model accuracy, and significantly speeds up training. It demonstrates practical deployment potential and offers a concrete memory-accurate-train-time tradeoff framework for FL on resource-constrained devices.

title: High-resolution Photo Enhancement in Real-time: A Laplacian Pyramid Network
summary:
Photo enhancement plays a crucial role in augmenting the visual aesthetics of
a photograph. In recent years, photo enhancement methods have either focused on
enhancement performance, producing powerful models that cannot be deployed on
edge devices, or prioritized computational efficiency, resulting in inadequate
performance for real-world applications. To this end, this paper introduces a
pyramid network called LLF-LUT++, which integrates global and local operators
through closed-form Laplacian pyramid decomposition and reconstruction. This
approach enables fast processing of high-resolution images while also achieving
excellent performance. Specifically, we utilize an image-adaptive 3D LUT that
capitalizes on the global tonal characteristics of downsampled images, while
incorporating two distinct weight fusion strategies to achieve coarse global
image enhancement. To implement this strategy, we designed a spatial-frequency
transformer weight predictor that effectively extracts the desired distinct
weights by leveraging frequency features. Additionally, we apply local
Laplacian filters to adaptively refine edge details in high-frequency
components. After meticulously redesigning the network structure and
transformer model, LLF-LUT++ not only achieves a 2.64 dB improvement in PSNR on
the HDR+ dataset, but also further reduces runtime, with 4K resolution images
processed in just 13 ms on a single GPU. Extensive experimental results on two
benchmark datasets further show that the proposed approach performs favorably
compared to state-of-the-art methods. The source code will be made publicly
available at https://github.com/fengzhang427/LLF-LUT.

AI.tldr: A fast, high-quality photo enhancement method LLF-LUT++ uses a pyramid Laplacian-based architecture with adaptive 3D LUTs and a frequency-aware transformer, delivering strong enhancement with real-time 4K performance on a single GPU.
AI.motivation: Current photo enhancement methods face a trade-off between enhancement quality and efficiency, hindering deployment on edge devices and real-world use for high-resolution images.
AI.method: LLF-LUT++ integrates global and local operators via closed-form Laplacian pyramid decomposition/reconstruction. It employs an image-adaptive 3D LUT leveraging global tonal characteristics from downsampled images, with two weight fusion strategies for coarse global enhancement. A spatial-frequency transformer weight predictor extracts distinct weights using frequency features. Local Laplacian filters refine edge details in high-frequency components. The architecture and transformer are redesigned to improve both performance and speed.
AI.result: On the HDR+ dataset, LLF-LUT++ achieves a 2.64 dB PSNR improvement. It processes 4K images in ~13 ms on a single GPU, and experiments on two benchmarks show favorable performance against state-of-the-art methods.
AI.conclusion: LLF-LUT++ delivers fast, high-quality photo enhancement suitable for real-world deployment, balancing global tone adaptation with local detail preservation, and will be open-sourced.

title: Leveraging LLMs for Semi-Automatic Corpus Filtration in Systematic Literature Reviews
summary:
The creation of systematic literature reviews (SLR) is critical for analyzing
the landscape of a research field and guiding future research directions.
However, retrieving and filtering the literature corpus for an SLR is highly
time-consuming and requires extensive manual effort, as keyword-based searches
in digital libraries often return numerous irrelevant publications. In this
work, we propose a pipeline leveraging multiple large language models (LLMs),
classifying papers based on descriptive prompts and deciding jointly using a
consensus scheme. The entire process is human-supervised and interactively
controlled via our open-source visual analytics web interface, LLMSurver, which
enables real-time inspection and modification of model outputs. We evaluate our
approach using ground-truth data from a recent SLR comprising over 8,000
candidate papers, benchmarking both open and commercial state-of-the-art LLMs
from mid-2024 and fall 2025. Results demonstrate that our pipeline
significantly reduces manual effort while achieving lower error rates than
single human annotators. Furthermore, modern open-source models prove
sufficient for this task, making the method accessible and cost-effective.
Overall, our work demonstrates how responsible human-AI collaboration can
accelerate and enhance systematic literature reviews within academic workflows.

AI.tldr: A human-supervised, multi-LLM pipeline for systematic literature reviews using a consensus scheme and an open-source visual analytics interface (LLMSurver) to classify papers; it reduces manual effort and performs at or below the error rate of single annotators with open models.
AI.motivation: SLRs are essential for mapping research domains but are labor-intensive due to large literature corpora and noisy keyword searches; there is a need for scalable, accurate, and cost-effective literature screening that leverages modern LLMs.
AI.method: A pipeline that uses multiple LLMs with descriptive prompts to classify papers and makes joint decisions via a consensus scheme. It is controlled interactively by a human-in-the-loop through an open-source visual analytics interface (LLMSurver), enabling real-time inspection and modification of outputs. Evaluation on ground-truth data from a large SLR (~8,000 candidate papers) comparing open and commercial LLMs from mid-2024 to fall 2025.
AI.result: The approach significantly reduces manual effort and yields lower error rates than a single human annotator. Modern open-source models are sufficient, making the method accessible and cost-effective.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates that responsible human-AI collaboration can accelerate and improve SLR workflows in academic research, with open-source models enabling broad accessibility and cost savings.

title: EvoCAD: Evolutionary CAD Code Generation with Vision Language Models
summary:
Combining large language models with evolutionary computation algorithms
represents a promising research direction leveraging the remarkable generative
and in-context learning capabilities of LLMs with the strengths of evolutionary
algorithms. In this work, we present EvoCAD, a method for generating
computer-aided design (CAD) objects through their symbolic representations
using vision language models and evolutionary optimization. Our method samples
multiple CAD objects, which are then optimized using an evolutionary approach
with vision language and reasoning language models. We assess our method using
GPT-4V and GPT-4o, evaluating it on the CADPrompt benchmark dataset and
comparing it to prior methods. Additionally, we introduce two new metrics based
on topological properties defined by the Euler characteristic, which capture a
form of semantic similarity between 3D objects. Our results demonstrate that
EvoCAD outperforms previous approaches on multiple metrics, particularly in
generating topologically correct objects, which can be efficiently evaluated
using our two novel metrics that complement existing spatial metrics.

AI.tldr: EvoCAD combines large language models with evolutionary search to generate CAD objects from symbolic representations, achieving superior topological correctness on CADPrompt using Euler-characteristic-based metrics.
AI.motivation: To leverage the generative and reasoning strengths of LLMs and vision-language models alongside evolutionary optimization to produce CAD objects that are not only visually plausible but also topologically correct.
AI.method: Sample multiple CAD objects and optimize them via an evolutionary algorithm guided by vision-language and reasoning LLMs (GPT-4V / GPT-4o). Evaluate on the CADPrompt benchmark and introduce two new topology-based metrics derived from Euler characteristics to measure semantic similarity between 3D objects.
AI.result: EvoCAD outperforms prior methods on multiple metrics, with a notable improvement in generating topologically correct objects. The two Euler-characteristic-based metrics complement existing spatial metrics in evaluating CAD objects.
AI.conclusion: The integration of LLMs with evolutionary optimization is effective for CAD generation from symbolic representations, and the proposed Euler-characteristic metrics provide meaningful, topology-aware evaluation of 3D objects.

title: Reconstructing 12-Lead ECG from 3-Lead ECG using Variational Autoencoder to Improve Cardiac Disease Detection of Wearable ECG Devices
comment: 24 pages, 5 figures, submitted to Nature Communications
summary:
Twelve-lead electrocardiograms (ECGs) are the clinical gold standard for
cardiac diagnosis, providing comprehensive spatial coverage of the heart
necessary to detect conditions such as myocardial infarction (MI). However,
their lack of portability limits continuous and large-scale use. Three-lead ECG
systems are widely used in wearable devices due to their simplicity and
mobility, but they often fail to capture pathologies in unmeasured regions. To
address this, we propose WearECG, a Variational Autoencoder (VAE) method that
reconstructs twelve-lead ECGs from three leads: II, V1, and V5. Our model
includes architectural improvements to better capture temporal and spatial
dependencies in ECG signals. We evaluate generation quality using MSE, MAE, and
Frechet Inception Distance (FID), and assess clinical validity via a Turing
test with expert cardiologists. To further validate diagnostic utility, we
fine-tune ECGFounder, a large-scale pretrained ECG model, on a multi-label
classification task involving over 40 cardiac conditions, including six
different myocardial infarction locations, using both real and generated
signals. Experiments on the MIMIC dataset show that our method produces
physiologically realistic and diagnostically informative signals, with robust
performance in downstream tasks. This work demonstrates the potential of
generative modeling for ECG reconstruction and its implications for scalable,
low-cost cardiac screening.

AI.tldr: WearECG uses a VAE to reconstruct twelve-lead ECGs from three leads (II, V1, V5); evaluates with MSE/MAE/FID and a cardiologist Turing test; further validates diagnostic utility by fine-tuning a pretrained ECG model (ECGFounder) on a 40+ condition multi-label task with real and synthetic signals; demonstrated on MIMIC data, showing potential for scalable, low-cost cardiac screening.
AI.motivation: 12-lead ECGs are the clinical gold standard but lack portability, while three-lead wearables are limited in capturing pathologies in unmeasured regions; there is a need to enable portable, scalable cardiac screening by reconstructing full 12-lead data from partial measurements.
AI.method: Variational Autoencoder with architectural improvements to capture temporal and spatial ECG dependencies; reconstruct 12-lead ECGs from three leads II, V1, V5; evaluate generation quality with MSE, MAE, and Frechet Inception Distance (FID); assess clinical validity via a Turing test with expert cardiologists; fine-tune ECGFounder, a large-scale pretrained ECG model, on a multi-label classification task involving over 40 cardiac conditions (including six MI locations) using both real and generated signals; validation on MIMIC dataset.
AI.result: The method yields physiologically realistic and diagnostically informative signals, with robust performance in downstream tasks; demonstrates potential for scalable, low-cost cardiac screening.
AI.conclusion: Generative modeling can enable accurate reconstruction of 12-lead ECGs from limited-lead data, supporting scalable and accessible cardiac screening and diagnosis.

title: NV3D: Leveraging Spatial Shape Through Normal Vector-based 3D Object Detection
summary:
Recent studies in 3D object detection for autonomous vehicles aim to enrich
features through the utilization of multi-modal setups or the extraction of
local patterns within LiDAR point clouds. However, multi-modal methods face
significant challenges in feature alignment, and gaining features locally can
be oversimplified for complex 3D object detection tasks. In this paper, we
propose a novel model, NV3D, which utilizes local features acquired from voxel
neighbors, as normal vectors computed per voxel basis using K-nearest neighbors
(KNN) and principal component analysis (PCA). This informative feature enables
NV3D to determine the relationship between the surface and pertinent target
entities, including cars, pedestrians, or cyclists. During the normal vector
extraction process, NV3D offers two distinct sampling strategies: normal vector
density-based sampling and FOV-aware bin-based sampling, allowing elimination
of up to 55% of data while maintaining performance. In addition, we applied
element-wise attention fusion, which accepts voxel features as the query and
value and normal vector features as the key, similar to the attention
mechanism. Our method is trained on the KITTI dataset and has demonstrated
superior performance in car and cyclist detection owing to their spatial
shapes. In the validation set, NV3D without sampling achieves 86.60% and 80.18%
mean Average Precision (mAP), greater than the baseline Voxel R-CNN by 2.61%
and 4.23% mAP, respectively. With both samplings, NV3D achieves 85.54% mAP in
car detection, exceeding the baseline by 1.56% mAP, despite roughly 55% of
voxels being filtered out.

AI.tldr: NV3D introduces per-voxel normal-vector features derived from local voxel neighborhoods (via KNN+PCA) to enrich 3D features for detection, with two sampling strategies to prune data (Density-based and FOV-aware bin-based). It uses element-wise attention fusion and achieves higher KITTI mAP than Voxel R-CNN, especially for cars and cyclists, even with ~55% voxel reduction.
AI.motivation: Current multi-modal and local-pattern approaches struggle with feature alignment and oversimplified local feature extraction for complex 3D object detection. There is a need for robust, local geometric cues that relate surface orientations to target objects (cars, pedestrians, cyclists) using LiDAR alone.
AI.method: Compute per-voxel normal vectors from voxel neighborhoods using KNN and PCA. Use two sampling strategies: (1) normal vector density-based sampling and (2) FOV-aware bin-based sampling to reduce data (up to ~55%). Apply element-wise attention fusion with voxel features as query/value and normal-vector features as key. Train and evaluate on the KITTI dataset for car and cyclist detection.
AI.result: NV3D without sampling achieves 86.60% and 80.18% mAP (car and cyclist) over baseline Voxel R-CNN by +2.61% and +4.23%. With both sampling methods, NV3D achieves 85.54% mAP for car detection, exceeding baseline by +1.56%, despite roughly 55% voxel filtering. Demonstrates improvements in detecting spatially shaped objects (cars, cyclists) by leveraging local normal cues and feature fusion.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating locally derived normal-vector features via KNN+PCA and pairing them with attention-based fusion yields improved 3D object detection on KITTI, with data-efficiency through intelligent sampling. Particularly beneficial for cars and cyclists due to their geometry.

title: Iterative Amortized Inference: Unifying In-Context Learning and Learned Optimizers
summary:
Modern learning systems increasingly rely on amortized learning - the idea of
reusing computation or inductive biases shared across tasks to enable rapid
generalization to novel problems. This principle spans a range of approaches,
including meta-learning, in-context learning, prompt tuning, learned optimizers
and more. While motivated by similar goals, these approaches differ in how they
encode and leverage task-specific information, often provided as in-context
examples. In this work, we propose a unified framework which describes how such
methods differ primarily in the aspects of learning they amortize - such as
initializations, learned updates, or predictive mappings - and how they
incorporate task data at inference. We introduce a taxonomy that categorizes
amortized models into parametric, implicit, and explicit regimes, based on
whether task adaptation is externalized, internalized, or jointly modeled.
Building on this view, we identify a key limitation in current approaches: most
methods struggle to scale to large datasets because their capacity to process
task data at inference (e.g., context length) is often limited. To address
this, we propose iterative amortized inference, a class of models that refine
solutions step-by-step over mini-batches, drawing inspiration from stochastic
optimization. Our formulation bridges optimization-based meta-learning with
forward-pass amortization in models like LLMs, offering a scalable and
extensible foundation for general-purpose task adaptation.

AI.tldr: A unified framework for amortized learning across tasks, introducing a taxonomy that classifies methods into parametric, implicit, and explicit regimes, and proposing iterative amortized inference to scale learning to large datasets by refining solutions over mini-batches, bridging optimization-based meta-learning with forward-pass amortization in large language models.
AI.motivation: To unify diverse amortized learning approaches (meta-learning, in-context learning, prompt tuning, learned optimizers, etc.) under a single lens and address scalability bottlenecks caused by limited task-data processing at inference.
AI.method: Present a taxonomy separating methods based on how task adaptation is externalized/internalized/jointly modeled (parametric, implicit, explicit). Identify a key scalability limitation of current approaches. Propose iterative amortized inference that refines solutions step-by-step over mini-batches, inspired by stochastic optimization, connecting optimization-based meta-learning with forward-pass amortization in models like LLMs.
AI.result: Provides a conceptual framework and a scalable inference approach. Bridges optimization-based meta-learning with forward-pass amortization, offering a scalable foundation for general-purpose task adaptation (work remains to be instantiated empirically in the abstract).
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework yields a scalable, extensible foundation for general-purpose task adaptation and highlights iterative amortized inference as a key path to scale to large datasets.

title: IVEBench: Modern Benchmark Suite for Instruction-Guided Video Editing Assessment
comment:
Equal contributions from first two authors. Project page:
  https://ryanchenyn.github.io/projects/IVEBench Code:
  https://github.com/RyanChenYN/IVEBench Dataset:
  https://huggingface.co/datasets/Coraxor/IVEBench
summary:
Instruction-guided video editing has emerged as a rapidly advancing research
direction, offering new opportunities for intuitive content transformation
while also posing significant challenges for systematic evaluation. Existing
video editing benchmarks fail to support the evaluation of instruction-guided
video editing adequately and further suffer from limited source diversity,
narrow task coverage and incomplete evaluation metrics. To address the above
limitations, we introduce IVEBench, a modern benchmark suite specifically
designed for instruction-guided video editing assessment. IVEBench comprises a
diverse database of 600 high-quality source videos, spanning seven semantic
dimensions, and covering video lengths ranging from 32 to 1,024 frames. It
further includes 8 categories of editing tasks with 35 subcategories, whose
prompts are generated and refined through large language models and expert
review. Crucially, IVEBench establishes a three-dimensional evaluation protocol
encompassing video quality, instruction compliance and video fidelity,
integrating both traditional metrics and multimodal large language model-based
assessments. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of IVEBench in
benchmarking state-of-the-art instruction-guided video editing methods, showing
its ability to provide comprehensive and human-aligned evaluation outcomes.

AI.tldr: A new benchmark IVEBench for instruction-guided video editing with 600 source videos, 7 semantic dimensions, lengths 32–1024 frames, 8 editing categories with 35 subcategories; tri-dimensional evaluation (video quality, instruction compliance, video fidelity) using traditional metrics and multimodal LLM-based assessments; demonstrates effectiveness for evaluating SOTA methods.
AI.motivation: Existing benchmarks inadequately support instruction-guided video editing, lacking source diversity, task coverage, and comprehensive evaluation metrics; need a standardized, human-aligned benchmark.
AI.method: Assemble IVEBench: 600 high-quality source videos across seven semantic dimensions; capture lengths 32–1024 frames; define 8 editing categories with 35 subcategories; generate/refine prompts via large language models and expert review; establish a three-dimensional evaluation protocol combining traditional metrics and multimodal LLM-based assessments.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show IVEBench effectively benchmarks state-of-the-art instruction-guided video editing methods and yields comprehensive, human-aligned evaluation outcomes.
AI.conclusion: IVEBench addresses evaluation gaps in instruction-guided video editing and provides a robust, diverse, multimodal benchmark to accelerate progress in the field.

title: Differentiable Fast Top-K Selection for Large-Scale Recommendation
summary:
Cascade ranking is a widely adopted paradigm in large-scale information
retrieval systems for Top-K item selection. However, the Top-K operator is
non-differentiable, hindering end-to-end training. Existing methods include
Learning-to-Rank approaches (e.g., LambdaLoss), which optimize ranking metrics
like NDCG and suffer from objective misalignment, and differentiable
sorting-based methods (e.g., ARF, LCRON), which relax permutation matrices for
direct Top-K optimization but introduce gradient conflicts through matrix
aggregation. A promising alternative is to directly construct a differentiable
approximation of the Top-K selection operator, bypassing the use of soft
permutation matrices. However, even state-of-the-art differentiable Top-K
operator (e.g., LapSum) require $O(n \log n)$ complexity due to their
dependence on sorting for solving the threshold. Thus, we propose DFTopK, a
novel differentiable Top-K operator achieving optimal $O(n)$ time complexity.
By relaxing normalization constraints, DFTopK admits a closed-form solution and
avoids sorting. DFTopK also avoids the gradient conflicts inherent in
differentiable sorting-based methods. We evaluate DFTopK on both the public
benchmark RecFLow and an industrial system. Experimental results show that
DFTopK significantly improves training efficiency while achieving superior
performance, which enables us to scale up training samples more efficiently. In
the online A/B test, DFTopK yielded a +1.77\% revenue lift with the same
computational budget compared to the baseline. To the best of our knowledge,
this work is the first to introduce differentiable Top-K operators into
recommendation systems and the first to achieve theoretically optimal
linear-time complexity for Top-K selection. We have open-sourced our
implementation to facilitate future research in both academia and industry.

AI.tldr: A differentiable Top-K operator DFTopK achieves linear-time complexity O(n), avoiding sorting and gradient conflicts, enabling efficient end-to-end training in cascaded ranking; shows revenue lift in online tests and is open-sourced.
AI.motivation: Top-K is non-differentiable in cascade ranking, causing training inefficiencies and misalignment with objectives; existing differentiable sorting methods introduce gradient conflicts and are slower; a differentiable, fast Top-K operator is needed for scalable recommender systems.
AI.method: Introduce DFTopK by relaxing normalization constraints to obtain a closed-form differentiable Top-K solution with linear-time complexity, avoiding sorting and the gradient conflicts seen in differentiable sorting-based methods.
AI.result: Experiments show improved training efficiency and superior performance on the public RecFLow benchmark and an industrial system; online A/B yields a +1.77% revenue lift under the same computational budget; implementation is open-sourced.
AI.conclusion: First to introduce differentiable Top-K operators into recommender systems and to achieve theoretically optimal linear-time Top-K selection; DFTopK reduces gradient conflicts and enables scalable end-to-end training.

title: PhySIC: Physically Plausible 3D Human-Scene Interaction and Contact from a Single Image
comment:
Accepted to ACM SIGGraphAsia 2025. Project website:
  https://yuxuan-xue.com/physic
summary:
Reconstructing metrically accurate humans and their surrounding scenes from a
single image is crucial for virtual reality, robotics, and comprehensive 3D
scene understanding. However, existing methods struggle with depth ambiguity,
occlusions, and physically inconsistent contacts. To address these challenges,
we introduce PhySIC, a framework for physically plausible Human-Scene
Interaction and Contact reconstruction. PhySIC recovers metrically consistent
SMPL-X human meshes, dense scene surfaces, and vertex-level contact maps within
a shared coordinate frame from a single RGB image. Starting from coarse
monocular depth and body estimates, PhySIC performs occlusion-aware inpainting,
fuses visible depth with unscaled geometry for a robust metric scaffold, and
synthesizes missing support surfaces like floors. A confidence-weighted
optimization refines body pose, camera parameters, and global scale by jointly
enforcing depth alignment, contact priors, interpenetration avoidance, and 2D
reprojection consistency. Explicit occlusion masking safeguards invisible
regions against implausible configurations. PhySIC is efficient, requiring only
9 seconds for joint human-scene optimization and under 27 seconds end-to-end.
It naturally handles multiple humans, enabling reconstruction of diverse
interactions. Empirically, PhySIC outperforms single-image baselines, reducing
mean per-vertex scene error from 641 mm to 227 mm, halving PA-MPJPE to 42 mm,
and improving contact F1 from 0.09 to 0.51. Qualitative results show realistic
foot-floor interactions, natural seating, and plausible reconstructions of
heavily occluded furniture. By converting a single image into a physically
plausible 3D human-scene pair, PhySIC advances scalable 3D scene understanding.
Our implementation is publicly available at https://yuxuan-xue.com/physic.

AI.tldr: PhySIC: a single-image framework that reconstructs metrically accurate humans, dense scene surfaces, and vertex-level contact maps in a shared frame, with occlusion-aware inpainting and physics-guided optimization; achieves plausible multi-human interactions in seconds and significantly improves scene accuracy, pose error, and contact detection over baselines.
AI.motivation: Reconstructing accurate human-scale geometry and their interactions with the surrounding scene from a single RGB image is essential for virtual reality, robotics, and 3D scene understanding, but faces depth ambiguity, occlusions, and physically inconsistent contacts.
AI.method: Start from coarse monocular depth and body estimates, apply occlusion-aware inpainting, fuse visible depth with an unscaled geometry to build a metric scaffold, and synthesize missing support surfaces (e.g., floors). Use a confidence-weighted optimization to refine body pose, camera parameters, and global scale by jointly enforcing depth alignment, contact priors, interpenetration avoidance, and 2D reprojection consistency, with explicit occlusion masking. Enables multi-human scenarios and reports ~9 s for joint optimization and <27 s end-to-end.
AI.result: Outperforms single-image baselines: reduces mean per-vertex scene error from 641 mm to 227 mm, halves PA-MPJPE to 42 mm, and increases contact F1 from 0.09 to 0.51. Qualitative results show realistic foot-floor interaction, seating, and reconstruction of heavily occluded furniture.
AI.conclusion: PhySIC converts a single image into a physically plausible 3D human–scene pair, advancing scalable 3D scene understanding and enabling realistic human-scene interaction reconstructions from monocular images.

title: Rescaling-Aware Training for Efficient Deployment of Deep Learning Models on Full-Integer Hardware
comment: Submitted to IEEE Embedded Systems Letters
summary:
Integer AI inference significantly reduces computational complexity in
embedded systems. Quantization-aware training (QAT) helps mitigate accuracy
degradation associated with post-training quantization but still overlooks the
impact of integer rescaling during inference, which is a hardware costly
operation in integer-only AI inference. This work shows that rescaling cost can
be dramatically reduced post-training, by applying a stronger quantization to
the rescale multiplicands at no model-quality loss. Furthermore, we introduce
Rescale-Aware Training, a fine tuning method for ultra-low bit-width rescaling
multiplicands. Experiments show that even with 8x reduced rescaler widths, the
full accuracy is preserved through minimal incremental retraining. This enables
more energy-efficient and cost-efficient AI inference for resource-constrained
embedded systems.

AI.tldr: Rescale-Aware Training enables ultra-low-bit rescale multiplicands with negligible model quality loss, greatly reducing hardware rescaling cost in integer AI inference and enabling energy-efficient embedded deployment.
AI.motivation: Integer rescaling in inference is a hardware bottleneck in integer-only AI; quantization-aware training (QAT) does not address the rescale cost; need hardware-aware quantization to reduce energy and latency without sacrificing accuracy.
AI.method: Quantize rescale multiplicands more aggressively post-training and introduce Rescale-Aware Training to fine-tune ultra-low-bit-width rescale factors; evaluate with experiments showing preserved accuracy with 8x reduced widths.
AI.result: Full accuracy preserved with minimal incremental retraining despite 8x narrower rescale multiplicands; reduced rescaling hardware cost; improved energy efficiency in embedded inference.
AI.conclusion: Rescale-Aware Training enables cost- and energy-efficient integer AI inference on resource-constrained devices; demonstrates that rescale operations can be quantized aggressively without harming performance; broad implications for hardware-aware quantization research.

title: InfiniHuman: Infinite 3D Human Creation with Precise Control
comment:
Accepted to ACM SIGGRAPH Asia 2025. Project website:
  https://yuxuan-xue.com/infini-human
summary:
Generating realistic and controllable 3D human avatars is a long-standing
challenge, particularly when covering broad attribute ranges such as ethnicity,
age, clothing styles, and detailed body shapes. Capturing and annotating
large-scale human datasets for training generative models is prohibitively
expensive and limited in scale and diversity. The central question we address
in this paper is: Can existing foundation models be distilled to generate
theoretically unbounded, richly annotated 3D human data? We introduce
InfiniHuman, a framework that synergistically distills these models to produce
richly annotated human data at minimal cost and with theoretically unlimited
scalability. We propose InfiniHumanData, a fully automatic pipeline that
leverages vision-language and image generation models to create a large-scale
multi-modal dataset. User study shows our automatically generated identities
are undistinguishable from scan renderings. InfiniHumanData contains 111K
identities spanning unprecedented diversity. Each identity is annotated with
multi-granularity text descriptions, multi-view RGB images, detailed clothing
images, and SMPL body-shape parameters. Building on this dataset, we propose
InfiniHumanGen, a diffusion-based generative pipeline conditioned on text, body
shape, and clothing assets. InfiniHumanGen enables fast, realistic, and
precisely controllable avatar generation. Extensive experiments demonstrate
significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods in visual quality,
generation speed, and controllability. Our approach enables high-quality avatar
generation with fine-grained control at effectively unbounded scale through a
practical and affordable solution. We will publicly release the automatic data
generation pipeline, the comprehensive InfiniHumanData dataset, and the
InfiniHumanGen models at https://yuxuan-xue.com/infini-human.

AI.tldr: InfiniHuman distills foundation models to generate unlimited, richly annotated 3D human data and a diffusion-based avatar generator for controllable avatars, enabling scalable, low-cost high-quality generation.
AI.motivation: Tackle data scarcity and expensive annotation in 3D human avatar creation; enable broad diversity (ethnicity, age, clothing, body shapes) through foundation-model distillation.
AI.method: Introduce InfiniHuman: InfiniHumanData automatically constructs a large multi-modal dataset (111K identities) via vision-language and image-generation models with multi-granularity text, multi-view RGB, detailed clothing, and SMPL shapes; InfiniHumanGen a diffusion-based generator conditioned on text, body shape, and clothing assets for controllable avatar creation.
AI.result: User study reports generated identities indistinguishable from scan renderings; dataset spans unprecedented diversity; reported improvements over state-of-the-art in visual quality, speed, and controllability; plan to publicly release data pipeline, dataset, and models.
AI.conclusion: InfiniHuman enables high-quality avatar generation with fine-grained control at effectively unbounded scale through automatic data generation, offering a practical, affordable path to scalable 3D human data and avatars.

title: How Reinforcement Learning After Next-Token Prediction Facilitates Learning
summary:
Recent advances in reasoning domains with neural networks have primarily been
enabled by a training recipe that optimizes Large Language Models, previously
trained to predict the next-token in a sequence, with reinforcement learning
algorithms. We introduce a framework to study the success of this paradigm, and
we theoretically expose the optimization mechanisms by which reinforcement
learning improves over next-token prediction in this setting. We study learning
from mixture distributions of short and long ``chain-of-thought'' sequences
encoding a single task. In particular, when the task consists of predicting the
parity of $d$ bits and long sequences are rare, we show how reinforcement
learning after next-token prediction enables autoregressive transformers to
generalize, whereas mere next-token prediction requires extreme statistical or
computational resources to do so. We further explain how reinforcement learning
leverages increased test-time computation, manifested in longer responses, to
facilitate this learning process. In a simplified setting, we theoretically
prove that autoregressive linear models following this training recipe can
efficiently learn to predict the parity of $d$ bits as long as the proportion
of long demonstrations in the data mix is not exponentially small in the input
dimension $d$. Finally, we demonstrate these same phenomena in other settings,
including the post-training of Llama-series models on mixture variations of
common mathematical reasoning benchmarks.

AI.tldr: RL after next-token training enables generalization on chain-of-thought parity tasks when long sequences are scarce; pure next-token struggles without abundant long demonstrations; results extend to Llama fine-tuning on math reasoning benchmarks.
AI.motivation: To theoretically analyze why reinforcement learning after pretraining improves performance over pure next-token prediction in autoregressive transformers, especially under mixture distributions of short and long chain-of-thought sequences and with longer test-time computation.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis of mixture distributions of short/long chain-of-thought sequences for a parity task, deriving conditions under which RL improves generalization; examination of autoregressive linear models under this training recipe; empirical validation via post-training of Llama-series models on math reasoning benchmarks.
AI.result: RL after next-token prediction enables generalization with rare long demonstrations, whereas pure next-token prediction requires large resources; longer test-time responses aid learning; in simplified models, efficient parity learning is possible when the fraction of long demonstrations is not exponentially small; observed in Llama-series post-training on mathematical reasoning benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: The RL-after-NTP training recipe helps overcome limitations of next-token-only training for iterative reasoning tasks under data constraints; provides theoretical and empirical support, suggesting practical guidelines on data mix and computation budget for reasoning benchmarks.

title: FACE: Faithful Automatic Concept Extraction
comment:
39th Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS
  2025)
summary:
Interpreting deep neural networks through concept-based explanations offers a
bridge between low-level features and high-level human-understandable
semantics. However, existing automatic concept discovery methods often fail to
align these extracted concepts with the model's true decision-making process,
thereby compromising explanation faithfulness. In this work, we propose FACE
(Faithful Automatic Concept Extraction), a novel framework that augments
Non-negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) with a Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence
regularization term to ensure alignment between the model's original and
concept-based predictions. Unlike prior methods that operate solely on encoder
activations, FACE incorporates classifier supervision during concept learning,
enforcing predictive consistency and enabling faithful explanations. We provide
theoretical guarantees showing that minimizing the KL divergence bounds the
deviation in predictive distributions, thereby promoting faithful local
linearity in the learned concept space. Systematic evaluations on ImageNet,
COCO, and CelebA datasets demonstrate that FACE outperforms existing methods
across faithfulness and sparsity metrics.

AI.tldr: FACE proposes Faithful Automatic Concept Extraction by augmenting NMF with KL-divergence regularization and classifier supervision to align concept-based explanations with the model's decisions, yielding faithful, sparse concepts with local linearity guarantees and improved faithfulness over prior methods on ImageNet, COCO, and CelebA.
AI.motivation: Existing automatic concept discovery methods struggle to align extracted concepts with the model's true decision-making process, leading to less faithful explanations. There is a need for concept discovery that ensures predictive fidelity to the original model.
AI.method: Augment Non-negative Matrix Factorization with a KL-divergence regularization term to align concept-based predictions with the model's predictions. Incorporate classifier supervision during concept learning to enforce predictive consistency. Provide theoretical guarantees that minimizing KL divergence bounds deviation in predictive distributions, promoting faithful local linearity in the concept space.
AI.result: Empirical results on ImageNet, COCO, and CelebA show FACE outperforms existing methods in faithfulness and sparsity metrics. The approach yields more faithful explanations and sparser concept representations, supported by theoretical guarantees.
AI.conclusion: FACE offers a principled framework for faithful concept discovery by tying concept learning directly to the model's predictive behavior, enabling more faithful and interpretable explanations across large-scale datasets.

title: ReLook: Vision-Grounded RL with a Multimodal LLM Critic for Agentic Web Coding
summary:
While Large Language Models (LLMs) excel at algorithmic code generation, they
struggle with front-end development, where correctness is judged on rendered
pixels and interaction. We present ReLook, an agentic, vision-grounded
reinforcement learning framework that empowers an agent to close a robust
generate--diagnose--refine loop by invoking a multimodal LLM (MLLM) as a tool.
During training, the agent uses the MLLM-in-the-loop both as a visual
critic--scoring code with screenshots--and as a source of actionable,
vision-grounded feedback; a strict zero-reward rule for invalid renders anchors
renderability and prevents reward hacking. To prevent behavioral collapse, we
introduce Forced Optimization, a strict acceptance rule that admits only
improving revisions, yielding monotonically better trajectories. At inference,
we decouple the critic and run a lightweight, critic-free self-edit cycle,
keeping latency comparable to base decoding while retaining most of the gains.
Across three widely used benchmarks, ReLook consistently outperforms strong
baselines in vision-grounded front-end code generation, highlighting the
benefits of agentic perception, visual rewards, and training-inference
decoupling.

AI.tldr: ReLook introduces a vision-grounded, agentic RL loop that uses a multimodal LLM as a visual critic and tool, plus a Forced Optimization rule to guarantee monotonic improvements; at inference, it decouples the critic to maintain latency, achieving strong gains in vision-grounded front-end code generation across three benchmarks.
AI.motivation: LLMs perform well at algorithmic coding but struggle with front-end rendering correctness, which is judged pixel-by-pixel. There is a need for vision-grounded feedback, robust training routines, and mechanisms to avoid reward hacking and collapse in generation–diagnosis–refinement loops.
AI.method: An agent iteratively generates front-end code and uses a multimodal LLM in the loop as a visual critic and source of actionable feedback. A zero-reward rule for invalid renders anchors renderability. Forced Optimization restricts updates to improving revisions, ensuring monotonically better trajectories. During inference, the critic is decoupled, and a lightweight self-edit cycle runs without the critic to preserve latency.
AI.result: Across three standard benchmarks, ReLook consistently outperforms strong vision-grounded baselines on front-end code generation, demonstrating the benefits of agentic perception, visual rewards, and training–inference decoupling.
AI.conclusion: Vision-grounded, agentic feedback loops with a decoupled inference phase can substantially improve front-end code generation, offering robust renderability guarantees and competitive latency.

title: Beyond 'Templates': Category-Agnostic Object Pose, Size, and Shape Estimation from a Single View
summary:
Estimating an object's 6D pose, size, and shape from visual input is a
fundamental problem in computer vision, with critical applications in robotic
grasping and manipulation. Existing methods either rely on object-specific
priors such as CAD models or templates, or suffer from limited generalization
across categories due to pose-shape entanglement and multi-stage pipelines. In
this work, we propose a unified, category-agnostic framework that
simultaneously predicts 6D pose, size, and dense shape from a single RGB-D
image, without requiring templates, CAD models, or category labels at test
time. Our model fuses dense 2D features from vision foundation models with
partial 3D point clouds using a Transformer encoder enhanced by a
Mixture-of-Experts, and employs parallel decoders for pose-size estimation and
shape reconstruction, achieving real-time inference at 28 FPS. Trained solely
on synthetic data from 149 categories in the SOPE dataset, our framework is
evaluated on four diverse benchmarks SOPE, ROPE, ObjaversePose, and HANDAL,
spanning over 300 categories. It achieves state-of-the-art accuracy on seen
categories while demonstrating remarkably strong zero-shot generalization to
unseen real-world objects, establishing a new standard for open-set 6D
understanding in robotics and embodied AI.

AI.tldr: A unified, category-agnostic method estimates 6D pose, size, and dense shape from a single RGB-D image without templates, achieving real-time performance and strong zero-shot generalization across 300+ categories.
AI.motivation: To overcome reliance on object-specific priors (CAD/models) and limited cross-category generalization caused by pose-shape entanglement and multi-stage pipelines, enabling open-set 6D understanding for robotics.
AI.method: Fuse dense 2D features from vision foundation models with partial 3D point clouds using a Transformer encoder enhanced by a Mixture-of-Experts. Use parallel decoders for pose-size estimation and dense shape reconstruction. Train solely on synthetic data (149 categories from the SOPE dataset).
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art accuracy on seen categories and strong zero-shot generalization to unseen real-world objects across four benchmarks (SOPE, ROPE, ObjaversePose, HANDAL), at 28 FPS.
AI.conclusion: Presents a new standard for open-set 6D understanding in robotics and embodied AI with a category-agnostic, end-to-end framework that does not rely on templates or category labels at test time.

title: Offline Reinforcement Learning with Generative Trajectory Policies
summary:
Generative models have emerged as a powerful class of policies for offline
reinforcement learning (RL) due to their ability to capture complex,
multi-modal behaviors. However, existing methods face a stark trade-off: slow,
iterative models like diffusion policies are computationally expensive, while
fast, single-step models like consistency policies often suffer from degraded
performance. In this paper, we demonstrate that it is possible to bridge this
gap. The key to moving beyond the limitations of individual methods, we argue,
lies in a unifying perspective that views modern generative models, including
diffusion, flow matching, and consistency models, as specific instances of
learning a continuous-time generative trajectory governed by an Ordinary
Differential Equation (ODE). This principled foundation provides a clearer
design space for generative policies in RL and allows us to propose Generative
Trajectory Policies (GTPs), a new and more general policy paradigm that learns
the entire solution map of the underlying ODE. To make this paradigm practical
for offline RL, we further introduce two key theoretically principled
adaptations. Empirical results demonstrate that GTP achieves state-of-the-art
performance on D4RL benchmarks - it significantly outperforms prior generative
policies, achieving perfect scores on several notoriously hard AntMaze tasks.

AI.tldr: A unifying ODE-based view of generative policies leads to Generative Trajectory Policies (GTPs), delivering fast, high-performance offline RL, achieving state-of-the-art on D4RL and perfect scores on several AntMaze tasks.
AI.motivation: Current generative policies suffer from a speed–performance trade-off: slow diffusion-based methods and fast but less capable single-step policies. A unifying continuous-time trajectory perspective promises better design and performance.
AI.method: Reframe diffusion, flow matching, and consistency models as learning a continuous-time ODE trajectory; propose Generative Trajectory Policies that learn the entire solution map of the ODE; introduce two theoretically principled adaptations to make GTPs practical for offline RL.
AI.result: State-of-the-art performance on D4RL; outperforms prior generative policies; achieves perfect scores on several hard AntMaze tasks.
AI.conclusion: The ODE-trajectory viewpoint clarifies the design space and enables a general, practical generative-policy paradigm for offline RL via GTPs.

title: Diffusion Transformers with Representation Autoencoders
summary:
Latent generative modeling, where a pretrained autoencoder maps pixels into a
latent space for the diffusion process, has become the standard strategy for
Diffusion Transformers (DiT); however, the autoencoder component has barely
evolved. Most DiTs continue to rely on the original VAE encoder, which
introduces several limitations: outdated backbones that compromise
architectural simplicity, low-dimensional latent spaces that restrict
information capacity, and weak representations that result from purely
reconstruction-based training and ultimately limit generative quality. In this
work, we explore replacing the VAE with pretrained representation encoders
(e.g., DINO, SigLIP, MAE) paired with trained decoders, forming what we term
Representation Autoencoders (RAEs). These models provide both high-quality
reconstructions and semantically rich latent spaces, while allowing for a
scalable transformer-based architecture. Since these latent spaces are
typically high-dimensional, a key challenge is enabling diffusion transformers
to operate effectively within them. We analyze the sources of this difficulty,
propose theoretically motivated solutions, and validate them empirically. Our
approach achieves faster convergence without auxiliary representation alignment
losses. Using a DiT variant equipped with a lightweight, wide DDT head, we
achieve strong image generation results on ImageNet: 1.51 FID at 256x256 (no
guidance) and 1.13 at both 256x256 and 512x512 (with guidance). RAE offers
clear advantages and should be the new default for diffusion transformer
training.

AI.tldr: Repalces VAE encoders in diffusion transformers with Representation Autoencoders (RAEs) built from pretrained representation encoders and trained decoders, yielding high-dimensional, semantically rich latent spaces and faster convergence; achieves strong ImageNet results.
AI.motivation: VAE-based encoders in Diffusion Transformers (DiT) are outdated and constrain performance: limited backbones, low latent dimensionality, and weak, reconstruction-focused representations that cap generation quality. A more semantically rich, scalable latent space is needed.
AI.method: Replace the VAE encoder with pretrained representation encoders (e.g., DINO, SigLIP, MAE) paired with trainable decoders to form Representation Autoencoders (RAEs); address high-dimensional latent spaces to enable diffusion transformers to operate effectively; provide theoretically motivated solutions to diffusion in high-dim latent spaces; avoid auxiliary alignment losses; deploy DiT with a lightweight, wide DDT head.
AI.result: RAEs enable faster convergence and strong ImageNet generation: 1.51 FID at 256x256 without guidance and 1.13 FID at 256x256 and 512x512 with guidance; improved reconstructions and semantically rich latent spaces; advantages suggest RAEs should be the default for diffusion transformer training.
AI.conclusion: RAEs offer clear advantages over traditional VAE-based latent encoders and should become the default latent modeling strategy for diffusion transformers.

title: Bayesian Topological Convolutional Neural Nets
summary:
Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have been established as the main
workhorse in image data processing; nonetheless, they require large amounts of
data to train, often produce overconfident predictions, and frequently lack the
ability to quantify the uncertainty of their predictions. To address these
concerns, we propose a new Bayesian topological CNN that promotes a novel
interplay between topology-aware learning and Bayesian sampling. Specifically,
it utilizes information from important manifolds to accelerate training while
reducing calibration error by placing prior distributions on network parameters
and properly learning appropriate posteriors. One important contribution of our
work is the inclusion of a consistency condition in the learning cost, which
can effectively modify the prior distributions to improve the performance of
our novel network architecture. We evaluate the model on benchmark image
classification datasets and demonstrate its superiority over conventional CNNs,
Bayesian neural networks (BNNs), and topological CNNs. In particular, we supply
evidence that our method provides an advantage in situations where training
data is limited or corrupted. Furthermore, we show that the new model allows
for better uncertainty quantification than standard BNNs since it can more
readily identify examples of out-of-distribution data on which it has not been
trained. Our results highlight the potential of our novel hybrid approach for
more efficient and robust image classification.

AI.tldr: A Bayesian topological CNN combining topology-aware learning with Bayesian sampling to improve data efficiency, calibration, and uncertainty quantification, especially with limited/corrupted data and for OOD detection.
AI.motivation: CNNs require large datasets and often produce overconfident predictions with poor uncertainty estimates. Integrating topology-aware learning with Bayesian inference aims to enhance data efficiency, calibration, and reliable uncertainty quantification.
AI.method: Introduce a topology-informed learning framework that uses manifold information to accelerate training, place prior distributions on network parameters, and learn appropriate posteriors. A consistency condition in the learning cost is included to adapt priors. The model is evaluated on benchmark image classification datasets against CNNs, BNNs, and topological CNNs.
AI.result: The proposed model shows superiority over conventional CNNs, BNNs, and topological CNNs, particularly when training data are limited or corrupted. It provides better uncertainty quantification and improves out-of-distribution detection capability.
AI.conclusion: A hybrid approach that merges topology-aware learning with Bayesian inference can yield more efficient, robust image classification, with potential applicability beyond standard CNNs and better resilience to data limitations and distributional shifts.

title: Learning to Make MISTAKEs: Modeling Incorrect Student Thinking And Key Errors
summary:
Research on reasoning in language models (LMs) predominantly focuses on
improving the correctness of their outputs. But some important applications
require modeling reasoning patterns that are incorrect. For example, automated
systems that can reason about and simulate student errors are useful for
providing real-time feedback in the classroom or offline practice for
educators-in-training. This paper presents a new method, MISTAKE, that (1)
constructs high-quality synthetic examples of reasoning errors by leveraging
cycle consistency between incorrect answers and latent misconceptions; and (2)
uses the generated data to learn models for student simulation, misconception
classification, and answer generation. We evaluate MISTAKE on three educational
tasks and find that it results in (1) higher accuracy when simulating incorrect
student answers based on specific misconceptions, (2) increased performance
inferring latent misconceptions from observed incorrect answers, and (3) higher
alignment with expert-written distractor answers when generating incorrect
answers (e.g., for multiple-choice tests).

AI.tldr: MISTAKE builds synthetic incorrect reasoning data via cycle consistency with latent misconceptions and uses it to train models for student simulation, misconception classification, and answer/distractor generation, yielding improved simulation accuracy, miscons. inference, and distractor alignment.
AI.motivation: There is a need to model incorrect reasoning patterns in LMs for educational applications such as real-time student feedback, teacher training, and practice problems, since most work targets correctness; modeling errors can support simulation and diagnosis.
AI.method: Introduce MISTAKE: (1) generate synthetic errors by leveraging cycle consistency between incorrect answers and latent misconceptions; (2) train models on this data for student simulation, misconception classification, answer generation, and distractor creation. Evaluate on three educational tasks.
AI.result: Higher accuracy in simulating incorrect answers tied to specific misconceptions; better inference of latent misconceptions from incorrect responses; better alignment with expert-written distractor answers for MC questions.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates that modeling incorrect reasoning patterns via synthetic data can enhance educational NLP tasks and support student modeling, with potential for broader impact and need for careful validation.

title: DiT360: High-Fidelity Panoramic Image Generation via Hybrid Training
summary:
In this work, we propose DiT360, a DiT-based framework that performs hybrid
training on perspective and panoramic data for panoramic image generation. For
the issues of maintaining geometric fidelity and photorealism in generation
quality, we attribute the main reason to the lack of large-scale, high-quality,
real-world panoramic data, where such a data-centric view differs from prior
methods that focus on model design. Basically, DiT360 has several key modules
for inter-domain transformation and intra-domain augmentation, applied at both
the pre-VAE image level and the post-VAE token level. At the image level, we
incorporate cross-domain knowledge through perspective image guidance and
panoramic refinement, which enhance perceptual quality while regularizing
