diversity and photorealism. At the token level, hybrid supervision is applied
across multiple modules, which include circular padding for boundary
continuity, yaw loss for rotational robustness, and cube loss for distortion
awareness. Extensive experiments on text-to-panorama, inpainting, and
outpainting tasks demonstrate that our method achieves better boundary
consistency and image fidelity across eleven quantitative metrics. Our code is
available at https://github.com/Insta360-Research-Team/DiT360.

AI.tldr: DiT360 is a DiT-based framework for hybrid training on perspective and panoramic data to improve panoramic image generation, using cross-domain guidance and token-level losses to boost boundary fidelity and realism, with strong results on text-to-panorama, inpainting, and outpainting; code released.
AI.motivation: The main bottleneck for geometric fidelity and photorealism in panoramic generation is the scarcity of large-scale real-world panoramic data; a data-centric approach is needed rather than solely focusing on model design.
AI.method: Proposes inter-domain transformation and intra-domain augmentation at pre-VAE image level and post-VAE token level. Image-level: cross-domain perspective guidance and panoramic refinement. Token-level: hybrid supervision including circular padding, yaw loss, and cube loss. Applies to text-to-panorama, inpainting, outpainting.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show improved boundary consistency and image fidelity across eleven quantitative metrics on multiple tasks; publicly available code.
AI.conclusion: DiT360 demonstrates that hybrid training with domain-aware augmentation and specialized losses yields better panoramic generation under data constraints, reinforcing a data-centric view and offering practical modules for future work.

title: Knowledge-Guided Machine Learning Models to Upscale Evapotranspiration in the U.S. Midwest
summary:
Evapotranspiration (ET) plays a critical role in the land-atmosphere
interactions, yet its accurate quantification across various spatiotemporal
scales remains a challenge. In situ measurement approaches, like eddy
covariance (EC) or weather station-based ET estimation, allow for measuring ET
at a single location. Agricultural uses of ET require estimates for each field
over broad areas, making it infeasible to deploy sensing systems at each
location. This study integrates tree-based and knowledge-guided machine
learning (ML) techniques with multispectral remote sensing data, griddled
meteorology and EC data to upscale ET across the Midwest United States. We
compare four tree-based models - Random Forest, CatBoost, XGBoost, LightGBM -
and a simple feed-forward artificial neural network in combination with
features engineered using knowledge-guided ML principles. Models were trained
and tested on EC towers located in the Midwest of the United States using
k-fold cross validation with k=5 and site-year, biome stratified train-test
split to avoid data leakage. Results show that LightGBM with knowledge-guided
features outperformed other methods with an R2=0.86, MSE=14.99 W m^-2 and MAE =
8.82 W m^-2 according to grouped k-fold validation (k=5). Feature importance
analysis shows that knowledge-guided features were most important for
predicting evapotranspiration. Using the best performing model, we provide a
data product at 500 m spatial and one-day temporal resolution for gridded ET
for the period of 2019-2024. Intercomparison between the new gridded product
and state-level weather station-based ET estimates show best-in-class
correspondence.

AI.tldr: Knowledge-guided ML with remote sensing upscales ET across the Midwest; LightGBM with knowledge features achieves best validation, delivering a 500 m daily ET product (2019–2024) with strong agreement to state ET estimates.
AI.motivation: Quantify evapotranspiration across broad areas and timescales beyond localized EC measurements; enable field-scale ET mapping for agricultural and land-atmosphere studies.
AI.method: Compared four tree-based models (Random Forest, CatBoost, XGBoost, LightGBM) and a simple feed-forward NN, all with knowledge-guided feature engineering; data from multispectral remote sensing, gridded meteorology, and EC towers; 5-fold grouped CV with site-year and biome stratification.
AI.result: LightGBM with knowledge-guided features performed best (R2=0.86, MSE=14.99 W m^-2, MAE=8.82 W m^-2). Feature importance favored knowledge-guided features. Generated 500 m daily ET product for 2019–2024; high agreement with state-level weather-station ET estimates.
AI.conclusion: Knowledge-guided features are critical for accurate ET prediction; ML-based upscaling can produce a robust gridded ET product that aligns well with traditional ET estimates.

title: Point Prompting: Counterfactual Tracking with Video Diffusion Models
summary:
Trackers and video generators solve closely related problems: the former
analyze motion, while the latter synthesize it. We show that this connection
enables pretrained video diffusion models to perform zero-shot point tracking
by simply prompting them to visually mark points as they move over time. We
place a distinctively colored marker at the query point, then regenerate the
rest of the video from an intermediate noise level. This propagates the marker
across frames, tracing the point's trajectory. To ensure that the marker
remains visible in this counterfactual generation, despite such markers being
unlikely in natural videos, we use the unedited initial frame as a negative
prompt. Through experiments with multiple image-conditioned video diffusion
models, we find that these "emergent" tracks outperform those of prior
zero-shot methods and persist through occlusions, often obtaining performance
that is competitive with specialized self-supervised models.

AI.tldr: Zero-shot point tracking can be achieved by prompting pretrained video diffusion models to visually mark moving points, propagating a colored marker across frames via counterfactual generation, and leveraging the initial frame as a negative prompt to keep the marker visible; emergent tracks outperform prior zero-shot methods and rival self-supervised trackers.
AI.motivation: Connect tracking and video generation to exploit the generative power of diffusion models for tracking tasks without additional training.
AI.method: Place a distinctive colored marker at the query point in the initial frame. Prompt the video diffusion model to regenerate the video from an intermediate noise level, causing the marker to propagate across frames and trace the trajectory. Use the unedited initial frame as a negative prompt to keep the marker visible in the counterfactual generation. Evaluate across multiple image-conditioned video diffusion models and compare to existing zero-shot and self-supervised trackers.
AI.result: Emergent tracks outperform prior zero-shot methods and persist through occlusions; in many cases the performance approaches that of specialized self-supervised trackers.
AI.conclusion: Video diffusion models can be repurposed for tracking tasks without additional training by using marker-based prompting and counterfactual generation, enabling competitive zero-shot tracking performance.

title: Query-Specific GNN: A Comprehensive Graph Representation Learning Method for Retrieval Augmented Generation
summary:
Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) has demonstrated its ability to enhance
Large Language Models (LLMs) by integrating external knowledge sources.
However, multi-hop questions, which require the identification of multiple
knowledge targets to form a synthesized answer, raise new challenges for RAG
systems. Under the multi-hop settings, existing methods often struggle to fully
understand the questions with complex semantic structures and are susceptible
to irrelevant noise during the retrieval of multiple information targets. To
address these limitations, we propose a novel graph representation learning
framework for multi-hop question retrieval. We first introduce a
Multi-information Level Knowledge Graph (Multi-L KG) to model various
information levels for a more comprehensive understanding of multi-hop
questions. Based on this, we design a Query-Specific Graph Neural Network
(QSGNN) for representation learning on the Multi-L KG. QSGNN employs
intra/inter-level message passing mechanisms, and in each message passing the
information aggregation is guided by the query, which not only facilitates
multi-granular information aggregation but also significantly reduces the
impact of noise. To enhance its ability to learn robust representations, we
further propose two synthesized data generation strategies for pre-training the
QSGNN. Extensive experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our
framework in multi-hop scenarios, especially in high-hop questions the
improvement can reach 33.8\%. The code is available at:
https://github.com/Jerry2398/QSGNN.

AI.tldr: Proposes a graph-based, query-guided approach for multi-hop question retrieval to improve retrieval in RAG, using a Multi-information Level Knowledge Graph (Multi-L KG) and a Query-Specific Graph Neural Network (QSGNN) with noise-robust training; shows strong gains, especially on high-hop questions (up to 33.8%).
AI.motivation: Multi-hop questions in retrieval-augmented generation are challenging due to complex semantics and noise from retrieving multiple information targets. Existing methods struggle to understand questions with complex structures and are susceptible to irrelevant targets.
AI.method: Construct a Multi-L KG to capture information at different levels; design QSGNN with intra- and inter-level message passing where each message is guided by the query; pre-train QSGNN using two synthesized data generation strategies to improve robustness.
AI.result: Empirical results show the framework is effective for multi-hop retrieval, with particularly large gains on high-hop questions (up to 33.8%). Code is released at the provided GitHub link.
AI.conclusion: A graph-based, query-aware representation learning approach on a multi-level knowledge graph significantly enhances multi-hop question retrieval for RAG, mitigating noise and improving high-hop performance; pre-training strategies bolster robustness.

title: Ev4DGS: Novel-view Rendering of Non-Rigid Objects from Monocular Event Streams
summary:
Event cameras offer various advantages for novel view rendering compared to
synchronously operating RGB cameras, and efficient event-based techniques
supporting rigid scenes have been recently demonstrated in the literature. In
the case of non-rigid objects, however, existing approaches additionally
require sparse RGB inputs, which can be a substantial practical limitation; it
remains unknown if similar models could be learned from event streams only.
This paper sheds light on this challenging open question and introduces Ev4DGS,
i.e., the first approach for novel view rendering of non-rigidly deforming
objects in the explicit observation space (i.e., as RGB or greyscale images)
from monocular event streams. Our method regresses a deformable 3D Gaussian
Splatting representation through 1) a loss relating the outputs of the
estimated model with the 2D event observation space, and 2) a coarse 3D
deformation model trained from binary masks generated from events. We perform
experimental comparisons on existing synthetic and newly recorded real datasets
with non-rigid objects. The results demonstrate the validity of Ev4DGS and its
superior performance compared to multiple naive baselines that can be applied
in our setting. We will release our models and the datasets used in the
evaluation for research purposes; see the project webpage:
https://4dqv.mpi-inf.mpg.de/Ev4DGS/.

AI.tldr: Introduces Ev4DGS, the first method to render novel views of non-rigid objects directly from monocular event streams in the image space, using deformable 3D Gaussian Splatting supervised by 2D event-space losses and a coarse 3D deformation model learned from event-derived masks; outperforms naive baselines and will release code and datasets.
AI.motivation: Event cameras have advantages for view synthesis and efficient, rigid-scene methods exist, but non-rigid cases typically rely on RGB inputs. It remains unresolved whether models can be learned from events alone. This work addresses that gap by enabling non-rigid view synthesis from monocular event streams.
AI.method: Estimate a deformable 3D Gaussian Splatting representation. Train with two losses: (i) alignment between the rendered outputs and the 2D event observation space, and (ii) a coarse 3D deformation model learned from masks generated from events. Requires only monocular event streams without RGB inputs.
AI.result: Experimental comparisons on synthetic and newly recorded real datasets with non-rigid objects show Ev4DGS yields valid results and superior performance relative to several naive baselines in this setting.
AI.conclusion: Ev4DGS demonstrates the feasibility of learning non-rigid novel view rendering from monocular events in the explicit observation space, leveraging a deformable Gaussian Splatting representation and event-derived supervision, with released datasets and code to support future research.

title: Ontolearn-A Framework for Large-scale OWL Class Expression Learning in Python
summary:
In this paper, we present Ontolearn-a framework for learning OWL class
expressions over large knowledge graphs. Ontolearn contains efficient
implementations of recent stateof-the-art symbolic and neuro-symbolic class
expression learners including EvoLearner and DRILL. A learned OWL class
expression can be used to classify instances in the knowledge graph.
Furthermore, Ontolearn integrates a verbalization module based on an LLM to
translate complex OWL class expressions into natural language sentences. By
mapping OWL class expressions into respective SPARQL queries, Ontolearn can be
easily used to operate over a remote triplestore. The source code of Ontolearn
is available at https://github.com/dice-group/Ontolearn.

AI.tldr: Ontolearn is a framework to learn OWL class expressions from large knowledge graphs, combining symbolic and neuro-symbolic learners (EvoLearner, DRILL), with an LLM-based verbalizer and SPARQL translation for remote querying; open-source.
AI.motivation: To enable scalable, interpretable learning of expressive OWL classes on large KGs, while providing human-readable explanations and practical access to data via SPARQL.
AI.method: Integrates EvoLearner and DRILL for class expression induction; adds a verbalization module using a large language model to translate OWL expressions into natural language; maps expressions to SPARQL queries for execution against remote triplestores; code available.
AI.result: Demonstrates efficient implementations of state-of-the-art learners, an end-to-end pipeline for classification, verbalization, and SPARQL-based querying; open-source release.
AI.conclusion: Ontolearn lays out a versatile, scalable framework for learning and applying OWL class expressions, combining symbolic/neuro-symbolic methods with NLP verbalization and SPARQL interoperability.

title: CodePlot-CoT: Mathematical Visual Reasoning by Thinking with Code-Driven Images
summary:
Recent advances in Large Language Models (LLMs) and Vision Language Models
(VLMs) have shown significant progress in mathematical reasoning, yet they
still face a critical bottleneck with problems requiring visual assistance,
such as drawing auxiliary lines or plotting functions to solve the problems.
Most LLMs and VLMs are constrained to text-only reasoning chains, while
multimodal unified models that can generate interleaved text and images lack
the necessary precision and controllability for such tasks. To address this, we
propose CodePlot-CoT, a code-driven Chain-of-Thought paradigm for "thinking
with images" in mathematics. Our approach leverages the VLM to generate text
reasoning as well as executable plotting code, which is then rendered into
images as "visual thought", to solve mathematical problems. To achieve this, we
first construct Math-VR, the first large-scale, bilingual dataset and benchmark
for Mathematics problems with Visual Reasoning, comprising 178K samples.
Second, to create high-quality training data, we develop a state-of-the-art
image-to-code converter specialized for parsing complex mathematical figures
into codes. Finally, using these training data, we train the CodePlot-CoT model
for solving mathematical problems. Experimental results show that our model
achieves up to 21% increase over base model on our new benchmark, fully
validating the efficacy of our proposed code-driven reasoning paradigm. Our
work opens a new direction for multimodal mathematical reasoning and provides
the community with the first large-scale dataset, comprehensive benchmark, and
strong approach for such problems. To facilitate future research, we make our
datasets, code, and pretrained models publicly available at
https://github.com/HKU-MMLab/Math-VR-CodePlot-CoT.

AI.tldr: CodePlot-CoT introduces a code-driven chain-of-thought paradigm for mathematical problems requiring visual reasoning. It uses a large bilingual Math-VR dataset, an image-to-code parser, and a model that renders plotting code into images as visual thoughts, achieving up to 21% gains on their benchmark.
AI.motivation: LLMs/VLMs struggle with problems needing visual aids and precise, controllable reasoning. There is a lack of large-scale bilingual visual-reasoning math data and robust figure-to-code tools to support such tasks.
AI.method: 1) Construct Math-VR, a large-scale bilingual dataset (178k samples) for math with visual reasoning. 2) Develop a state-of-the-art image-to-code converter to parse complex mathematical figures into code. 3) Train CodePlot-CoT to generate text reasoning and executable plotting code, render code output as images ('visual thought'), and solve problems. 4) Evaluate on the new benchmark and compare to base models.
AI.result: CodePlot-CoT achieves up to 21% improvements over the base model on Math-VR_CodePlot-CoT benchmark, validating the effectiveness of code-driven multimodal reasoning. The authors release datasets, code, and pretrained models.
AI.conclusion: The work introduces a new multimodal reasoning paradigm that combines text, code, and images for mathematics, offers the first large-scale dataset and benchmark for visual reasoning in math, and lays groundwork for future research on “thinking with images.” The resources are publicly available to facilitate community research.

title: Diffusion-DFL: Decision-focused Diffusion Models for Stochastic Optimization
summary:
Decision-focused learning (DFL) integrates predictive modeling and
optimization by training predictors to optimize the downstream decision target
rather than merely minimizing prediction error. To date, existing DFL methods
typically rely on deterministic point predictions, which are often insufficient
to capture the intrinsic stochasticity of real-world environments. To address
this challenge, we propose the first diffusion-based DFL approach, which trains
a diffusion model to represent the distribution of uncertain parameters and
optimizes the decision by solving a stochastic optimization with samples drawn
from the diffusion model. Our contributions are twofold. First, we formulate
diffusion DFL using the reparameterization trick, enabling end-to-end training
through diffusion. While effective, it is memory and compute-intensive due to
the need to differentiate through the diffusion sampling process. Second, we
propose a lightweight score function estimator that uses only several forward
diffusion passes and avoids backpropagation through the sampling. This follows
from our results that backpropagating through stochastic optimization can be
approximated by a weighted score function formulation. We empirically show that
our diffusion DFL approach consistently outperforms strong baselines in
decision quality. The source code for all experiments is available at the
project repository: https://github.com/GT-KOALA/Diffusion_DFL.

AI.tldr: Diffusion-based Decision-Focused Learning (DFL) models the distribution of uncertain parameters with a diffusion model and optimizes decisions via stochastic optimization; introduces a lightweight score-function estimator to avoid backprop through diffusion, achieving better decision quality than baselines; code available at the repo.
AI.motivation: Deterministic point predictions fail to capture real-world stochasticity; decision quality in DFL can improve if predictive models represent uncertainty; diffusion models provide flexible distributional modeling for this purpose.
AI.method: Represent uncertainty with a diffusion model; train with reparameterization to enable end-to-end diffusion training; alternatively, use a lightweight score-function estimator that requires only a few forward diffusion passes and no backprop through sampling; derive from weighted score function formulation to approximate gradients through stochastic optimization.
AI.result: Empirically outperforms strong baselines in decision quality; diffusion DFL is effective though the full backprop approach is memory/computation heavy; code available.
AI.conclusion: Diffusion-based DFL is a superior, practical approach to decision-focused learning under uncertainty; the proposed estimator makes it scalable; future work could explore further efficiency or applications.

title: Attention Factors for Statistical Arbitrage
comment: Accepted to the 6th ACM International Conference on AI in Finance
summary:
Statistical arbitrage exploits temporal price differences between similar
assets. We develop a framework to jointly identify similar assets through
factors, identify mispricing and form a trading policy that maximizes
risk-adjusted performance after trading costs. Our Attention Factors are
conditional latent factors that are the most useful for arbitrage trading. They
are learned from firm characteristic embeddings that allow for complex
interactions. We identify time-series signals from the residual portfolios of
our factors with a general sequence model. Estimating factors and the arbitrage
trading strategy jointly is crucial to maximize profitability after trading
costs. In a comprehensive empirical study we show that our Attention Factor
model achieves an out-of-sample Sharpe ratio above 4 on the largest U.S.
equities over a 24-year period. Our one-step solution yields an unprecedented
Sharpe ratio of 2.3 net of transaction costs. We show that weak factors are
important for arbitrage trading.

AI.tldr: An Attention Factor framework for statistical arbitrage: learns conditional latent factors from firm characteristics to identify similar assets, extracts time-series signals from residuals, and jointly estimates factors and trading policy to maximize risk-adjusted returns after costs; achieves very high Sharpe in US equities.
AI.motivation: Exploit temporal price differences and cross-asset similarity; establish that weak factors matter for arbitrage, and that joint learning improves profitability after trading costs.
AI.method: Learn Attention Factors via embeddings of firm characteristics to capture interactions; identify similar assets by factors; use a sequence model on residual portfolios to extract time-series signals; jointly estimate factors and arbitrage policy.
AI.result: Out-of-sample Sharpe > 4 on large-cap US equities over 24-year period; one-step solution Sharpe 2.3 net costs; demonstrates importance of weak factors.
AI.conclusion: Joint factor estimation and attention-based modeling enhances arbitrage profitability; weak factors play a significant role; method yields high risk-adjusted performance after costs.

title: MATH-Beyond: A Benchmark for RL to Expand Beyond the Base Model
summary:
With the advent of DeepSeek-R1, a new wave of reinforcement learning (RL)
methods has emerged that seem to unlock stronger mathematical reasoning.
However, a closer look at the open-source ecosystem reveals a critical
limitation: with sufficiently many draws (e.g., $\texttt{pass@1024}$), many
existing base models already solve nearly all questions on widely used math
benchmarks such as MATH-500 and AIME 2024. This suggests that the RL
fine-tuning methods prevalent in the LLM reasoning literature largely sharpen
existing solution modes rather than discovering entirely new ones. Such
sharpening stands in contrast to the broader promise of RL: to foster
exploration and to acquire new skills. To move beyond this plateau, we
introduce MATH-Beyond (MATH-B), a benchmark deliberately constructed to defeat
common open-source models of up to 8B parameters even under large sampling
budgets. Improving performance on our benchmark via RL requires methods that
learn to reason in ways that go beyond base model capabilities in repeated
sampling. Since the problems are drawn from subsets of DAPO-Math-17K and
DeepScaleR datasets, they remain topically equivalent to standard high-school
math. Validating our premise, RL fine-tuned models such as
Nemotron-Research-Reasoning-Qwen-1.5B and DeepScaleR-1.5B-Preview perform
poorly on MATH-B at $\texttt{pass@1024}$, showing how existing approaches fall
short on tackling harder instances. We hope MATH-B will catalyze
exploration-driven RL approaches that elicit deeper reasoning capabilities. We
release MATH-B at https://huggingface.co/datasets/brendel-group/MATH-Beyond.

AI.tldr: Proposes MATH-Beyond (MATH-B) benchmark to reveal limitations of open-source models under large sampling; RL fine-tuning tends to sharpen existing solution modes rather than enabling genuinely new reasoning; MATH-B is designed to defeat 8B-parameter models at pass@1024 and spur exploration-driven RL for deeper reasoning; dataset released publicly.
AI.motivation: Current RL fine-tuning for LLM reasoning often merely sharpens existing strategies on standard benchmarks, with large sampling allowing base models to solve many problems. This saturates benchmarks like MATH-500 and AIME 2024, hindering progress toward deeper, exploration-driven reasoning. A new benchmark is needed to force models to develop reasoning beyond their base capabilities.
AI.method: Construct MATH-Beyond from subsets of DAPO-Math-17K and DeepScaleR, ensuring problems challenge even strong open-source models at high sampling budgets. Evaluate base models and RL-finetuned models (e.g., Nemotron-Research-Reasoning-Qwen-1.5B, DeepScaleR-1.5B-Preview) on pass@1024 to assess whether RL can yield genuinely new reasoning.
AI.result: Base models with large sampling budgets already solve most questions on standard benchmarks; RL-finetuned models perform poorly on MATH-Beyond at pass@1024, indicating that existing RL approaches do not induce the deeper reasoning required by this benchmark; MATH-Beyond successfully defeats common open-source models under heavy sampling.
AI.conclusion: MATH-Beyond provides a testing ground to catalyze exploration-driven RL approaches that elicit deeper, beyond-base capabilities. The dataset is released at HuggingFace and can drive research toward reasoning methods that go beyond mere sharpening of existing strategies.

title: An Eulerian Perspective on Straight-Line Sampling
summary:
We study dynamic measure transport for generative modeling: specifically,
flows induced by stochastic processes that bridge a specified source and target
distribution. The conditional expectation of the process' velocity defines an
ODE whose flow map achieves the desired transport. We ask \emph{which processes
produce straight-line flows} -- i.e., flows whose pointwise acceleration
vanishes and thus are exactly integrable with a first-order method? We provide
a concise PDE characterization of straightness as a balance between conditional
acceleration and the divergence of a weighted covariance (Reynolds) tensor.
Using this lens, we fully characterize affine-in-time interpolants and show
that straightness occurs exactly under deterministic endpoint couplings. We
also derive necessary conditions that constrain flow geometry for general
processes, offering broad guidance for designing transports that are easier to
integrate.

AI.tldr: This work analyzes dynamic measure transport via stochastic processes to identify when flows are straight-line (zero acceleration) and exactly integrable; it provides a PDE criterion, characterizes affine interpolants, and links straightness to deterministic endpoint couplings, offering design guidance for transport geometry.
AI.motivation: Motivated by generative modeling needs: to transport probability measures with dynamics, and to know when the resulting flow is tractable (straight-line) via first-order methods.
AI.method: Develops a PDE characterizing straightness as a balance between conditional acceleration and the divergence of a Reynolds (weighted covariance) tensor; analyzes affine-in-time interpolants; derives necessary conditions for general flows to guide design of easier-to-integrate transports.
AI.result: Characterization of straight flows via a PDE; affine-in-time interpolants are fully characterized and occur exactly with deterministic endpoint couplings; derives necessary conditions constraining flow geometry for general processes, providing design guidance for simpler transports.
AI.conclusion: The framework helps design transport mechanisms in generative modeling that yield simpler, more easily integrable flows, and clarifies when straight-line transports are possible based on endpoint coupling and flow geometry.

title: Chronologically Consistent Generative AI
summary:
We introduce a family of chronologically consistent, instruction-following
large language models to eliminate lookahead bias. Each model is trained only
on data available before a clearly defined knowledge-cutoff date, ensuring
strict temporal separation from any post-cutoff data. The resulting framework
offers (i) a simple, conversational chat interface, (ii) fully open, fixed
model weights that guarantee replicability, and (iii) a conservative lower
bound on forecast accuracy, isolating the share of predictability that survives
once training leakage is removed. Together, these features provide researchers
with an easy-to-use generative AI tool useful for a wide range of prediction
tasks that is free of lookahead bias.

AI.tldr: Introduces chronologically consistent, lookahead-bias-free LLMs trained only on pre-cutoff data, yielding a replicable, conservative forecast tool with fixed weights and a chat interface.
AI.motivation: Eliminate lookahead bias and leakage from post-cutoff data to enable reliable evaluation of predictive signals in LLMs and provide a baseline framework for research.
AI.method: Train families of LLMs with strict temporal separation: data used for training is limited to pre-defined knowledge-cutoff date; models have fixed weights and a simple conversational chat interface; and the framework yields a conservative lower bound on forecast accuracy that is free of training leakage.
AI.result: Provides a ready-to-use, lookahead-free generative AI tool with a chat interface, fixed weights for replicability, and a conservative accuracy bound; useful across prediction tasks and suitable as a baseline for researchers to isolate true predictive signal.
AI.conclusion: The work offers a safe, replicable, lookahead-bias-free generative AI framework that enables researchers to study prediction tasks without data leakage and quantify the minimal level of predictive performance that persists after removing lookahead bias.

title: Boundary-Guided Policy Optimization for Memory-efficient RL of Diffusion Large Language Models
summary:
A key challenge in applying reinforcement learning (RL) to diffusion large
language models (dLLMs) lies in the intractability of their likelihood
functions, which are essential for the RL objective, necessitating
corresponding approximation in each training step. While existing methods
approximate the log-likelihoods by their evidence lower bounds (ELBOs) via
customized Monte Carlo (MC) sampling, the forward computational graphs of all
MC samples need to be retained for the gradient computation of non-linear terms
in the RL objective, resulting in significant memory overhead. This constraint
restricts feasible sample sizes, leading to imprecise likelihood approximations
and ultimately distorting the RL objective. To overcome this limitation, we
propose \emph{Boundary-Guided Policy Optimization} (BGPO), a memory-efficient
RL algorithm that maximizes a specially constructed lower bound of the
ELBO-based objective. This lower bound is carefully designed to satisfy two key
properties: (1) Linearity: it is formulated in a linear sum where each term
depends only on a single MC sample, thereby enabling gradient accumulation
across samples and ensuring constant memory usage; (2) Equivalence: Both the
value and gradient of this lower bound are equal to those of the ELBO-based
objective in on-policy training, making it also an effective approximation for
the original RL objective. These properties allow BGPO to adopt a large MC
sample size, resulting in more accurate likelihood approximations and improved
RL objective estimation, which in turn leads to enhanced performance.
Experiments show that BGPO significantly outperforms previous RL algorithms for
dLLMs in math problem solving, code generation, and planning tasks.

AI.tldr: BGPO is a memory-efficient RL method for diffusion LLMs that uses a linear, per-sample lower bound on the ELBO objective, enabling gradient accumulation across many MC samples with constant memory and matching ELBO optimization in on-policy settings, leading to improved performance.
AI.motivation: RL with dLLMs suffers from intractable likelihoods whose ELBO-based approximations require retaining forward graphs of MC samples, causing heavy memory overhead and restricting sample sizes, which degrades objective accuracy.
AI.method: BGPO constructs a specially designed ELBO lower bound that is linear across MC samples and depends on a single sample per term. This enables gradient accumulation across samples and constant memory usage; the value and gradient of the bound equal those of the original ELBO objective in on-policy training, making it a faithful approximation.
AI.result: Empirical results show BGPO outperforms prior RL approaches for dLLMs on math problem solving, code generation, and planning tasks.
AI.conclusion: By enabling large MC sample sizes with a memory-efficient bound that preserves ELBO value/gradient, BGPO yields more accurate likelihood approximations and improved RL objective estimation, translating into better performance across tasks.

title: Representation-Based Exploration for Language Models: From Test-Time to Post-Training
summary:
Reinforcement learning (RL) promises to expand the capabilities of language
models, but it is unclear if current RL techniques promote the discovery of
novel behaviors, or simply sharpen those already present in the base model. In
this paper, we investigate the value of deliberate exploration -- explicitly
incentivizing the model to discover novel and diverse behaviors -- and aim to
understand how the knowledge in pre-trained models can guide this search. Our
main finding is that exploration with a simple, principled,
representation-based bonus derived from the pre-trained language model's hidden
states significantly improves diversity and pass@k rates -- both for
post-training, and in a novel inference-time scaling setting we introduce. For
inference-time, exploration with representation-based diversity improves
efficiency, consistently improving pass@k rates across a variety of models and
reasoning tasks. For example, for Qwen-2.5-14b-Instruct we obtain over 50%
improvement in verifier efficiency on almost all tasks. For post-training, we
show that integrating this exploration strategy into an RL pipeline improves
reasoning performance over that of the initial model and over standard RL
post-training. For example, on AIME 2024, our post-trained
Qwen-2.5-7b-Instruct's pass@80 matches the pass@256 of GRPO on the same model,
demonstrating a 3x improvement in test-time sample efficiency. Overall, our
findings suggest that deliberate exploration -- with the right notion of
diversity -- is a practical path toward discovery of new behaviors beyond
sharpening.

AI.tldr: Deliberate exploration using a representation-based diversity bonus from pre-trained LM hidden states improves diversity, pass@k, and efficiency in RL for LMs, across post-training and inference-time settings, indicating exploration can enable discovery of new behaviors beyond mere sharpening.
AI.motivation: Investigate whether explicit exploration drives novel behaviors in language-model RL, and how pre-trained knowledge can guide such exploration.
AI.method: Introduce a representation-based diversity bonus derived from the LM's hidden states to incentivize exploration; evaluate in post-training RL pipelines and inference-time scaling; measure pass@k and verifier efficiency across models and tasks (e.g., AIME 2024)
AI.result: Significant gains in diversity and pass@k; >50% improvement in verifier efficiency for Qwen-2.5-14b-Instruct; post-training yields improved reasoning performance and, for Qwen-2.5-7b-Instruct on AIME 2024, match of GRPO's pass@256 (pass@80); overall 3x improvement in test-time sample efficiency.
AI.conclusion: Deliberate exploration with a principled diversity notion, anchored in pre-trained model representations, is a practical path to discovering new behaviors beyond simple sharpening of existing capabilities.

title: Tight Regret Upper and Lower Bounds for Optimistic Hedge in Two-Player Zero-Sum Games
summary:
In two-player zero-sum games, the learning dynamic based on optimistic Hedge
achieves one of the best-known regret upper bounds among strongly-uncoupled
learning dynamics. With an appropriately chosen learning rate, the social and
individual regrets can be bounded by $O(\log(mn))$ in terms of the numbers of
actions $m$ and $n$ of the two players. This study investigates the optimality
of the dependence on $m$ and $n$ in the regret of optimistic Hedge. To this
end, we begin by refining existing regret analysis and show that, in the
strongly-uncoupled setting where the opponent's number of actions is known,
both the social and individual regret bounds can be improved to $O(\sqrt{\log m
\log n})$. In this analysis, we express the regret upper bound as an
optimization problem with respect to the learning rates and the coefficients of
certain negative terms, enabling refined analysis of the leading constants. We
then show that the existing social regret bound as well as these new social and
individual regret upper bounds cannot be further improved for optimistic Hedge
by providing algorithm-dependent individual regret lower bounds. Importantly,
these social regret upper and lower bounds match exactly including the constant
factor in the leading term. Finally, building on these results, we improve the
last-iterate convergence rate and the dynamic regret of a learning dynamic
based on optimistic Hedge, and complement these bounds with algorithm-dependent
dynamic regret lower bounds that match the improved bounds.

AI.tldr: This work tightens regret bounds for optimistic Hedge in two-player zero-sum games; in the strongly-uncoupled setting with known opponent actions, social and individual regrets scale as O(sqrt(log m * log n)), with matching lower bounds; further, last-iterate convergence and dynamic regret are improved with tight constants.
AI.motivation: To determine the true dependence on the action counts m, n for regret of optimistic Hedge, close the upper-lower bound gap, and extend the tight analysis to dynamic regret and convergence properties.
AI.method: Refined regret analysis by reformulating the bound as an optimization problem over learning rates and negative-term coefficients; derive improved upper bounds; construct algorithm-dependent lower bounds; analyze last-iterate convergence and dynamic regret; provide matching alpha-beta constants.
AI.result: Upper bounds improved to O(sqrt(log m log n)) for both social and individual regret; lower bounds show these bounds are tight, including constants; improvements also extend to last-iterate convergence rate and dynamic regret with matching lower bounds.
AI.conclusion: In the strongly-uncoupled setting with known opponent action set, the dependence of regret on m and n for optimistic Hedge is optimal; dynamic and convergence properties also achieve tight bounds, clarifying the theoretical performance of optimistic Hedge.

title: QeRL: Beyond Efficiency -- Quantization-enhanced Reinforcement Learning for LLMs
summary:
We propose QeRL, a Quantization-enhanced Reinforcement Learning framework for
large language models (LLMs). While RL is essential for LLMs' reasoning
capabilities, it is resource-intensive, requiring substantial GPU memory and
long rollout durations. QeRL addresses these issues by combining NVFP4
quantization with Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA), accelerating rollout phase of RL
while reducing memory overhead. Beyond efficiency, our findings show that
quantization noise increases policy entropy, enhancing exploration, and
enabling the discovery of better strategies during RL. To further optimize
exploration, QeRL introduces an Adaptive Quantization Noise (AQN) mechanism,
which dynamically adjusts noise during training. Experiments demonstrate that
QeRL delivers over 1.5 times speedup in the rollout phase. Moreover, this is
the first framework to enable RL training of a 32B LLM on a single H100 80GB
GPU, while delivering overall speedups for RL training. It also achieves faster
reward growth and higher final accuracy than 16-bit LoRA and QLoRA, while
matching the performance of full-parameter fine-tuning on mathematical
benchmarks such as GSM8K (90.8%) and MATH 500 (77.4%) in the 7B model. These
results establish QeRL as an efficient and effective framework for RL training
in LLMs.

AI.tldr: QeRL is a quantization-enhanced RL framework for LLMs that combines NVFP4 quantization with LoRA and Adaptive Quantization Noise to speed up rollout, reduce memory usage, and improve exploration, enabling efficient RL training on very large models (up to 32B) on a single GPU while maintaining competitive accuracy.
AI.motivation: Reinforcement learning for LLMs is highly resource-intensive in memory and compute; quantization noise can boost exploration and efficiency. There is a need to scale RL training to very large models with limited hardware.
AI.method: Integrates NVFP4 quantization with Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) and introduces Adaptive Quantization Noise (AQN) that dynamically adjusts quantization noise during training. Evaluates on LLMs up to 32B, comparing against 16-bit LoRA, QLoRA, and full-parameter fine-tuning on benchmarks like GSM8K and MATH 500.
AI.result: Achieves over 1.5x rollout speedup. Enables RL training of a 32B LLM on a single H100 80GB GPU. Outperforms 16-bit LoRA and QLoRA in reward growth and final accuracy, and matches full-parameter fine-tuning on GSM8K (90.8%) and MATH 500 (77.4%) for a 7B model.
AI.conclusion: QeRL is an efficient and effective framework for RL training in LLMs, delivering both substantial speedups and strong performance.

title: Adversarial Attacks Leverage Interference Between Features in Superposition
summary:
Fundamental questions remain about when and why adversarial examples arise in
neural networks, with competing views characterising them either as artifacts
of the irregularities in the decision landscape or as products of sensitivity
to non-robust input features. In this paper, we instead argue that adversarial
vulnerability can stem from efficient information encoding in neural networks.
Specifically, we show how superposition - where networks represent more
features than they have dimensions - creates arrangements of latent
representations that adversaries can exploit. We demonstrate that adversarial
perturbations leverage interference between superposed features, making attack
patterns predictable from feature arrangements. Our framework provides a
mechanistic explanation for two known phenomena: adversarial attack
transferability between models with similar training regimes and class-specific
vulnerability patterns. In synthetic settings with precisely controlled
superposition, we establish that superposition suffices to create adversarial
vulnerability. We then demonstrate that these findings persist in a ViT trained
on CIFAR-10. These findings reveal adversarial vulnerability can be a byproduct
of networks' representational compression, rather than flaws in the learning
process or non-robust inputs.

AI.tldr: Adversarial vulnerability stems from efficient information encoding via feature superposition, not from learning flaws or non-robust inputs; interference between superposed features makes attack patterns predictable. Demonstrated in synthetic settings and a ViT on CIFAR-10, it explains transferability and class-specific vulnerabilities as a byproduct of representational compression.
AI.motivation: There is debate whether adversarial examples arise from decision boundary irregularities or reliance on non-robust inputs. This work proposes a third view: vulnerability emerges from how networks compress information through superposition, enabling perturbations to exploit interference between features.
AI.method: (1) Theoretically analyze superposition as representing more features than dimensions, (2) show that perturbations exploit interference between superposed features, (3) provide synthetic experiments where superposition is controlled to demonstrate sufficiency for vulnerability, (4) validate findings on a Vision Transformer trained on CIFAR-10.
AI.result: Superposition is shown to be sufficient to create adversarial vulnerability in controlled synthetic settings. The framework accounts for transferability across models with similar training and class-specific vulnerability patterns. In a ViT trained on CIFAR-10, vulnerability persists, suggesting it is a byproduct of representational compression rather than learning flaws or non-robust inputs.
AI.conclusion: Adversarial vulnerability can be explained as a consequence of efficient information encoding via feature superposition, a byproduct of representational compression. This reframes vulnerability as arising from how networks encode information, and provides mechanistic insights into transferability and class-specific susceptibilities.

title: Reinforced sequential Monte Carlo for amortised sampling
summary:
This paper proposes a synergy of amortised and particle-based methods for
sampling from distributions defined by unnormalised density functions. We state
a connection between sequential Monte Carlo (SMC) and neural sequential
samplers trained by maximum-entropy reinforcement learning (MaxEnt RL), wherein
learnt sampling policies and value functions define proposal kernels and twist
functions. Exploiting this connection, we introduce an off-policy RL training
procedure for the sampler that uses samples from SMC -- using the learnt
sampler as a proposal -- as a behaviour policy that better explores the target
distribution. We describe techniques for stable joint training of proposals and
twist functions and an adaptive weight tempering scheme to reduce training
signal variance. Furthermore, building upon past attempts to use experience
replay to guide the training of neural samplers, we derive a way to combine
historical samples with annealed importance sampling weights within a replay
buffer. On synthetic multi-modal targets (in both continuous and discrete
spaces) and the Boltzmann distribution of alanine dipeptide conformations, we
demonstrate improvements in approximating the true distribution as well as
training stability compared to both amortised and Monte Carlo methods.

AI.tldr: A framework that fuses amortised neural samplers with particle-based SMC for sampling from unnormalised densities, via MaxEnt RL, off-policy training, adaptive tempering, and replay-based integration, yielding improved accuracy and stability.
AI.motivation: Sampling from unnormalised densities is hard; existing amortised or MC methods struggle with multimodality and exploration. By linking sequential Monte Carlo (SMC) with neural sequential samplers trained with maximum-entropy RL, the paper aims to leverage the strengths of both: expressive neural proposals and principled particle-based diversity.
AI.method: Propose a unified framework where learned sampling policies define proposal kernels and twist functions. Use an off-policy RL training procedure that treats SMC samples as a behavior policy to better explore the target. Develop techniques for stable joint training of proposals and twist functions and an adaptive weight tempering scheme to reduce variance. Extend experience replay to combine historical samples with annealed importance sampling weights in a replay buffer.
AI.result: Empirical demonstrations on synthetic multi-modal targets (continuous and discrete) and the Boltzmann distribution of alanine dipeptide show improved approximation of the true distribution and enhanced training stability relative to both amortised and Monte Carlo methods.
AI.conclusion: The work establishes a practical synergy between amortised neural samplers and particle-based methods, providing training strategies (off-policy RL, adaptive tempering, replay-buffer integration) that improve sampling quality and stability for unnormalised densities, with broad applicability to complex multimodal distributions.

title: Domain-Specific Constitutional AI: Enhancing Safety in LLM-Powered Mental Health Chatbots
summary:
Mental health applications have emerged as a critical area in computational
health, driven by rising global rates of mental illness, the integration of AI
in psychological care, and the need for scalable solutions in underserved
communities. These include therapy chatbots, crisis detection, and wellness
platforms handling sensitive data, requiring specialized AI safety beyond
general safeguards due to emotional vulnerability, risks like misdiagnosis or
symptom exacerbation, and precise management of vulnerable states to avoid
severe outcomes such as self-harm or loss of trust. Despite AI safety advances,
general safeguards inadequately address mental health-specific challenges,
including crisis intervention accuracy to avert escalations, therapeutic
guideline adherence to prevent misinformation, scale limitations in
resource-constrained settings, and adaptation to nuanced dialogues where
generics may introduce biases or miss distress signals. We introduce an
approach to apply Constitutional AI training with domain-specific mental health
principles for safe, domain-adapted CAI systems in computational mental health
applications.

AI.tldr: Proposes a domain-adapted, Constitutionally-guided AI safety framework for mental-health CAI, aiming to improve crisis handling, guideline adherence, and scalability in sensitive settings.
AI.motivation: Rising global mental illness and the need for scalable, AI-assisted mental health care, coupled with the unique risks of handling sensitive data and vulnerable users that exceed general AI safety safeguards.
AI.method: Apply Constitutionally guided (Constitutional AI) training using domain-specific mental health principles to develop safe, domain-adapted conversational AI systems for mental health applications.
AI.result: Introduces a training framework and approach for safe mental-health CAI; the abstract does not report empirical results.
AI.conclusion: Using mental-health domain principles in Constitutional AI can yield safer, more responsible CAI systems for mental health, but requires future validation of crisis-intervention accuracy, guideline adherence, scalability, and nuanced dialogue handling.
